HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Three Questions Too Heavy to Carry for Another Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
My mentor, Scribe, is hereby dumping his three most burdensome unanswered questions. He tells me he doesn't want to lug them for another year, much less into the next millennium. If you want to respond to Scribe you can use thelipsite@aol.com, but don't expect me to get involved. He's just an old coot.
One: Would the Mets have won the World Series if Mike Piazza had acted more like Roger Clemens? 
 This is a troubling issue that the more enlightened counselors to youth have been avoiding. Meet fire with water, they teach. Don't engage with rage. The consensus is that Piazza is among the most decent and thoughtful of superstars and that Clemens is a surly intimidator. Early in Game 2 of the Series, when Clemens (who, Scribe insists on reminding, hit Piazza in the head with a pitch during the regular season) fired a piece of Piazza's broken bat back at him, the pitcher was offering a challenge.
Piazza responded by pawing the ground with a wishy-washy "What's your problem?" look.
"At that moment," says Scribe, "the Fall Classic was writ. Achilles whipped Hector and the Mets lost heart. It's the umps' fault for copping out of their responsibility to punish Clemens. They were intimidated by him and the Yankee aura."
Scribe wonders if Piazza had fired the bat right back at Clemens, announcing that he would not be bullied, maybe even starting a bench-clearing brawl, would the Mets have lost their awe of the Yanks? Scribe drank with Billy Martin and Ty Cobb, so what does he know about the need of modern youngsters to be offered role models, whatever the cost?
"So Clemens ends up the role model," growls Scribe. "You'll see the fruits of this next season in the Little Leagues."
Two: Should Bob Knight have fired the president of Indiana University while he had the chance?
Scribe tells me that after Knight was fired by Indiana's president, Myles Brand, he went hunting with George Bush (the former president) and the King of Spain. Knight is not going to be unemployed any longer than he wants to be. He is the Roger Clemens of coaches.
A few years ago, before he started losing games and national luster, Knight could have gotten rid of just about anyone in the state of Indiana except Larry Bird. He abused players and authority figures, acted out his rages. No one dared throw the bat back.
But now, the university presidents who bought the big-time sports package as an institutional steroid boost want to regain control from their athletic departments. A third force, small but growing, is those professors with any memory of higher education's mission. They want to reclaim the integrity of the classroom. If they ever got together (if you've ever sat in on a departmental meeting, you won't hold your breath), their power would be formidable.
Meanwhile, the million-dollar coaches whose dicey tenure depends on increasingly sophisticated 17-year-olds, their mothers and "advisers," are on the verge of blowing themselves up. Scribe predicts that the next major scandal will involve their perversion of the Americans With Disabilities Act; by getting illiterate blue-chippers declared learning disabled, the coaches can keep them eligible to play.
"I like this N.B.A. developmental league," Scribe says. "Not everyone needs to go to college. I'd send my kids only to 'low-binge' universities, the ones where the president doesn't keep a keg in every dorm so the kids forget there are 150 in a class, where the jocks don't have tutors to write their papers.
"Too bad about Knight. A head case, but he was on the level."
Three: What did Marion Jones know and when did she know it?
I don't want to touch this one. When Jones appeared on the covers of Time and Newsweek before the 2000 Olympic Games, in which she was hyped to win five gold medals, Scribe told me, "She is unbreakable."
"Whatever it is her hippo hubby is taking, or even sharing," he said, "she is too important to be implicated."
Her husband, the 300-pound former Olympic shot-putter C. J. Hunter, did not pass several pre-Olympic drug tests, and did not compete in Sydney. I chastised Scribe for guilting Marion by association. He replied that an athlete as attractive and as talented as Marion, especially an athlete from the Olympics' main money country, would have to be caught wearing her human growth hormone IV before officials noticed officially.
I told Scribe that was the same kind of innuendo that the news media helped losers spread about FloJo, and if he kept it up he could end up my ex-mentor.
He shrugged and said it might not matter. Since Marion won only three golds, she might be out of hype. If she didn't have some hot new commercials, she could be archives.
"Some of the same kids who don't read me," said Scribe, "probably wonder which group Marion and C. J. sing with."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
The Mass Marketing of Venture Capital

BYLINE: By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

 BODY:
MARTIN N. GRANT could have bought more shares in America Online. But that would have been Old School. What Mr. Grant, a marketing executive, really wanted was a taste of new-economy high finance. So ignoring the dot-com carnage and general stock market gloom, Mr. Grant put $25,000 into a venture capital fund run by EarlyBirdCapital, a Web-based investment bank. The fund has invested $40 million in some 30 technology start-ups, and hopes to rake in big profits when those companies go public or are sold.
"I'm taking advantage of something I was locked out of before," said Mr. Grant, 42, president of the CTN Media Group, an advertising and publishing company in Atlanta. "This could be a home run down the line." 
 In one of the latest forms of investment democratization, newfangled venture capital opportunities are opening a risky but exclusive club to a broader public. Even Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant, is in discussions to offer such high-stakes opportunities to ordinary investors through its 401(k) retirement plans.
Until recently, venture capital was open only to institutions, like pension funds, and to the very rich. For such private equity investments, which also include hedge and buyout funds, the Securities and Exchange Commission requires that individual investors have a net worth of at least $1 million, or as much as $5 million in some cases, and annual income of at least $200,000 over the last two years. But top venture capital funds require minimum investments of $5 million or more.
Now, sometimes for as little as $5,000, investors who meet the S.E.C. requirements, as Mr. Grant does, can play. The new opportunities come from dozens of banks, brokers and private equity firms, and from new Internet investing sites. They include upstart venture capital funds with lower minimums, upscale "funds of funds" that pool investors' money across venture capital and buyout funds, and specialized mutual funds that invest in start-ups. According to the Spectrem Group, a consulting firm, the opportunities are within reach of what it says are the 7.2 million American households with a net worth of at least $1 million.
Never mind that venture-backed dot-coms are collapsing. Or that initial public offerings have dwindled. And never mind that the industry has Himalayan peaks and troughs -- the average venture capital fund gained 3.4 percent in the second quarter of this year, after 20.6 percent in the first quarter and 57.6 percent in the last quarter of 1999, according to Venture Economics. Or that funds of funds, often with two layers of fees, might offer slimmer returns.
"This is fun," said James Santerre, 62, a retired executive. He recently plowed $100,000 into Envisionet, an Internet technical support firm, through StoneGate Partners, a Boston investment boutique.
The Glenmede Trust Company, a financial advisory firm in Philadelphia, requires a minimum of $500,000 for a pool invested in top venture capital funds run by, among others, TA Associates and New Enterprise Associates. Glenmede charges annual fees of 1 percent and gets 5 percent of profits if an investor doubles his money. The charges come on top of the fees collected by the venture capital funds themselves, typically 2 to 3 percent annually from investors and 20 to 25 percent of the funds' profits.
At W.R. Hambrecht, a San Francisco investment bank, $5,000 buys a stake in investment vehicles that each back a single start-up. Investors, who receive twice-yearly updates, pay a 2 percent fee, and Hambrecht takes 20 percent of any profits.
Financial advisers recommend that investors put no more than 5 to 10 percent of their total portfolios into private equity investments, including venture capital. Small wonder: only 4 in 10 companies that venture capitalists back will ever make any money.
Unlike a venture capital fund, StoneGate Partners lets investors choose companies in which to invest. The minimum for any single bet is $25,000. Since June 1997, StoneGate has raised $70 million from 400 people to back 14 companies. "This is a chance for investors who would not have gotten into the top-tier venture capital funds" said StoneGate's co-founder, Kenneth L. Wolfe.
But StoneGate has yet to produce meaningful returns. None of its companies have gone public.
An even more mass-market venture capital product, the meVC Draper Fisher Jurvetson Fund I, is already in a slump. Started through the Silicon Valley venture capital firm Draper Fisher Jurvetson, the fund, which works like a closed-end mutual fund, raised $330 million from some 20,000 investors to back information-technology start-ups. MeVC shares, which began trading at $20 in June on the New York Stock Exchange, have since declined by half. They closed at $10.19 on Friday.
A possible reason for the slump is that so far, meVC has put to work only $118 million in 18 companies. While the fund plans to invest over two years, in the meantime it is tying up investors' cash. By contrast, a venture capital fund asks for cash only when it invests in a company. MeVC charges annual fees of 2.5 percent, on all fund assets, and will take 20 percent of any profits. "The fund is tracking the Nasdaq pretty closely," said Cindi Perez, the fund's chief marketing officer.
BUT while anyone can buy meVC shares, without meeting the S.E.C. standards, ordinary investors may not have the stomach for start-up financing, which typically takes at least four years to show returns. "The fund has been promoted as a long-term investment, but that's just not how average retail investors tend to think," said David M. Toll, senior editor of The Private Equity Analyst, a newsletter.
Many people, Mr. Toll included, instead view funds of funds, requiring minimum investments of $100,000 or more, as the most promising option for a broader public. Such funds raised $11 billion in the first 11 months this year, down from $15 billion last year, according to his newsletter. But individuals appear to be accounting for a greater share, according to Andrew Craighead, co-manager of the private investments group at J. P. Morgan's private bank.
Aiming to bring Silicon Valley-style investing to Main Street, Fidelity, which runs one in four employee 401(k) plans, is in discussions with the Carlyle Group, a private equity firm in Washington, about putting Carlyle venture capital and buyout funds on Fidelity's 401(k) menus. But according to executives close to the discussions and to David Snow, editor in chief of PrivateEquityCentral.net, a Web-based newsletter that recently reported the talks, the two firms face high legal hurdles.
But as David M. Rubinstein, a Carlyle Group managing director, put it, "It's a great untapped market -- if there's a mechanism that can be developed with the S.E.C."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Armed to Send Chads Into Voting Oblivion

BYLINE: By JOHN HENDREN 

DATELINE: ROSEMONT, Pa.

 BODY:
BY the time Samual R. Shoup finished tinkering with the voting machine he began assembling in a Philadelphia basement in 1895, he had built a family business that endured nearly a century.
Then, in 1992, financial troubles forced Ransom F. Shoup II, the founder's grandson, to stop making a new generation of computerized voting machines and to turn the business into a parts and service shop. His predicament lay largely in the 100,000 lever-operated machines that the company had sold from the turn of the century to the Carter administration: They still worked. Half were in use this Nov. 7, and local governments were happy to have them. 
 A revitalizing jolt from Florida changed that. The 2000 presidential election left voting equipment makers with a black eye visible from Tallahassee to Tibet. And now, as Congress, state legislatures and chagrined election officials consider updating the geriatric machinery of democracy, an unprecedented opportunity awaits Shoup Voting Solutions and other voting-equipment makers.
Local governments had little incentive to replace their antiquated machines for decades, until the disputed ballots of Florida exposed their weaknesses.
"I guess our timing is just right," said Mr. Shoup, who as the company's director of government relations has started demonstrating a new Shoup touch-screen machine to municipal governments in North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia. "Our phones have been ringing off the hook."
It is too early to tally sales, but the handful of small and mostly private manufacturers that dominate the industry report a surge of inquiries. Many are from local election officers who oversee punch-card and lever machines and from state lawmakers who want to replace a patchwork of county-selected voting devices with a uniform system.
"Normally counties don't call a vendor. It's the other way around," said Larry Ensminger, a vice president for corporate development at Global Election Systems, based in McKinney, Tex. He said his company had heard from election officials in Florida, Texas, Washington and elsewhere. "This is kind of a unique situation."
Last year Diversified Dynamics was looking for a company to make its computerized voting machine. Now the company, based in Richmond, Va., is fielding cold calls from would-be partners, said Thomas G. Davis, the founder. More than 50 local governments have asked about the system since the election. The product manager, William Akers, has logged thousands of miles over the last month, showing a prototype to local election officials along the mid-Atlantic coast.
"It's an industry that nobody cares about -- until something happens," Mr. Akers said. "My biggest concern is we won't be able to get enough" machines to meet demand.
Voting-machine makers are receiving unsolicited help from the federal, state and local officials whose careers are decided on the Republic's creaking gears and levers. Among the states considering new laws governing voting machines are California, Connecticut, Illinois, Maine, Michigan, New Jersey, New York and Washington.
Wisconsin banned punch-card voting systems on Nov. 29, and the Speaker of the California Assembly, Robert Hertzberg, wants to spend $300 million to upgrade voting machines in his state, the nation's most populous. In Michigan, Secretary of State Candice Miller wants the same machine in every voting booth.
LOCAL county commissioners are calling experts like Kimball Brace, a consultant at Election Data Services, based in Washington. A task force of the National Association of State Election Directors met in early December to consider what advice to give local governments.
"Nobody wants to be the next Palm Beach," said Mr. Brace, who testified in Florida's Leon County Circuit Court in Vice President Al Gore's challenge of the election results.
Americans have quibbled over voting methods since landowners in the 13 colonies first spoke their candidates' names to an election officer. By 1888, voters were marking their first secret ballots. Like voice votes, the paper ballots still used by 1 percent of voters are vulnerable to misreadings or mischief.
The modern voting machine industry was born in 1869, when Thomas A. Edison patented a mechanical device intended for members of Congress. In 1892, Lockport, N.Y., held the first public election using a lever-operated machine, made by a Rochester safemaker, Jacob H. Myers, according to Sequoia Pacific Voting Equipment. Sequoia inherited the company that Myers created in 1895 to "protect mechanically the voter from rascaldom."
A CENTURY later, the rascaldom and error-prone systems persist. The counties and municipalities that oversee elections in the United States have patched together a quilt of varied voting systems. Each has problems. The most-often reviled culprit in the 2000 election was the punch-card ballot used by one in three voters. Voters pick candidates by poking out pencil-point sized holes -- or chads, in election parlance -- in the ballot.
Any system can fail, but experts say the relatively cheap punch-card systems tend to render more votes uncountable. "It took me twice to make sure I got through the chad completely," said Deborah Director, 28, a speech pathologist in Boca Raton, Fla. "I heard lots of people complaining that they didn't know if they voted for the right person."
Twenty-seven percent of voters fill in the dots on ballot cards that are counted by an optical scanning machine, the way high school multiple-choice tests are scored. But these can also cause voters to unwittingly nullify their ballots. An errant pen stroke picked up by the scanner makes it appear the voter chose too many candidates, called overvoting. In some cases, pen marks fail to show up on the scanner.
The lever-operated machines once made by companies like Shoup and Sequoia Pacific are still used by 18 percent of American voters. Voters pull a lever next to the candidate's name and the machine counts how many times each lever is pushed. The machine bars overvoting, but if the levers break, replacement parts are often unavailable. And the machine leaves no audit trail.
Voting-machine makers are just beginning to sell 21st-century touch-screen and automated teller-style machines they consider "Floridaproof." Their challenge is to persuade the nation's 10,000 local election jurisdictions to buy the latest -- and priciest -- machines.
Shoup plans to start selling the Cadillac of voting machines next year. The touch-screen SVS system, which costs $4,000 to $5,000 each, fits into a suitcase, prevents overvoting and confirms votes with an X next to the candidate's name on a large color screen. A final page lets voters confirm or change the slate of candidates they have selected.
Blind voters use the Shoup system by listening to verbal prompts through headphones and touching a corner of the screen to choose candidates. The cost, however, could give some county officials sticker shock. The company recommends one machine for 500 to 700 voters. For Palm Beach County, where 462,644 citizens cast ballots this year, the machines would cost $2.6 million to $4.6 million.
"If you're a county commissioner and the choice is to pave the streets or put a new wing on the public hospital or buy a new voting system, most of the time the new voting system loses," said Doug Lewis, head of the Election Center, a nonprofit training and research group based in Houston.
With that in mind, Shoup will lease the machines and may offer up to $1,000 for trade-ins of the company's circa 1982 electronic machines.
Diversified Dynamics, meanwhile, is preparing to sell the Chevrolet of computer voting systems. The A.T.M.-style device weighs 10 1/2 pounds, uses soft buttons to the side of the monochrome screen, fits in a metal briefcase and sells for $1,500.
"This machine is ugly," the company's Mr. Akers acknowleged, "but economical. Bridges and roads buy votes. Voting machines don't."
To use this machine, a voter first receives a credit card-sized smart card from the polling place and slides it into a reader. The card, which carries a magnetic strip with data, tells the machine which ballot to pull up. If the voter overvotes, a warning pops up saying, "You are trying to enter more votes than this contest allows." The brains of the computer lie in the removable programming card that the manufacturer can update via e-mail messages. The machine also has a politically connected pitchman: its chairman, L. Douglas Wilder, is a former governor of Virginia.
Of course, electronic systems have critics, too. Some fear clever programming could alter outcomes. Manufacturers say trial runs and limiting access to programming prevent that. Like lever machines, there are no ballots for an audit trail, although the machines can print out each voter's electronic ballot.
Some lawmakers appear willing to make the leap. In Connecticut, Susan Bysiewicz, the secretary of state, has said her office had considered replacing Roosevelt-era lever machines with optical scan technology, but now leans toward touch-screens after Florida's problems.
Either way, Global Election Systems may gain. The company is hedging its bets. It sells a touch-screen system, already in limited use in seven states, for $3,200 to $3,600, and a decade-old optical scanning system for $5,700. Counties need only one optical scanner for each precinct, compared with several computerized systems.
OTHER manufacturers, including the MicroVote Corporation of Indianapolis and Election Systems and Software of Omaha, have developed competing computerized systems.
"The fight out there is between the A.T.M. machines, and the optical scans," said Christopher Thomas, director of elections in Michigan, where 3,000 out of 5,500 precincts use optical scan systems. "All these cities and townships are going, 'Jeez, $5,000 versus $20,000 per precinct?' If we did nothing we would probably be at 85 percent optical scan within the next two to four years."
The District of Columbia Board of Elections plans a $1 million upgrade of its punch card system by putting a Sequoia Pacific optical scanner in all 160 precincts.
The Connecticut legislature's nonpartisan research office found that optical scan systems were no cheaper than touch-screens over time, when paper ballots and other costs were considered. That offers little allure to Michigan, where local municipalities buy the machines and counties buy the ballots. Even optical scans would be a modernization in states like Washington, where 16 of 39 counties still use punch cards.
Whether rising interest in the products of an industry that usually draws about as much attention as attic insulation will translate into an explosion of new orders remains to be seen. Sluggish growth has been part of the reason the industry has been dominated by comparatively small private companies. Even the industry's only major public company, Global Election Systems, had sales of only $20.2 million last year. Major makers like General Dynamics and Rockwell International have entered and left the market.
Florida's experience has taught election directors caution. They often take three to five years to consider new systems, and even then see little reward in taking risks.
While many have been impressed by the Diversified Dynamics machine, which has been approved by an independent testing regimen created by the Federal Election Commission, "nobody wants to be the first," Mr. Akers said.
To governments that are sanguine about their aging systems or plan a partial upgrade, Richard Caruso, Shoup's chief executive, invokes Florida in a warning likely to be repeated in sales pitches in coming months: "That could have happened in any state in the country."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
The High Price of Estate-Tax Cheating

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
CHEATING on estate taxes, which are paid by some of the wealthiest Americans -- roughly 2 percent of the population -- has become even more common than cheating on individual income taxes, according to a new study by the Internal Revenue Service.
And the biggest offenders are those with the most to lose -- some heirs of the very rich, who leave estates of at least $20 million, the I.R.S. has found. 
 How much potential tax revenue is lost to cheating? Brian Erard, an economics and tax consultant in Reston, Va., who conducted the study for the I.R.S., said the actual value of the taxable estates he reviewed, from 1992 audits, was 13 percent higher than what was listed on the tax returns. As a result, the government was shorted an estimated $1.5 billion in taxes. If extrapolated to this fiscal year, the total would be $4.2 billion.
The I.R.S. estimates that 13 percent of incomes are not reported on income tax returns, the same shortfall as for estate returns. But Mr. Erard said the income tax figures took into account the underground economy, where people deal in cash, while his estimate did not include unreported estates. If it had, he said, the estate tax shortfall would be higher.
Mr. Erard examined 4,417 estate tax returns that were audited in 1992. An estimated 59,176 estate tax returns were filed that year, and 10,200 were audited.
(Ten percent of the audited returns were accepted as filed and 24 percent received a reduction in their tax bill; the remaining 66 percent received an additional tax bill.)
In 1992, a tax return was required for all estates of $600,000 or more, a figure that Congress raised to $675,000 for this year. President-elect George W. Bush has said that he will seek repeal of the estate tax next year.
Mr. Erard's study, released this month, followed an analysis of 1995 estate tax returns earlier this year by Mr. Erard and the agency. It found that estates were more likely to be reported at less than their full value if a lawyer prepared the estate tax return. That could result more from client pressure to underreport than from aggressive action by lawyers, the report said. It also found rampant undervaluing of art, especially in the largest estates.
Last April, the I.R.S. released a report that found rampant cheating on gift taxes, especially on gifts of $1 million or more. Audits of 1,651 gifts to relatives and friends found that more than 80 percent understated the value. The average understatement was $303,000. Individuals are permitted to give as many gifts as they want, up to $10,000 each, but gifts above that amount are taxed.
Charles Davenport, a Rutgers University law professor who has written extensively in support of the estate tax, said he was not surprised by the findings.
"Executors tend to value very low, with the notion that if they have to bargain, they can come up," he said. "The courts have encouraged this by almost always striking a compromise. That encourages people to go low, and if you don't get an audit, then you get a very low value and pay much less tax."
Mr. Erard's study is the latest indication that Charles O. Rossotti, the I.R.S. commissioner, is investing in research to find ways for the agency to make more effective use of its enforcement resources.
To identify income tax cheats, the I.R.S. analyzes all income tax returns using a statistical technique known as the discriminate function, or "dif score." Individual income tax returns with the highest scores are then audited.
The dif score criteria are secret, but frequent audit targets are individuals with unusually large deductions for, say, medical expenses, and sole proprietorships that report large losses that offset wage income.
Estates tend to be audited when appraisals are skimpy or absent, when big discounts are proposed for closely held property like a family business, and when documents are messy.
MR. ERARD says that the agency lacks a statistical technique to select estate and gift taxes for audit, but that one could be readily developed.
So is the agency planning to adopt this recommendation? "We have no plans to create such a statistical tool," said Ken Hubenak, an I.R.S. spokesman.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3084 words

HEADLINE: Perelman's Endless (and Costly) Love

BYLINE: By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
RONALD O. PERELMAN declared to the world last week that a love affair he began 15 years ago is still going strong.
Mr. Perelmen, the 57-year-old financier, has had no shortage of romances, all chronicled breathlessly on the gossip pages. In June, he wed for the fourth time, to the sultry actress Ellen Barkin. He is still battling his wife before that, the Democratic party fund-raiser Patricia Duff, whom he divorced in 1998, over custody of their 6-year-old daughter, Caleigh. His previous marriages were to Claudia Cohen, the gossip columnist, and Faith Golding, a bank heiress. 
 When not married, he has had well-publicized flings -- with Eleanor Mondale, daughter of the former vice president, and others.
But the news last week concerned a much older mistress, one who is looking a little dowdy and is, in fact, in need of a makeover.
That mistress is Revlon, the $1.9 billion cosmetics company that has been the object of Mr. Perelman's fascination, except for one brief unfaithful period last year, since 1985. He bought the company for $1.8 billion after a long, hostile takeover battle that put him on corporate America's map as a tenacious investor to be feared; he was backed at the time by Michael R. Milken's seemingly bottomless supply of junk bonds.
On Friday, Revlon's stock closed at just $6.07 a share, down a staggering 89 percent from its recent peak in April 1998; as a result, the value of Mr. Perelman's 42 million shares has plunged from $2.4 billion to just $255 million. Mr. Perelman hired a new chief executive a year ago, and he has narrowed the company's losses. But Revlon still lost 25 cents a share last quarter, and a turnaround is by no means certain.
Still, Mr. Perelman remains infatuated by Revlon. "It's one of the great consumer brand names in the world," he said in a rare interview last week. "It produces a product that makes people happy, and it's got the guts to be a great operating company."
Mr. Perelman proved his love on Thursday: he disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that MacAndrews & Forbes, his holding company, has spent a large amount -- perhaps as much as $250 million -- to buy back zero-coupon junk bonds that he had issued in 1997 to try to extract some cash from Revlon without selling any of his shares.
The bonds, which were trading below 50 cents on the dollar as recently as September, were secured by nearly half of Mr. Perelman's stake in the company and were due to mature next March.
But there was no reason for him to act. He could have simply turned over his Revlon shares to bondholders and walked away. Instead, he went to great personal expense to hold on to a lackluster stock with unclear prospects.
In fact, his actions may dispel some of the lingering suspicions that Mr. Perelman was out to make a quick buck at the expense of other shareholders -- an accusation that he has denied. If Revlon's stock price is any guide, he may not have won many fans among the company's shareholders, but for now at least, he has cast his lot further with them.
Mr. Perelman's latest investment in Revlon, while indirect, is also notable because it is his first sizable transaction involving a public company in more than two years. While other financiers rushed headlong into technology stocks, Mr. Perelman stayed on the sidelines, betting just $100 million -- a pittance for a man worth at least perhaps $4 billion -- on a few Internet start-ups.
His Revlon move is also mystifying because he has so many other more tempting opportunities these days. By temperament, Mr. Perelman is a value investor, and the stock market finally appears to have shifted in his favor.
Yet he has instigated no splashy new deals, even while his contemporary and sometime sparring partner, Carl C. Icahn, has gleefully made a bundle on investments in Nabisco Group Holdings and General Motors.
MR. PERELMAN'S lack of action -- until Thursday -- even caused some people on Wall Street to wonder if he had been overwhelmed by losses suffered by several companies in his portfolio, and whether he had refrained from doing deals because he was short on cash. He does, after all, have an expensive lifestyle to support: several homes, including a 40-acre estate in East Hampton, N.Y., two Manhattan town houses and a place in Palm Beach he uses on many weekends.
Mr. Perelman and his consigliere, Howard Gittis, who has been with him since shortly before he bought Revlon, fervently deny any cash crunch. "Our debt is the lowest it's been in 15 years," Mr. Gittis said. They are simply waiting for the right opportunity, he said, and a credit market in which they can leverage their investments.
Arguably, putting more money into a poorly performing investment -- Revlon has lost money for eight consecutive quarters -- is a contrarian value bet. That seems especially true considering that, at least on paper, Revlon is far from Mr. Perelman's only money-losing investment.
Mr. Perelman's investing streak began to falter four years ago, when Marvel Entertainment, the comic book company he controls, filed for bankruptcy. He was forced to abandon the investment, at one point worth as much as $1.2 billion, after engaging in a highly public duel with Mr. Icahn for control of the company. (Mr. Icahn, who had bought Marvel's bonds at a discount, lost some $70 million for his trouble.)
Then came Mr. Perelman's misadventure in Sunbeam, the household appliance company in which he acquired a 14 percent stake in exchange for shares he owned in the Coleman Company, the camping gear maker, in 1998. The value of his Sunbeam stock has fallen from $425 million two years ago to a recent $9.7 million.
His investments in two other small companies, M&F Worldwide and Panavision, are also down sharply.
All told, Mr. Perelman's public holdings are worth $1.5 billion, down more than 60 percent from their peak in 1998. These losses do not even take into account his passive investment in the News Corporation, in which he owns 23 million American depository receipts after an asset sale four years ago. They have fallen 14 percent this year.
CONSIDERING that he has perhaps $2 billion more in assets -- cash, real estate, art and other private holdings -- it is hard to feel too sorry for him. Yet it is also surprising to see him take a gamble on a company when he has already lost so much.
So why would Mr. Perelman throw good money after bad?
One investment banker who has worked with Mr. Perelman for years is not surprised that he remains devoted to Revlon. "This is his most visible investment," he said. "It's much more important to him than Marvel ever was."
It must be -- and more than his other investments, too. Much of the amount that Mr. Perelman spent buying back the Revlon bonds was effectively financed by an estimated $300 million he has received from stock sales and other proceeds from his one thriving investment: the Golden State Bancorp, based in San Francisco.
His stock sales took advantage of the 58 percent increase in Golden State's stock this year, thanks to astute management and an expectation that interest rates are heading down.
Mr. Perelman is also hoping to raise at least $190 million more through a controversial deal he is arranging between two of his smaller holdings. Last month, he proposed selling his 83 percent stake in Panavision, a money-losing movie camera company, to M&F Worldwide, which sells licorice extract to the tobacco and confectionary industries.
If, as planned, M&F buys Mr. Perelman's Panavision stake at $26 a share, the price he paid for his shares plus "an appropriate premium to be negotiated," that would be more than six times greater than Panavision's current stock price. The deal, which is being reviewed by a special committee of M&F directors, has already inspired two lawsuits by M&F shareholders.
SITTING in their expensively furnished offices in the MacAndrews & Forbes headquarters -- a town house on the Upper East Side -- Mr. Perelman and Mr. Gittis profess surprise at the controversy. "It was an astounding thing to me," Mr. Perelman said; he contended that Panavision was sorely undervalued by the stock market, thanks in part to the small number of shares -- just 735,000 -- that trade publicly. He said Panavision, the dominant renter of movie cameras to filmmakers, was uniquely poised to take advantage of the growth in digital film.
"This is a company on the verge of being one of the only suppliers to the digital revolution," Mr. Perelman said enthusiastically.
He has held on to M&F, despite its own lagging stock price of just over $4 a share, because it has a large net operating loss that can be used to shelter the losses of future acquisitions. Its executives, he said, had searched fruitlessly for an acquisition for most of the last two years. . "We finally realized we had the perfect transaction right here," he said.
When Mr. Perelman is in doubt, his investment credo seems to be this: invest in what you know.
Mr. Gittis denied that either the Golden State stock sales or the proposed M&F-Panavision deal were motivated by any desire of Mr. Perelman to raise cash, to fund the Revlon bond purchases or otherwise. "Money is fungible," he said. "This is all part of a general bit of tidying-up activity. With the problems in the credit markets, the prudent thing to do is to clean up our obligations and keep liquid.
"That way," he added, "when opportunities present themselves, we can take advantage of them."
That sentiment, however, jibes much more with the old Ron Perelman, the one who built his reputation in the 1980's as a hard-nosed deal maker, than it does with the man who just plowed more money into Revlon. Whatever his other reasons for hanging on to Revlon, Mr. Perelman has clearly relished the social aspects of owning a cosmetics company whose public image has been intimately entwined with supermodels like Cindy Crawford.
How else to explain why Mr. Perelman has clung to Revlon through a booming market in which he could have sold the entire company for a huge profit?
But cling Mr. Perelman has. He did take the company public in March 1996 -- but he sold off just 17 percent of the stock, raising $188 million. That amount did little to reduce Revlon's hefty debt load -- now $1.6 billion, the enduring legacy of his buyout.
Not that he was immune to temptation. In February 1997, he managed to raise more than $500 million issue those zero-coupon junk bonds, which were secured by one of his most precious possessions: 20 million shares of Revlon stock. That represented nearly half of his own 83.5 percent holdings.
The bonds were structured so that if Mr. Perelman could not pay them off when they came due, bondholders would get the shares. (Still, even if that happened, he would not lose control of Revlon. Because his remaining shares have supervoting provisions, he would maintain a voting, if not economic, majority.)
WITH a glut of inventory and an uninspiring product lineup, Revlon saw its stock sink into the single digits last year, and it looked as if the bondholders would get only a small fraction of their money back -- perhaps as little as 10 percent -- next March, when the debt was to come due. Investors dumped the bonds, depressing their price to as low as 15 cents on the dollar in January, according to Merrill Lynch.
This year, as the market for new issues of high-yield debt turned increasingly bearish, Mr. Perelman's ability to refinance the bonds before the due date looked dim. The easiest way around that appeared to be to let the unfortunate bondholders have his 20 million shares come March.
But even with Revlon in such sad shape, Mr. Perelman was loath to give up so many shares. So he quietly began buying bonds last spring, causing the bonds to rise to a high of 70 cents on the dollar, according to Merrill Lynch data. He eventually acquired control of $630 million in face amount of the bond issue.
Mr. Perelman would not say how much he had spent to buy the bonds. But assuming a price in the middle of the bonds' trading range, he could have invested as much as $250 million. He hopes to exchange the remaining $140 million face amount for new bonds, and in return will pledge just 7.3 million shares, less than half of what he would have given up otherwise.
The stock market clearly took his gamble as a positive sign: Revlon's shares traded up $1.20 each, to $6.15 a share, after the news was disclosed on Thursday.
Still, there are good reasons for the low price of Revlon's shares. Profits at Revlon began to falter two years ago, as the company failed to develop hot products. Its most recent big hit was ColorStay, a lipstick introduced in 1994 and made famous by Ms. Crawford; it was guaranteed to withstand kissing, eating and drinking. Soon, the product was widely imitated by competitors whose products took away market share.
As its sales slumped, Revlon was saddled with excess product volume at retailers just as many drugstore chains were consolidating and closing stores. As a result, Revlon lost $2.80 a share in 1998, compared with a profit of 85 cents a share the previous year.
Since then, Revlon's share of the cosmetics market has continued to erode. For the 52 weeks ending Nov. 5, Revlon products accounted for 23 percent of cosmetic sales at mass merchants like drugstores, supermarkets and discount retailers, according to Information Resources, which tracks consumer product sales. That was down from 27 percent in 1998. And Revlon's sales were down 19 percent for the first nine months of this year.
Revlon's troubles come as some mass merchants have lost cosmetic sales to trendier specialty retailers, like Sephora and Bath and & Body Works. "There has been a migrational shift among consumers from traditional retailers like drugstores," said Allan Mottus, a cosmetics consultant. "Revlon has to figure out how to excite the next generation of consumers."
Mr. Perelman's first reaction to Revlon's slump was to try to cast his beloved company aside and sell it. In April 1999, he hired investment bankers Lazard Freres and Goldman, Sachs to shop the business, but nobody bit. Though Revlon was bloated with debt, he insisted that it was worth more than $50 a share. Nobody wanted to pay more than $35.
Determined to make over the company, Mr. Perelman pulled Revlon off the block and installed a new chief executive, Jeffrey Nugent, the former worldwide president of Neutrogena, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, which had lately become one of Revlon's fiercest competitors.
Mr. Nugent has sold assets and slashed costs. In the first nine months of this year, Revlon's general and administrative expenses were down 26 percent from the same period in 1999. Much of the savings came from reduced trade promotions; Mr. Nugent is gambling that he can better sell Revlon's products by giving retailers fewer up-front incentives to sell the cosmetics, rewarding instead those merchants who have lower-than-expected product returns with a share of the savings.
REVLON also appears to have slashed marketing expenses. At the current pace, Revlon's total spending on global advertising and marketing could fall as much as 25 percent this year, estimated Heather Hay Murren, an equity analyst at Merrill Lynch.
The cost-cutting has led to improved results at Revlon, but the company is still losing money: $12.6 million, or 25 cents a share, , in the third quarter. That was better than what analysts expected -- a loss of 32 cents a share -- and a considerable improvement over a loss of $3.13 a share in the same period in 1999.
But analysts are still undecided about Revlon's prospects under Mr. Nugent.
"They have some great brands, but there are still execution risks," said Ms. Murren of Merrill Lynch.
Revlon is poised to introduce several new products next year, including Skinlights Face Illuminators, which are supposed to brighten the wearer's skin and serve as a new alternative to foundation.
At least one savvy investor is betting that Mr. Perelman can rejuvenate Revlon. Over the last few months, his old rival, Mr. Icahn, has bought some of Revlon's bonds -- although he avoided the zero-coupon debt recently repurchased by Mr. Perelman in favor of other bonds secured by Revlon's businesses.
Mr. Icahn said in an interview that this time he would stay behind the scenes. "I just think the bonds are cheap," he shrugged. So far, Mr. Icahn has been true to his word. Mr. Perelman said he did not know whether Mr. Icahn had an investment.
Still, Mr. Perelman's plans for Revlon will require money, and the company has precious little to spare. Some analysts worry that it will not be enough to finance the ambitious turnaround plan started by Mr. Nugent. At the end of the third quarter, Revlon had around $105 million in cash and available bank loans.
Revlon anticipates that it would need as much as $35 million to continue its cost-cutting efforts over the next year.
While Revlon should still have enough money to keep running its business, its efforts to restructure and introduce new products may be a little too ambitious, given the amount of cash it has on its books, said George Chalhoub, a junk bond analyst at Merrill Lynch.
Revlon has been spending its cash at an alarming pace, he said, eating through $105 million in the last two quarters alone. If Revlon continues to spend at that rate, the company will run out of money by the end of March.
"In my opinion, Mr. Nugent will have to be content with a significantly slower rate of improvement," Mr. Chalhoub said. "They cannot continue at the same cash burn rate, unless they slow down the implementation of their business plan." Otherwise, the company will have to seek out an outside investor or sell assets.
MR. NUGENT replies that he may not need to spend at the same rate in the coming months. "This was a transitional year," he said. "Our advertising spending should be up significantly in 2001."
But even if Mr. Nugent's turnaround plans proceed as scheduled, it will take some time before Mr. Perelman can judge whether his faith in Revlon has paid off.
Whatever Revlon's fate, Mr. Perelman and Mr. Gittis say they have the interest, and the means, to do other deals when the right opportunities come along.
For now, though, Mr. Perelman's reputation and an increasingly large share of his fortune hinge on what happens in what remains his longest-standing love affair -- with Revlon.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 6; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 803 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Easy Money, Harder Times And the Road In Between

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
THE record-setting economic boom of the last decade has had an almost magical quality. Each time it has flirted with ending, a savior has stepped in.
In the mid-1990's, with growth slowing, American companies plowed billions of dollars into computers, improving productivity and, with it, the economy. In 1998, as Asia's economies were collapsing, American consumers stepped up their spending on big-ticket items like cars and appliances. 
 Around the same time, as corporate spending on software was slowing, executives began investing heavily in the Internet.
The dust behind this magic has been debt. Because of banks' willingness to take risks they once would not have taken, consumers and businesses alike have been able to spend money that they did not yet have. Thousands of people bought houses for the first time, and companies were able to keep pace with the rapid technological changes. Consumer debt now stands at $7.5 trillion, more than twice what it was in 1990, while corporate debt has reached $10.6 trillion.
For the magic to continue -- that is, for the economy to avoid a nasty recession in the next few years -- the borrowers must remain prosperous enough to pay off their bonds, credit cards and mortgages.
With the economy now slowing sharply, that prospect looks less certain than it did just a month or so ago. In fact, the unprecedented level of private debt could well be the biggest single threat to the soft landing that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has been seeking. "This could be the economy's Achilles' heel," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist of Economy.com, a research firm in West Chester, Pa.
Already this year, the number of personal bankruptcies has risen steadily, even as the unemployment rate has remained at its lowest level in 30 years. Four times as many companies have had their credit ratings downgraded as have had them improved, the worst such ratio since 1990, according to Moody's Investor Services. The nation's second-largest bank, Bank of America, said this month that its fourth-quarter profits would suffer because it had to write off $1 billion in bad loans.
Some of this is normal. Debt usually rises during an expansion, because people see tantalizing opportunities to spend money. In retrospect, anyone would have happily paid interest on borrowed money during the late 1990's to have earned a 20 percent annual return in the stock market.
But what could set the recent boom apart from others is the sheer scale of the borrowing, fueled by optimism and banks' aggressive marketing. During the good times of the 1960's, the ratio of household debt, including mortgages, to disposable income rose less than 10 percent, according to Economy.com. In the last decade, it has jumped almost 25 percent. The average American family now owes more money than it makes, after tax, in one year.
"We've had such unusual prosperity," said David Levy, vice chairman of the Levy Institute Forecasting Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. "It's not surprising that people don't worry about catastrophic problems with credit."
Indeed, the debt presented little trouble initially because wages, hours worked and stock values have all risen smartly since the mid-90's. Now, however, some companies are starting to cut back on overtime and even regular hours. Many of the first to suffer are the same lower-income people whose debt payments have surged in recent years.
If they can no longer make the payments, bankruptcy filings will rise even further, and consumer spending will slow. Banks, stung by loans they cannot recover, will pull back, making it more difficult for some consumers to obtain mortgages or credit cards. Spending will fall again. Corporate profits will suffer, hampering the stock market. Investors will rein in buying for themselves and their families, just as hourly wage earners are doing likewise.
At the same time, companies' credit ratings have fallen, because capital investments are not yielding enough of a return to pay off corporate debt, said John Lonski, the chief economist at Moody's. With money now harder to get because of the lower credit ratings -- and overproduction hampering some key industries -- businesses, like consumers, may also reduce spending.
"It's a very fragile period, and it's very easy to see a scenario where things get out of hand," Mr. Zandi said.
None of this is preordained. The federal government has reduced its debt in recent years and has more flexibility than in the past to jump-start the economy with tax cuts or new programs. The Fed can also lower interest rates to lessen debt payments, thereby encouraging more spending and investment. At some point, though, America may have to overcome its debt problems the old-fashioned way: by spending no more than it makes.

HEADLINE: The Election;
For the President, a Perfect Time for a Recession

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
IT looks like George W. Bush is going to get lucky again.
The amazing United States economy no longer looks so amazing. Economic growth has plummeted, from 5.6 percent in the second quarter to 2.7 percent in the third, and companies from Microsoft to U.P.S. have warned that the slowdown is likely to lower their profits. 
 With energy prices high, stocks weak and a sudden slowdown in demand for personal computers, some analysts predict that the economy could enter a recession as early as the first quarter of next year, shrinking for the first time in a decade.
"We're slowing down, and we're slowing really hard," said Doug Cliggott, American equity strategist for J. P. Morgan.
It's all just perfect -- if you're the president-elect. First off, if a recession hits just as he takes office, he can blame it on President Clinton. And the earlier in Mr. Bush's term that a recession strikes, the better the odds that the economy will be growing by the 2002 and 2004 elections.
In addition, the slowdown increases the odds that Mr. Bush will be able to push through Congress the giant tax cut that was at the core of his campaign.
That proposed $1.3 trillion cut, whose benefits would go mainly to the wealthiest taxpayers, faces opposition from Democrats and some moderate Republicans. Just last Thursday, House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert said he thought Congress should cut taxes more narrowly than Mr. Bush proposes.
But the economy's sudden chill gives Mr. Bush new ammunition for his plans. By giving people more money to spend, government tax cuts (and new spending programs) stimulate the economy, at least for short periods of time.
Last fall, when Mr. Bush first offered his tax cut proposal, the economy needed more stimulus about as much as a drunk needs another double. The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates six times between June 1999 and May of this year to slow growth and keep inflation down.
Under those circumstances, most economists felt that Mr. Bush's proposed tax cuts -- or Vice President Al Gore's spending hikes -- would be counterproductive. Now, with the economy souring, a dose of stimulation looks like a much better idea.
"The worse the economy looks, the greater the chances of bipartisan support for fiscal stimulus," said Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
That is true even though the cuts Mr. Bush has proposed would provide a smaller boost than similar reductions aimed mainly at the poor or middle class, Mr. Roach said. A person who receives a $20,000 tax cut is likely to put some of that money in the bank or the stock market, where it does not immediately help the economy; one who gets a $200 tax cut will probably spend it.
Stuart Rothenberg, a nonpartisan political analyst, said the economic slowdown will allow Mr. Bush to make a case for tax cuts that resonates beyond his core supporters.
Until now, Mr. Bush's argument has been "more ideological -- that you can't trust Washington," Mr. Rothenberg said. "The rationale for a tax cut is really that you don't have enough money in your pocket."
 MR. BUSH is lucky in yet another crucial way, Mr. Roach noted. If the federal government were already in deficit, Mr. Bush's flexibility to cut taxes would be limited, because tax cuts reduce government revenues.
In that case, the only way the government could make up the difference would be by borrowing more money. In the long run, that borrowing would suck up private capital and cause long-term interest rates to rise.
But under President Clinton, the federal government's deficits have turned into surpluses. So Mr. Bush has a cushion to cut taxes.
"The surplus, the large surplus, certainly gives the authorities more leeway to act should they want to do so," Mr. Roach said.
Thomas E. Mann, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said the Congressional Budget Office was likely to increase its estimates for the federal budget surplus early next year. "That, combined with the economic slowdown, will increase the market for a tax cut," Mr. Mann said. Even so, Mr. Mann does not expect Congress to pass Mr. Bush's plan in its entirety, especially since the cuts are heavily loaded toward the second half of this decade, while the need for stimulus is immediate.
Still, Mr. Bush should be careful what he wishes for. If he cuts taxes too far without cutting spending, the surplus will eventually evaporate, deficits will swell and higher interest rates will choke the economy.
If he reaches that point, he may find that luck has its limits.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
It's the Iron Horse That Rules the Frustrating Skies

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
THREE of the country's top four airlines have canceled hundreds of flights recently and plan to reduce their schedules because, they claim (and three federal judges have agreed), that their workers are slowing down or refusing to work overtime in order to pressure management at the bargaining table.
The cuts will add to the chaos of a holiday travel season already made trying by overcrowding, a creaky air traffic control system and winter storms. As travelers wait in airport lounges or in morose runway conga lines, they may want to use the time to consider the relative merits of the Railway Labor Act, the 74-year-old law that governs labor relations in the airline industry. 
 Unlike the National Labor Relations Act, the country's primary labor law, the Railway Labor Act does not allow workers to strike when their contracts expire. Workers continue under their existing agreement until a new one is negotiated, or the three-member National Mediation Board, which administers the Railway Labor Act, permits workers to walk out.
As a result, contract negotiations can drag on for years after the previous agreement has expired. Frustrated airline workers have increasingly engaged in stealth job actions that cripple an airline's operations -- and inconvenience passengers -- but appear to live within the letter of the law. Pilots decline to fly overtime; mechanics find more reasons to take jets out of service.
Paradoxically, the Railway Labor Act, the country's oldest law governing collective bargaining, was created to limit such disruptions. Its origins reach back more than a century, to when railroads were the driving force behind the new industrial economy. The total miles of track in the country soared from a mere 23 in 1830 to 35,000 by the end of the Civil War to a peak of 254,000 in 1916. And by the eve of World War I, railroads employed 1 in 25 workers.
The industry's tremendous growth was also marked by outsized corruption and brutal labor disputes. Some of the country's most famous strikes, like the Great Upheaval of 1877 and the Pullman Strike of 1894, involved the railroads. The labor battles led to frustrating disruptions; even a small union at a critical junction could tie up the commerce of the entire country.
Congress, trying to avert such disruptions, passed a series of laws, beginning with the Arbitration Act of 1888. But none worked very well. Finally, in 1924, President Calvin Coolidge asked the railroads and the unions to come up with a recipe for labor peace.
Remarkably, they did.
THE rail unions came to the talks from a position of strength. They had made great strides during World War I, when President Woodrow Wilson nationalized the railroads, placing William G. McAdoo, his son-in-law, in charge. Between 1917 and 1920, the average railroad worker's annual salary rose more than 80 percent to $1,820. After the war, the unions had begun lobbying Congress to take over the railroads.
When the two sides met to fashion a new labor law, the owners agreed to recognize the rights of unions to organize if labor would drop the idea of a government takeover.
The Railway Labor Act was adopted by Congress in 1926 with few alterations. It cemented the rights of unions, but also restricted their ability to interrupt service. Ten years later, the Air Line Pilots Association, which was having difficulty getting management to abide by other labor laws, successfully lobbied to have the fledgling airline industry covered by the Railway Labor Act as well.
The act the railroads and the unions came up with, and which governs the airline industry today, commits management and labor to the process of collective bargaining to settle their disputes. If talks founder, the two must to continue bargaining with the aid of a federal mediator. A strike or the hiring of replacement workers can only take place after the National Mediation Board declares an impasse, triggering a 30-day "cooling off" period that is usually taken up with intense bargaining right up to a strike deadline. Even then, the law allows the president to end any walkout by creating an emergency board to fashion a settlement.
The Railway Labor Act has never been seen as perfect. Both management and labor have criticized it. Lately, the biggest objection is that negotiations do not get serious until the mediation board starts the 30-day countdown.
But the odds of changing the act are slim. A joint committee of labor and management reviewed it five years ago and decided to keep it intact. That is partly because it would take an act of Congress, whose involvement is not something either side is willing to invite. And the fact is that the act, for all its shortcomings, still offers benefits to unions, management and consumers.
Organizing under the Railway Labor Act has proved to be easier and more lasting than under the National Labor Relations Act. Seventy-five percent of airline workers and 80 percent of railroad workers are unionized today, while in other areas union membership has eroded dramatically.
And if unions could strike when their contracts expired, airlines would be under constant threat of walkouts, making life even more unpredictable for passengers.
"If we didn't have the Railway Labor Act, the airline industry in the United States would be like an Italian railroad," said Richard B. Hirst, formerly chief labor negotiator at Northwest Airlines. "They have 39 unions and one of them is always on strike."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
European Ties Bind and Form Knots

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
MONTHS before the summit meeting held last week in Nice, European leaders began to lay out their long-range visions for the European Union: Some advocated a sort of United States of Europe, others a far looser association.
But the debate was put aside as the summit approached. Many believed that focusing on such big issues could undermine efforts to resolve the "technical matters" at hand, which added up to reshaping decision-making structures so that the enlargement of the bloc could go forward. Getting into heated polemics over the future would only get in the way, they argued. 
 But were those big-picture issues really put aside?
In the aftermath of the union's longest and, some say, least successful summit, many experts are saying those competing visions for the future were in fact behind some of the head-on collisions that made it so difficult to reach agreement on small matters in Nice. The Nordic countries and Britain tend to steer clear of steps they think could lead to Europe as a superstate, while France and Germany have traditionally favored the closest ties, warming to the notion of a power that would offer a counterweight to America.
So the European Union remains very much a work in progress, leaving unresolved the fundamental questions about what exactly it aims to be. It had its beginnings in the 1950's, fueled by the idea that former World War II foes could be stronger and more secure if they banded together for trade and, perhaps, for political integration as time went on. So far, it is clear that the union has built unparalleled European prosperity and achieved a degree of financial integration. But the basic question that was there from the start remains: Must deeper political integration follow? And what sort?
Talk of a United States of Europe goes back a half-century, to the time of war-weary visionaries like the French economist Jean Monnet. But can anyone yet see the way to a central government that collects taxes and oversees a uniform tax code in all of its member states? When might citizens from Greece to Sweden be drafted into a European Army? Could a bedrock bill of rights ever be drawn up that applies to all of Europe's citizens? Clearly, not soon.
During the five days of negotiations at Nice such radical possibilities were never openly discussed But experts say the potential for discord over them haunted any number of decisions, from the refusal of many nations to move to majority voting on such key issues as tax and social policy to the decision to adopt a charter of human rights that did not have the force of law.
"In a way, it was absolute hypocrisy to say that the debate on the future of the union could be postponed," said Daniel Cohn-Bendit, the leader of the 1968 French student movement who is now a member of the European Parliament. "Each country came to the meeting with a model in mind. If they saw a United States model they were willing to give up their vetoes; if they saw a financial agreement where the individual nations remained strong, then they had to keep those vetoes."
And for those who wanted to see a deeper union, the results were very disappointing.
Romano Prodi, the president of the European Union, said it was clear that many countries saw Europe simply "as a clearing house" that they could "move away from when you can't get anything or when you've already got enough."
The visions for the future that have been proposed lately vary widely. Last May, Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, proposed a European federation with a directly elected president and parliament sharing real executive and legislative powers.
In June, France's President, Jacques Chirac, proposed a looser arrangement -- more of a "united Europe of states rather than a United States of Europe." But, he suggested, if a core group of European Union countries wanted to move faster toward union, they should be allowed to do so.
In October, Britain's Prime Minister, Tony Blair, laid out another view in which institutional changes would give the European Union greater political coherence and perhaps greater democratic legitimacy. He is attracted to the idea of a charter of responsibilities that would better define the roles of the union and national governments. He also suggested a second chamber or senate for the European Parliament.
To some degree, the visions each reflect the union's popularity with voters back home, which varies. This year, for instance, Denmark's prime minister failed when he tried to get support, in a referendum, for joining the euro. In Britain too the union has always been an object more of grudging acceptance than of real enthusiasm.
Across Europe, there are even differing degrees of interest in sorting out the larger questions. Experts say that for years the union could take steps forward without dealing with the issue of where the finish line was going to be. Now, some experts say, this will only make decision making more and more difficult.
"The Nice summit showed the growing divides that are opening up," said Graham Mather, the president of the European Policy Forum in Brussels and London. "You can see the divide between some of the original countries and the Nordic countries, for instance. Where some really want to press on, others have a far looser vision and these are really two irreconcilable visions that make it hard to agree on details."
Mr. Mather and others believe that as the union expands eastward to include nearly a dozen countries formerly Communist countries, the clash of visions will only become more complicated.
"In the past it didn't matter so much," said Mr. Mather. "But now things are speeding up and the disparity of views has become rather important."
But some union members, at least, are pressing for an action plan. Prompted by Germany's desire to get a few more details hammered out, the European Union did commit itself to holding another reform conference in 2004 on the division of powers between Brussels and member states.

HEADLINE: The Election;
Democrats Seek a Silver Lining

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR a party that controls neither the White House, the Senate, the House nor a majority of the nation's governorships for the first time since 1954, the Democrats are remarkably cheerful.
One key reason is that Democrats think they won the election for the presidency on Nov. 7 and thus were not repudiated by voters. "All of us know Al Gore won this election and we're sad," said Representative Louise Slaughter of New York. And Gov. Gray Davis of California, where Democrats won Congressional and legislative seats, said that although the presidential race was "heartbreakingly close, by any other measure, election night was a good night for Democrats." 
 Looking ahead, their electoral expectations are sunny. They expect to win the Senate in the next election; it is now split 50-50, but with 20 Republicans and only 14 Democratic seats up in 2002. They also think they could overturn the nine-seat Republican majority in the House in 2002, having gained seats in three consecutive elections. But Republican control of redistricting machinery in big states like Florida, Michigan, New Jersey, Ohio and Pennsylvania makes that goal difficult.
Of course, since these are the Democrats, they don't all agree. Al From, president of the centrist Democratic Legislative Council, contends that Democrats failed to win the House or take the presidency because they failed to brag sufficiently about the economy and were playing populist themes of "class warfare" when they should have been humming dot-com melodies. Even so, the council's tone was much milder than after Democratic defeats of earlier years.
Stan Greenberg, who emerged as Mr. Gore's pollster in early summer, disagreed sharply. He said, "Gore's overall populist theme -- centered on using our prosperity to enrich all families, not just a few -- enabled him to consolidate his own vote, attract Nader voters at the end and reach out to independent and Bush voters. If the election were run on message alone, Al Gore would be president with a considerable majority of the popular vote."
Instead, he said, Mr. Gore won only a plurality because Mr. Bush held an advantage on "trust" and skillfully blurred issues, voters who supported H. Ross Perot in 1996 moved to Mr. Bush and the public was tired of President Clinton.
But, as Mr. Gore said Wednesday night, it was time for him to go, and the Democratic stage is now peopled by the winners. And those Democrats who did get elected seem remarkably united, in part by Mr. Gore's determined fight. Even Democrats who did not particularly like Mr. Gore or thought he had run a poor campaign rallied behind him against what they felt was an unfair process or a phony count.
A factor even more important to the Democrats' mood is the sense that their issue agenda dominated the 2000 election. "We were on the same page as the American people," said Representative George Miller of California. "Our agenda is the one that the American people want," said Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate leader. "The Republicans were campaigning on our issues," said Representative Bobby Scott of Virginia.
The Democrats' lack of rancor over Republicans' using education and health care as effective election issues stands in stark contrast to Republican complaints when President Clinton seized their ideological high ground on welfare and a balanced budget. Democrats almost sound admiring when they say, as did Representative David Bonior of Michigan, the minority whip, "They did a good job of fuzzing up the differences." But the different view of issue piracy reflects a fundamental difference between the parties, or at least their self-perceptions.
Democrats think of themselves as the party that wants to pass laws and establish programs. So on even an issue like prescription drug coverage for the elderly -- where their approach is at almost complete variance from the Republicans' -- Democrats are optimists who see Republican campaigning on the issue as an opportunity to get a discussion going and search for a distant compromise whose details they cannot yet imagine.
Listen to Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts: "The powerful lesson of this election is to try to find real solutions to the problems the vice president and Governor Bush talked about. People want us to roll up our sleeves and go to work on prescription drugs and a patients' bill of rights."
For experienced legislators like him, a compromise, even for less than half a loaf, is progress, and there is always enough credit to go around. There are Republicans who think along those lines too. But the party's leadership in Congress -- for example Representative Tom Delay of Texas or Senator Larry Craig of Idaho -- discuss "compromise" and "bipartisanship" as perilous concepts, Trojan horses by which the Democrats mean to subvert G.O.P. principles. Democrats, of course, are not so optimistic that they think they are better off than if they still had the White House. While they sometimes rebelled at having their destiny affected by Bill Clinton, he was a Democrat; now they must contend with George W. Bush, a Republican.
And they say they know better than to start a war with him. Bill Carrick, a Los Angeles consultant, said "we have to do some business," saying "Not since Nixon have we had a Republican president who seems to be as committed to doing things as Governor Bush is."
Still, many Democrats see a possibility of fights, being skeptical of Mr. Bush's seriousness on bipartisanship and his willingness to tangle with his party's right wing. Representative David Obey of Wisconsin said, "In Texas he was used to dealing with people who had his mindset even if they had a different party label." Senator Barbara Mikulski of Maryland said, "Democrats want to be cooperative, but they don't want to be co-opted." She said Mr. Bush should be invited "to live up to his campaign promise to try to bring people together." But, she warned, "If they're declaring war, we're ready."
In other words, the unusually cheerful Democrats think they win if Mr. Bush works with them, by enacting their program. And they win if he works against them, by showing him to be an extremist in moderate clothing when the nation is tired of extremes.

HEADLINE: DATABANK DECEMBER 11-15;
As Stocks Sink, Investors Flee to Safety

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices resumed their slide last week as Microsoft, Compaq Computer and the merger partners Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan joined the long list of companies warning of profit shortfalls. That overshadowed investor relief that the presidential election stalemate had finally ended and news that in -flation remained tame.
 The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index was again the biggest casualty, battered for four con- secutive sessions after an advance on Monday moved it briefly back above 3,000. By Friday, the Nasdaq had shed 264.16 points, or 9.1 percent, to 2,653.27, its fifth decline in six weeks. 
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index followed the same daily pattern, falling 57.74 points for the week, or 4.2 percent, to 1,312.15, a new low for the year.
 The Dow Jones industrial average ended with a loss of 277.95 points, or 2.6 percent, at 10,434.96.
 All the turmoil drove some investors to the bond market, which expects the Federal Reserve to abandon its rate-tightening bias at its policy meeting on Tuesday. ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.
