PUB-DATE: December 17, 2000

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1308 words

HEADLINE: Winning;
Now He Must Persuade the Voters

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
BACK in 1998, when he was still ambivalent about his party's entreaties that he seek the White House, Gov. George W. Bush described himself as a "cork on a raging river." But he has never seen the sort of roiling political currents, chutes and rapids that he is about to ride.
Mr. Bush, soon to become the nation's 43rd president, enters office with history against him. Only three presidents before him assumed office after losing the popular vote, and all governed a century or more ago before the pressures of the 24-hour media age. Not one of them went on to a second term. 
 Indeed, so certain are many in Washington that Mr. Bush, in finally prevailing in this disputed election, has seized a poisoned chalice that Democrats are already looking toward retaking Congress in the midterm election of 2002.
Mr. Bush is an optimist by nature, however, and he is assuming an office that offers a leader more levers of power, more opportunities to shape his own destiny, than any other. Comparing the presidency to a Superball, Fred I. Greenstein, a Princeton scholar of the presidential leadership, said: "It's a kind of resilient institution. You drop it and it's capable of bouncing very high and unexpectedly."
For proof of how a president can prevail even in the most perilous political circumstances, look no further than Bill Clinton. When the Republican ascension in Congress stymied him, he learned how to use the regulatory powers of his office and how to appeal directly to the American people. Through the turmoil of the impeachment drama and right up to the present day, his job approval ratings have remained confoundingly high.
Mr. Bush, too, has shown his own kind of resilience, whether in his 1994 race for governor against Ann Richards, his Republican primary comeback after his New Hampshire drubbing by Senator John McCain or his success in the fall's presidential debates. And he certainly never shied away from a fight during the campaign. Just ask Mr. McCain and Vice President Al Gore.
But those battles were fought in large part by surrogates. Less clear is whether Mr. Bush, wielding the visibility and authority of the presidency, can himself convince the American people that his policies are correct, that he is a leader worthy of enough respect that, four years hence, they should vote him in for a second term.
"First thing he's got to do is be the president," said one Republican official. "Dick Cheney's not the president. He's the president. He's got to start putting himself forward responding and meeting with the news media and the public and start selling his agenda."
John F. Kennedy showed just how powerful perception is. He won office by a razor-thin margin that the Republicans contested in the courts for several weeks. But he quickly captivated the nation with his wit, his beautiful wife and children, and his approval ratings rose dramatically even before he took office.
Gerald R. Ford, the only inhabitant of the Oval Office never to be elected president or vice president, reassured the nation after the searing Watergate scandal with a magnificent speech promising that "our long national nightmare is over." And he employed touches of modesty, like doing away with the playing of "Hail to the Chief."
But Mr. Ford also stands as a warning that presidents who come to power in disputed circumstances have little margin for error. His popularity plummeted when he pardoned Richard M. Nixon without first preparing the public.
"When their legitimacy is in doubt," said Richard Shenkman, a presidential historian, "when they make unpopular choices, there's thunderous reaction in the country. We're not willing to give them the benefit of the doubt."
Mr. Bush dearly needs some legislative successes early next year to show that he can be the "uniter" he promised to be and break the gridlock in Congress. But he will be aided, according to several students of the presidency, by the fact that public expectations are so low, given the near-perfect division of Congressional power, that even a series of small accomplishments might raise Mr. Bush's standing enormously.
"Never has the bar been set lower," said Stephen J. Wayne, a professor at Georgetown University, who studies the relationship between the president and Congress. "I don't think the American people really expect him to do that much that quickly."
But over time, they do expect results. And some of what Mr. Bush may accomplish later will be determined by the agenda he sets now.
Like President Ronald Reagan, he could introduce his administration to Capitol Hill by going for one sweeping agenda item. Reagan's overwhelming priority in his first year in office was his tax cut, and he pushed it through.
Or, like Bill Clinton in 1992, Mr. Bush could start with small steps. Mr. Clinton quickly signed into law bills like the Family and Medical Leave Act and a voter registration measure that had been vetoed by President Bush. If Mr. Bush wanted to follow the same path, he could sign an abolition of the estate tax, a tax reduction for some married couples and a ban on certain late-term abortions. All three measures passed Congress with some Democratic support, only to be vetoed by President Clinton.
But this piecemeal approach carries some risk. Conservatives could become restive if Mr. Bush appears irresolute on issues like abortion or tax cuts or Supreme Court appointments. And those conservative Democrats who ally with him on some issues will come under increasing pressure from their party to return to the fold.
If Mr. Bush decides to try for something bigger, the question is what issue best serves his needs. His aides say one of his first efforts will be to push through an array of education measures he campaigned on, including new funds for literacy. But Mr. Bush's centerpiece proposal for school accountability would shift federal funds into vouchers for poorer parents if schools in poor areas fail to improve. Most Democrats adamantly oppose vouchers, however, and if he failed to persuade them, his very public efforts at bipartisanship could come to a screeching and acrimonious halt.
Mr. Bush's call for a $1.3 trillion, 10-year tax cut is also perilous. Even so, all signs are that he plans to move ahead with a broad cut, perhaps even accelerating income tax reductions in response to the slowing economy.
MORE intriguing, there is just a possibility that Mr. Bush will stun everybody -- handlers, pundits and opponents alike. Imagine that he spurns the conservatives who put him in office and are demanding their due. Imagine an extraordinary step, like naming a major Democrat to head a commission on voting reform, or skipping over Antonin Scalia and naming a more moderate chief justice when William H. Rehnquist retires. And imagine him doing it all with a smile.
"He could emerge like Harry Truman," said John Weaver, the political director of the McCain campaign. "President Truman was always underestimated by his opponents. People made fun of President Truman's intellectual heft and ability. History has afforded him justice. But Harry Truman was willing to take on tough issues."
Mr. Bush, it must be remembered, campaigned for the presidency on his character. The next four years, and especially his first 100 days in office, will surely test that quality as it has never been tested before. Can he rise to the occasion and inhabit Oval Office in such a way as to earn the mandate that eluded him in the election?
Very soon, Mr. Bush will have to plunge into that whirlpool. He's lost valuable transition time and the clock is ticking. "Every day is precious to him," said one Republican. "He really doesn't have a honeymoon, he has a first date. That first date will be important as to whether he ends up in a marriage or divorce four years later."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 17; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 2273 words

HEADLINE: Can Bush Mend His Party's Rift With Black America?

 BODY:
As president, George W. Bush will have to mend many rifts, but none, perhaps, as wide as the divide between the Republican Party and African-Americans. Nine out of 10 black voters cast ballots for Al Gore. Many living in Florida felt their votes didn't count. The United States Commission on Civil Rights plans to investigate complaints about voting irregularities there, and perhaps in other states, to determine whether rights were violated on Election Day.
Last July, in a campaign speech before the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Mr. Bush said, "The party of Lincoln has not always carried the mantle of Lincoln" and pledged, "Strong civil rights enforcement will be a cornerstone of my administration." 
 With those words in mind, we asked for suggestions about how President-elect Bush can bridge the gap between African-Americans and his party.
 
Jesse Jackson, president, Rainbow/PUSH Coalition.
President-elect Bush has promised to be president of all the people -- a welcome sentiment, especially to African-Americans, who in past Republican administrations have experienced a closed White House. Having lost the national popular vote -- and the black vote by nine to one -- he must recognize that the gap between African-Americans and his party is grounded not in malice but in historical neglect and oppression. I believe that the way to inclusion is not through symbolism, but by expanding opportunities through expanded civil rights.
Mr. Bush must address poverty. This issue goes beyond race, since most poor people are white, female and young, and addressing it can help all of America see that aiding one group doesn't necessarily hurt the other.
He must also address racial profiling, the inequities of capital punishment and the need for effective hate-crime laws. And he must support affirmative action. Colin Powell would not have been considered for secretary of state if affirmative action had not allowed us to experience his leadership skills. We shouldn't burn the bridge that brought him over.
Finally, this election has generated deep emotions, even alienation, as a result of what may be the denial of voting rights, not just in Florida, but throughout the nation. Mr. Bush should support the United States Commission on Civil Rights in its hearings across Florida; this is a credible, bipartisan commission that can find out what went wrong there, and the findings could have broad national applications. Mr. Bush must acknowledge that the Voting Rights Act needs to be renewed and expanded.
In sum, George Bush must help rekindle the flame of hope -- flickering weakly at this moment -- in democracy for all, so that his own dream of binding the wounds of the nation may be achieved.
 
Floyd H. Flake, pastor, Allen A.M.E. Church, Queens.
To heal the breach, Mr. Bush must address the basic concerns that average African-American voters have for their communities and children. What resonates? Basic issues like equal access to home ownership, public-school improvement, safety in the inner cities through a balance of prevention and punishment and a continuation of the unprecedented wealth created in the New Economy.
Almost more than anything else, President-elect Bush must dig deep into his own party and convince more conservative factions to open their minds to policies that had African Americans and Hispanics reaching across the aisle to vote for him in two Texas gubernatorial elections.
 
Ward Connerly, chairman, American Civil Rights Institute.
Having become president by the narrowest of margins, President-elect Bush will be tempted to govern cautiously, for fear of aggravating our divisions. He should be sensitive to these divisions but not let them stop him from providing bold leadership. It is essential that he tell us what he believes we ought to hear, not what he thinks we want to hear. We will respect him in the end for doing so.
As a people, we must reaffirm our dedication to certain fundamental principles: respect for the rule of law, treating others as we want to be treated and equal treatment under the law. If Mr. Bush can get the American people to rededicate themselves to these basic principles, then he will have laid a solid foundation upon which we can build a more unified America.
 
John Ridley, screenwriter.
After an election like this one, what Mr. Bush needs in the black community is what we in Hollywood call a comeback role: Like John Travolta in "Pulp Fiction," he needs to do something so monumental it forces us to forget about all the other earlier awful stuff. Might I suggest he try playing the part of the strong but silent type? Deeds, not words, will rehabilitate the man. Get Jesse Helms to quit blocking the appointment of a black federal judge in the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals. Back the University of Michigan's support of affirmative action. Then he should be quiet and not jump up and down all happy with himself. Do the right thing. We'll notice on our own.
 
Robert L. Johnson, chairman, Black Entertainment Television.
Here are three things President-elect Bush should undertake in the first 100 days:
* He should encourage his new attorney general to investigate charges of voting irregularities in Florida and set up a blue-ribbon commission to investigate racial profiling by local and state police.
* He should invite black leaders to the White House to hear their concerns about his administration's commitment to issues affecting their communities.
* He should hold a 90-minute televised town hall meeting to take questions about race relations from journalists and viewers.
 
Michelle Alexander, director, Racial Justice Project of the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California.
Mr. Bush must decide if he was telling the truth to the N.A.A.C.P. when he condemned racial profiling, calling it the new "Jim Crow," and said that "strong civil rights enforcement will be a cornerstone" of his administration, or whether he was being more candid when he told law enforcement groups that the Justice Department should not function "as a review of police operations."
Mr. Bush should suspend federal executions until decisions about who lives and who dies cannot be predicted based on the color of one's skin and access to a well-paid lawyer. Show us, Mr. Bush, that you are more interested in educating our youth than in executing and incarcerating them.
 
J. C. Watts Jr., chairman, House Republican Conference.
The simple truth is that the views of African-Americans and the Republican Party are much closer than most might think. African-Americans are not Democrats because they believe in the party's liberal-leaning values, and the party has forgotten its most loyal constituents in the black community.
If we Republicans continue to communicate our common-sense principles throughout black America, we may eventually gain a whole new generation of young black voters who vote Republican. The principles Republicans stand for -- morality, integrity, and personal responsibility -- are universal.
 
David A. Bositis, senior analyst, Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies.
In the short term, there is nothing George W. Bush can do to reconcile with African-Americans. They rejected the Bush candidacy in a resounding manner, and the events in Florida since Nov. 7 have convinced them that the election was won because black votes were not counted.
Were I to propose a first step to the president-elect, it would be to use the bully pulpit to get those states, including Florida, that permanently disenfranchise ex-felons to ease their laws. He should do this for two reasons. First, it would represent a reproach to his white Southern conservative brethren. Second, since African-Americans believe he diminished their vote, he can start to atone by actively working to restore the voting rights of those who have none -- many of whom are African-Americans.
 
Faye M. Anderson, former vice chairman, Republican National Committee's New Majority Council.
What must Mr. Bush do to bridge the racial divide? At the very least, he must resist the temptation to attribute his dismal showing among black voters to alleged Democratic "race-baiting."
Mr. Bush should not think that appointing black cabinet members, regardless of their beliefs, will help. A position that is anathema to blacks will be no less so if articulated by Colin Powell or Condoleezza Rice.
So it is Bush himself who must do the heavy lifting. A meaningful first step would be to reach out to the established black leadership.
Since the Reagan administration, Republicans have bypassed black leaders in favor of their handpicked "independent thinkers," who are distrusted by black voters. Like it or not, the Congressional Black Caucus and heads of civil rights and labor groups are trusted by black voters. Republicans should try talking to them.
 
Julian Bond, chairman, N.A.A.C.P.
In his speech to the nation Wednesday night, George W. Bush spoke of the "details" in the differences between the two parties. In fact, there were huge differences during the campaign -- and in its aftermath, there is a chad-chasm.
To bridge this chasm, the new administration must immediately acknowledge the well-documented charges of minority voter suppression in Florida and elsewhere, investigate them, and pursue civil or criminal action where appropriate.
Mr. Bush should name a commission, with a membership that includes some of those who have worked for decades to ensure that every citizen's vote can be cast and counted, to recommend ways to end suppression of votes and intimidation and exclusion of voters
His highest-ranking Justice Department appointees must have demonstrated a commitment to fairness.
Thirty-five years after passage of the Voting Rights Act, securing the right to vote for all seems little to ask from a president who preaches compassion.
 
Shelby Steele, research fellow, Hoover Institution.
 How can President-elect Bush heal the rift with blacks? That this question must be asked makes a point in itself. Shouldn't black leaders have bargained with Mr. Bush throughout his campaign so that today they would have standing with this new president? After all, Mr. Bush reached out to blacks more than any Republican in memory. Yet blacks rallied against him as if he were George Wallace in 1968.
Black leaders keep making Democratic party affiliation a test of the black identity itself. This may get out the vote, but it makes blacks the easiest group in American life for both parties to take for granted. As Mr. Gore made clear by separating himself from Jesse Jackson's claim of racial injustice in Florida voting, black Democrats are an afterthought even to Democrats.
The moral authority of Mr. Bush's presidency will turn on the way he applies a conservatism of individual responsibility to the problems of poverty and inequality. Welfare reform, which recognized personal responsibility, has become the most successful social program in four decades. Mr. Bush's test-and-teach education policies in Texas have made responsibility the key to learning. All Mr. Bush can do is tirelessly make the case that personal responsibility is the new frontier of social reform.
 
Donna L. Franklin, author of "What's Love Got To Do with It?: Understanding and Healing the Rift Between Black Men and Women."
Photo opportunities with African-Americans are simply not enough. So how to start? Under Mr. Bush's leadership, Texas has led this country in executions -- and a disproportionate number of those executed were African-Americans. The capital punishment system in states throughout the country is plagued with legal incompetence, unscrupulous trial tactics and faulty evidence. And in the federal criminal-justice system, racial and geographic differences have been found to play a role in sentencing. Mr. Bush should impose a moratorium on the death penalty pending a thorough review of the system.
Welfare needs rethinking, too. Since Congress passed the landmark welfare reform law in 1996, the number of people on public assistance is half of what it was in 1994. But we now know that the reduction in the welfare rolls was created in part by a strong economy. With the economy showing signs of slowing, potential recipients -- many of them single mothers and their children -- need a president who will make sure that all the states are in compliance with the federal welfare guidelines.
 
Coretta Scott King, founder, Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change.
Mr. Bush should hold regular meetings with the Congressional Black Caucus, the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, the Black Leadership Forum and other important groups. This would go a long way to building needed bridges of trust and understanding.
And he should set a goal of making his administration the most racially inclusive in history. He should be able to verify at the end of his term that he has appointed more people from minority groups to policymaking positions and federal judgeships than any other president in history, as did Presidents Carter and Clinton in their tenures.
The president-elect should strive to rise above the narrow confines of party ideology and work for a genuine bipartisan consensus on issues like affirmative action, federal aid to education, raising the minimum wage, criminal justice reform and job training in depressed communities.
If he meets these challenges with sincerity and courage, he can truly become "a uniter, not a divider," to the benefit of all Americans.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1830 words

HEADLINE: The Legal Spectacle;
Divining the Consequences of a Court Divided

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SIXTY years ago, Robert H. Jackson, President Franklin D. Roosevelt's attorney general, published a reflection on F.D.R.'s titanic battle with the Supreme Court that had reached its climax in the failed court-packing plan. In 1937, the president, enraged by the court's striking down of the New Deal's economic cornerstones, had proposed to expand its membership to as many as 15 justices by adding a new seat for each member who refused to retire at 70. Born in political desperation, the plan came under withering attack as a threat to the separation of powers and died after the court began to uphold some New Deal programs.
The smoke had cleared by 1940, and Mr. Jackson, on the threshold of his own distinguished Supreme Court career, sought to extract some deeper meaning from the events. "So now, as always before, the struggle against judicial excess has ended by leaving it to the justices themselves to correct the errors of the court," he wrote in "The Struggle for Judicial Supremacy." 
 And then he added: "Another generation may find itself fighting what is essentially the same conflict that we, under Roosevelt, and our fathers under Theodore Roosevelt and Wilson, and our grandfathers under Lincoln, and our great-grandfathers under Jackson, and our great-great-grandfathers under Jefferson fought before them. The truce between judicial authority and popular will may, or may not, ripen into a permanent peace."
Given the current court's activism on a variety of fronts -- its attack on Congressional authority and its tilting of the federal-state balance toward the states -- those long-ago words had acquired a strong resonance even before the justices' plunge into presidential politics last week. Now, in their invocation of profound political struggle over the appropriate boundaries of judicial power, Robert Jackson's words sound eerily prescient for a time when the dividing line between law and politics, however clear in theory, has been blurred in practice.
The same five justices who, in effect, decided the outcome of a presidential election Tuesday night -- Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Associate Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy, and Clarence Thomas -- have been allies in a series of decisions that have placed the court at the center of a fundamental, if until now largely unobserved, debate over the exercise of political power in America.
For the first time since the New Deal, the court has curbed the use of what Congress assumed to be its authority over interstate commerce; in two recent cases, the court found that neither a federal gun control law nor the Violence Against Women Act had a sufficient connection to interstate commerce to come under Congressional jurisdiction.
The 5-to-4 majority has endorsed sweeping new theories of sovereign immunity for the states against the reach of federal law, while at the same time overturning state legislatures' own political judgments on whether and how to take race into account in drawing lines for Congressional and legislative districts.
While on the surface, not all these rulings seem consistent, what unifies them is a kind of judicial triumphalism -- an overriding of judgments made elsewhere in the political system, an insistence on having the last word -- that is, in many respects, the opposite of what conservative politicians and judges said they wanted most as the Supreme Court emerged from the activist turmoil of midcentury.
I'LL use the adjective 'untethered,' " William E. Leuchtenburg, a leading historian of the New Deal period at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and a longtime student of the court, said in an interview last week. "These decisions are not tethered to any text. It's precisely the conservative objection to the Warren court, or to Roe v. Wade."
But until now, Professor Leuchtenburg said, the court's recent decisions have provoked nowhere near the public scrutiny or unease engendered by the court's rulings of the mid-1930's.
That was because while the New Deal decisions were direct obstacles to Roosevelt's economic recovery plans, grabbing the public's attention by threatening its welfare, the federalism revolution of the Rehnquist court has played out in highly technical decisions involving obscure, even elusive doctrinal areas like the 10th and 11th Amendments.
"There's not one person in 10,000 who ever heard of Alden v. Maine," Professor Leuchtenberg said, referring to a 1999 decision that went far beyond the court's precedents to immunize states from suits in their own courts under federal labor law.
One effect of last week's events, he predicted, could be to bring about renewed, sustained scrutiny of the court's role in the country's political life.
While the court's intervention in the presidential election was unprecedented, the justices do, in fact, venture regularly into the thicket of electoral politics and are likely to do so more often as cases reach the court from the round of redistricting certain to follow the imminent release of population figures from the 2000 census.
As a taste of the cases to come, the court heard arguments several weeks ago on the validity of a North Carolina Congressional district that an earlier decision had found to be an unconstitutional race-based gerrymander. Following the court's opinion, the district has been redrawn and is no longer majority black. But the question remains whether the legislature drew the lines with race too much in mind, with the further question being, how much is too much?
During the argument last month in Hunt v. Cromartie, the lawyer for the plaintiffs accused the North Carolina legislature of hiding its racial motive by claiming as a "nice dodge" that it drew the lines simply to protect incumbents. Suddenly a voice from the bench interrupted. "Well, it isn't usually a dodge," Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, former majority leader of the Arizona State Senate, said firmly. "Legislators constantly are faced with drawing legislative districts, and my own experience is that the motive in most cases is political in drawing those boundaries."
It was surprising to see a justice stepping outside the judicial role to summon so overtly the directly relevant experience of an earlier, far different life.
 SEEN from the current context, that moment is a concrete reminder that for all the television-camera-free, cloistered atmosphere of the Supreme Court building, the justices are very much of the world. While Justice O'Connor is the only one of the current justices to have held elective office, David H. Souter was a state attorney general, Anthony M. Kennedy a lawyer-lobbyist in Sacramento, Stephen G. Breyer a senior Senate committee aide, Chief Justice Rehnquist a Republican poll-watcher in Phoenix and later a Justice Department official in the Nixon administration. Without political sophistication and sponsorship, no one is considered for a federal district judgeship, let alone the Supreme Court.
That justices embrace particular ideologies is neither surprising nor in any way illegitimate; it is part of how they came to be selected. In a culture where political differences are so often packaged as lawsuits, political sophistication is an asset to any judge.
But what has troubled many critics of the court's actions first to stop the Florida recount and then to prevent it from resuming is that the pair of 5-to-4 decisions appeared driven not by the high politics of judicial philosophy but by naked partisanship. In fact, the majority's ideology, which includes deference to the states and a high threshold for getting into federal court with untested constitutional theories, would have predicted an opposite result.
One Republican law professor, a supporter of Gov. George W. Bush with ties to several justices, said the perception of rank politics was inaccurate but at the same time understandable. "I would have hoped they would have found a way not to be perceived as acting on their own political preferences," Professor Richard J. Pierce Jr. of George Washington University Law School said in an interview. "When very sophisticated, knowledgeable people, not rabid people, believe that's what happened, it's tragic. I am very, very concerned for the court."
Professor Pierce said he did not believe the members of the majority were motivated by a desire to install Mr. Bush as president. The dynamic was more nuanced.
"I assume every judge always tries to do the right thing, to act in a judgelike manner, to be fair and impartial," he said. "They struggle within themselves, with recognizing the political implications of cases but doing their best to put that knowledge aside. But the justices are human beings, and this case offered the worst environment to place a human being trying not to be a politician in robes."
First, he said, was the context; those who defend the court's ruling see it as a necessary corrective to a liberal, if not lawless, state court that twisted state law in an effort to change the election's outcome. "The perception of everything that happened is tremendously colored by individual preference," he said. "Every Republican I know was screaming bloody murder about the Florida Supreme Court, that it was engaged in an outrageous robbery and that its decision could not stand. It was not so much 'get my man in office' as 'keep the evil people from stealing the office from my man.' "
The final factor was speed. "It takes a while for the good part of a judge to conquer the powerful human instinct to make a decision in accord with his or her political preferences," he said. Once the justices decided to hear the Bush appeal, he added, "time became the enemy."
Given the mood with which the week ended, Robert Jackson's 60-year-old inquiry about whether there might ever be "permanent peace" between judicial authority and popular will sounds almost quaint. The question is whether there can be anything that might resemble peace, even fleetingly. When the court reopens for business three weeks from tomorrow , nothing will appear to have changed, and yet nothing will be quite the same.
 THE debate over whether the justices acted out of partisanship or necessity will continue. But the possibility, however remote, that a Supreme Court decision can determine the presidency has now entered the public consciousness. The chance that a nominee as ideologically combative as Justice Scalia, whose confirmation vote 13 years ago was 98-0, would be confirmed today, at least without a major battle in a closely divided Senate, appears almost impossible.
Accountability is elusive for life-tenured judges, so it is their successors who may well be called, prospectively, to account. One result of the justices' remarkable exercise of power last week could be to raise the court's own political profile so high that any future vacancy might well produce a rancorous political struggle.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY;
Boom Times for Office Parties

BYLINE: By Aaron Donovan 

 BODY:
The stock market has stumbled and the economy is slowing, but the holiday party is alive and well.
Vault.com, a Web site about the workplace and careers, reports that 64 percent of employers it surveyed planned to increase or maintain their spending on parties this year, compared with 1999. Xylo, a research firm in Bellevue, Wash., says 52 percent of employees work at companies that hold office holiday parties. 
 Far from an excuse to get drunk or rowdy, the office party often has become an extension of work itself. Some consultants even recommend that the party-goers rehearse.
"You're giving people a chance to see the richness of you as a person," beyond the narrow role they see each day, said Frank Carillo, president of the Executive Communications Group in Englewood, N.J., which coaches executives on effective presentations.
Mr. Carillo recommended arriving at the party with a mental list of conversation topics that go beyond work-related matters, speaking crisply and in complete sentences, asking open-ended questions and avoiding discussions about religion or, God help you, politics.
 Aaron Donovan

HEADLINE: In a First for Swiss, Women in Geneva Gain Maternity Benefits

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Working women in Geneva canton will be the first in Switzerland to receive mandatory maternity benefits, raising hopes among advocates that Switzerland will not be the only country in Western Europe without such paid leave for much longer.
Cantonal lawmakers approved the legislation this week; it is to take effect in July. The move was considered significant because last year, Swiss voters nationally strongly rejected paid maternity leave. 
 While the United States has never mandated paid leave, it is routinely provided in much of Europe. Swiss law, on the other hand, requires that a woman take eight weeks off work after childbirth, but it does not guarantee a salary during that period. Britain gives a new mother up to 18 weeks' leave at 90 percent of her salary, and the Netherlands and Scandinavian countries typically pay 100 percent.
Even though more women are working throughout their childbearing years, the question of guaranteeing rights to new mothers is not universally supported. The United Nations International Labor Organization has been struggling to convince countries to sign a global accord setting out maternity benefits.
A key sticking point has been whether time off after childbirth should be compulsory. Last June a handful of countries, including the United States, voted against a provision to guarantee 14 weeks' maternity leave.
Maternity benefits were included in Switzerland's constitution more than a half-century ago, but the Swiss have voted four times -- in 1971, 1984, 1987 and last year -- against enforcing that provision. A legal loophole dating back to the last century, when an eight-week ban on work after childbirth was introduced to "protect" young mothers, requires the government to act separately to set up maternity insurance.
Last year's electoral rebuff left many women determined to fight for a mandatory benefit. They include the country's former president, Ruth Dreifuss, who said last year that 54 years of waiting since the constitution was passed was enough.
Currently many women receive some money from their employers, but unless the company has a policy, maternity benefits must be negotiated individually. As a result, it is estimated that about 200,000 women in Switzerland receive no benefits.
In fact, the federal Parliament in Bern has quietly been moving to institute compulsory insurance. Last week the Senate passed a motion calling for 14 weeks' paid maternity leave. The House had already approved the measure.
The Geneva canton's new law is subject to federal approval, but authorities have indicated they will not stand in its way. "We hope it creates a domino effect," said a spokesman for the federal social security office.
A prominent argument against the measure was that women already receive generous social benefits and that any new right would drain state funds, which were needed to offset above-average unemployment.
But in the past year, the economy has come roaring back, and this has lessened concern about financing. In addition, the considerable shortage of skilled workers in the country has drawn proposals that Swiss companies -- which often pay women as little as 70 percent of what men earn in comparable jobs -- learn to be more flexible to mothers.
The cantonal plan would pay 80 percent of a woman's salary for 16 weeks. The rejected federal planwould have offered 14 weeks. The plan is to cost $29 million a year, split by companies and workers.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 60; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
For Hunger's Victims, Sustenance to Bolster Embattled Spirits

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Louis Bratcher, a homeless man wearing old, tattered clothes, was walking through the main concourse at Pennsylvania Station when he heard a familiar voice over the noise of hundreds of commuters rushing to board trains bound for the New Jersey suburbs.
"Louis!" 
 It was his daughter Dena, whom he had not seen in a half-dozen years. She was working as an Amtrak ticket agent.
They talked briefly. Mr. Bratcher, now 66, was ashamed that he was living at the station.
"I was homeless," he recalled. "I met my daughter where she worked. I was so embarrassed for her to see me."
That evening, four or five years ago, was the last time he saw any of his children.
"I don't like to put my burdens on my kids," said Mr. Bratcher, who has three other children: Jackie, Calvin and Denise. "My problems are not their problems."
Mr. Bratcher spends most nights trying to sleep on a wooden bench in a walkway underneath the platforms that serve the Nos. 1, 2, 3 and 9 subway lines at Penn Station. He worked for 40 years as a truck driver, at different times delivering food and stationery and driving a moving truck. But he was paid under the table, he said.
"That was where I messed up," he said. "When I went to get benefits after the work, I couldn't get them because I was off the books."
So now that he is retired, he has no pension to draw from -- only minimal help from Social Security -- and for 10 years has had no place to call home.
During the winter, his nights are often sleepless. "It's terrible," he said. "When you hear a sound and it doesn't sound like a friendly sound, you wake up and you want to know what's going on. You sleep like an animal."
In the mornings, when Mr. Bratcher goes to a center for the elderly in Midtown that feeds the homeless and provides them a place to spend time, he ends up falling asleep in his chair, just like the other men without homes who go there for food and warmth.
Finding shelter is a struggle for Mr. Bratcher and the others who arrive each morning at the center, run by a nonprofit organization called Project FIND (for Friendless, Isolated, Needy and Disabled), which has organized several daytime centers and homeless shelters for the elderly in Midtown and on the Upper West Side.
But finding food is often even more difficult.
Project FIND is a member of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The project was recently awarded $10,000 from the fund to help provide food for the homeless. It will use the grant for its free dinners for the elderly homeless people who use the center, on Ninth Avenue opposite the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
The meal will most likely be served in a brown paper bag and include a sandwich, fruit and milk. The agency hopes to give out 33 meals a day, or 10,000 for nearly a year, that would be covered by the grant.
"Getting the homeless to accept services is a very difficult task," said Cynthia Dial, the executive director of Project FIND. "One of the things we're trying to do with this program, by handing out a meal at the end of the day, is to try to get them to come back to us, and to try to earn their trust."
Six days a week, elderly people from the neighborhood, many of them homeless, go to the center for inexpensive warm meals and for recreation, like pool, cards, tai chi and television.
About noon at the coffeehouse, as the center is called, the staff receives meals from the Woodstock Hotel on West 43rd Street, which Project FIND runs.
Out on the street, finding food is hard even for someone like Mr. Bratcher, who knows shop owners who will give him a leftover sandwich or a cup of coffee when business is slow.
Sometimes agencies distribute food and clothes to the homeless at night. But Mr. Bratcher said that it was difficult for him to find out when and where the trucks arrived, and that the elderly were often overlooked. "The younger people, they will climb over you and push you out of the way, and they take all the best stuff," he said.
Mr. Bratcher said that he received little more than $200 a month in Supplemental Security Income. It does not last more than a week, he said, because he often has to pay people who gave him food the month before. So he gets free meals from churches and social service agencies.
"Quite a few times I've wondered how I'm going to eat," Mr. Bratcher said. "It's the worst feeling in the world to know a person is hungry because they don't have the necessary funds to get a meal."
 
The Elderly and Children
 Hunger in the city can take many forms. It does not just strike people who are homeless. Though people of all ages are hungry, experts say the elderly and children are the hardest hit.
When Virginia Leslie's children are hungry, they know better than to start rifling through her kitchen cabinets. Because food is scarce, Cherrie, 13, Christopher, 11, and Sabrina, 9, are sure to ask first before they eat.
"The rent is not a problem," Ms. Leslie said. "Feeding them is a problem, and clothes."
Ms. Leslie is one of the many New Yorkers who during these times of economic prosperity have struggled to keep food on the table.
But she, like thousands of others, has received aid from an agency supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Every month, Ms. Leslie, 50, goes to the Pelham Fritz Apartments, a housing shelter on West 118th Street, where she is given a big black plastic bag full of food. The shelter and the small pantry it operates are run by the Children's Aid Society, one of the seven local charities supported by the fund.
The pantry, a small basement storage room at the end of a maze-like cinder block corridor underneath the shelter, is kept locked to protect its contents: can after can of sliced apples, evaporated milk, apricot halves, corn and carrots. It also has a large cylindrical crate full of rice, and boxes of jumbo pasta shells. Over a typical two-month period, it serves about 3,000 people, more than half of them children.
The item that vanishes first is baby formula. "The last one went yesterday," said Sixto Melendez, who oversees the pantry, as he looked at the empty spot on the metal shelf where it had been stored.
Ms. Leslie, like the other struggling parents who use the pantry, has no other way to feed her children. She suffers from depression, high blood pressure, a pinched nerve in her spine and arthritis that makes it difficult to walk outside when the temperature drops below 40 degrees.
She had been a home health aide for 15 years. But because the painkillers she takes for her arthritis and the pinched nerve cause drowsiness, she lost her job nine years ago and has not been able to regain her home health aide certification.
She now has a home health aide of her own, Martha Simmons, who has been with the family about two months.
But she does not go outside much, and after dark, neither do her children. They live in the Martin Luther King Jr. Houses on Lenox Avenue in Harlem. At 6 p.m., the three-block stretch occupied by the King projects is virtually devoid of activity.
"I never really cared for the projects," Ms. Leslie said. She has lived there nine years. "But I had no choice." Before she moved into her apartment in the King houses, she lived in a homeless shelter with her three children.
The Children's Aid Society also paid for a bunk bed and wooden dressers for the children's bedroom. And after a few phone calls from Vivian Silverio, the social worker from the society who works with the family, the New York City Housing Authority painted the apartment walls and fixed broken windows and doors.
 
Soup Kitchen Lines Grow
According to a study released two months ago by Food for Survival, the city's largest food bank, in 1998 615,000 people sought help each month from city soup kitchens and food pantries, up from 309,000 people who sought such assistance each month in 1995.
Lucy Cabrera, the president of the food bank, attributed the increase to government initiatives that reduced the number of people who receive food stamps and welfare benefits. "You have now those people who might have one worker in the family who is underemployed, making wages but not enough to afford to live in the City of New York," she said. "And you still have the homeless and those who live way below the poverty line."
Food for Survival estimates that of the people who use the food programs, 35 percent are children.
Philip Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, called the problem of child hunger in America "a clear and present danger."
"If a child goes hungry for a period of time, depending on the age of the child, we can have serious health problems," he said. "If they're not getting the necessary nutrients for normal growth and development, there can be significant delays to their social, emotional and cognitive development."
Gertrude T., 38, wants her children to do well in school but has trouble putting food on the table. She knows that the key to her children's success is learning English and getting good grades. She fears that she may not be able to provide them the best possible environment for doing their homework.
After she makes an after-school meal for her two boys, Fredy, 9, and David, 6, they sit down at the family table to do their homework. But not always for a long time.
"My little one says 'My brother is bothering me,' " she said in Spanish. "And my big one says 'My brother is bothering me.' "
So she separates them by asking David to go into the bathroom. It's the only other room the family has.
Gertrude, her husband, Fred, 45, and Fredy sleep in a full-size bed in their Lower East Side studio apartment. David sleeps on a couch just a few feet away in what for nearly eight years has been the living room, dining room, kitchen and bedroom.
The children finish their homework by 6:30, when their father comes home. He earns $140 a week as a butcher at a nearby meat market.
Gertrude worked at a Broadway garment factory for 11 years before Fredy was born, but now that she has two children she said she did not have the time to work. "If I worked, I would have to have someone look after my children," she said. "And that would take away whatever I made at the factory."
The family receives $325 a month in food stamps. Fred, a legal resident but not yet a citizen, is ineligible for them and so does not count toward the family's allotment. So they go to Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York for food. Catholic Charities operates a food pantry out of the Cardinal Francis Spellman building on East Second Street, where Gertrude has gotten canned fruit and vegetables, rice and powdered milk about once a month during the past year.
The food assistance programs at the center are supported by money from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and from various private donations, including money from the Neediest Cases Fund.
"We don't say, 'Come once a month' ," said Sister Lucita Cangemi, who works with the family. "We say, 'Come when you need it.' "
The Protestant federation this year received 20 applications from member agencies for grants to help them combat hunger or homelessness. At its office on Park Avenue South on a frigid morning this month, the federation awarded nine of their agencies grants worth $10,000 each from the Neediest Cases Fund, the majority of which went to support hunger relief efforts, including Project FIND.
Megan E. McLaughlin, executive director of the federation, says there is a paradox in her agency's role fighting hunger. "We have to provide these services, but we need to seek to end these services," she said at the ceremony at which the grants were awarded.
While the agency seeks to find the roots of the problem, donors to the Neediest Cases fund make the lives of those who are hungry a little easier. "The Neediest Cases money can't be used for research or training or anything like that," said Judith Milone, director of client services for the federation. "It has to be used for direct service."
The federation gave one of the grants to the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, which helps the homeless of the Upper East Side find housing, for outreach efforts to encourage more elderly adults to use the house's lunch programs.
"We saw a large number of older adults show up for food," said Martha Dorn, the house's associate executive director. "Many of them do not have family they can rely on."
 
Coping, With Help
From the Upper East Side to a solidly middle class neighborhood like Forest Hills, Queens, some elderly are quietly going hungry. One of them is Roza Vladescu, 89, a Holocaust survivor who lives in Forest Hills.
She does not have enough money to pay for extravagant meals. She spends $1 a day on a service that provides her with a modest warm lunch six days a week.
"For me, it's enough," she said. "I need to have a little force, otherwise I fall down on the street."
She found the program with the help of Selfhelp Community Services, a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the charities supported by the Neediest Cases Fund.
Mrs. Vladescu depends on $618 a month in her late husband's Social Security benefits. She had been eating lunches at a nearby senior center run by Selfhelp, but after an operation on her foot to remove cancer, she said, walking to the center every day was too painful.
So she walked into a nearby Selfhelp office that specializes in helping Holocaust survivors. There Mrs. Vladescu met with a social worker, Susan Morgan, who told her that she could apply for a meal delivery program offered by the local community group, the Forest Hills Community House.
Though getting food was the most pressing issue for Mrs. Vladescu, Ms. Morgan is continuing to work with her, helping her to organize her bills. Over the summer, the agency also gave Mrs. Vladescu a new air-conditioner to prevent straining her heart.
"I was suffocated here," Mrs. Vladescu said.
 While hunger is an ever-present concern in the lives of many New Yorkers, there are a few times when getting the next meal is temporarily forgotten.
On a recent afternoon, a worker at the Project FIND coffeehouse called out for the people holding Nos. 11 to 20. Mr. Bratcher picked up his number, 19, but didn't go to eat the meal that had been prepared: chicken with barbecue sauce, broccoli, corn, milk and orange juice. He said he was too distraught to eat because he was thinking about his grown children.
He does not know where they live. He said he had gone to places where he thought he might find them, but had not had any luck. As he remembered his daughter Dena he thought about how he could find enough money to get to Corona, Queens, the neighborhood where they used to live, to see if he could find her.
"I haven't seen her in quite some time," Mr. Bratcher said, as the corners of his bloodshot eyes dampened. "But I sure would like to see her."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The Genesis of a Huge Contract

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Sometime after George W. Bush and his partners sold the Texas Rangers to Tom Hicks, Bush, then the governor and now the president-elect, attended a game at the Ballpark in Arlington.
"I bumped into him," Doug Melvin, the Rangers general manager, said, "and he said: 'Doug, you need to get some pitching. You know you can spend as much money as you want now.' " 
 Bush was joking, Melvin added, but last week, with the blessing -- no, the encouragement -- of Hicks, Melvin signed Alex Rodriguez to the biggest player contract in sports history.
"I didn't know back then about being a general manager," Melvin said, recalling the years (1979-84) he worked for the Yankees, at one point making $12,000 a year pitching batting practice. Nor did he know about $252 million contracts.
Free agency was still in its infancy when Melvin ended his minor league pitching career and began working for a living. The historic Rodriguez signing came just 12 days before the 25th anniversary of the arbitration decision by Peter Seitz that created free agency.
A quarter of a century later, with the economic pendulum having swung 180 degrees to their side, players are earning more money than their predecessors could have imagined.
But with each major contract -- Rodriguez, Manny Ramirez, Mike Hampton, Mike Mussina have signed this off-season's biggest contracts for a total of $621.5 million -- owners of some lower- or middle-revenue clubs become more militant in their resolve to grab back control of salaries when the current collective bargaining agreement expires at the end of next season.
On the other hand, others involved in baseball ask why the union should be willing to make major concessions when clubs continue spending as they are. "There won't be a negotiation," one person said. "They'll just re-sign. There's not a chance."
Commissioner Bud Selig will answer the question by saying he understands that thinking but the players have to do their share to restore payroll parity. He will have a difficult job, however, selling that view, and the militant owners will perhaps push for a freeze on signings after next season.
Melvin fully understands his position in the developing situation.
"I'm sure there are some people in the industry who wish I was still throwing batting practice," he said. "I'm taking a lot of heat from the industry on this. I'm really a low-keyed guy, but it's pretty stressful. I'm trying to balance the excitement of having a guy like that on your club with some of the anguish you have with the deal."
The total of the 10-year package could have been less than $252 million, Melvin said, if the Rangers had been willing to include clauses allowing Rodriguez to be a free agent after three years and after six years.
"They wanted outs at three years and at six years," Melvin said. "Tom said he wasn't interested in that. He said, 'If I'm going to sign this player, I want to do it for a long time.' That's why the salary is high the last few years."
The contract has an escape clause after seven years, which Melvin said the Rangers did not mind. "At that point," he said, "he has to take a look at the salaries."
The Rangers have been criticized most for their willingness to make the contract so huge without having any ostensible competition.
The Seattle Mariners, Rodriguez's former team, offered a rate of $18 million a year for five years, only three of them guaranteed. "They just weren't in the competition," said Scott Boras, Rodriguez's agent.
He said the Atlanta Braves offered 10 years, but a person involved in the Braves ownership said they were talking five years at perhaps $25 million a year. The Braves also were not willing to include a no-trade clause, ending their chances at any price.
"Alex wasn't interested in that," Boras said. "We definitely wanted to stay in one place."
Melvin dismissed the no-competition complaint. "The old thing is no one else was competing against you," he said. "You hear that after the fact, but you don't hear that when you're in negotiations."
For Hicks, an experienced entrepreneur, it was love at first sight, and that quick development was the key to the deal. From his first meeting with Rodriguez, Hicks knew he wanted this player on his team. Rodriguez has that effect on people. Besides being a terrific shortstop, he is a remarkably impressive young man. The combination was irresistible for Hicks.
Of course, he would like to have signed Rodriguez for less, but Boras would not let it happen. He told Hicks what it would cost, and they negotiated from there.
"It wasn't going to be a clear-cut 7-year, $20 million-a-year deal," Melvin said. "We found out that wasn't going to work."
Melvin spoke with Boras the first night of the winter meetings in Dallas. Hicks had gone to New York for a bar mitzvah.
"I met with Scott just to try to find out if there was still the sincere interest we had heard from him," Melvin related.
They did not meet Saturday while Melvin conducted business with other free agents and Boras met with other teams. They resumed their talks Sunday at 1 p.m. But two hours earlier Hicks and Melvin met to formulate a proposal.
The two sides talked for four hours, going back and forth on years and money and opt-out and salary-escalator clauses. Boras sensed that the Rangers would not be flexible and considered the possibility that he would have to look elsewhere.
They recessed for an hour at about 5 p.m. so that the Rangers could announce the signing of Ken Caminiti, a free-agent third baseman. They returned to their meeting room at the Wyndham Anatole Hotel and negotiated for another hour, breaking at 7 p.m.
Hicks went to have dinner with his family; Melvin and Boras remained at the hotel working separately on other matters. At 8:30 they reconvened and continued exchanging ideas. Several times Boras left the room to make telephone calls. Hicks and Melvin did not know if he was talking to other teams about Rodriguez or other teams about another client, Darren Dreifort.
One of the calls was to Rodriguez, who was in Las Vegas. The client instructed the agent to close the deal if he could.
Now agent and club officials moved toward an agreement, throwing out the early opt-out clauses, adding more money to the later years of a 10-year contract. Somewhere around 1:30 a.m., they were confident they had a deal. Boras had already called Rodriguez and told him it was basically done.
A few small issues remained, but nothing that would intrude on completion of the historic contract.
Melvin slept for about three hours that night. "It was a little bit tough," he said. "I was somewhat excited, but I also knew there'd be some kind of an impact from the industry."
Hicks flew to New Orleans on business Monday morning and Melvin attended the minor league draft and a general managers' meeting.
At 3 p.m. Boras handed Melvin a document to review. Hicks arrived shortly before 5, and Rodriguez officially joined the Rangers.
More than three months from the start of next season, the Rangers are given little chance of winning the American League West championship because they lack starting pitching and a closing relief pitcher.
"They may write on my grave 'Doug Melvin never won because he didn't believe in pitching,' " the former minor league pitcher said. "It's not that I don't believe in it. Our system, a 162-game schedule and expansion, has thinned out our pitching. I'm not trying to justify the money we spent. It's philosophical. I've changed my philosophy over time.
"This is not a knock against Mike Hampton, but if you take a pitcher like Hampton and the games he'll play through the term of his contract, Alex will readily play that number in a year and a half. There's a chance to come out and see Alex Rodriguez for 150 games a season. You see those pitchers a lot less times."
Contrary to a popular view of the Rodriguez contract, Melvin said it did not include a provision that said Rodriguez had to be baseball's highest-paid shortstop.
"Scott asked about that kind of thing early on, but we said we can't do that," Melvin said, referring to Boras. "What if Derek Jeter had that in his deal? It would go to infinity. A-Rod gets bumped, and the next day Jeter has to get bumped because A-Rod got bumped. Then A-Rod would have to get bumped again and on and on and on."
The contract does include a clause that is intended, after the eighth and ninth years, to maintain Rodriguez's status as the highest-paid player in the game. That status is to be determined based on March 31 salaries. After each of those seasons, the Rangers are to give him a $5 million raise in his $27 million salary or make his salary $1 million more than the highest-paid player, whichever is greater. If the Rangers decline, they must make him a free agent.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
He Wasn't Moving; He Wasn't Breathing

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

 BODY:
THREE years later, Reggie Brown is working as an auto-dealership trainee in Austin, Tex., and playing pickup basketball to keep his weight down. His wife, Kerrie, is expecting their first child, a boy, in May.
"I'm as healthy as I'm going to get," he said with a soft laugh from his Round Rock, Tex., home. "I'm limited a little in turning my neck, but it's not a problem. I do a good job of fooling people, I guess." 
But on Dec. 21, 1997, as a second-year linebacker with the Detroit Lions, this 6-foot-2-inch first-round draft choice out of Texas A&M suddenly couldn't turn his neck at all. Early in the fourth quarter of a 13-10 victory over the Jets in that season's finale, he and another Lions linebacker, Antonio London, had tackled running back Adrian Murrell after a 2-yard gain.
The other players got up, but Brown didn't. He was not only not moving, but he was also not breathing and he was unconscious. Doctors and trainers hurried to him.
"It was a routine play, but somebody fell backwards on me," he said. "I was in the wrong position, I guess. I just remember the few seconds before I went out."
Unconscious and unable to breathe or move, his face was turning blue. Moments earlier, the 77,624 spectators in the Pontiac Silverdome had been roaring, but now, as they and all the television viewers stared silently at what is football's scariest scene, you could hear a tear drop.
"I stopped breathing for a minute and a half, they told me later," Brown said.
Out there near the Jets' 30-yard line, Dr. Terry Locke, then the Lions' orthopedist, and Kent Falb, then their trainer, saved Brown's life with mouth-to-mouth resuscitation that got him breathing. After an ambulance rolled onto the field, its red lights flashing, he was rushed to a Pontiac hospital.
"I was unconscious for 30 or 40 minutes," he said. "I didn't come to until I was in the hospital."
Unable to move his arms and legs, Brown feared that he might never walk again. He had sustained a bruised spinal cord that, according to Dr. Russell Nockels, created a "complete collapse in terms" of Brown's being able to breathe and move his limbs. But his paralysis turned out to be temporary.
The next morning, Brown had surgery at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit to fuse the first and second vertebrae in his neck.
"Two days later, I took my first steps," he said. "That's when I knew that I would be able to walk without any problems."
Kerrie Patterson, now his wife, had flown into Detroit that afternoon. Their plan was if the Jets won, thereby knocking the Lions out of the playoffs, they both would return to Texas where she was playing basketball at Texas A&M. If the Lions won to qualify for the playoffs, she would stay for a week.
"I was supposed to pick her up after the game," Brown said. "Instead, she came to the hospital and stayed a couple of weeks."
Nearly three weeks later, Brown, wearing a halo-style neck brace, walked to a podium and held a news conference. Several days later, on a private jet chartered by the Lions, he and his parents returned to Texas. He spent a week at a Houston hospital in physical therapy. Two months later, he discarded the neck brace. He graduated from Texas A&M with a degree in agriculture economics in 1999.
"I'm not required to do any rehab now," he said. "I just have to see a local doctor once a year."
In addition to the insurance coverage of his past and future medical bills relating to his injury, Brown received a $200,000 injury-protection payment as well as $200,000 from the players' disability plan. William Clay Ford, the Lions' owner, arranged for Brown to enter the Ford Motor Company's dealership trainee program at Pavilion Lincoln Mercury in Austin.
"It's a two-year program where someday you can own your own dealership," Brown said. "I started a month and a half ago. I'm working in the parts department right now but you go through every department -- parts, service, new car sales, used car sales, accounting. The business courses I took at A&M in my agriculture economics major have helped me."
The day he was hurt, two of his Texas Aggie teammates, Aaron Glenn and Ray Mickens, were among the Jets staring from their sideline.
"I see them around in the off-season," Brown said. "I know Marcus Coleman and Chris Hayes too. We discuss what happened that day."
Reggie Brown, now 26, has DirecTV that enables him, as he said, "to watch every game," including today's Jets-Lions game at Giants Stadium, their first meeting since the game when he got hurt. But he has blended into a new life. Asked if he would mind being photographed at the dealership, he answered gently.
"I would rather not," he said. "I try to keep myself out of the scene. I don't like to bring attention to myself. I try to fit in as much as I can."

HEADLINE: Urban Projects Tough Sell in Greenmarket

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
These are edgy days at the Union Square Greenmarket, where more than 100 farmers come in from the countryside, four days a week, to sell their produce, cheese and baked goods. Since a petition objecting to looming construction projects on the square was circulated on Dec. 9, worrisome rumors have been flying. The specifics vary, but they boil down to the same fear: that some farmers will probably be bumped out of their spots in the market during the construction.
"I just can't take a hiatus for six or seven or eight months," said Ken Barber, of Stone Arch Farm in Valois, N.Y., who has been selling his summer fruits and homemade cakes since the market started about 27 years ago. "If I lose that time, I'm done. I'm done. 
 "I don't know what's going on," he added, "and it's frustrating."
Two construction projects, both long planned and well publicized, are scheduled to begin on Jan. 2. A century-old water main on the west edge of the park that burst last winter is to be repaired, a job that city officials estimate will take six months. And a long-awaited $5 million renovation of the park will extend its green space into the southwest corner, where there is now a slab of asphalt, and add shrubs, rows of trees and benches. Officials estimate that construction will take at least a year.
"Everybody's going to be inconvenienced," said Lys McLaughlin, executive director of the Council on the Environment of New York City, a nonprofit group that runs the city's 29 Greenmarkets. "There may be some farmers that lose their space" while construction is under way.
That prospect frightens the 50-odd farmers with stands along the park's west side. They are not comforted by reassurances that the dislocation will be temporary, or that in the end they will be selling their fruits and vegetables, their cheeses and breads, in a sleeker, greener park.
"If I'm not able to sell for three months, I honestly don't know," said Stewart Borowsky, who sells wheatgrass that he grows at his home in Monticello, N.Y. "I guess I'll have to go out of business. And the customers -- what about them?"
New York's Greenmarkets were founded in the mid-70's, and many city dwellers say they can barely imagine life without them. On busy Saturdays, 100,000 shoppers crowd the Union Square market, the biggest and most varied of the 29 markets. In the summers, it is regularly visited by busloads of foreign tourists and seems almost as firmly planted as the Empire State Building.
"This market is really critical, not just for the farmers but for New York City," said Frances Stone, a freelance photographer who was shopping recently. "Where else can you find 20 different kinds of apples? Gristedes?"
Alfred Milanese, who sells homemade pretzels and is a spokesman for the farmers, worries that months of disruption, noise and chaos caused by construction could have long-term effects on the market and on individual farmers who could be forced out during this coming winter and spring.
"This whole community that is formed here is very fragile," he said. "People think it can't topple. But it can."
Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said he did not know precisely how much space would be needed for the projects, "but we love the Greenmarket," he said. "We are trying to keep the disruption to a minimum, and do what we can to accommodate the market."
Community Board 5 is planning a meeting soon to discuss the construction plans.
"This is not insurmountable," Mr. Barber, the farmer, said. "I understand they have to remodel. Hopefully, we can talk this out. This place is a treasure, and if farmers are pushed out, they probably won't come back. Hopefully, we can find room for everybody."

HEADLINE: Fitness Clubs Will Be Sold So a Chain Can Expand

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
In an effort to pay for a nationwide expansion, the upscale Manhattan gym chain Equinox Fitness Clubs has agreed to be acquired by two private investing firms, according to Equinox's chief executive.
After more than six months of negotiations, Equinox, which is privately held, agreed to be sold late Friday to North Castle Partners, L.L.C., a private equity company in Greenwich, Conn., and J.W. Childs Associates in Boston, for "significantly north of $100 million," said Harvey Spevak, Equinox's chief executive. The companies plan to announce the deal tomorrow, he added. 
 Mr. Spevak said the deal will give Equinox enough cash to fund a capital-intensive national rollout with the goal of dotting major cities in the United States with versions of its Manhattan clubs, which fill loft-like spaces with the latest in gym equipment and seek to attract young, affluent customers. The company hopes to add four to six clubs a year for the next five years, he added.
Equinox began in 1991 as a family-owned club on the Upper West Side, and will continue to be run by the its current management, including Danny Errico, a member of the founding family, Mr. Spevak said. There are now 11 Equinox gyms, mostly in Manhattan. While Equinox membership fees vary, they average about $115 per month. Other health club chains charge roughly $75 a month.
Fitness clubs like Equinox often cost more than $10 million each to build, according to industry analysts. Mr. Spevak said he was not worried about such ambitious expansion plans at a time when the economy appears to be weakening. "We don't attract people on the bubble," he said, describing his clients as financially able to withstand a slowing economy. Gym fees, he added, are "a small percentage of their overall discretionary spending."
Nonetheless, he said Equinox's expansion plans would include only cities where there is a significant percentage of wealthy residents, like Los Angeles and San Francisco. "We're not going to be building in Albuquerque," he said.
He would not say exactly where the national rollout will begin, citing competitive concerns.
The fitness club industry is rife with failed businesses that were ruined by highly leveraged expansion, a point Mr. Spevak said has not been lost on him. "The industry had a black eye because of bad debt in the 80's," he said. He said his plans were based on "good strong fundamentals.' "'
