HEADLINE: Alan Greenspan and the Temple of Boom

BYLINE: By Robert Kuttner; Robert Kuttner is co-editor of The American Prospect. His most recent book is "Everything for Sale: The Virtues and Limits of Markets."

 BODY:

 MAESTRO
 Greenspan's Fed and
 the American Boom.
 By Bob Woodward.
 Illustrated. 270 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $25.
 
 GREENSPAN
 The Man Behind Money.
 By Justin Martin.
 Illustrated. 284 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Perseus Publishing. $28. 
 Bob Woodward has written about America's most reclusive power centers, from the Central Intelligence Agency to the White House to the Supreme Court -- and now the Federal Reserve Board. Woodward's method, the subject of admiration, envy and scorn, is to cultivate so many players that soon everyone feels compelled to volunteer his or her side of the story. His critics have faulted him for running a kind of journalistic protection racket: Nice little reputation you have there; it would be a shame if anything happened to it.
By extension, Woodward is said to be overly kind to those who do talk. In a famously scathing review of five of his previous books, the essayist Joan Didion wrote that "the informant who talks to Mr. Woodward . . . knows that his or her testimony will be not only respected but burnished into the inside story"; despite their reportorial virtuosity "these are books in which measurable cerebral activity is virtually absent."
In "Maestro," Woodward has refined his technique, mostly for the better. As usual, everyone talks. But "Maestro" offers a good measure of cerebral activity. In a surprisingly short book, Woodward lucidly explains the axes of intellectual and political disagreement over monetary policy, productivity growth, irrational exuberance and more, shedding new light on major conflicts of the Greenspan era and demystifying this most political of ostensibly technical institutions. He supplements his interviews with extensive archival research and connects the dots with his own analysis. You wonder how he has the nerve to put a complex conversation from 1989 in quotation marks -- until you realize that this time he's unearthed a little-known verbatim transcript.
Starting with the book's worshipful title, Woodward is certainly kind to Alan Greenspan, perhaps a little too kind. But these days, who isn't?
Two months after Greenspan took office in August 1987, the stock market lost over 22 percent of its value in a day. The nation's largest financial institutions, thinly capitalized and in debt to one another, can collapse if money markets seize up for lack of buyers or lenders. Greenspan, working closely with E.+Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Fed, embarked on a course far more interventionist than his onetime mentor, the free-market apostle Ayn Rand, might have commended. Woodward explains just how Corrigan discreetly instructed bank executives to keep lending to momentarily insolvent debtors. The Fed would back them up. All this was illegal and, if it didn't work, could violate countless fiduciary duties and prudent-man rules. But it was precisely what the Fed had failed to do in 1929. This time, the system held.
From there, Woodward recounts how the Maestro gradually brought his ample skills to his masterwork -- the longest boom in American history. Greenspan perceived that something fundamental had changed, allowing faster rates of noninflationary growth and lower unemployment than previously thought possible. He proceeded not from theory but from data. In the process the Fed was transformed, from a dour financial fortress that would readily throw millions out of work before risking a little inflation into a temple of boom. We get no major revelations, but a lot of nice nuance and detail.
By tradition, other members of the Fed's board of governors and the Open Market Committee (which sets key interest rates) seldom vote down their chairman. A Fed chairman on the verge of losing a vote usually fashions a face-saving compromise. Those who lose don't last. Even Greenspan's predecessor, the formidable Paul Volcker, called it quits after losing a 4-3 vote. As Woodward shows, Greenspan maintains his political equilibrium as skillfully as he equilibrates monetary policy. Rarely, when colleagues are leaning against him, he makes a personal appeal. Usually, he has already worked key members one at a time.
Before the Greenspan era, the Open Market Committee voted as a body on each change in interest rates. In the anxious aftermath of the 1987 crash, Greenspan persuaded his colleagues to change the process. The committee would now vote a policy "directive," but leave the timing and magnitude of rate-setting to the chairman. In Fed jargon, the directive would be either neutral, "asymmetric-negative" (prefiguring a rate cut), or "asymmetric-positive" (signaling a probable increase). Greenspan promoted the shift as a subtler way of influencing the markets. But, as Woodward writes, the committee "was basically ceding operational control to Greenspan." Several strong-willed colleagues, with agendas of their own, quit once they saw that Greenspan held most of the cards.
So what's not to like, either about Alan Greenspan or about Bob Woodward's portrait of him? History will surely judge Greenspan as an exceptionally successful Fed chairman. Still, Woodward's "Maestro" is a shade too asymmetric-positive. His charity reflects both the implicit bargain in his method and a genuine admiration for his subject. In his account, Greenspan managed the Fed, the economy and the political footwork virtually without error. The only misjudgments Woodward allows are those that Greenspan acknowledges himself. In 1991, pressing for a rate cut, Greenspan realizes he doesn't have the votes and backs off. Woodward writes, "Greenspan realized he may have made a mistake in trying to move impulsively."
Woodward softens blemishes. As
a private consultant, Greenspan had written a report in 1985 endorsing the savings and loan manipulator Charles Keating. Woodward accepts at face value Greenspan's alibi: "Keating hadn't done anything wrong at that point, or if he had, it wasn't detectable." We should all be the targets of such investigative reporting.
Isn't there anything that Greenspan did wrong? He deserves immense credit for resisting pressure to extinguish the boom by overreacting to real or imagined inflationary threats. By contrast, nearly every postwar recession was engineered by previous inflation-phobic Federal Reserve Boards. He brokered and kept the grand bargain of the 1990's: deficit reduction for lower interest rates. Greenspan also did brilliantly at heading off several potential catastrophes, all outside the Fed's explicit franchise, including the stock market crash of 1987, the huge banking losses of the early 1990's, the Mexican peso collapse of 1994, the Asian contagion of 1998 and the failure of Long Term Capital Management. He may even have talked down a fevered stock market.
But, as critics like James K. Galbraith and Alan Blinder, a former vice chairman of the Fed, have pointed out, the economy was probably capable of somewhat faster noninflationary growth somewhat sooner. George Bush (Sr.), for one, may have been justified in seeing Greenspan's interest rate cuts in the 1990-91 recession as too little and too late. Woodward tells that story pretty much from Greenspan's point of view.
To be sure, notable public figures often choose sympathetic biographers, and writers frequently profile people they admire. Mostly, Woodward's rendition of events is scrupulous and illuminating. "Maestro," however, has a few quirks. The narrative is mostly chronological, but we get four pages on Greenspan's early years sandwiched into the middle of the 1988 election. Some of those interviewed on background complain (on background) that their fingerprints were not supposed to be visible, but it is so clear who talked that Woodward might as well have published a list. He opens with a paean to his research assistant so effusive ("my full-time collaborator at every step of this book -- reporting, writing, and editing") that you wonder what the division of labor really was and why he didn't just give young Jeff Himmelman a byline.
But the book's one substantive weakness is more its narrow focus than its favoritism. Given his exceptional access and research, Woodward might have chosen to pursue more about the Federal Reserve itself. Alan Greenspan is not just a central banker, but also a regulator; he is indulgent of bank mergers and other inventions of the market. To the consternation of other members of the board of governors, the Fed staff reports directly to him. None of this particularly interests Woodword. But there will be more comprehensive books on the Greenspan Fed, and all will owe a debt to Woodward's "Maestro."
Justin Martin, a former staff writer at Fortune magazine, had the double misfortune to publish a Greenspan biography within weeks of Woodward's, and not to have gained his subject's cooperation. Yet there is interesting material here. Where "Maestro" concentrates on Greenspan's tenure at the Fed, Martin mostly covers Greenspan's earlier life. Besides informing us about Greenspan's childhood love of baseball, his early career as a musician and his first marriage, and about details of his connection to Ayn Rand, Martin helps the reader see the way Greenspan's earlier career made him such an effective Fed chairman. As a business consultant and data analyst, mining such arcana as freight car loadings and steel shipments, Greenspan gained a better understanding of the real economy than most high theorists. All this might have made Martin's "Greenspan" a neat complement to Woodward's "Maestro," if only Martin had been a more effective writer. His extensive interviews often yield unremarkable quotations. (" 'I had very high regard for Alan,' recalls Kissinger.") Oddly, he devotes more space to Greenspan's tenure as President Gerald Ford's chief economic adviser than to his 13 years at the Fed.
Neither Woodward nor Martin quite addresses the central irony of the Greenspan era. Though Greenspan is a stout free-market man in a staunchly free-market era, each of his successes was a triumph of economic intervention. Another great conservative monetary economist, Milton Friedman, argued that monetary policy should be put on automatic pilot, because Fed chairmen, subject to political pressure and human error, were at risk of oversteering the economy into recession or inflation.
But had Greenspan not moved vigorously in 1987 to flood the system with money, the 1990's might have been more like the 1930's. Had the Fed and the Treasury not moved to orchestrate carefully bounded bailouts of Mexico and Korea, of Long Term Capital Management and of technically insolvent money center banks, the market system would have been worse off. Had Greenspan not taken the trouble to revise Friedman's "natural rate of unemployment" theory in light of changes in the real economy, growth would have been needlessly slowed.
Evidently markets oversteer at least as much as Fed chairmen. And it turns out that institutions of government (of which the Fed is one) can learn from past mistakes and sometimes turn in virtuoso performances. Even most free-marketeers would prefer an activist Fed run by Maestro Greenspan to one operating on autopilot.
But is the Fed as currently structured the best possible institution to manage the economy? Do the criteria under which it operates serve the broadest public interest? The damage control was superb, but should there have been more preventive regulation? And what will happen if Greenspan's successor lacks the Maestro's touch? Both Woodward and Martin find Greenspan so compelling a figure that they have emphasized the great man at the expense of exploring the institution.

HEADLINE: One Man's Justice

BYLINE: By Jeffrey Rosen; Jeffrey Rosen, an associate professor at the George Washington University Law School and the legal affairs editor of The New Republic, is the author of "The Unwanted Gaze: The Destruction of Privacy in America."

 BODY:

 Law Without Values
 The Life, Work, and Legacy of Justice Holmes.
 By Albert W. Alschuler.
 325 pp. Chicago:
 The University of Chicago Press. $30. 
 Justice Oliver WENDELL HOLMES was a cold, savage and brutal man. He was indifferent to human suffering; he came "devilish near to believing," as he put it, "that might makes right"; and he scorned all political and moral enthusiasms except for eugenics. This is the thesis of Albert W. Alschuler's "Law Without Values," an exuberantly and entertainingly polemical attack on the character, scholarship and philosophy of America's most revered judicial saint. Never mind the hagiography served up by Holmes's fawning acolytes. The real Holmes, according to Alschuler, was a social Darwinist who glorified war and had contempt for the losers in democratic struggles. He was not someone you would have wanted as a friend.
Alschuler, who teaches at the University of Chicago Law School, argues convincingly that Holmes's supporters were able to repackage him as a progressive simply because he happened to write the most famous dissent in American history when he defended the constitutionality of New York's maximum-hour law for bakers. ("The 14th Amendment does not enact Mr. Herbert Spencer's 'Social Statics,' "Holmes wrote in 1905, even though he himself was the only true social Darwinist on the Supreme Court.) But although Holmes voted to uphold progressive laws, he also voted to uphold illiberal, even fascistic ones. He voted in favor of virtually all laws because of his radically restrained view of judicial authority. "I quite agree that a law should be called good if it reflects the will of the dominant forces of the community," Holmes wrote to Felix Frankfurter, "even if it will take us to hell."
In his determined pursuit of this vision, Holmes upheld some of the darkest statutes ever passed by American legislatures. In 1903, for example, he refused to invalidate Alabama's scheme of voter registration, which used literacy tests, poll taxes and other ruses to exclude nearly all the 180,000 blacks in the state from voting. In an opinion that managed to be quixotic and perverse, Holmes held that if the registration scheme really was a fraud on the Constitution, the court couldn't order the plaintiff to be registered without participating in the fraud.
Even more notoriously, Holmes in 1927 upheld laws that eventually led to the sterilization of more than 18,000 "imbeciles" in 30 states, many of whom were hardly mentally disabled. "Three generations of imbeciles," Holmes wrote in his opinion, "are enough." Alschuler quotes a letter in which Holmes talked about "restricting propagation by the undesirables and putting to death infants that didn't pass the examination, etc., etc." What to make of such sentiments? Enthusiasm for eugenics, as Judge Richard Posner has noted, was a staple of progressive thought during Holmes's career -- advocates included George Bernard Shaw and Theodore Roosevelt. And if some of Holmes's comments seem outrageous even by the standards of his day, perhaps Alschuler takes his private letters a bit too literally. Holmes, like many of us, often indulged in deliberately shocking hyperbole in private, to amuse himself and his friends and to unsettle conventional pieties.
Even if Holmes was an enthusiastic eugenicist, it's not clear how relevant his anti-egalitarian views were to his jurisprudence. "I am so skeptical as to our knowledge about the goodness or badness of laws that I have no practical criticism except what the crowd wants," he wrote, even as he confessed that he loathed "the thick-fingered clowns we call the people."
Alschuler finds Holmes's defense of judicial restraint "ambiguous" and incoherent because it failed to specify how the dominant power was dominant. But Holmes's attitude toward democracy might best be described as aristocratic indifference: he viewed legislative battles as a spectator sport for Nietzschean judges, who were meant to keep their hands off the vulgar disputes of the grasping masses while fixing their gaze on more important achievements, like creative genius, everlasting fame or heroic death on the battlefield. Consistent with this vision, Holmes was willing to use his judicial power to intervene primarily in cases involving clear violations of First Amendment rights, where the possibility of democratic struggle itself was at risk.
After reading Alschuler's spirited attack on Holmes, I found myself all the more admiring of Holmes's dark skepticism, wicked wit and hunger for greatness, and all the more convinced of his deep relevance in the 21st century. The most important liberal and conservative legal movements today are the heirs of Holmes -- from critical race and critical legal theorists on the left to law and economics scholars on the right to contemporary pragmatists and functionalists in the center. Nearly all share Holmes's view that the public purposes asserted for laws, like supposedly objective notions of right and wrong, are often hypocritical masks for raw power struggles. But while the contemporary heirs of Holmes are often eager to use the courts to impose their own visions of the good and true on citizens, Holmes himself rejected the crude proposition that all law is politics. Unlike many of his followers today, Holmes was sufficiently skeptical of his own exclusive ability to discern the truth that he insisted that judges should not use their undemocratic power to impose supposedly objective (but actually, vigorously contested) principles of right and wrong on a deeply divided nation.
Alschuler wants to persuade us that Holmes's scholarly and judicial achievements were "mostly negative" because his "revolt against objective concepts of right and wrong" led to "a revolt against natural law." But Holmes's rejection of the claim that abstract principles of natural law exist independently of the values and customs of a particular society did not, in fact, lead him to embrace what Alschuler calls "law without values." On the contrary, Holmes recognized that positive law is suffused with values; he wrote that "law is the witness and external deposit of our moral life."
Holmes's judicial abstinence may have grown out of his aristocratic indifference, but he points the way toward a vision of judicial humility that is more relevant than ever in a pluralistic and egalitarian age in which people violently disagree. For reminding us of the power of Holmes's embattled vision, in spite of his valiant efforts to discredit it, we have Albert Alschuler to thank.

HEADLINE: Children's Books

BYLINE: By Simon Rodberg 

 BODY:

 Skyscrapers
 How America Grew Up.
 By John B. Severance.
 Holiday House, $18.95.
 (Ages 10 and up) 
 The cover of John B. Severance's "Skyscrapers: How America Grew Up" features a photo of the tippy-top of the Woolworth Building surrounded by clouds. In this grounded but entertaining history for middle-grade readers, Severance aims to demystify what made that tower rise so high. From Mrs. O'Leary's cow to Donald Trump, he ties together engineering, economics and aesthetics and the personalities who dominated them.
The story of skyscrapers is one of technological and urban growth, set mostly in New York and Chicago. But Severance's tale is really a history of outsize megalomania building outsize monuments to its own majesty. He writes that cathedrals and pyramids have one thing in common with the 19th- and 20th-century tall buildings we know as skyscrapers: the power of the human ego. The egos sparkle in this information-packed narrative of how continual competition drove American building ever higher.
The one element missing might be called the David Macaulay factor: a cogent explanation of skyscrapers' design. How does a thousand-foot pile of steel and glass manage to stand up straight? Severance gives us some tidbits, but his book, full of beautiful photographs, suffers from the lack of diagrams to make technologies like frame-tube structure comprehensible. We want to know the way those things work.
As a story, though, "Skyscrapers" is gripping. One feels a chill of fear from the inside drama of how the Citicorp Center in Manhattan came a hurricane away from collapsing, and a thrill of triumph for the architect and the consulting engineer who saved it.
Severance also manages to make architectural theory seem both relevant and understandable, particularly in his narrative on the origins and excesses of the International style. His last chapter sounds a note of skepticism about the humanity of these human monuments. But the thrust of the book is that of the Great Leap Upward. Simon Rodberg

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Scott Veale

 BODY:

THE COLLECTED SHORT FICTION OF BRUCE JAY FRIEDMAN. (Grove, $14.) These humorous tales, published between 1953 and 1995, feature dizzying flights of fancy and whammo endings, taking on subjects as varied as psychiatrists, Hollywood, cocaine, guilt, sex and Jewish mothers. "Friedman has been likened to everyone from J. D. Salinger to Woody Allen," Christopher Buckley wrote here in 1995. "This collection should finally establish him for what he is: Bruce Jay Friedman, sui generis and no mean thing." Speaking of Jewish mothers, Friedman's 1964 novel, A Mother's Kisses (University of Chicago, $14), describes the efforts of a 17-year-old Brooklyn boy to break free from the gravitational field of "the most unforgettable mother since Medea," according to our reviewer, Haskel Frankel. She is "heaven and hell jammed into a hammock-sized bra and a too-tight girdle. She is a Bensonhurst Mae West."
 
THROUGH THE BRAZILIAN WILDERNESS, by Theodore Roosevelt. (Cooper Square, $19.95.) Roosevelt was, among other things, an avid naturalist, and his informal account of the 48-day Roosevelt-Rondon expedition in 1913-14 to map the "River of Doubt" is filled with harrowing encounters with rapids, blistering heat, mosquitoes, fire ants and jungle illness. In 1914, the Book Review called this an "excellent volume" by an author "blessed with a power for minute and careful observation." In Stranger in the Forest: On Foot Across Borneo, by Eric Hansen (Vintage Departures, $13), a young American traveler chronicles his solo trek through the wilds of Borneo, a journey with more than its own share of close calls and improbable adventures. The result is "a gracefully written and passionate book" whose author "is more interested in the people he meets than in discussing his own considerable courage and endurance," Tim Cahill wrote here in 1988.
 
THE LAST SURVIVOR: Legacies of Dachau, by Timothy W. Ryback. (Vintage, $12.) An American journalist takes the pulse of the German town of Dachau, using the (possibly fabricated) memories of an 87-year-old Holocaust survivor to stage a morality play about a haunted place and its troubled residents. The book "is elegantly written without ever neglecting the magnitude of horror that underlies every gesture, breath and nuance in Dachau," Thane Rosenbaum wrote here last year.
 
LOVERS FOR A DAY, by Ivan Klima. (Grove, $12.) These Czech stories, written both before and after the fall of Communism, revolve around themes of love and death, featuring factory workers, students and other characters whose dreary lives are tempered by the consolations of sex, humor and fantasy. "Klima's view of love is often witty, sometimes playful, and has a convincing sense of the erotic, but it is never sanguine," Andrew Miller said here last year.
 
WHO I WAS SUPPOSED TO BE: Short Stories, by Susan Perabo. (Scribner, $11.) In this debut collection, a data processor squanders her inheritance on one of Princess Diana's gowns and Batman's butler recounts the demise of his dissolute boss. "Perabo's clear, wry sentences meld a prose style that's reminiscent of Raymond Carver's with a sensibility that's informed by People magazine," Dana Kennedy wrote here last year.
 
SELECTED LETTERS OF DAWN POWELL: 1913-1965, edited by Tim Page. (Owl/Holt, $16.) Dawn Powell (1896-1965) was primarily known for her novels but wrote hundreds of letters to friends, relatives and other writers. This selection by a devoted admirer displays her social gifts and her "ironic, triumphant, mocking and game" voice, Lorrie Moore wrote here in 1999. Her letters offer "a portrait of a hard-working, resilient female artist and professional. . . . A reader comes to the last of them already missing their company."
 
CROSSING: A Memoir, by Deirdre McCloskey. (University of Chicago, $15.) A renowned economist and historian tells of her decision at the age of 52 to change herself from a man into a woman, of the grueling physical procedures involved in her transformation and of the emotional evolution she experienced on the way. "This is a woman worth knowing," Maxine Kumin said here in 1999. "She has given us a highly readable, dramatic account of her crossing."
 
THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF JOSEPH STALIN, by Richard Lourie. (Da Capo, $15.) In this ambitious novel, the dictator reviews his own rise to power at the same time his archrival, the exiled Trotsky, is writing his own book about Stalin's life. The result is an uneven but "often engaging" tale that "effervesces as the memoirists battle each other for control of the truth," Ken Kalfus said here in 1999. Scott Veale

SECTION: Section 6; Page 46; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 8796 words

HEADLINE: What's Tab Turner Got Against Ford?

BYLINE: By Michael Winerip; Michael Winerip is a staff writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
'I'll be back later," Tab Turner told his secretary as he rushed out of his North Little Rock law office, a file full of damning documents under his arm, a cell phone in one hand, a cup of coffee in the other. Brenda Gwin smiled but did not bother to ask what exactly her boss meant by "later." Later could be 3 o'clock that afternoon or later could be one day next week. Even during normal times, Tab Turner is an incredibly busy man, a product-liability lawyer who has grown rich by specializing in sport utility vehicle rollover cases, who files scores of lawsuits each year against auto manufacturers. But lately, with rollover fatalities repeatedly being linked to the Ford Explorer and its recalled Firestone tires, Turner has been rocketing around the nation faster than a car with a sudden acceleration problem. Rarely is he in the same city two days in a row.
New S.U.V. cases keep rolling his way; at the moment, he has 20 crashed Explorers and 50 mangled Firestone tires stored in a Little Rock warehouse for safekeeping in case he needs to produce them for trials against Ford or Bridgestone-Firestone. 
 It was 10:20 on a Thursday morning in mid-November, and he was due in Houston in two hours to meet a quadriplegic on a ventilator, a woman who all but died when the Ford Explorer she was riding in had a tread separation on the rear right Firestone and rolled over. Turner's spirits were high. "A perfect case," he called it. The police report from the crash was full of good news for Turner: there was no driver error reported, no speeding, no alcohol, no other vehicle involved, the pavement was dry, the rollover occurred on the roadway. When the ambulance arrived, the victim was still in the overturned Explorer, hanging by her seat belt. "Can't do much better than that," Turner said.
In Houston, he was planning on explaining the latest developments in the lawsuit to the woman, her family and her three local attorneys and then flying back to Little Rock. But he was also thinking that afterward he might try to settle a second matter in Houston, then maybe fly to Dallas to settle a third of his 100 or so S.U.V. rollover lawsuits. That was the nice thing about owning a jet. He might suddenly fly to L.A., Akron or Detroit to settle cases there.
"I just wait for his call to find out where he is," said his secretary, who often changes his hotel reservations several times a day.
His drive to the Little Rock airport is only 10 minutes, but Turner is not one to squander 10 seconds, and he worked the cell phone the whole way, sipping his sixth coffee of the morning, steering at times with his elbow and trying to mediate a dispute between several trial attorneys scattered around the country who were all jockeying for a piece of a federal class-action lawsuit in Indianapolis involving the Firestone recall. "The problem is, there's just too many greedy lawyers involved," Turner said into the cell phone. "There's even airline crash people jumping into this -- you never know what they're up to."
The 41-year-old Turner owns, and has mastered, the three machines essential for the modern plaintiff attorney -- the cell phone, the laptop computer and the corporate jet -- and they have enabled him to do to Ford Motor Company what it would have taken a dozen lawyers to do a decade ago. "Ford can't keep up with me," he says, and it's clearly true; they ask him to fly to them when they're ready to talk settlement, because he's more mobile. Turner is a Southern Baptist who believes it would be wrong to drink a beer in front of his three young daughters, and he wryly refers to settlement negotiations as "come to Jesus meetings," presumably because the automakers have seen the folly of their ways. "Ford's ready to get serious on this one," he'll say. "They're ready for their come to Jesus meeting." In one recent stretch, he says, he settled 11 cases (10 of them rollovers) in six weeks, for a combined total of $11.5 million, a third of that his contingency fee.
No one was more responsible than Turner for helping keep the Explorer-Firestone problems atop the national news for so long, to the point that even Ford officials say they've never seen an auto-safety story like it -- not the Chevrolet Corvair in the 1960's, not the Ford Pinto or Firestone 500 tire recall in the 1970's, not the side-mounted gas tank on G.M. pickups in the 1990's.
After a decade of litigating S.U.V. rollovers, Turner has amassed an extraordinary library of Ford internal documents, and he e-mails them around the nation with gusto, to reporters, Congressional investigators, Nader types and fellow plaintiff attorneys. Throughout the summer and fall, he supplied crucial documents to reporters as they vied to be first to figure out who knew what when at Ford and Firestone concerning defective tires that federal investigators have now linked to 148 deaths, mainly in Explorers.
It was Turner who provided the Ford documents showing that when the Explorer was developed in the late 1980's, the prototype repeatedly failed Ford's own rollover tests; and it was Turner who provided documents showing that Ford played a major role in developing the flawed Firestone tire.
When Congressional investigators needed someone to make sense of the thousands of pages of evidence that Ford and Firestone produced at hearings, they discreetly invited Turner to sift through the papers for them. More than once, Ford officials arrived while Turner was there, and he hid behind a closed Senate office door.
When Joan Claybrook, the president of Public Citizen, the Nader consumer group, was lobbying Congress for tougher auto-safety laws last fall, she called Turner for help finding people involved in Explorer accidents. At one point, Claybrook says, "Tab helped get 15 victims to Washington for me practically overnight."
Though Turner is a sole practitioner working out of a modest suburban office, Ford has no greater legal nemesis. For weeks, Ford's 250-person public-relations department fought a guerrilla war, trying to contain the damage of documents leaked by Turner. "Every day Tab would take one of those documents and say, 'Here's a little grenade -- let me throw it in there,"' says Ford's vice president for public relations, Jason Vines, who calls Turner "one of those sharks out there who think they've found the keys to the A.T.M."
But if Turner has been able to clamp his sharky little jaws around the Ford A.T.M., it is because he has been able to beat the auto company at trial before, three times convincing juries that Ford knowingly produced defective vehicles. In 1995, Turner persuaded a Houston jury that all Ford Bronco II's -- not just the one involved in that accident- were dangerously tippy and unstable, that Ford executives ignored warnings from their own engineers and that, as a result, the company was 100 percent at fault for the death of a 20-year-old college student, even though the rollover that killed her was precipitated by a tire-tread separation. The jury award was $25 million, the largest trial verdict at that time in an S.U.V. rollover case.
In 1996, Turner was the first to beat Ford in a sudden-acceleration trial, convincing an Arkansas jury that two elderly women had died because their Grand Marquis suddenly raced off with no warning.
And now he is maneuvering to be the first since the recall to put the Explorer, America's most popular S.U.V., on trial. Despite repeated attempts by Ford and Firestone to win a postponement (Ford eventually settles the vast majority of its rollover suits), a Corpus Christi judge has set the case of Donna Bailey -- the quadriplegic in Houston -- for trial on Jan. 8. Turner says he does not expect to settle this one. He says that he is particularly eager to shine the spotlight on Ford, and that it should accept a major share of the blame. As he has said over and over, in eight-second sound bites for Katie Couric, Bryant Gumbel and Dan Rather: "This is a case of a bad tire on a bad vehicle. Tread separation should not cause a vehicle to roll over."
If the case does go forward, it will very likely be one of the more sensational product-liability trials in years, a legal showdown that gets to the heart of how we live. The sport utility vehicle is as good a symbol as any of America's unprecedented economic boom. The S.U.V.'s elevated "command seating" gives the owner a king-of-the-road, doobie-doobie-doo conceit and has proved popular with a broad class of well-to-do consumers, from good old boys hauling their Chris-Crafts fishing to soccer moms taking the fifth grade C.Y.O. champs out for pizza. The S.U.V. was marketed to be all things to all prosperous people, performing on road, off road, hauling heavy loads or precious cargo. It has made automakers rich, accounting for half of Ford's profit by the late 1990's.
But that same S.U.V. is just as passionately despised by another segment of drivers who can't see past it on the highway and think of it as the piggy vehicle of our time. S.U.V.'s are tanklike (a Ford Excursion weighs 7,700 pounds); their gas mileage can be atrocious (an Expedition gets 12 miles per gallon in the city; 17 on the highway). And God forbid if you're driving in an ordinary sedan and get into a crash with an S.U.V. -- you are more than three times as likely to die than if you had been hit by a midsize car.
Many car models have fan clubs, but S.U.V.'s may be the only one with a hate club, a group of San Francisco people so angry about the vehicle's gas-guzzling ways that they surreptitiously tag them with bumper stickers saying: "I'm changing the climate! Ask me how." "We call these vehicles 'superpredators' and the people that drive them 'superparasites,"' says Charles Dines, a club founder.
S.U.V.'s also have their own special safety flaw. The tradeoff for command seating is a higher center of gravity, making the S.U.V. many times more likely to roll during a sharp emergency turn than, say, a Ford Taurus station wagon or a Ford Windstar minivan or most sedans. If you fill a sedan with people and suitcases, it is less likely to roll over because the weight is added below the car's center of gravity, so it acts like ballast; with an S.U.V., the weight is added above the center of gravity, making the vehicle more tippy. (Indeed, a recently published federal safety scorecard gives a fully loaded Explorer the worst rollover rating, one star out of a possible five.)
Which is not to say that the Explorer stands out as particularly rollover-prone among S.U.V.'s. Despite all the horrible publicity, federal fatality data and safety ratings seem to indicate that the Explorer is pretty typical of midsize S.U.V.'s. Jon Harmon, a Ford spokesman, tells reporters that if the bad Firestone tires had been on another S.U.V., "you wouldn't be talking to me; you'd be talking to one of those other companies."
He may be right. But Ford is America's S.U.V. king, and those tires, built to Ford specifications, were on Explorers. So there will be a measure of Shakespearean justice if the day of reckoning does come early next year in Corpus Christi and it is Ford that is called to stand at trial in defense of the S.U.V.
An Explorer trial would have the undivided attention of Turner's fellow attorneys. Bridgestone of Japan says it has set aside $450 million to pay for expected legal claims against its Firestone subsidiary, but plaintiff attorneys worry that Firestone could declare bankruptcy, tying up lawsuits for years. Ford, they know, can pay instant cash.
Turner is juiced. He is a former Division II All-America lineman out of Ouachita Baptist University in Arkadelphia, Ark., and practices law with the fury of a guy who likes to hit. When he heard that the Texas judge had set a trial date, he informed colleagues with a three-word e-mail message: "Lock and load."
That mid-November morning, as he waited for his Cessna to take off from Little Rock, the cell phone rang yet again, and it was the head of a test-driving company calling with the latest results. A few months before, Turner hired the Arizona company to run two Explorers through a series of extreme maneuvers. "Howdy, Steve," Turner said. "I had a productive trip. Sorry I missed you, but money always comes first."
The jet was taxiing for takeoff. "Oh! How did Mark lose control? . . . Wow! And he's O.K.? . . . Did you get it on video? . . . All right! . . . Let's keep this quiet for now. The last thing we need at this point is one of these media hounds finding out." As the jet climbed upward, Turner put the cell phone down. "Rolled over," he grinned. "Can't do better than that -- that's worth a half-million dollars right there."
It would be good news for Donna Bailey in Houston. The plane had broken through the clouds; he would be there in an hour. He had agreed to take her case months before and had put in a lot of time on it, though this would be his first meeting with Bailey. One reason Turner is so successful is he tries to cock a cold eye on these cases, saving the emotion for the jury. He carefully screens accident reports, accepting about one of every five rollovers, eliminating cases where alcohol is a factor, where the rollover is tripped by an off-road object like a curb or more than one vehicle is involved. In short, he tries to take only single-vehicle rollovers that happen on the pavement so he can make the S.U.V. engineering the central issue at trial.
He hadn't met Bailey yet because he hadn't needed to. But he was planning an unusual strategy for this trial and had to have her approval. He knew almost nothing about her. When asked what she did for a living, he said: "I think a teacher, but I'm not sure. I may be thinking of another case." He said he wouldn't concentrate on that kind of detail until the week of the trial.
If you ask some of the key witnesses to the Explorer-Firestone drama -- Jason Vines at Ford, Joan Claybrook at Public Citizen, Brian O'Neill at the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety -- why it has become the biggest auto-safety story in decades, they can only offer theories. "I've been doing this since 1970," says O'Neill. "I've never seen anything like it."
Vines says a lot of it is that Ford and Firestone are well-known American brands. While Firestone is foreign-owned, Fords and Firestones have worked together for a century and even intermarried. Claybrook suggests it is because the public smells a Watergate-like coverup. She says people are angry that Ford was replacing defective Firestones on Explorers as far back as 1998 in Saudi Arabia and not telling U.S. safety officials. She says Jacques Nasser, Ford's C.E.O., asked her why the story struck such a nerve, and she answered, "The public smells a rat."
Part of it would have to be that S.U.V. buyers are wealthy, vocal and not used to their fancy machines failing. At hearings this fall, almost everyone had an S.U.V. story. Senator William Frist of Tennessee, for one, described the death of a close friend, a surgeon taking his son to college, in a Firestone-Explorer wreck just days after the Aug. 9 recall of the 6.5 million tires.
Whatever the reasons, one thing is certain: the story's power is about more than just the number of people killed. Assuming government figures are right and 148 Americans have died in these crashes in the last decade, that total is modest in the universe of auto-safety statistics. Each year, 40,000 Americans die on highways, and safety officials estimate thousands of them could have saved their lives simply by buckling their seat belts. And the tire debacle is in many ways the lesser S.U.V. story: some 670 car passengers are killed each year when they are unlucky enough to get into crashes with an S.U.V. -- that's 6,700 deaths by S.U.V. in a decade.
Nor should it be news that S.U.V.'s roll over. Experts have been warning about it for decades. From the time the S.U.V. was introduced in its primitive form -- the World War II jeep -- Americans loved the design but hated the consequences. After the war, civilians wanted to buy surplus jeeps, but the Army banned their sale because of the rollovers. In 1970, American Motors became the first major auto company to offer a compact S.U.V., the Jeep CJ, which sold well but was also the target of a "60 Minutes" expose and numerous rollover lawsuits. For the past 30 years, each decade has featured an S.U.V. marketing coup followed by a rollover scandal.
In the 1980's, as every automaker fought for a piece of the new S.U.V. market, Ford's Bronco II made lots of money, selling 760,000 in seven years. Then a 1989 Consumer Reports study found the Bronco II so unstable that the magazine recommended against buying it. From 1983 to 1999, 1,742 persons were killed in Bronco II rollovers, according to federal data analyzed by Alice and Randy Whitfield, consultants for plaintiff attorneys. As of 1995, Ford had settled 334 Bronco II rollover cases for a total of $113,385,504.60.
To erase that memory, in 1990 Ford remodeled the Bronco II into the Explorer, which resulted in the most spectacular S.U.V. marketing success of all time -- 3.6 million sold -- and now there's this, the worst S.U.V. rollover scandal ever.
Americans are like moths drawn to the flame when it comes to S.U.V.'s. Even Turner the rollover lawyer owns an S.U.V., a Chevy Suburban that he uses at work, one of the very biggest, safest rated and piggiest (12 miles per gallon in the city; 15 on the highway).
The federal auto-safety agency, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (N.H.T.S.A.), has been doing S.U.V. rollover studies for 27 years and in the early 1990's considered setting a minimum stability standard to cut down on fatalities. The safety agency concluded that to noticeably reduce the rollover rate would mean getting rid of most midsize S.U.V.'s (like the Explorer) and up to half of the fullsize S.U.V.'s. To make them safer, they would need to be widened and lowered until they started looking like station wagons again.
In this era of strong antiregulatory sentiment, even a Democratic administration had no stomach for telling the public it couldn't have what it wanted. As the federal agency noted, reducing rollovers would necessitate "drastic design changes to a vehicle type that is sought after by consumers." Which gets to another reason the story has played out so large: over a few weeks last summer, the Explorer-Firestone problems stunned the public into realizing how much federal auto-safety enforcement had deteriorated in the last 20 years.
A plaintiff attorney like Turner and federal safety officials would seem to be natural allies. They are both out hunting the same thing: auto-safety problems. And there was a time when the two groups did work together. In 1978, when an attorney named Mark Robinson Jr. won $6.7 million in the Ford Pinto case known as Grimshaw, he was in regular contact with the head of N.H.T.S.A., Joan Claybrook, and her federal investigators. Indeed, a few months later, relying partly on evidence from Robinson's trial, Claybrook initiated legal action, prompting Ford to recall the Pinto.
Claybrook, who left in 1981, right after President Reagan's election, is widely regarded as the last aggressive director of the auto-safety agency. She is still close to many plaintiff attorneys, including Turner. It was a few years ago, over dinner in Washington, that Turner first mentioned to her that he had several Explorer-Firestone rollover cases. In contrast, most plaintiff attorneys consider recent N.H.T.S.A. administrators the enemy. They do not share secrets over dinner. Since Claybrook, top officials have been far more pro-business; when they leave government, they often work for auto companies.
Turner's biggest challenge in a trial is often figuring out how to discredit the federal safety agency. In 1996, he tried a sudden-acceleration case against Ford. At the time, no lawyer had won one of these trials, in large part because of a 1989 N.H.T.S.A. study concluding that no sudden-acceleration defect pattern existed and that driver error was the main culprit.
To win, Turner had to undermine both Ford and the federal government. He had to convince jurors that he -- a common plaintiff's lawyer -- knew more about auto safety than the federal agency supposedly looking out for the public's interest. That little-noticed trial speaks volumes about the federal agency's decline.
Two elderly sisters, 75-year-old Jasmine Stell and 79-year-old Cecil Pugh, had finished shopping at a Little Rock mall and then climbed into Stell's late-model Grand Marquis. Stell turned on the key, and the next thing anybody knew the car rocketed out of its parking space, racing so fast one shopper jumped onto the hood of his car to dodge the vehicle. In seconds, the car slammed into a large concrete planter that said "Park Plaza Mall." The vehicle was totaled; the two women died.
Turner claimed that the car was defective, that a malfunction in the engine's electronic system had prompted it to speed off for no apparent reason. Ford blamed driver error.
As so often happens in auto-defect suits, neither side was able to definitively say what caused this particular crash. The two best witnesses, the women in the car, were dead. Another witness -- the shopper who jumped out of the way -- said that as the speeding car passed, he heard a sound consistent with someone pumping the brakes. But when the brakes were tested later, they seemed fine. Just before she died, Stell told a medic that she kept pressing her foot down but that the car went faster.
Ford's attorney emphasized the N.H.T.S.A. study debunking sudden acceleration. What happened to the women was tragic, he said, and yet perfectly explainable: it appeared that poor, confused Mrs. Stell had mistakenly floored the gas pedal instead of the brake. Ford's star witness was Gen. Jerry Curry. From 1989 to 1992, under President George Bush, Curry, a retired Army general, was N.H.T.S.A.'s administrator. He testified in support of the agency's study discrediting sudden acceleration. When asked how he would explain the women's accident, Curry answered, "If they do what the normal people do when that has been documented by the government, they put their foot on the wrong pedal." Curry spoke with confidence: the federal government, he said, "wouldn't allow a dangerous vehicle to be sold."
Turner likes to open by telling jurors he's just a country boy from Arkadelphia, but when it was his turn for cross-examination, he skinned and gutted General Curry. Turner got Curry to acknowledge that after he left government, he worked for the auto industry and was paid $340 an hour to testify for Ford in this and several other cases each year. Turner asked Curry how he could say that federal investigators wouldn't allow a dangerous vehicle on the road.
"What about the Pinto?" Turner asked of the Ford compact best remembered for a gas tank that became an exploding inferno in rear-end collisions.
"The Pinto got a very bad rap," answered Curry, at that moment himself going up in flames right before the jurors' eyes.
Turner had heard that Ford was concerned enough about sudden acceleration to keep a fat file of complaints sent in by owners. It took six months of discovery requests before he finally located that file in Ford's parts and services department. There were about 1,000 complaints in 10 boxes, and after sorting through them, he flew around the country taking depositions from the 12 most upstanding citizens with the most exemplary driving records.
He interviewed Ronald Campbell, a Virginia state trooper, who said he was starting his wife's Grand Marquis to move it from the front of the house to the driveway when it took off across the yard, and no matter how hard he pressed the brake, it kept accelerating until he turned off the ignition, stopping just short of a propane tank. He interviewed David McEachen, a California Superior Court judge who described his Ford Crown Victoria lurching and hitting the garage wall. He interviewed three Secret Service agents -- including one who guarded Vice President Dan Quayle -- and each described an incident when a government-leased Ford raced off from a parked position and kept going, though the drivers said they repeatedly hit the brake.
But the testimony that really sank Ford came from Joseph Gorman, a faithful Ford employee for 30 years, so trusted he served as a driver for William Clay Ford (father of the current chairman) and his wife, Martha Firestone Ford. The Fords were visiting New Orleans, staying at the Intercontinental Hotel, and Gorman was to drive Mrs. Ford to see some plantation homes.
As he prepared to leave the circular drive in front of the hotel, Gorman testified, he shifted the Lincoln from park to drive, keeping his foot on the brake: "There was a sudden surge. I immediately hit the brake, but the car did not stop. We hit the front of the building, the pillars . . . and I think we hit one or two automobiles that were parked along the front of the building and then we came to a stop." It took just seconds, he said, but the car traveled 60 feet, and he was scared.
"Why were you scared?" Turner asked.
"Let this happen to you, and you'll find out," Gorman said. "I just couldn't get the car to stop, and I was scared for my life and scared for Mrs. Ford." Mrs. Ford was treated for a bloody nose. Gorman said that Ford later sent out two engineers to interview him. They did not believe him. "One of the engineers indicated to me that he thought that it was human error," he testified.
"Was it?"
"I told the gentleman that I didn't think so." Nor did the Arkansas jurors. They found Ford at fault and awarded the sisters' estate $311,000. (Ford appealed, but wound up settling.)
Is sudden acceleration real? are some S.U.V.'s dangerously prone to rollover? What is an acceptable tire-tread failure rate? There would be no need for Tab Turners if a trusted referee existed to arbitrate the claims of auto companies, Nader groups, insurers and motorists. Unfortunately, the federal body set up to do so, N.H.T.S.A., is understaffed, slow to react, unreliable and the captive of all sorts of political agendas. The last time N.H.T.S.A. was aggressive was under Jimmy Carter. Spurred by an eerily similar tire failure -- the recall of millions of Firestone 500 radials -- Claybrook recommended tough new standards for tires and light trucks that would have affected the first generation of S.U.V.'s. And then came Ronald Reagan. Reagan slashed the agency's budget, revoking several new regulations -- including a dashboard warning light for tire-inflation problems.
N.H.T.S.A. never recovered. One of the few things Democrats and Republicans agreed about during Congressional hearings this fall was how pathetically the agency performed during the Firestone-Explorer crisis. In fairness, the Reagan cuts had never been recouped. N.H.T.S.A.'s budget last year was one-third less than it had been in 1980 real dollars. This was the result of three terms of pro-business Republican presidents and two of a Democratic administration that reinvented government by cutting it further.
There is plenty of blame to go around. The agency's sad state was partly the work of Republican congressmen like Michael Oxley of Ohio during the Gingrich years. In 1995, Representative Oxley worked hand in hand with Chrysler to limit N.H.T.S.A.'s recall powers -- right in the midst of an agency investigation of Chrysler for a rear-door latch problem on minivans that was linked to 41 deaths. (After much bad publicity, Chrysler grudgingly agreed to a voluntary replacement of the van latches.)
Credit for N.H.T.S.A.'s sorry condition goes to Democratic congressmen, too, like Representative John Dingell of Michigan, the automotive state, who undermined the Clinton administration's early efforts to put an aggressive director at N.H.T.S.A.'s helm in 1993. "Dingell blocked several strong candidates for this job to protect the auto industry," says Claybrook, a fellow Democrat. And while Dingell has denied that, the director's post wound up going to a medical doctor with no experience in government safety regulation.
For people who care about auto safety, what has happened to N.H.T.S.A. has been torture to watch. Brian O'Neill is no radical; as president of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, he does safety research sponsored by insurance companies. It makes him a rare hybrid -- a mix of big-business interests (insurance) with a financial incentive for aggressive safety laws (to reduce claim costs). After 30 years on the job, O'Neill is disheartened by the agency's problems. "Auto safety is a major public health issue," he says, the leading killer of Americans ages 1 to 34. "And yet the National Institute for Dental Research gets more money than N.H.T.S.A.
"We have denigrated government work. N.H.T.S.A. has a real hard time hiring engineers. Why would a bright young engineer want to go work for N.H.T.S.A.?" There is something even more demoralizing here than an agency that has been shrunk. This is an agency that has been caged so long its investigative and regulatory muscles have atrophied from 20 years of disuse.
On July 22, 1998, when State Farm, the nation's largest auto insurer, warned N.H.T.S.A. about a spike in Firestone-Explorer wrecks, the federal agency did nothing. In 1998, when Ford began replacing defective Firestones on its Explorers in Saudi Arabia and Venezuela because of rollover deaths there, N.H.T.S.A. missed it entirely. Their explanation at Congressional hearings: how could we know? Ford didn't tell us!
N.H.T.S.A. investigators failed to notice that Firestone ATX tires were detreading on Explorers across America's Sun Belt, until they saw it on television. On Feb. 7, a report on KHOU-TV in Houston did exactly the sort of investigation that N.H.T.S.A. people had lost the ability to perform. The KHOU team -- Anna Werner, David Raziq, Chris Henao -- collected cases by word of mouth, interviewing tire experts, liability lawyers (including Turner), disgruntled Firestone employees, consumer advocates and family members, until they had tabulated 30 deaths.
Nor were the N.H.T.S.A. investigators capable of pinpointing what factories were manufacturing the bad Firestones. It was a team of Ford engineers who figured that out in late July, using the same Firestone claims data that N.H.T.S.A. had been sitting on for weeks. And it was Ford that pressed Firestone for the recall, not N.H.T.S.A.
On Sept. 6, at a House hearing one month after Ford and Firestone had announced that a large percentage of the bad tires had come from a Decatur, Ill., Firestone plant, Sue Bailey, the acting N.H.T.S.A. administrator, was asked by Representative Greg Ganske, Republican of Iowa, whether the agency had sent investigators to Decatur. "Not to my knowledge," Bailey answered.
"Why not?" Ganske asked.
"I think that clearly is a question we should consider," Bailey said.
"I can't believe you haven't thought of that," Ganske said. In fairness to Bailey, she had been on the job just three weeks. And she did show up to take the heat. As several congressmen noted, Rodney Slater, President Clinton's transportation secretary, ducked a request to testify that day. It's no wonder Ford loves to hire former N.H.T.S.A. directors like General Curry and Diane Steed (under Reagan) to testify as expert witnesses about how safe a vehicle is. If there were an auto defect, a N.H.T.S.A. administrator might well be among the last Americans to know.
For lawyers like Turner, there is a historical moment involving Ford and President Nixon that crystallizes how the auto industry wields power in Washington. On April 27, 1971, Nixon held a private White House meeting with John Ehrlichman, Henry Ford II and Lee Iacocca, then Ford's president, that would have stayed secret forever if not for Watergate and the subsequent release of the White House tapes.
Iacocca and Henry Ford II had come to ask Nixon to go easy on safety and pollution regulations. Henry II complained that the price of the Pinto could be driven up by "safety requirements, the emission requirements, the bumper requirements." Iacocca explained that he had made Ford's case to Nixon's transportation secretary, John Volpe, telling him: "Would you guys cool it a little bit? You're gonna break us." And Volpe said: "Hold it. People want safety." To which Iacocca replied: "What do you mean they want safety. We get letters. . . . We don't get anything on safety!" Iacocca was peeved about pending air-bag regulations. "The citizens of the U.S. must be protected from their own idiocy," he told Nixon, "so we will put in a sophisticated device that will blow up on impact and package him in an air bag and save their lives." But, he said, Ford needed a major implementation delay.
Happily for Ford executives, they found a receptive president. Nixon assured them that he was "extremely pro-business" and said that the best way to protect Ford was "a delaying action." Nixon made it plain that he had no stomach for consumer advocates, "a group of people that aren't one really damn bit interested in safety or clean air." The president assured Ford and Iacocca that they could speak freely in front of Ehrlichman. "John is a lawyer who says nothing," Nixon explained, and there was laughter.
But Nixon was wrong. Ehrlichman went to prison for Watergate, then found religion, and by 1990 was being hired as a consultant for attorneys suing Ford who wanted him to elaborate about the meeting. Later on that same day, Ehrlichman has testified, he had a second meeting with Nixon. And Nixon told him to direct Transportation Secretary Volpe to delay all pending safety measures. "The secretary was to stop all of these . . . safety regulations," Ehrlichman recalled. "The president wants it all stopped." The president also "instructed me to tell Charles Colson, one of his assistants, to exploit the Ford meeting," he said. "I wrote a memo to Charles Colson conveying the president's wish that he hit up the Ford people for a political contribution."
Helen Petrauskas, Ford's vice president for safety, says the industry has changed in the last 15 years, and Ford has come to see that customers want safety features and will pay extra for them. "If you ask people why they bought a vehicle, safety is one of the top three or four reasons," she said. The "old idea" of pitting safety against profitability no longer applies, she said.
Ford officials say the Explorer is a safe vehicle that got stuck with a bad tire. They acknowledge being slow to spot the problem, mainly because the tire is the only part of the vehicle Ford doesn't warranty (the tire company does). And so Ford didn't have the raw claims data that would have shown a spike in accidents; instead, Ford relied on Firestone, which kept saying there was no problem.
Once N.H.T.S.A. opened an investigation last May, Petrauskas says, Ford pressed Firestone for the same claims data that the tire company was turning over to federal investigators, so Ford could make its own judgment. Firestone kept resisting, she says, "telling us this material is confidential." Even when Ford and Firestone lawyers negotiated a deal for the data in late June, she says, "we still had to make two or three 'Where is it?' contacts." The data wasn't made available until late July, she says, and immediately six Ford engineers drove to Firestone's Akron offices to collect it. Within days, Ford pinpointed a high level of claims involving ATX tires produced at all four Firestone plants, as well as Wilderness AT tires from Firestone's Decatur plant, and pressed Firestone for the recall.
Sorting out the who knew what when has become a morass, as infighting between the corporations has turned nasty at times. This was evident at a Nov. 27 deposition of Robert Martin, Firestone's recently retired vice president for quality assurance. The daylong deposition was held in a ballroom at the Hermitage Hotel in Nashville and looked like a national bar association convention; there were three dozen plaintiff attorneys (including Turner), representing 114 lawsuits, joined by a dozen Ford and Firestone attorneys.
When a Ford lawyer asked Martin why Firestone hadn't handed over the claims data sooner, Martin shot back, "Your legal department chose not to sign a confidentiality agreement."
Turner was picked by his colleagues to be leadoff man for the plaintiff attorneys, in part because he understands the engineering issues so well. He has a gift for eliciting the telling anecdote that sticks in a juror's mind. After a series of highly technical questions, Turner suddenly shifted and asked Martin how he felt about the Explorer's safety record. "I would not like my 16-year-old granddaughter to learn to drive on an Explorer," said the Firestone man.
As the story unfolded last summer, it took a while for the news media to realize how intertwined the development of the Firestone tire and the Explorer were. Ford officials repeatedly tried to distance themselves from the manufacture of the recalled Firestones. In his Congressional testimony, Ford's Nasser claimed, "This is a tire issue, not a vehicle issue." However, a finished tire doesn't simply arrive at a Ford plant and get plunked on an Explorer. The Firestone ATX was made to order for Ford. Ford set the specifications, and during two years of testing that tire on Explorers in 1989 and 1990, Ford engineers repeatedly requested changes by Firestone, dictating tire size and air pressure.
These are things Turner has known for more than a decade, since he first began litigating Bronco II rollover cases. As he says, "There are some advantages to doing the same thing for 10 years." From hundreds of Ford depositions and thousands of pages of discovery documents collected in the course of hundreds of lawsuits, he knew that one of Ford's biggest worries in designing both the Bronco II and its successor, the Explorer, was the rollover problem. Turner knew from Ford's own road-test results that one factor affecting rollover was the tires' size and air pressure: the bigger the tire, the tippier it made the S.U.V. for sharp turns. Turner had the Ford engineers' tables and charts showing they constantly juggled the size and air-pressure of the tires in hopes of making the prototype Explorer more stable.
But as much as they juggled, the rollover issue would not go away. In September 1989, Roger Stornant, a Ford engineer working on the Explorer prototype, wrote that Ford's general counsel was concerned that it would be the only manufacturer "with a vehicle that has a significant chance of failing the Consumer Union test" for rollover stability. This would have been very bad for Ford; a few months before, the consumer magazine had given the Bronco II a "poor" stability rating.
For style reasons, Ford would have loved a larger, 245-centimeter-wide tire on its new Explorer; a big tire is a marketing plus for an S.U.V., part of the macho appeal. For best tire wear, Ford and Firestone would have also liked a high air pressure of 35 p.s.i. (The higher the tire pressure, the less the tire's rubber surface comes in contact with the road, meaning less friction and less wear.) As Ford's Harmon says, "Any tiremaker will prefer a higher tire pressure. It's better for tire wear."
But at Ford's Arizona Proving Grounds in May 1989, when they tested the 245 Firestone tire at 35 p.s.i. on an Explorer prototype in a J-turn maneuver (an extreme turn of the wheel to the left, which you might use to avoid an animal or car), it lifted two tires off the ground (known as a rollover response). The other S.U.V. used for comparison, the Chevy S-10 Blazer, did not roll with a 245, 35-p.s.i. tire. In fact, Ford engineers did six tests of the Chevy S-10, and it did not roll once; the Explorer prototype rolled 5 of 12 times.
In the end, the Ford engineers settled on a smaller tire, a 235, with a low air pressure, 26 p.s.i., to improve the Explorer's stability. But not all Ford engineers agreed it was wise to rely so much on tire size to improve stability. Robert Bacigalupi, a tire engineer who worked on both the Bronco II and Explorer, wrote a memo in 1986 when the same issue came up with the Bronco II, noting "better alternatives to tire size are for example lowering the vehicle for lower center of gravity, adding weight low in the vehicle and widening the track." But, he noted, such solutions usually get put off because "cost or timing implications tend to stall them."
And time was short. Through the summer of 1989, Ford test drivers in Arizona submitted nightly rollover results by fax to Dearborn. The Explorer was six months from Job 1, the date when the first vehicle is due off the assembly line. "There's a lot of pressure and stress to ensure we make Job 1," Henry Sleath, a Ford test driver, told Turner in a deposition.
The most ambitious changes proposed by Dave Houston, Charles White and Ron Campbell, Ford engineers, to make the Explorer more stable -- widening it by two inches and lowering the engine two to three inches by switching from a twin I-beam to short long arm (S.L.A.) suspension -- would have taken the most time and expense and could have delayed the debut of a vehicle expected to make a great deal of money. Indeed, in 1991 the Explorer would make $599 million in profits before taxes.
Ford engineers were directed by supervisors to "utilize as many of the chassis revisions as possible without delaying Job 1." A few changes were made; the springs were altered, the prototype was lowered half an inch and the 26 p.s.i. tire pressure was used.
As the first Explorers rolled off the assembly line, Ford engineers knew how delicate a safety margin there was for those tires. That February, in 1990, Jim Avouris, a Ford engineer, asked Firestone to alert its dealers to use only the recommended tire and nothing larger than 235's. A letter was sent to Firestone dealers warning of the dangers of using the wrong size tire: "Failure to follow these precautions may adversely affect the handling of the vehicle and possibly cause loss of control and rollover, which could result in serious injury or death."
It would be years before Ford undertook the more ambitious changes suggested by its engineers; the S.L.A. suspension was added in the 1995 Explorer, although the engine was not significantly lowered then either, in part, a Ford memo says, because of "program cost." The two-inch widening is slated for the 2002 Explorer. Ford acknowledges that these changes improve the Explorer, but says it was already very safe.
A few weeks before the recall last summer, Turner first mentioned to a reporter that he believed the 26 p.s.i. played a major part in precipitating the tread separations. Sharyl Attkisson of CBS had been one of the most aggressive correspondents on the story, but she had not heard of this issue before. "I wondered how long it would take people to see it," Turner said.
They see it now. Firestones have been most prone to fail in hot climates -- the Mideast, Venezuela and across America's Sun Belt. The lower 26 pressure -- chosen for stability reasons -- also meant more tire friction, more heat. In fact, within weeks of the recall, Ford upped its recommendation to 30 p.s.i. for the tire. Ford's Harmon says Ford did this because Firestone claimed it would help the tire's durability. But, he said, 26 p.s.i. should not have been a problem. He points out that from 1995 to 1997, Goodyear had a contract to produce about half the tires for the Explorer; those 2.6 million Goodyears were inflated to a 26 p.s.i. and did not fail the way Firestones did.
The explanation for that may be the obvious -- Goodyear produced a better tire, which had more of a safety margin to absorb the stress of 26 p.s.i. Tread separations have not been a problem on Explorers with Goodyear Wranglers.
But it also appears that Ford had some indication back in the mid-1990's that the Goodyear tire, which is more than a pound heavier than the Firestones, was more durable. In five tread-wear road tests for Ford between February and July 1994, Vehicular Testing Services compared the durability of Firestones versus Goodyears being made for the Explorer. The Firestone ATX did markedly poorer than the Goodyear on every test, in some cases wearing out twice as quickly.
The Firestone Wilderness tire that was used on the Explorer beginning in 1996 had the lowest acceptable heat resistance rating the government gives, a C; the Goodyear had a B. And in a tire being run at 26 p.s.i., being exposed to more friction, heat resistance mattered.
So why didn't Ford stay with the superior Goodyear for its Explorers? Money. In 1996, Goodyear decided it couldn't produce an Explorer tire at the price Ford was willing to pay. Ford is renowned for its aggressive cost cutting, reflected by the corporate rise of Jacques Nasser, nicknamed Jac the Knife. Repeatedly during 1995 and 1996, Ford pressed Goodyear to reduce costs. In a Jan. 17, 1996, letter from Lee Connolly, Goodyear's director of tire sales, to C.J. Hole, a Ford purchasing director, Goodyear said it needed a price increase from Ford because of higher raw material costs.
On Jan. 26, Ford declined, complaining that Goodyear prices were already "uncompetitive." "The pricing level disparity between Goodyear and your competitors is a significant concern to us," Hole wrote. Unable to budge Ford, Goodyear stopped making tires for the Explorer. From 1997 until the recall, Ford contracted exclusively with the company that had the cheaper tires, Firestone.
Ford's Harmon says that at the time Ford thought it was getting a comparable quality tire from Firestone at "better value. In retrospect we were wrong."
Ford executives disparage Turner for using company documents to raise safety questions. They say only one measure of safety matters: "If you look at the Explorer's real-world safety record," Petrauskas says, "it's significantly better than the average car and the average S.U.V. And since it can't be attacked on its real-world record, all that leaves is picking through the documents."
By "real world" she means federal fatality crash data. But like so many auto-safety issues, interpreting the data is not straightforward. There are data for four Explorers: the biggest Explorer (four-door, four-wheel-drive) has a better fatality rate than the average for all passenger vehicles; the two-door, four-wheel-drive model and the four-door, two-wheel-drive model have fatality rates similar to the average for passenger vehicles; the smallest (two-door, two-wheel-drive) has a considerably higher fatality rate.
If a family is making a choice based on the safety data between an Explorer and a van -- say a Dodge Caravan or Ford Windstar -- it would pick the van, which has lower fatality and rollover rates. But this is what makes auto safety part science and part art. Just because one vehicle has a higher fatality rate doesn't necessarily mean it is more dangerous. Part of that rate depends on the demographics of who's driving what vehicle. Sports cars have high fatality rates even though they are often well engineered, but they tend to be driven by younger males who go fast, pushing up the death rate. Vans may be boxy and stiff-riding, but they tend to be driven by safety-conscious families.
Ford engineers understood this when they designed the Explorer. They had decided to make it bigger than its Bronco II predecessor, more of a family vehicle, and knew that fact all by itself would improve the safety record. "With the high (80/20) mix of 4 door vehicles we can expect a less aggressive driver profile with a corresponding reduction in all accident statistics," says a Ford memo.
The Explorer-Firestone story is a parable for this antigovernment era, with Tab Turner playing a lead role as free-market capitalism's de facto commissioner of auto safety. Ford may resent the Tab Turners of America, yet Ford is in good part responsible for the proliferation of Tab Turners.
Automakers have used their lobbying muscle and their political allies in Congress and the White House to get their fondest wish, an auto-safety agency with no teeth. But a regulator that doesn't bite once in a while loses credibility. With no trusted arbiter in Washington, safety issues get litigated over and over in state courts. We are living in a time of rollover lawyers, tire lawyers, sudden-acceleration lawyers. Jurors have become the referees of auto safety, and Tab Turner is their mentor.
Ford says that since the recall more than 200 Explorer lawsuits have been filed. All but a handful will most likely be settled; how much Ford is willing to pay will depend on the outcome of the few that reach a jury. What might Donna Bailey's case in Corpus Christi look like if it does go to trial? Turner hopes a lot like the Bronco II rollover case that he tried in Houston in 1995. In that lawsuit, a Bronco II full of Texas A&M college students suffered a tread separation on a right-rear General Tire and rolled over on a flat road, killing Jennifer Cammack. The jury found Ford entirely at fault, awarding $25 million. (Ford appealed, but settled the case for what Turner calls "a very substantial sum.")
Edward Rogers, a Houston architect, was a member of that jury and says that when it came to deciding how much each party was responsible, they discussed assigning some blame to the tire. "It was the immediate cause," Rogers said. "But it would be a reasonable expectation that a vehicle will have a tread separation and should be able to handle it, even fully loaded. If there's so little margin of error in the center of gravity, then the vehicle was at fault." He says that what jurors discussed most was all the engineering compromises Ford had made instead of reducing the rollover problem. "Ford did a calculation to deal with the consequence of an inferior design rather than change it," Rogers said. "That blew us away."
This may not bode well for Ford in the Corpus Christi case. Ford engineers who developed the Explorer were trying to make the very same safety changes as the Ford engineers who developed the Bronco II a decade earlier -- widening the vehicle and replacing the front-end suspension -- but they, too, were overruled for cost reasons. Jurors expected that monthlong Bronco II trial was going to be a technical snoozer, but they were mesmerized. "Watching Turner take apart Ford, it was like watching a made-for-TV movie," Rogers said.
On that mid-November day, as Tab Turner jetted her way, Donna Bailey and her two brothers waited nervously in Room 519 at the Texas Institute for Rehabilitation and Recovery. She had seen Turner on the TV news and considered him a little bit of a celebrity. His visit would certainly liven up the day. Being paralyzed was driving her mad with boredom. The 43-year-old used to work as a physical trainer for corporations. She loved the outdoors and had been going on a rock-climbing expedition with two friends on the day of the rollover last March.
That two-door Explorer was heading north on U.S. 181, Bailey recalls, when she heard the thudding sound of a tire coming apart. "It happened so fast," she said. Her friend "was trying real hard to keep control." Bailey remembers her yelling. "Then we fell over. They got out. They were fine. But I was hanging upside down from my seat belt. And I just remember thinking I was dead. And a man was trying to kick in the windshield to get to me.
"I don't know if you want to write this, but I died and came back. I saw four angels. They said I had a message and sent me back."
"We believe God allowed it," said her brother Tim, an actor. "We believe He made the best provisions possible, so this case could be national news and they could be brought to justice."
Bailey said the best times now are weekends, when her two teenage children visit. Her ex-husband drives them the 200 miles from Corpus Christi to the Houston facility. "They pamper me," she said. "They groom me and feed me." Her big project now is learning to operate an electric wheelchair for quads. You control it with your breath, by what's called the sip-and-puff method. Sip in hard, the chair goes backwards; sip in soft, the chair goes left. Puff out strong, you go forward; puff out softly, you go right. Bailey still hadn't mastered it. The breathing tube in her throat kept throwing her off. She couldn't seem to puff hard enough to get the damn chair to go straight. Instead, her weak puffs made the chair veer right, and she kept hitting into walls.
