HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 12-17-00;
To Loaf or Not to Loaf

BYLINE: By John Leland; John Leland is a reporter in the Style department of The New York Times.

 BODY:
Are you lazier now than you were eight years ago?
Neither Al Gore nor George Bush ever actually raised the question during the campaign. But once you get past all the stuff about lockboxes and bariffs and terriers, this has been the subtext of the contest. The election, as we were reminded, was less about issues than about personal style, and like dogs and their owners, nations often resemble their leaders. So what leadership style were we prepared to claim as our own: that of the energizer veep or of the man who raised coasting to a form of personal expression? As the legal wrangling stretches into untold excesses of overtime, the election comes down to a referendum on the coasting question. Whatever happens between now and Inauguration Day, that giant snoring sound you hear is the first susurrance of an electorate eager to take five. 
 For eight years, Bill Clinton was a natural to lead a nation swept in workaholic frenzy -- a huffing, puffing mass of cholesterol and ambition, leading the country as if it were the world's biggest aerobics class. He detained staff members and reporters in marathon strategy sessions. His public speeches set endurance records. The bags under his eyes could carry groceries. The populace responded in kind, working longer hours and making kids do more homework. By 1998, the average American family worked 15 more weeks a year than it did in 1969.
The brainy young wonks on Clinton's staff were models for the age, creating the midnight-oil-burning, pizza-ordering paradigm for the dot-com crowd that followed. (Clinton's anthem, "Don't Stop," called for more sustained effort than the party's previous, sloth-friendly "Happy Days Are Here Again.") Television shows about families virtually disappeared; shows about workers -- E.R.," "The Practice," "Ally McBeal," "The West Wing" -- multiplied like billable hours.
In a period that gave us Viagra, an Ecstasy boom, progress against H.I.V. and a Barry White boxed set -- could there be any more favorable conditions for widespread whoopee? -- the nation seemed more interested in being handcuffed to the office than to the cute officemates. Even the era's defining sex scandal was all aggressive acquisition and legal grind, no leisurely afterglow -- something to keep Clinton busy when the spoil sports shut the government down.
But eight years was enough, already. A big part of the work force that entered the Clinton years afraid of never getting on the economic treadmill now dreams of getting off. People entering the job market now say they would rather have more time than more money. Even kids are burned out. A recent Harvard admissions paper described applicants as "dazed survivors of some bewildering lifelong boot camp." The Piscataway, N.J., school board declared a moratorium on excessive homework.
Yet here was Al Gore, earnestly promising to continue the legacy of those workaholic Clinton years. During the campaign, he repeated the mantra that the administration had created 19 million new jobs, as if this were not the equivalent of a father boasting that he had created that many new household chores. Nineteen million new jobs? Who had time or energy? If Gore prevails, he may find himself a wired alpha among tired betas.
George W. Bush, by contrast, found himself on the other side of the coasting question. Not for him the vanity of toiling late at night under fluorescents, hoping to get a star for attendance. As governor of Texas, he typically knocked off at 5 p.m., and still managed to schedule a couple hours during the day to exercise, play video games, get a massage or nap. He clipped the time he spent reviewing each scheduled execution from half an hour to 15 minutes. If briefings droned too long, his adviser, Karl Rove, told The Los Angeles Times, Bush would point to his computer's solitaire program. So when he began the arduous task of his transition before the wrangling in Florida had gotten under way, it was a distressing turn of events. If this man stands for anything, surely it is for working only as hard as he has to.
The national economy is already starting to kick back. Investors have soured on dot-coms, with their tireless, nonhierarchic team members who think success means working 130-hour weeks, crashing on the office couch, putting off adulthood till their options are vested. Instead, the market has returned to its previous bias for the old blue chips, where success means never having to say you're too busy for golf or a long martini lunch. That's what hierarchies are for.
All movements have their unsung heroes, and the conquest of coast is no exception. Of note are Miami-Dade County's vote counters, who decided that they didn't care to spend Thanksgiving poring over disputed chad. But the real avatars of the new loafing were those Florida voters who could not muster the effort to poke all the way through the ballot, leaving a lazy dimple as a measure of their intentions. Theirs was not a strong will expressed ambiguously, I like to think, but a sluggish will articulated with elan. The people have spoken, and they are pooped.
And the big winner? However the electoral haggling comes out, I'm betting on Gore's old boss. After eight years of leading the age of overwork, Bill Clinton again finds himself on the golden edge of the curve: out of work, empty of nest, with a sweet pension and enough gimme caps to last a lifetime. He is not the type to stay home baking cookies. But if the nation is indeed entering a recumbent revolution, what better role model than a man who walked away from the choicest job in the free world? He is once again set to lead the nation. This time in a nap.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.;
Monthly Surcharge On Rent

 BODY:

Q. Does a landlord have the legal right to impose a $20.74 monthly surcharge for an air-conditioner in my apartment? The surcharge is charged for the entire year even though I use the air-conditioner only during the summer months. These charges amount to more than $240 a year. . . . L. Lampkin, Manhattan.
 
A. Joel Abramson, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said that any right that the landlord may have to impose such charges must be contained in the lease. Accordingly, he said, the letter writer should check the lease to determine whether there is a provision that allows the landlord to impose the surcharge. 
 "It's not uncommon in situations where the electric service is included in the monthly rent for the lease to contain a provision allowing for a surcharge for air-conditioner usage," Mr. Abramson said. "And in most cases, such surcharges can be charged on a year-round basis even though the air-conditioner is only being used for a few months during the summer."
If the lease does not contain a provision for the imposition of a surcharge, he said, the tenant would not be legally required to pay it.
Mr. Abramson also said that if the letter writer is a rent-regulated tenant, and has previously been allowed to use the air-conditioner without having to pay a surcharge, it is possible that the imposition of a surcharge at this point would be considered an illegal rent increase.
That, he said, is because a service provided to a tenant at the commencement of a tenancy -- including the right to use an air-conditioner without having to pay a surcharge -- cannot be withdrawn by the landlord.
If that is the case here, he said, the letter writer can file a request for a reduction in rent with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, based on a reduction in services. Such a request can be filed at the agency's office at 92-31 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, Queens. Information: (718) 739-6400.
 
Managing Agents On Co-op Boards
 
Q. Is it illegal for two co-managing agents to be on the board of a co-op or condominium? Would the answer be different if one of the agents was also one of the original sponsors of the conversion? . . . Herbert Isaacs, Manhattan.
 
A. Michael Finder, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that the governing documents of many co-ops and condominiums would permit service on the board by managing agents and sponsors.
"Some governing documents require only that a board member be at least 18 years of age," Mr. Finder said, adding that in most cases, managing agents who sit on boards serve as recording secretaries.
He said that a potential conflict of interest on the part of a managing agent or a sponsor who is a director would not prohibit either from serving on the board. Rather, Mr. Finder said, a board member with a conflict of interest on specific matters would be prohibited from voting on those matters.
Moreover, he said, while a sponsor is prohibited by law from exercising control over a co-op after five years have passed since the conversion, it would be difficult to establish that mere service on the board after the five years have passed constitutes continued control by the sponsor.

LENGTH: 1033 words

HEADLINE: FILM: The Year in Film: Critics Pick Their Favorites;
Paradise and Politics

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
'THE DECALOGUE' Krzysztof Kieslowski's 10-part masterwork was first shown on Polish television in 1988-89 and finally released in theaters this year. It is a sweeping meditation on the human condition that ranks beside the greatest works of Ingmar Bergman in its depth and the potency of its layered symbolism. Loosely based on the Ten Commandments, the cycle's 10 fables, set in and around a Warsaw housing development, ponder the meaning of life and death, morality and the existence of God. Kieslowski's skeptical, open-ended vision suggests that the answers can be intuited only from riddles, signs, portents and sudden, odd strokes of fate. For all its somberness, the individual stories are extremely entertaining. And the visionary realism of this Polish filmmaker, who died four years ago, invests the most mundane objects with a luminous metaphysical weight and an awareness of the interconnectedness of things.
 
'YI YI' ("A ONE AND A TWO") Edward Yang's moving, beautifully photographed three-hour drama explores the lives of an extended family in contemporary Taipei. Beginning with a wedding and ending with a funeral, the film is a multi-generational portrait of Taiwan in today's booming, glass-towered economy. The most compelling character is a rebellious, camera-wielding 8-year-old boy (Jonathan Chang), given to astonishing philosophical apercus. Amid all the domestic tumult and high-tech wheeling and dealing, the movie asks profound questions about human choice and the possibility of second chances. Its introspective mood is echoed by cinematography that observes the characters through reflecting windows.
 
 'TRAFFIC' Adapted from a British miniseries about the international drug trade, Steven Soderbergh's despairing film (the most powerful American ensemble film since "Nashville") interweaves the parallel stories of drug traffickers and law enforcers to create a riveting panorama of greed, corruption and social decay. Michael Douglas is a newly appointed American drug czar (with a teenage daughter who free-bases cocaine) investigating this treacherous territory. The brilliant cast includes Don Cheadle, Benecio Del Toro, Luis Guzman, Dennis Quaid, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Amy Irving. The movie makes absolutely clear why the war on drugs as it has been waged so far in the United States cannot be won.
 
 'HUMANITE' The French director Bruno Dumont's devastating film views the world through the eyes and ears of a repressed, clumsy police detective and possible murderer (Emmanuel Schotte) investigating the rape and murder of an 11-year-old girl. With an intensely naturalistic soundtrack and a stinging visual acuity (a closeup of a woman peeling a potato, for instance, suggests the peeling away of raw human skin) the movie creates an almost unbearable vision of the physicality of life and implies that what we think of as civilization is a fragile membrane barely preventing us from all-out bestiality.
 
 'BEAU TRAVAIL' Claire Denis's adaptation of Melville's "Billy Budd" moves the allegory to a French Foreign Legion outpost in the east African enclave of Djibouti. At once voluptuous and austere, the movie is a woman's contemplation of an all-male society. Its rigorous codes of authority, repression, discipline and honor become the cinematic equivalent of a military ballet in which the Legionnaires' drills and training rituals are ecstatic rites of purification. Cool, hallucinatory, unforgettable.
 
 'NURSE BETTY' In the darkly comic fairy tale that echoes "The Wizard of Oz," an aspiring nurse (Renee Zellweger) afflicted with traumatic amnesia after witnessing her husband's murder, travels to Los Angeles to marry her favorite soap opera character, a handsome doctor (Greg Kinnear). As the killers (Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock) pursue her, the movie becomes an alternately hilarious and poignant reflection on the American addiction to Hollywood fantasy. The movie finds the misanthropic chill of the director Neil LaBute ("In the Company of Men") partially thawed.
 
 'THE COLOR OF PARADISE' The touching Iranian film, directed by Majid Majidi, contemplates the world as experienced by a blind 8-year-old boy whose impoverished father balks at caring for him. For all the sadness and emotional uncertainty, the movie's evocation of the natural world (both its beauty and its destructive power) is ecstatically sensuous. It is like going back to the Garden of Eden.
 
 'HUMAN RESOURCES' When an idealistic young man fresh out of business school takes a white-collar management job in the factory where his father has worked as a laborer for 30 years, everything at first seems rosy. Very quickly, however, he finds himself falling into a treacherous rabbit hole of duplicity and corporate politics that pit father and son against each other in a war between management and labor. Using a cast of mostly nonprofessional actors, the French director Laurent Cantet has made a deeply insightful film about the dirty politics of the business world.
 
 'YOU CAN COUNT ON ME' The directorial debut of the playwright and screenwriter Kenneth Lonergan is a small, perfectly observed portrait of a young single mother (Laura Linney) and her wastrel brother (Mark Ruffalo) who returns to visit her in their upstate New York hometown. The sister, who works in a bank, recklessly initiates an affair with her starchy, married new boss (Matthew Broderick), while her brother's well-meaning efforts to be a surrogate father to her 8-year-old son backfire. Sibling devotion streaked with pain and resentment is distilled in exquisitely fine-tuned performances.
 
 'CAST AWAY' The heart of this modern-day Robinson Crusoe drama about a Fed Ex employee shipwrecked after a plane crash in the Pacific comes as close as a Hollywood movie has ever done to conveying the loneliness, fear and sheer craziness of being stranded on a desert island. The awesome man-against-nature sequences are everything "The Perfect Storm" promised but failed to deliver, and its plane crash is the scariest ever depicted in a movie. But in true Hollywood fashion, these indelible sequences are book-ended by a schmaltzy love story.

LENGTH: 2762 words

HEADLINE: Jim Surdoval: Politician, Dealmaker, Convicted Felon

BYLINE: By DEBRA WEST 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
JAMES SURDOVAL has long been the man to see in Yonkers. Part political adviser, part administrator and 100 percent dealmaker, Mr. Surdoval has always known how to get a job done.
In the thick of the city's desegregation crisis, he organized the forces for compliance with a federal court order. When the City Council's resistance to that order threatened to bankrupt Yonkers with fines, he helped introduce a strong mayor system that changed the power structure. And while the city was still struggling with insolvency and its history of racial division, he offered hope with a glittering downtown revitalization project. 
 But those achievements aside, the most remarkable thing about Mr. Surdoval is that after admitting to a crime that makes parents hysterical and lawmakers cry for tougher sentencing, he has survived, bruised but not broken.
In April, Mr. Surdoval, who is 43, pleaded guilty to having sex with a 15-year-old boy he met in an Internet chat room and to downloading child pornography on his home computer. In September he was sentenced to five years' probation.
Through it all, he has barely missed a paycheck. He retains the support of friends and has suffered little of the finger-pointing that people convicted of sex crimes often report.
That speaks to the survival skills of Mr. Surdoval, a Yonkers native who has quietly shaped city politics from behind the scenes for a dozen years. He has successfully skated between candidates and political parties, either as a media consultant to campaigns or as an on-staff adviser.
"At the end of the day, Jim knows a tremendous amount of stuff," said Andrew Beveridge, a longtime Democratic district leader in Yonkers, who has known Mr. Surdoval since 1985. "He's a political operative and a political consultant and he knows Yonkers better than anybody. He understands the state. He understands how you get federal money. He understands everything about government. And people like him."
Mr. Surdoval, whose grandparents settled in Yonkers nearly a century ago, had dropped out of college and was working in advertising in Manhattan when he began campaigning, first for candidates for the City Council and then for a young Democratic candidate for mayor, Nicholas C. Wasiscko. In 1987, Mayor Wasiscko made Mr. Surdoval his No. 2 man, helping to handle the desegregation case.
"It was an exciting, troubling time," Mr. Surdoval said. "I helped organize for compliance with the court order. I was out in the trenches. I met a lot of people."
Mr. Wasiscko lost the following election and when he tried to come back the next time around, Mr. Surdoval backed his Democratic rival, Terence M. Zaleski. He became chief of staff in the Zaleski administration but was later fired and went to campaign for Mr. Zaleski's Republican rival, the current mayor, John D. Spencer.
Mayor Spencer made Mr. Surdoval his director of downtown and waterfront development, Yonkers's attempt to gentrify its riverfront with a park, office space and apartments. Mr. Surdoval secured $75 million in state and federal grants for the project.
"Some people say because I go from a Republican to a Democrat I'm like a gun for hire," Mr. Surdoval said. "But the issues are the same. I've never changed principles. I just change candidates."
Sitting in his Warburton Avenue apartment here, with its neat, mission-style furniture, fresh flowers and stunning view of the Hudson River, Mr. Surdoval talked about his life before and after his criminal case.
A tidy man, as unremarkable as his beige pressed corduroy pants, Mr. Surdoval said he wanted to set the record straight, but "every time I've tried to explain it, I've either been misinterpreted or accused of blaming the victim."
When Mr. Surdoval was sentenced in September, Judge Kenneth H. Lange of the County Court ridiculed a letter Mr. Surdoval sent him in which Mr. Surdoval explained he was only trying to counsel the boy, who would boast online of his relationships with older men. Mr. Surdoval said he first chatted online with the boy in hopes of encouraging him to attend meetings for gay teenagers at the Loft, an organization for homosexuals in White Plains. Later, he said, he visited the boy intending only to give him a magazine article about gay teenagers.
"Certainly, the screen name that you used, CompuBoy69, suggests something other than a mentoring approach," Judge Lange said.
The court-appointed psychiatrist who evaluated him said Mr. Surdoval's attempts to explain his circumstances amounted to a refusal to accept responsibility. And because of that, Mr. Surdoval was deemed a moderate risk sex offender, or level two on a scale of one to three. With a moderate risk classification, the police can release the name, photo and zip code of a convicted sex offender to neighborhood groups considered vulnerable. With a high risk offender, the police can also disclose the offender's street address. Warning the public about a low risk offender is prohibited.
The Yonkers police would not say if they have disclosed information on Mr. Surdoval.
"After the sentencing and hearing the judge's reaction, I realized it's a no-win situation," Mr. Surdoval said. "I'm not going to explain myself anymore. I obviously hope that people are not going to judge me for this one thing and assume that the worst thing that has happened to me is the most important thing about me."
Still, when he talked about the case, Mr. Surdoval seemed uneasy. He set his hands as if he were weighing both sides of an argument, as if he were wondering if he should just tell the story the way he sees it (that he had one encounter with a sexually active and willing gay teenager who sought out older men online) or tell the apologetic version he has come to realize is more expedient.
In the end, Mr. Surdoval chose to discuss his circumstances as if they were a political argument. No one called Joey Buttafuoco a pedophile because he had sex with an under-age Amy Fisher, he said, but time and again news stories have called Mr. Surdoval a pedophile. It is a label he said is inaccurate and smacks of homophobia. (Of course, Mr. Buttafuoco's name has become a guaranteed laugh for comedians and he went to jail for his crime.)
"The scarlet letter of the Internet age is to be painted with that brush and labeled a pedophile," Mr. Surdoval said. "I'm not a pedophile. What happened was wrong and it was a felony. But this is an age-of-consent case. I don't mean to minimize it, but I was immediately stereotyped as the guy in the raincoat who hangs around playgrounds and that's not me."
Mr. Surdoval's crime was revealed almost by accident.
In January 1999, the body of 12-year-old Orlandito Maldonado was found buried next to an abandoned ice cream stand along the Saw Mill River Parkway in Dobbs Ferry. The boy had disappeared months earlier from his Yonkers neighborhood, and the police believed that a 38-year-old carpenter, Robert DeRosario, might know something about it.
Neighborhood boys had told investigators that Mr. DeRosario, who lived a few blocks from Orlandito, had offered to pay young boys for sex and that they last saw Orlandito in the lobby of Mr. DeRosario's building. The day Orlandito's body was identified, the police seized Mr. DeRosario's computer and their investigation took an unexpected turn.
The computer's hard drive revealed that Mr. DeRosario was a frequent visitor to an America Online chat room for gay men in Westchester. Interviewing the boys Mr. DeRosario chatted with online led the police to other men who used the chat room to arrange meetings with under-age boys.
That started a crackdown on Internet pedophilia that cast Westchester in a sinister light. Arrests were announced almost weekly, making it the talk from Scarsdale to Somers.
Over the course of a year, nine men were arrested and charged with having sex with boys they met through an AOL chat room. All have pleaded guilty or were convicted. A few of the men faced charges involving more than one boy, but most of them, including Mr. Surdoval, faced sodomy charges involving only one boy.
That boy, who started meeting men online when he was 14 and continued until his parents discovered his activities and sent him away for treatment, had had sex with all nine men charged in the course of the investigation.
Few of the men received jail time. Nicholas Puner, a former Planning Board chairman in the Town of New Castle who admitted to sodomizing two boys, was sentenced to 60 days in jail; Patrick Murphy, a former spokesman for Pepsico Inc. who is HIV-positive and pleaded guilty to child endangerment as well as sodomy, was sentenced to six months; and Walter Salvatore, the only man charged in the roundup who chose to go to trial, was sentenced to one to three years in prison.
As for the murder case that started it all, no one has yet been charged with Orlandito's murder. In May, Mr. DeRosario pleaded guilty to abusing 12 boys, some of whom he met on the Internet. He was sentenced to 10 years in prison.
Mr. Surdoval has fared surprisingly well for a man who is an admitted felon.
He spent the night in jail when he was arrested, but was not sentenced to any prison time. Instead he was given five years' probation, during which he cannot drink alcohol, visit stores that sell pornography, be alone with anyone under the age of 18 or keep a computer in his house.
He was suspended with pay from his job as the director of downtown waterfront redevelopment when he was charged in September 1999, and fired when he pleaded guilty seven months later. Even before he was fired, however, he had secured work as a consultant with three developers whom he knew from his work in city government, and he said his income is now about the same as the $107,000 city salary he used to earn.
Mr. Surdoval never hid the fact that he was gay. But to realize that his sex life has now been dissected and discussed by co-workers, strangers and friends has been difficult, he said.
"My life has changed," Mr. Surdoval said. "I used to work in an office. Now I work at home alone. I'm lonely. I feel embarrassed and ashamed. I don't feel comfortable being me with this new recognition."
The support of his live-in companion, a 25-year-old man whom he met two years ago through an Internet chat room, has helped him through tough times, he said.
His harshest critics, he said, are gay acquaintances who fear that an openly gay man caught with a teenage boy tarnishes the image of gay men everywhere.
"There's such a stigma against it within the gay rights movement," Mr. Surdoval said. "That's what they don't want to be seen as, recruiters. Believe me, I'm no recruiter."
Gay activists aren't the only ones who have distanced themselves from Mr. Surdoval. Mayor Spencer; his chief of staff, Kathy Spring, and Vincenza A. Restiano, the City Council president, would not return telephone calls regarding Mr. Surdoval. But many people who are not in public office expressed sympathy for and confidence in Mr. Surdoval.
"I think he was guilty of bad judgment," said Bob E. Donnelly, a lawyer from Dobbs Ferry who has been friends with Mr. Surdoval since 1975. "Anyone is capable of doing one dumb thing. Jim is an intensely bright and hardworking guy who stayed in public life because he had high ideals."
James Jacobs, a sociologist and law professor at New York University, said he was not surprised that, professionally, Mr. Surdoval has been able to overcome the stigma associated with his crime.
"Look at Marv Albert; he's back on television," Dr. Jacobs said. "Look at President Clinton. It's interesting to see who is able to flick this kind of thing off. The more social and professional resources you have, the more protection you have. If you have a lot of chips in the bank, and you have a lot of friends and a lot of favors owed to you, you can get back your life even if you are convicted of a crime."
Americans are funny, Dr. Jacobs said. They can be very punitive but often they are forgiving, particularly if there is an illness to blame, like alcoholism.
That may be behind the forgiveness.
"I think we are criminalizing something that is a mental problem," Mr. Beveridge said.
On the other hand, the acceptance may stem from something unique to Mr. Surdoval. In discussing his success in garnering $75 million in state and federal money for the waterfront project, Mr. Surdoval said, "What I was best at is selling the concept."
In the rehabilitation of his own image, he is selling a concept too: that he was somehow the victim of a wild teenager.
"This boy was pretty aggressive as I understand it," said Mr. Beveridge, who quickly discussed legal strategies, courtroom maneuvers and the absence of DNA evidence.
Another old friend agreed.
"Have you looked into the number of men that boy was involved with?" asked J. Edward Meyer, who retired in April after 23 years on the New York State Board of Regents. "Talking to Jim's lawyer, the young man was the heavy in this situation."
Mr. Meyer, a onetime State Assemblyman, has known Mr. Surdoval for almost 25 years. When Mr. Surdoval was 18, he helped with Mr. Meyer's unsuccessful campaign for Congress. ("He made suggestions about the people I should meet, the events I should attend and the demographics of the city," Mr. Meyer said.)
Now in private practice as a lawyer, Mr. Meyer said he was not surprised Mr. Surdoval's career had not been thwarted by the charges against him. "Regardless of his sexual problems, he's a person who brings to the table some substantial issues," Mr. Meyer said.
Andrew Maniglia was deputy mayor during the Zaleski administration and worked alongside Mr. Surdoval. Now both men work for Ginsburg Development Corporation. Mr. Maniglia oversees Ginsburg's development in the Rockland County town of Haverstraw.
Mr. Surdoval is a consultant, giving advice on and writing grants for the project, which includes 850 residences and a ferry connection from Haverstraw to Ossining. It is one of three waterfront consulting jobs Mr. Surdoval secured while he was suspended from his Yonkers government job.
Mr. Surdoval declined to name the other two. ("That's the good part about working in the private sector; I don't have to tell you," Mr. Surdoval said.)
Mr. Maniglia is an old friend of Mr. Surdoval's and he is glad to work with him again.
"I don't think this sole incident should be the last judgment on his life," he said. "He's a very talented individual with a lot to offer."
Asked whether Mr. Surdoval's criminal record made Ginsburg Development Corporation think twice about hiring him, Mr. Maniglia would only say, "The company policy is not to comment on consultants."
Not everyone is so forgiving. There is plenty of bad blood between former Mayor Zaleski and Mr. Surdoval. Mr. Zaleski fired Mr. Surdoval in 1993 for ethics violations after Mr. Surdoval cashed a friend's paycheck from the city. At the time, Mr. Zaleski called Mr. Surdoval's behavior "fraudulent," while Mr. Surdoval says the firing was based on an unrelated political conflict.
. No charges were brought against Mr. Surdoval, and hundreds of supporters, Democrats and Republicans alike, founded a "Fairness for Jim Surdoval Committee" to raise money for him to fight the accusations. Mayor Spencer was on the committee.
Mr. Zaleski still has a lot to say about Mr. Surdoval.
"He was part of the Yonkers network of people and players that in my opinion don't serve the city well," said Mr. Zaleski, who lives in Garrison now and works as a lawyer and lobbyist. "He was a fundamentally untrustworthy individual. He was doing things that were totally self-serving."
Mr. Zaleski said he knew of Mr. Surdoval's criminal troubles from news reports and was shocked to think that anyone from his administration was involved in sexual wrongdoing.
"That type of criminally repugnant behavior just turns my stomach," he said.
But Mr. Surdoval shrugs off Mr. Zaleski's criticism.
"In the end, he moved to Cold Spring, and I stayed in Yonkers, running the office of downtown development."
Under Yonkers law, Mr. Surdoval is now prohibited from working on his former domain, the waterfront, until April 2002, two years after he pleaded guilty. But he can work on other aspects of Yonkers politics and he says he still speaks to "people in City Hall" frequently.
"My own bet is he'll help in one political campaign or another," Mr. Beveridge said. "They'll call him in because he understands Yonkers better than anybody else."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK;
Growing Up Together With the Family Business

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
MORE than 30 years have passed since she failed to jot down the correct phone number of an important prospect calling from California, but Christine Jelley still remembers the sinking feeling she had -- at age 8 -- of disappointing her parents.
"Every order was a life-or-death proposition in those days," said Ms. Jelley, now 41. She was talking about the electronics company her father and mother, Michael and Cecilia Coyle, had started in their Bay Shore garage. 
 "The phone was in their bedroom and doubled as the business phone," she said. "It was intimidating trying to handle the business calls properly. But I also had the feeling my brothers and I were really needed to help make the business a success."
And if she botched one call, that didn't stop her parents from giving her plenty more opportunities to make good. There were some lean years, but the business, M.C.G. Surge Protection, eventually grew enough so that Mr. Coyle could lease warehouse space and get out of the garage.
"Those days were no bed of roses," said Mr Coyle, now 69. "The kids got factored in because there were no other bodies to do the work. It was sink or swim."
The company, which will have about $4 million in sales this year, now provides full-time employment to nearly 30 people, including the three Coyle siblings. Michael, 42, is chief engineer; Ms. Jelley runs the advertising department; and Glen, 36, is the in-house graphic artist. Patrick Coyle, 27, a cousin, is the sales manager.
M.C.G. Serge Protection is one of four companies singled out by the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University as exemplary Long Island family businesses. On Dec. 6, Ms. Jelley joined her younger brother to accept congratulations from the Center for Family Business.
The other three families businesses were Scotto Brothers Enterprises of Woodbury, which runs restaurants and banquet halls; the Fortunato Organization of Bohemia, a commercial construction company; and Fireworks by Grucci in Brookhaven.
All four enterprises have addressed one of the paramount problems that family businesses often face, the transition from one generation to the other, said Paul Salerno, the center's chairman and a partner in PricewaterhouseCoopers in Melville.
"Nine out of 10 businesses in the U.S. are family businesses, and they account for almost half of the gross domestic product," Mr. Salerno said. "But most of the time -- I'm talking 70 percent of the time -- the next generation doesn't inherit the business."
Instead, family businesses are sold to outsiders or broken into smaller pieces. The reasons vary. "The founder often doesn't have a succession plan," Mr. Salerno said. "If he does, the next generation isn't happy with it. They may not be willing to commit to his vision of how the company will move forward, or take on the roles he's assigned."
"Sometimes there's really no communication at all," he said. "Daddy may have a plan, but he isn't telling anyone."
Felix Grucci Jr., 49, the president of Fireworks by Grucci since 1983, said that because of Congressional divestiture requirements, he would have to step down from the company before he is sworn in as a United States representative next month.
A senior family member said that Mr. Grucci's sister, Donna Grucci Butler, 51, was expected to succeed him.
In separate interviews, representatives of the four families said they were generally satisfied that they had integrated family and business responsibilities. The incoming generation of executives -- men and women now in their 30's and 40's -- spoke of how their family and business activities were productively intertwined; how as children and teenagers they valued feeling truly needed as they worked alongside adults; and how they respected their elders for qualities like persistence, fairness and dedication to hard work.
Silvana Scotto-Zangri said that interfamily cooperation, both in running the business as well as in raising the next generation, was a cornerstone of her Port Washington childhood. Her father, Anthony Scotto, and three uncles built a one-table Shore Road pizzeria into a $140-million-a-year restaurant and catering empire, and their families pitched in to rear the next generation.
"You're not raised by your mother and father; you're raised by everybody's mother and father," said Ms. Scotto-Zangri, 30, who runs the family's Watermill banquet hall in Smithtown. "You could walk into any one of their houses, open their refrigerator, and help yourself if you were hungry," she said.
As a teenager, she made ample pocket money working in the pizzeria. "Kids would say: 'You get all the free pizza you want. That is so cool,' " she said, laughing. "The downside is you have to work every Friday and Saturday night."
At the pizzeria, and later in the family's growing chain of banquet halls, which now include Westbury Manor and Fox Hollow, she frequently observed how her father handled difficult situations at work.
"What comes to mind is how fair he is," she said. "If someone were caught drinking on the job, he'd always give them another opportunity, after rehab. My father is the king of second chances."
Paul Fortunato, 40, remembers taking water to construction sites as a boy. As a teenager, he picked up various building trades working on construction sites, often alongside his older brother, Bernard Jr. When their father, Bernard Sr., retires -- he is now in his 70's -- Paul Fortunato will become the chief executive of Fortunato Development Inc., the family-owned real estate company. Bernard Jr., 45, is in line to become the chief executive of Fortunato Sons Inc., the contracting company.
"My father," Paul Fortunato said, "will retire when he's ready to retire. There is no date set."
Meanwhile, Bernard Sr., who inherited the 100-year-old company from his father, Dominic, in 1977, continues to groom the next generation. His third son, Peter, 35, is creating his own role in the business, Mr. Fortunato said.
Paul Fortunato said: "Traditionally, we did business on a handshake. As a kid in the business, I learned the importance of mutual respect and that you don't negotiate quality. I learned that you respect your employees but that at the same time you don't let them walk all over you."
"You've got to treat people the way you want to be treated," he continued. "You may pay more to hire the right people, but you've got to get the people who can do the work and do it right. In the long run, what I learned is that the work you do is only as good as the people who do it."
He continues to find inspiration in the example set by his grandfather. "He wore a Stetson hat and a black coat," Mr. Fortunato said in a quiet voice. "He started out in the Bronx as a bricklayer. He used to wear a jacket and tie to the job, to be professional. He'd take off the jacket, roll up the sleeves and lay bricks. You better believe the work was done the right way."
Dominic Fortunato's work ethic remains the foundation of the business today. "I remember being out on sites as a kid," Mr. Fortunato said. "When the old man was around, boy, you knew it. He was awesome."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1465 words

HEADLINE: As Hotels Rise in Vancouver, Occupancy Rate Falls

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia

 BODY:
NINETEEN new hotels have been built in this coastal city and near its suburban airport since 1996, adding more than 6,000 rooms. The hotels' developers were enticed in part by a plan to expand greatly the waterfront convention center at Canada Place. That plan was later rejected, although the tourism industry is still pushing for an upgrade at Canada Place.
A construction crane perches atop the 48-story Sheraton Vancouver Wall Center, which will be the tallest building on Vancouver's skyline when completed in March. Newly opened hotels carry such names as Marriott, Hilton, Sandman, Fairmont, Delta, Westin, Holiday Inn and Hampton Inn. Numerous companies also hold options on land. In 1995, when plans first emerged to expand the convention center, the greater Vancouver area had 17,731 hotel rooms. Today it has more than 24,000. 
 Downtown, hotels were built close to Canada Place or wherever developers could find space in the compact business district.
Vancouver's downtown, with its stunning architecture and reflective glass buildings, is squeezed into the southern end of a narrow three mile long peninsula in Burrard Inlet. At the northern tip, water laps around the 1,000-acre Stanley Park, where joggers have views of ships anchored in the harbor and rugged coastal mountains across the bay.
The city of two million people sprawls southward on the mainland, where hotel owners have also built heavily near the Vancouver International Airport, a 15-minute drive from downtown in the suburb of Richmond. Sixteen million passengers pass annually through the airport, which just completed an expansion that cost $58.3 million (United States dollars).
"There are a number of international name hotels who would build tomorrow if they could find the right spot if the convention center is expanded," says Gordon Johnson, past president of the Vancouver Hotel Association and a regional director for Delta Hotels, a Toronto-based company. Since 1998, the company has opened two new hotels that are a 10 minute walk from Canada Place: the 434-room Delta Pinnacle and the 225-room Delta Vancouver Suites.
The building spree began after British Columbia's provincial government in 1995 called for expressions of interest for an expansion of the Vancouver Convention and Exhibition Center. Many international associations had outgrown Canada Place, which can accommodate a convention of up to only 2,500 people. The tourism industry feared that the benefits the city realizes from conventions would decline and the city would not be able to compete with Seattle, San Francisco and San Diego.
The plan that emerged was called the Portside Project It was to have been a $650 million complex containing a convention center, a 1,000-room hotel operated by Marriott and more berths for cruise ships to Alaska, which dock at Canada Place. But that proposal was rejected by the provincial government as too expensive.
Unwilling to let the cruise industry languish because it brings a million people a year into the city, contributing $330 million a year to the economy, the Vancouver Port Authority immediately began its own $51 million berth expansion, which is to be completed in 2003.
IN October the tourism industry unveiled a proposal for a $320 million expansion adjacent to Canada Place, which could be built by 2005. Meeting and exhibit space would quadruple to 553,000 square feet from 134,000 and enable the center to play host 7,000 delegates, almost triple the current capacity..
"We must take advantage of this unique opportunity to build on the previous success of this important economic engine," said Rick Antonson, president of Tourism Vancouver. "The status quo is not an option." Under the proposal, tourism companies would provide $58 million in financing and the provincial and federal governments $262 million. Mr. Antonson is confident financing can be secured soon because tax revenues derived will, he estimates, pay back investments in 10.7 years. Delegates are expected to spend $310 million a year, according to estimates of a task force made up of tourism, hotel and business representatives. No government action has yet been taken on the proposal.
The expansion proposal does not include a hotel. But Marathon Developments Inc., the development arm of Canadian Pacific Ltd., the transportation, energy and hotel company, owns 81 acres of former rail yards and marinas near Canada Place on which the Vancouver tourism industry would expand the the convention center.
Graeme Stamp, Marathon's executive vice president, is seeking approval from the city for an 800-room hotel there as well. He is talking to executives of hotel companies about operating the hotel after it is built.
James Kaufman, general manager of the new Sheraton Vancouver Wall Center hotel, owned by the Wall Financial Corporation, which has its headquarters here, said, "Maybe we'd like to build the hotel ourselves." The company is completing a 308-room tower addition that is the last phase of Sheraton Vancouver Wall Center, which will be the largest hotel in British Columbia, with 762 rooms.
Peter Wall, the company's chairman and chief executive, said he believes his new hotel will succeed even without an enlarged convention center. He is building 45,000 square feet of meeting space, believing that convention hotels that do not put in meeting space, spas, restaurants and lounges will have a hard time filling their rooms.
This strategy was echoed by the Tokyo-based Aoki Corporation, which in June completed a $32 million renovation of its 510-room Westin Bayshore Resort and Marina adjacent to Stanley Park -- one of eight existing hotels that have invested in extensive renovation in recent years. The Westin Bayshore built a 48,000-square-foot conference center, including 23 meeting rooms and the city's largest ballroom, at 16,000 square feet. "We want to serve a niche market for planners who want to do smaller conferences that require 300 to 400 hotel rooms with a resort atmosphere," said Mark Andrew, the Westin's general manager.
While his hotel is aiming at groups holding smaller meetings, he would be happy to be part of larger gatherings. "Hopefully, we will get an expanded convention center and large citywide conventions like Seattle enjoys," Mr. Andrew said. If the center becomes a reality, the Westin Bayshore would build a 200 to 300 room addition within five to 10 years.
As new hotels have sprung up, occupancy rates have dropped, from 76 percent in the greater Vancouver area in 1996 to 67.5 percent in 1999. Hotel executives expect a further decline this year to 65 or 67 percent.
The empty rooms are taking a toll. "Some big convention hotels are becoming predatory and going after the leisure and individual corporate travelers, the mainstay at nonconvention hotels such as ours," said Stephen Darling, general manager of the new 207-room Westin Grand, which O'Neill Hotels and Resorts of Vancouver opened last year at the south end of the downtown in a high-tech district. "Last spring, they waged a rate war." Yet the 31-story Westin Grand, whose tower is curved in the shape of a grand piano, will post a better-than-average occupancy rate this year, 72.8 percent, because it is conveniently located near the high-tech companies, where most of its corporate clients are doing business.
Francis Parkinson, general manager of the recently opened $42 million, 392-room Fairmont Vancouver Airport Hotel, said suburban Richmond and the airport "had the province's highest occupancy, in the 85 to 95 percent range." He added, "That attracted us, plus the airport was looking for a high end hotel."
The Fairmont is the only hotel in Canada located on an airport concourse and its lobby overlooks departure gates. Guests can check into flights though an in-room check-in service, and some Canadian airlines will deliver boarding passes to guests' rooms. Arriving travelers can hand baggage claim tags to bellmen.
Two years ago, Richmond had 2,000 hotel rooms, but this has exploded to 4,200 rooms today. "Business is not as good as we anticipated," Mr. Parkinson said, "but we are holding our own."
Nine proposed hotels with 1,495 rooms have either been postponed or canceled because of the convention center delay. A billboard on a downtown parking lot bears a sketch of a 170-room Hilton Suites Vancouver hotel and the slogan "the land where dreams become reality." It was to have opened on the site by late 2000, but has yet to break ground.
"There will be some short-term pain for the hotel industry until the new convention center is built," said Mr. Johnson of Delta Hotels. "But we will pull our socks up and get through the next few years. This is an extremely healthy market with good prospects to come."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Redevelopment to Start Near Shore in Long Branch

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: LONG BRANCH

 BODY:
EARLIER this month this old resort city's long-awaited plan to transform 150 acres of its tattered Atlantic Ocean shoreline into a new neighborhood was nudged forward by $11.2 million in loans and grants from the state.
The state financing will help spur the construction of Pier Village, an $80 million residential and retail complex, and in turn promote development in the rest of the renewal area. There, up to 1,300 residences, an entertainment center and thousands of square feet of commercial space are planned. 
 In the three years since the city's plan has been in place, there have been signs of change, including the renovation of an oceanside resort hotel, the former Hilton, and the opening this summer of a new beach club. But progress has been slow.
"We're going into a difficult area of the city that needs state assistance," said Howard H. Woolley Jr., Long Branch's business administrator. "But since there is no one pot of public money, it takes creativity on the part of the state and the developer and persistence on the part of the city."
Pier Village, which will include 100,000 square feet of shops and 440 rental apartments, is a keystone in Long Branch's efforts to rebuild. It will rise on 16 acres between Melrose Terrace and Laird Street, next to the site of the former Kids World amusement pier, which was destroyed by fire a decade ago. Ground is to be broken this summer, according to the Applied Development Company of Hoboken, the developer.
A section of Ocean Boulevard, which runs through the redevelopment area, will also be redesigned. Now a busy six-lane highway, it will be changed to a four-lane avenue with pedestrian walkways and bike paths.
In exchange for the state financing, the developer has agreed to build 88 rental and condominium units for families with low and moderate incomes.
The significance of Pier Village is that it will sustain the city's goal of becoming a year-round community, not just a seasonal resort, said Pratap Talwar, a principal at the Thompson Design Group of Boston, which developed Long Branch's renewal plan. It will also "help create the market conditions for and serve as an impetus to further development," he said.
The plan -- the result of years of discussions among city officials, residents and business groups -- is also meant to improve the city's economy. Long Branch's financial health, along with the tourism it relied on for its tax base, began to falter in the 1950's when shore towns farther south became more popular.
Among other things the plan, known as Long Branch Tomorrow, divides the redevelopment district into five sectors, sets guidelines for developers and incorporates the state's coastal development regulations into local zoning, to streamline the approval process. It also dovetails with New Jersey's development and redevelopment plan, which guides growth to areas where highways, sewers and utilities are in place and away from areas where they are lacking.
UNDER the state plan, Long Branch, which is served by two rail stations, is designated a "regional center." Mr. Talwar said this implies it can accommodate higher-density development and is eligible for state assistance.
Jane M. Kenny, commissioner of the state's Department of Community Affairs, said the Pier Village project "is a great example of smart growth and of the kind of development we envisioned when we think of the possibilities the state plan promotes." For cities to grow, she added, "we have to provide a climate for private investment." Of the total state investment, $9.2 million will be for property acquisition, loans to the developer and permanent financing for the market-rate rentals. The other $2 million will be for the improvements to Ocean Boulevard.
For the Applied Development Company, the state money is key to moving the project ahead. "It's necessary to make the project economically viable and to attract capital from the private sector," said Gregory S. Russo, a vice president at Applied, which the city named earlier this year to redevelopthe Pier Village site.
Applied was also named the developer of 25 acres in the district's Beachfront North. On that site, between Madison Avenue and Marine Terrace, Applied is planning up to 350 residences and 20,000 square feet of retail space.
Mr. Russo said construction of that $62 million project is subject to his company's securing $10 million in state money, which he expects to receive by next month. Meanwhile, Applied is acquiring properties and relocating residents and businesses. As a result, he said, the project will probably start at the same time as Pier Village, which involves fewer relocation issues.
The city has also granted the developer a graduated five-year tax abatement on the rental and retail components of both projects and will help with land acquisition and relocation costs. The state will also provide relocation assistance.
Previous efforts to rebuild the city's oceanfront were hindered by local politics, community opposition and cumbersome regulations. Under the current plan those hurdles have been neutralized to a large degree. Still, few projects have sprouted in the redevelopment area.
P LANNING moves slowly, and I don't think that necessarily is a bad thing," Mayor Adam Schneider said. "The goal is not to have developers backed up at the door, but proposals that work." He said the city had already rebuffed some developers, whose proposals deviated too much from the plan or did not benefit Long Branch. Others in the industry said the relocation and acquisition issues were too great for some companies.
Mr. Russo of Applied said his company, which is active along the Hudson River waterfront in New Jersey, became involved in Long Branch because of local support for redevelopment, the current lack of competition and "the incredible draw of the ocean." That, he added, makes these projects viable even if the economy turns down.
Even before the news of the state assistance, there were some signs that the city's shoreline was beginning to come back. Community leaders point to their refurbished beachfront, the $12 million renovation in the last two years of the 250-room Oceanplace Conference Resort, which may be expanded in 2001; and a beach club on Ocean Avenue that was carved from a vacant armory. The club opened last summer with a sold-out membership of about 400 families, said Joseph F. Lagrotteria, one of its owners.
The city next month will also begin accepting proposals from developers for the 30-acre Beachfront South area of the redevelopment district, which could accommodate additional residential development. Meanwhile, Mayor Schneider said the city would focus on moving forward on one of the three proposals for a new pier for retail, commercial and entertainment uses and perhaps transportation as well. Two of the proposals also call for ferry service to Manhattan.
And in the Beachfront North area, Applied has started the process of relocation. Elizabeth and Joseph Rufalo, 13-year residents, are among the first families to sell their homes. They have moved from the area to a condominium apartment they own in Newark, where Mr. Rufalo works as an administrative analyst for the city. Mrs. Rufalo, who is retired, worked as director of curriculum for the Newark Board of Education and is member of Long Branch Tomorrow, the civic group.
"I was a little disappointed," Mrs. Rufalo said of the realities of relocating. "But I am a realist and know progress goes on. It was just a matter of time." Now, she added, she and her husband are thinking about moving back when the new homes are built.
Mr. Russo said he would create a preferred waiting list for the 175 people who will have to move because of the project and who want to return.
He said Pier Village will consist of one- to three-bedroom rentals with 850 to 1,200 square feet on the upper three levels of several four-story buildings. The ground floors will be for shops and restaurants. Monthly rents will be $900 to $1,800.
Of the 350 units planned at the Beachfront North site, 130 will be rentals similar in size and rent to those at Pier Village. There also will be 120 condominiums that will range in size from 1,000 to 2,000 square feet and in price from just under $200,000 to $400,000; the 100 town houses, with 1,500 to 2,500 square feet, will cost $225,000 to more than $500,000.
Mr. Russo said that while construction of the two projects would be staggered, "there will be a constant supply of units."
The hope, said Mayor Schneider, is that once Applied's projects and the new pier are in place, "the investment climate will have improved so future projects will make sense financially without state assistance."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut;
Housing Is Replacing Planned Stamford Offices

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
ALL through the 80's, office buildings popped out of the ground in Stamford like crocuses in spring, but no one gave much thought to where the employees would live. As the housing supply shrank and prices rose, they settled in communities up the line, their vehicles flooding the highways, railroad parking lots and Stamford streets.
Today, office construction is at a standstill, but a critical housing shortage has attracted some developers from nearby states to take over office projects that have languished unbuilt for two or three years, reworking them as rental apartments. Plans for at least three major commercial complexes have been redesigned as housing, and the shift is hailed by city officials as an overdue correction of an imbalance in Stamford's real estate market. 
 Unlike cautious office tenants, eager apartment seekers are at the door, checks in hand, when rentals become available. And backers for new apartments are not hard to find. "Pension funds, the primary source for apartments," said Jeffrey Dunne, senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis, the real estate brokerage firm, "are willing to accept the lower yields of apartments as opposed to offices, because they feel apartments are a safer investment with less ongoing capital requirements."
In spite of the tightest commercial market in decades, "office development is still paying the price for what happened when they built too much on spec," said Robin Stein, Stamford's land use bureau chief. Vacancy rates for quality downtown space have dropped to between 4 and 5 percent, but developers and brokers say that while prospective tenants for new buildings exist, commitments have not materialized, and without tenants there are no lenders.
"The market tells you that more office buildings are not needed in Stamford," said Anthony Malkin, president of W&M Properties of Manhattan, which operates in eight states, including Connecticut. In recent years, the focus has shifted from new offices to "a conglomeration of multifamily development, night life, retail and UConn."
The two most prominent proposed office projects in Stamford are regarded by many real estate professionals as too large to sign up tenants for the 50 percent of space required to secure financing. Connecticut Place, Louis Dreyfus Property Group's proposed 23-story, 574,000-square-foot building at Washington Boulevard and Richmond Hill Avenue, has all its approvals but with no firm starting date has not yet signed up any tenants. The Hines Interest project at 425 Atlantic Street, was approved by the city in 1997 but attracted no tenants. It has submitted a new site plan for an additional 50 feet in height, bringing it to 26 stories. But by eliminating a trading floor, for which it found no interest, it retains its original size of 580,000 square feet.
But some rivals think these plans are too big to succeed. "This is not a 600,000-square-foot market," said Thomas Rich, senior vice president of F. D. Rich, the redeveloper of Stamford's central business district in the 70's and 80's. His own projected complex, consisting of a 230,000-square-foot office building and a 110-unit luxury apartment tower, "has a better chance of getting off the ground," he said. Opposite the University of Connecticut's Stamford branch on Broad Street, it is in compliance with current zoning, but it too has no tenants.
Arthur Collins, chairman of Collins Enterprises in Greenwich, who has developed 725,000 square feet of offices and 231 condominium units overlooking Stamford Harbor, hopes to get a 75,000-square-foot building called Harbor Watch under construction in 2001. "The problem for Hines and Dreyfus," he said, "is that major tenants are not coming from Manhattan any more. They are already in Stamford; they've grown and want to consolidate a few locations."
Nevertheless, Mr. Dunne, along with other brokers, believes the Dreyfus building, with its approvals in place, could be the first to go up. "If we don't have a significant drop in the economy," he said, "there will be sufficient demand for one new building."
But demand seems more immediate for buildings that increase the supply of housing. With the adoption two weeks ago of an amendment to Stamford's zoning regulations, developers of mixed-use projects -- including residential, office and retail components -- in downtown Stamford may apply to have property designated as an "inclusionary floating zone." The new zone requires them to set aside 10 percent of their units at lowered rates. If a developer does not include any offices, only 6 percent of the units must be low cost.
"In a residential market as hot as this," Mr. Stein said, "developers are willing to comply with the affordable-housing component." The measure was created by Richard W. Redniss, president of Redniss & Mead, a Stamford-based land use planning and engineering group, in cooperation with the city and the Downtown Special Service District.
UNDER the new zoning rules, the units set aside for lower cost will not necessarily be part of the projects but may be located partially or altogether at other sites in Stamford. Developers will form partnerships with nonprofit groups or other developers to produce housing plans, which must be approved by the Stamford Zoning Board. Some developers with properties in the central business district are critical of inclusionary zoning as restrictive and an unfair burden on their finances and time, but Mr. Redniss said, "The city is trying to provide a set of tools to foster housing that probably would not be built otherwise."
Of the three residential projects that converted from office use, Signature Place by Roseland Property of Short Hills, N.J., was the first to use the new zone. It intends to build on a site locally famous as "the hole in the ground," a vacant 4.2-acre commercially zoned wilderness behind the Stamford Town Center mall that has been empty of everything but weeds for 20 years. A previous proposal called for a 495,000-square-foot office tower.
Under the zone, "Roseland was allowed to trade in the commercial development rights for more housing than is allowed by current zoning," Mr. Redniss said, "yielding 932 apartments in three towers." Fifty-six additional units will be built at a different site and will be priced below market for people with incomes at 50 percent of the area median, which is $102,400 for a family of four. The developer expects to begin construction in June or July on the project, which will contain ground-floor shops and a pedestrian avenue through a central park.
A second site at Washington Boulevard and West Park Place, previously slated for 250,000 square feet of offices, is to be developed by Archstone Properties of Boston, which hopes to begin construction next fall. The proposal is for 244 apartments, including 10 units at 25 percent of median income, eight at 50 percent and four at 60 percent, with a ground-floor retail component. Families of four earning $25,000 a year could be accommodated at the 25 percent level.
Palmer Hill, the third site, at Havemeyer Lane on the Stamford-Greenwich border is being developed under the "floating" provision of the zone. The developers of Palmer Hill will apply after Jan. 1 to build up to 250 units with an undetermined percentage of reduced rate units and ground-floor shops. A vacant office building of 117,000 square feet formerly occupied by Conair now stands on the property but will be demolished. The developer is Starwood Buckingham of Princeton, N.J., which says it will build half of the below-market-rate units on the site, and half of them elsewhere.
Archstone is investing $280,000 toward developing its off-site units and Roseland will pay $2 million for that purpose. Both companies still must work out plans with potential partners in the low-cost housing to present to zoning officials.
These are not the only apartment ventures in the works, but, Mr. Redniss said, "in these three projects alone we will get about 1,500 units of housing instead of over a million square feet of offices."
A study commissioned by Stamford has found a strong demand for market-rate apartments ranging from $1,500 to $3,000 a month, as well as a need for about 2,800 units of low-cost housing for families earning $50,000 and less to satisfy demand from this year through 2004. The study was produced by Abeles Phillips Preiss & Shapiro, Inc., development consultants commissioned by Stamford's Community Development Agency and Housing Authority. Over the next 20 years, Stamford is expected to build 7 million to 10 million square feet of offices, said Stephen MacKenzie, Stamford's director of economic development. "Housing built close to major employers will take some of it out of the running," he said.
There is speculation that some existing office space in Stamford may be vacated, deferring new construction further.
According to people in the real-estate industry in Stamford, W&M Properties, which specializes in reinvigorating existing office buildings to improve their profitability, has contracted to buy First Stamford Place, a fully rented 800,000-square-foot complex within walking distance of the railroad station. The current owner is TrizecHahn of Toronto, a real estate giant that is divesting itself of $1 billion worth of real estate. The price is said to be $151 million. W&M would not comment on the report.
In addition, International Paper, which bought Champion International's 484,000 square-foot Atlantic Street building early this year, is said to have accepted an offer to sell the property to a consortium of Morgan Stanley and two New Jersey developers: Alan Landis and Gale & Wentworth. A spokeswoman confirmed that International Paper has a contract to sell the building by Dec. 31, but she would not comment on who the buyers are.
Dean J. Shapiro, executive director at Insignia/ESG, the real-estate brokerage, said, "Xerox could move to its Rochester location." Bill McKee, Xerox's spokesman in Rochester, says that is unlikely.
Ed Tonnessen, executive vice president at Albert B. Ashforth Inc., speculates that "we will see at least 300,000 square feet come back on the market, most of it courtesy of the dot-coms and all of it in small chunks. Priceline has already given back 60,000 square feet."

HEADLINE: With Little Discord, County Adopts Budget

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
DESPITE some disagreements, county legislators unanimously adopted a $1.2 billion budget last week with little of the partisan rancor often seen in budget deliberations.
Democrats, who control the Board of Legislators, praised the 17-member legislature for a spirit of bipartisanship and collegiality, but Republicans said some of the credit should go to a strong economy that made the choices easier than usual.
County officials said the budget, which includes a tax cut for the third consecutive year, was also the product of an increasingly amicable relationship between the legislative and executive branches of county government. 
 "A good thing doesn't have to have a political party tag on it," County Executive Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat, said of the budget that will reduce the county property tax levy by 5.2 percent. "What matters is whether it's good for people of Westchester."
The budget represents a total savings for taxpayers of $18.4 million next year.
Mr. Spano rejected the argument that the smooth budget process was merely the byproduct of a good economy.
"Nassau County isn't doing it so well, and they're dealing with the same economy that Westchester is," Mr. Spano said. He pointed out that the legislative and executive branches of the Westchester government have done their arguing quietly and privately, which is more palatable to the public.
As the chairman of the Democratic-controlled Board of Legislators, George S. Latimer, said, "We haven't seen this kind of working together in Albany or Washington."
That is not to say there are no disagreements, observed Richard G. Wishnie, another Democrat and the chairman of the Budget and Appropriations Committee. "Let's be realistic," he said. "We are 17 individuals representing different constituencies, and people have to have their say and give their input.
"But when the time comes to pass the budget and address the concerns of the county, I love my colleagues because they put the importance of the county as a whole before their individual priorities," he added.
For most homeowners in Westchester, the budget for 2001 means a decrease in the property tax rate from $4.73 per $1,000 of market value to $4.06 next year. The actual rates, however, vary from municipality to municipality and will not be known until sometime next year, when assessments are completed.
Several of the Republicans on the board (it is split 9 to 8) said the majority was praising bipartisanship when the real reason the budget passed without much rancor was far less idealistic.
"In the past, in order to reduce taxes, we've had to make cuts," said Paul J. Noto, the minority leader, who represents parts of Harrison, the town of Rye and the village of Mamaroneck, and all of Port Chester and Rye Brook. "That makes things much harder because you're making difficult choices. This time, the debate centered on what do you spend on new programs or add to existing ones as opposed to what you would cut."
In large part, he said, the spirit of cooperation was borne out of larger-than-expected revenue projections -- about $263.3 million -- from county taxes on the sale of consumer goods, and on healthy hotel and vehicle registration taxes.
Katherine S. Carsky, a Republican and Conservative legislator from parts of Greenburgh, Scarsdale and Yonkers, suggested that lawmakers not get swept away by their successes this year.
"There was no point in voting against this budget, which was settled on the basis of extra sales tax revenue," she cautioned. "It's the future we have to be aware of. The danger is that in good times it's very easy to let the costs creep up, but come the day we have a faltering economy, we'll have to face the music."
But Mr. Wishnie, the chairman of the Budget and Appropriations Committee, did not share Ms. Carsky's concerns, pointing out that the budget has a rainy day fund of $26 million.
The new budget calls for spending $38.7 million on subsidized day care for low-income families. It also calls for $600,000 to pay for 26 additional county government positions in park maintenance, pesticide notification and restaurant inspection, among others.
Other budget lines include $570,000 for county libraries and art programs, $410,000 for domestic violence programs, and $225,000 for after-school and weekend programs for children.

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING;
Giving Advice Through Rose-Colored Stock Options

BYLINE: By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin teaches at Emerson College in Boston and is the author of "The Good, the Bad, and Your Business" (John Wiley & Sons). His column on business ethics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AS dot-com companies hurried onto the public markets during the Internet stock run-up of the late 1990's, everyone wanted a piece of the action. Not only were the companies' founders sitting on a potential pot of gold in their equity, employees also got in on the possible upside by holding stock options. And the options booty was also extended to outsiders, like lawyers and consultants.
Dot-com stocks, of course, have taken a tumble since those heady days, and options are not as attractive -- if they have any value at all. But that doesn't negate the need for many start-up companies to find alternative payments for services they receive. Cash, after all, is precious for day-to-day operations, so many dot-coms continue to use shares or stock options to pay outside vendors and consultants. 
 For an outsider who supplies a tangible product in exchange for equity, such deals pose few conflicts. But what if the outsider is in the business of providing objective advice -- about when to go public, for example? Could such advice be tainted by the self-interest of reaping a big payoff from the company's initial public offering?
The quandary is front and center when lawyers accept stock or stock options in a company instead of cash for their advice and services.
"It pits human nature to be professional versus human nature to look out for oneself," said Jeffrey Haas, professor of securities law at the New York School of Law. "Both are very strong primitive notions."
But paying with stock can make economic sense for a new business. "In the beginning of a company's life, equity becomes the only currency you have to buy top-flight services," said Fred Marcusa, a senior partner at Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler in Manhattan.
Mr. Marcusa still receives only cash for his services. But he says many people who give advice can be influenced by the simple fact that they are paid -- whether in cash or in stock. He said he thought the conflict over lawyers' taking stock in lieu of cash resulted from "a certain amount of jealousy" among people at other firms who didn't get in on the action.
Others reject outright the idea of receiving stock. "I just don't do it," said Gerald E. Boltz, a partner in the Los Angeles office of Bryan Cave. "It has an impact on objectivity. The company is entitled to objective legal advice. I'm not sure it's good for the company or the attorney."
While the American Bar Association has decided that there is nothing illegal or unethical about lawyers' taking stock in lieu of cash, it has set only broad parameters: The transaction must be reasonable, the client must consent to the transaction in writing, and the client must have reasonable opportunity to seek a second legal opinion on the deal.
Recognizing that some companies may not have the wherewithal to pay a high-ticket lawyer in cash, the A.B.A. suggests that if stock is used, the amount should be equal to the cash value of the services, based on the stock price at the time of the transaction. But many people see a qualitative difference between taking cash and taking stock of comparable value, especially in a hot market. "It's like swinging for the fence," Professor Haas said of accepting stock. "If, normally, you're getting $300 or $400 per hour for doing this type of work, if the stock turns out to be a home run, it could turn into $1,500 an hour, in essence."
That something is ethical simply because it's socially acceptable is an arguable point. Ethical conflicts become clearest when the payoff from going public is huge.
"It's not the form of compensation you want to keep your eye on, but the relative magnitude," said William H. Simon, a professor of legal ethics at Stanford Law School. "If a large fraction of a lawyer's portfolio is invested in a client, then people worry that his independence will be compromised and he'll be more likely to overlook improper practices or even encourage them in the hope of personal gain."
When the stock market settles down, the conflict isn't as clear, and neither are the concerns of the lawyers who accepted the stock. Lawyers shouldn't be asking themselves whether to take stock instead of cash, but rather when to cut off clients who don't pay in cash.
The real issue isn't whether there is a conflict in accepting stock compensation. Of course there is potential for conflict. The challenge is how to deal with it.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Carter Marsh, Red Abbott

 BODY:
Carter Scott Marsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Scott Marsh III of New Vernon, N.J., was married last evening to Jamison Owen Abbott, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Denis Abbott of Cochranville, Pa. The Rev. Zachary Fleetwood performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J.
Mr. and Mrs. Abbott, who graduated cum laude from Princeton, are teachers and coaches. The bride, 25, is the associate director of athletics at Episcopal High School in Alexandria, Va., where she also teaches history and is the head soccer and lacrosse coach. The bridegroom, 27, who is known as Red, teaches physics and mathematics at the Landon School in Bethesda, Md., where he also coaches football and wrestling. 
 The bride's father, who retired as a managing director in the private client group of E. M. Warburg Pincus, the investment bank in New York, is now a consultant for the Beacon Trust Company, a money management business in Chatham, N.J. Her mother, Elizabeth Marsh, is a trustee of the Newark Museum and of Drew University and is a co-founder of New Jersey Seeds, a nonprofit organization in Hightstown, N.J., that helps prepare economically disadvantaged students for independent secondary schools.
The bridegroom's mother, Dixie Abbott, and his father, a member of the Pennsylvania State Horse Racing Commission, own the Charlton Bloodstock Agency, a thoroughbred racehorse brokerage service in Cochranville.
