HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY & MEDIA;
Rules for AOL Time Warner May Have Only a Narrow Impact

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Amid all the talk last week about how the government's restrictions on the merger of America Online and Time Warner would usher in new competition for high-speed Internet access, one salient fact seemed to be lost: only 12 percent of the nation's homes subscribe to Time Warner's cable service.
So anything that the AOL-Time Warner deal ushers in regarding high-speed Internet service will be directly relevant to fewer than an eighth of the nation's consumers. Anyone, therefore, who thinks that the AOL-Time Warner deal has set a pattern for the nation's broadband Internet industry may end up being rudely surprised. 
 Despite the sweeping predictions of consumer benefits from the Federal Trade Commission's ruling, many things about the future of the high-speed Internet business remain uncertain -- for regulators; for the nation's Internet, telephone and cable television companies; for consumers; and most definitely for AOL Time Warner.
"AOL's done a great job with its technology strategy and getting access to Time Warner's cable systems," said Brian Adamik, president of the Yankee Group, a technology research and consulting firm in Boston. "But they still have 88 percent of the problem to fix."
Scott Cleland, founder of the Precursor Group, an independent communications research firm in Washington, took a similar view. "This is a wedge, this is progress," he said. "But they still have a huge amount of work to do." Mr. Cleland's comments could very easily apply to regulators, as well.
The two main communications links into homes are telephone wires and cable television systems. Currently, the nation's big local telephone companies are required to sell piecemeal access to parts of their networks to other companies. That makes it relatively straightforward for other companies to provide high-speed data services over phone wires. But cable companies are not generally required to sell access to their systems. (The separation between the regulatory regimes for telephone and cable companies goes back decades and is largely a product of the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company's special position as a national monopoly.)
As it happens, it was AOL itself that did more than any other company to bring this regulatory discrepancy to light. After AT&T started gobbling up cable properties in the late 1990's, AOL pushed for new laws or regulations that would force AT&T to open its cable systems.
But without explicit legislation, federal regulators cannot simply tell cable companies to open their systems. What they can do is extract concessions in the context of a merger-approval process. That is the context of AOL and Time Warner's agreement to last week's conditions. And it is why AT&T agreed to allow other Internet providers onto its systems eventually, a policy AT&T announced about a year ago in its successful effort to win approval to acquire the MediaOne Group, a cable company.
But last week's concessions by AOL and Time Warner do not have some magical precedent-setting value that will somehow automatically bring the rules to bear on the other big cable companies.
That said, most of the other cable giants, like Cablevision, Charter, Comcast and Cox, will probably end up trying significant acquisitions of their own the next few years. And when they do, the regulators may very well be there waiting for them, expecting similar concessions -- unless the Bush administration decides that open access is no longer a priority.
The AOL-Time Warner concessions are "clearly a step in the right direction, and it is more than any other cable company has agreed to to date," said R. Steven Davis, senior vice president for law and policy at Qwest Communications International, which owns the former U S West Inc., the big Bell regional phone carrier. "It takes away that argument that it is not technically feasible for them to do this."
Meanwhile, AOL has considerable work ahead if it hopes to be anywhere as dominant as it has been on the Internet. The company has more than 25 million subscribers worldwide, almost all of whom now use standard modems. But within five years it is likely that most of its United States customers will be using broadband Internet links -- with or without AOL. So AOL needs to ensure it has broadband options nationwide, not just in the slices of the country served by Time Warner's cable systems.
"For this deal, the cable access question was a sideshow," Mr. Cleland said. "The main event is combining AOL's majority audience with Time Warner's content. That is a national model."
AOL still has to go out and negotiate access to other companies' cable systems and it is unlikely that the company would turn its back on any technology that would allow it to hold on to its customers as they migrate to broadband. The F.T.C. is requiring AOL to continue offering D.S.L. -- a high-speed phone line technology that competes with cable modems -- as a condition of approving the merger. But continuing to offer D.S.L. might be something AOL was inclined to do anyway.
In the end, it is difficult to avoid coming back to the 12 percent figure and reaching the conclusion that high-speed Internet access via cable was never a sufficient rationale for the AOL-Time Warner merger. But AOL's Internet services -- on Time Warner's system or anyone else's -- are a powerful distribution and promotion medium for Time Warner's old economy products: magazines, movies, music. And none of the F.T.C.'s vaunted conditions do anything to change that.

HEADLINE: PATENTS;
Putting a Value on the Intangible

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND 

 BODY:
In the last few years, patents, copyrights, trademarks and trade secrets have assumed an enormous role in the economy, where value consists of the assets that companies carry on their books. Until recently, that largely meant land, equipment and manufactured goods. Now, increasingly, those assets are information and ideas.
But how will such intellectual property be appraised impartially and calculated on a company's balance sheet? 
 For now, these intangible assets can be accounted for just about any way a company chooses. There are no rules for evaluating or reporting intellectual property, and that unnerves many business owners and corporate leaders, especially after the plunge since April in the stock values of so many companies built on precisely such intangible assets. Few people doubt that companies that rely on patents, trademarks and copyrighted ideas will continue to fuel the Information Age. So executives, economists and policy makers are eager to find ways to assign realistic worth to such property.
"Our capacity for tracking, measuring and reporting intangible assets is falling way behind where the economy is moving," said Margaret Blair, who recently was co-chairwoman of a Brookings Institution task force on intangible sources of value. "The economy has moved dramatically in the last five years, and intangible assets have taken on vastly more importance and now exceed tangible assets in terms of value."
Private businesses have already begun making their own internal policies for evaluating intangible assets -- including reputation, brands and customer loyalty as well as patents and copyrights.
In 1970, the Financial Accounting Standards Board said that costs and expenses associated with intangible assets should be recorded and amortized. But it offered no guideline on how to value intangible assets and it added this caveat: "Solving the problem is complicated by the characteristics of an intangible asset: its lack of physical qualities makes evidence of its existence elusive, its value is often difficult to estimate, and its useful life may be indeterminable."
So private companies have not developed universal standards, and all face a lack of information about what others are doing. The Brookings task force learned that businesses felt unable to approach the problem because there were no statistics.
In a report published in September, the task force recommended that the Bureau of Economic Analysis, a government agency that measures gross domestic product and other economic standards, should collect that information. But she said that last year Congress denied the bureau's request for money to collect information on e-commerce.
The task force also said that Congress should review American intellectual property laws so they match regulations in other countries.
Much of the patent system has been revamped recently to harmonize with laws in Europe and Japan, but the United States has failed for more than a decade to join an international treaty on trademarks, for example.
The task force also suggested that the Securities and Exchange Commission make it easier for companies to document investments in intangible assets. Most companies supported these ideas, though it was not always so.
"When we started, the corporate sector was split," she said. "The old-economy companies who felt they were undervalued by the market loved what we were doing because they wanted to be able to tell investors that they had intangible assets. But the high-tech sector wasn't as enthusiastic; they probably suspected they were overvalued by the market and didn't want to open that Pandora's box."
The split closed after the Nasdaq stock market began a significant decline last spring, she said. Now, she added, high-technology companies are eager to let investors know what they are doing.
"In this country, there are a lot of companies trying to develop ways of managing their intellectual property portfolios," Ms. Blair said. "It's going on big time in the corporate sector, there's tremendous money being thrown at consultants and Big Five accounting firms to help solve this problem."
The stakes are considerable. Combined, copyright industries like movies, television, books, music and home entertainment software now make up a larger share of the economy than manufacturing, chemical making, electronics or any other traditional industry does individually, according to the International Intellectual Property Alliance.
"Intellectual property is perhaps the hottest financial sector of the new economy," said Nir Kossovsky, co-founder of the Patent and License Exchange (www.pl-x.com), an online intellectual property brokerage firm.
"Monopolistic rights," he added, "are the only remaining form of sustainable competitive advantage. So from the point of view of business, intellectual property rights are the ultimate key success factor."
Still, putting a price on a patent can be tricky. One way is to measure the value of transactions that a property owner completes by using a patent or trademark, but that can understate the explosive growth of new markets and new technologies.
At the Patent and License Exchange, Mr. Kossovsky and his partners have developed a formula for appraising patents, a method they say is similar to a stock-market technique known as a call option.
But Mr. Kossovsky's method does not create the universal standards for assessing intellectual property that many business leaders would like and that Ms. Blair says may be necessary to prevent the economic turbulence that can result when companies are incorrectly valued.
. "Nobody wants to mess with a successful economy," she said, "but some of us are nervous about the increasing volatility of the stock market and the potential that what we are calling success is a bubble that could pop on us." As soon as possible, she added, executives, regulators and others need to cooperate on developing a standard acceptable to all.
"This report is our effort to get the policy-making community focused on this problem," Ms. Blair said of the Brookings task force's analysis. "Solving the problem will require significant rethinking at all levels. It's not a problem that business or government can solve alone."

SECTION: Section C; Page 14; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Among Wall St. Firms, the List of Those Left to Merge Shrinks

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Was that the last wave?
Three multibillion-dollar buyouts shook Wall Street this year, fulfilling predictions that banks would rush to snatch the remaining independent securities firms. The deals narrowed the longstanding divisions between banks and brokerage firms and widened the gap between the global giants of finance and their regional competitors. 
 With the list of available firms on Wall Street whittled to a few, the endgame in the competition to provide financial services to the biggest corporations and wealthiest individuals has arrived. In 2001 and beyond -- with most Wall Street firms feeling the pressure from a slowdown in trading and new stock offerings -- the survivors are expected to concentrate more on honing their strengths than on bulking up through the sort of acquisitions that transfixed Wall Street this year.
Within several months, the Swiss bank UBS bought the PaineWebber brokerage firm for $12 billion; Credit Suisse bought the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette investment bank for $13 billion; and then came the real stunner: Chase Manhattan agreed to buy the venerable J. P. Morgan for $32 billion, a deal that is expected to close before the end of the year.
There was a different strategic rationale behind each transaction, and each may have been possible without the legislative change late last year that repealed the Depression-era divisions between banks, investment banks and insurance companies that had been mandated by the Glass-Steagall Act. But a simple belief motivated each of the buyers: the view that size and global scale would be necessary to compete in a less-regulated financial services industry.
UBS, Credit Suisse and Chase Manhattan all want to be among the lasting group of global financial powerhouses, so they are bolstering themselves by paying big premiums for established competitors.
The three buyers each took advantage of the availability of an essentially freestanding firm, a dying breed on Wall Street. J. P. Morgan and PaineWebber were independent public companies and Donaldson's owner, the French financial conglomerate AXA, wanted to sell it.
"What we have seen is the last frenetic scramble for the big firms to position themselves as global top-tier companies," said Jerome Kenney, who plots corporate strategy for Merrill Lynch. Foreign banks rushed to capitalize on relaxed regulations about who could own what, and some American companies did not want to be left without a partner, he said.
"You can make a lot of money as a major investment bank, but the market can't support 50 of them," Mr. Kenney added.
Few analysts or financial executives think that the merger trend is over, but some say that they expect fewer marriages of convenience and more strategically focused transactions. They may be stating the obvious because, by most measures, only two major Wall Street firms of digestible size remain independent -- Lehman Brothers Holdings and the Bear Stearns Companies. But they argue that simply becoming bigger is not a panacea; what is more important is having a leading market share in core businesses.
"We're seeing a broad restructuring of the industry and the concentration on building critical mass, business by business," said Robert W. Stein, chairman of the global financial services industry practice at Ernst & Young. "We will continue to see financial services institutions positioning themselves to have a bigger presence in narrower and narrower markets."
Mr. Stein said the sale of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette was a prime example. Credit Suisse bought the firm, known as the leading underwriter of junk bonds, to broaden the offerings of its investment banking division, Credit Suisse First Boston.
Donaldson was on the block because AXA had decided to concentrate on the insurance and money management businesses and Donaldson "was not really compatible with them," Mr. Stein said. But that type of consolidation was not the focal point of the revision of the financial services law. That measure, known as Gramm-Leach-Bliley, was passed by Congress at the end of 1999 and paved the way for the convergence of various services, including banking, brokerage and insurance businesses.
In fact, the biggest convergence of all, the formation of Citigroup, was forged before the repeal of Glass-Steagall on the assumption that the repeal legislation would eventually pass. When Citicorp, the nation's biggest banking company, announced plans to merge with Travelers, a big insurance and brokerage company, many analysts heralded that deal as a sign of things to come in the consolidation of financial institutions. But, while there has been a rush to grab the remaining midsize firms on Wall Street, none of the transactions has much resembled the Citigroup deal.
"I don't see this as a race," said Rocco Maggiotto, head of strategic planning for PricewaterhouseCoopers. "At various times, the strategy, the available currency and the price come together."
Whether that confluence can continue with the financial markets in a pronounced slump is unclear, Mr. Maggiotto said. In a more uncertain economy, firms will probably be more inclined to test relationships through alliances and joint ventures before plunging headlong into a merger, he added.
As a example of such a relationship, he pointed to the nascent venture between Merrill Lynch, the nation's largest brokerage firm, and HSBC, the London-based banking company. They are joining forces to offer online banking and brokerage services in Canada and in several European countries.
Some analysts see the arrangement as a possible prelude to an acquisition of Merrill by HSBC, though executives of both companies have denied that. James Gorman, a former McKinsey consultant who is now a Merrill executive, said the joint venture represented the way financial services firms were going to do deals.
For its part, Merrill has sat out the latest round of the consolidation game. It has made acquisitions to strengthen its mutual fund and stock-trading operations but has not bought any banks or insurance companies and has rebuffed overtures from potential acquirers, like Chase Manhattan.
Mr. Kenney has been predicting for years that there will eventually be as few as seven global banking firms. After this year's mergers, he said, there will be eight: UBS, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, Merrill and the combined J. P. Morgan-Chase.
That group has formed around one of the main axes of financial services -- combining banking, securities and money management, Mr. Kenney said. Along the other axis are companies that will concentrate on insurance and asset management, like AXA and Allianz of Germany.
Citigroup looks more and more like an anomalous hybrid, with its emphasis on cross-selling to its various customers everything from life insurance to mutual funds to credit cards. Citigroup executives maintain that cross-selling is working, but many analysts now argue that the most successful approach will be to build lasting relationships with customers by providing what they want, how they want it.

PUB-DATE: December 18, 2000

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1811 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Exposing the Fraying Edges in the Fabric of the Economy

 BODY:
The American economic expansion, already the longest on record, is nearing its 10th birthday, and while growth has slowed, economists generally expect a "soft landing" that will avert a recession.
But the fact that things have gone so well for so long does not mean there are no risks. We asked the four people who rotate in writing the Economic Scene column that appears on Thursdays to ponder a simple question: What factors pose the greatest threat to our nation's prosperity in 2001? Their answers varied, ranging from worry over a possible decline in the dollar to concern about the potentially stifling impact that new regulations might have on growth. 
 Here are their responses:
 
HAL R. VARIAN -- Economics professor and dean of the School of Information Management and Systems at the University of California at Berkeley.
Economists aren't known for their optimism. We more often see clouds where others find the silver linings.
On the eve of 2001, I see four economic clouds facing the United States economy: the downward trend of the stock market; signs of less-than-robust retail sales; the overvalued dollar and the resulting current account deficit; and the high personal and corporate debt burden.
None of these is a big problem on its own, but the combination could be deadly. A pessimistic scenario begins with a plunge in the stock market, leading to a significant drop in consumer spending. Foreign investors liquidate their positions, causing a further fall in the stock market and precipitating a run on the dollar. Overextended consumers and corporate borrowers experience financial distress, damping down spending even more, which leads to a full-fledged recession.
That's the nightmare scenario. In truth, each of these risk factors does have a positive side. An optimist could argue that the market is simply coming back to reality after its high-tech binge. And retail sales may not be growing as fast as last year, but their growth is still significantly above long-term averages. The dollar does appear to be unusually strong, but, if it weakens, exports would become more competitive, improving the balance of trade and keeping unemployment down. Finally, some economists argue that the household savings rate is mismeasured since retained capital gains are not counted as part of savings; if you add them in, the private savings rate is quite high by historical standards.
The sole remaining cloud is corporate debt. Capitalist economies have a long history of overinvestment in hot new technologies. In the 1880's, more miles of railroad track were laid than in any other decade of American history. In the 1890's, the resulting excess capacity led to more miles of track in bankruptcy than in any other decade in American history. In the 1990's, we have seen huge investments in information technology, with much of the infrastructure investment being debt-financed. We are already seeing signs of excess capacity in long-haul fiber optics. Will telecommunications infrastructure suffer the same fate as the railroads?
 
ALAN B. KRUEGER -- Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives.
The United States economy has performed extraordinarily well the last nine years, and the most plausible forecast is for continued growth, albeit at a slower pace. Nevertheless, there are two main potential threats to economic prosperity, one gradual and the other sudden. The gradual threat is a return to the slower productivity growth of the 1970's and 1980's; the sudden one is a loss of foreign investor confidence.
Due to the wonders of compound interest, in the long run productivity growth is virtually everything. The United States economy has boomed because output per hour worked grew 3 percent a year since 1995 -- twice as fast as in the preceding 20 years. Despite claims about oil shocks causing the 1970's slowdown and information technology causing the 1990's boom, no one knows for sure the origins of either. Productivity growth could slow again. If it grows by 1.5 percent a year over the next decade instead of 3 percent, national income will be nearly 20 percent less.
Not only banana republics can suffer sudden losses in investor confidence and sharp swings in exchange rates. The current account deficit -- the net flow of trade and investment income to the United States -- surged past 4 percent of gross domestic product this year, a record level. Foreign investors financed our $400 billion current account deficit. Hardly anyone believes this situation is sustainable.
Economists Maurice Obstfeld of the University of California at Berkeley and Kenneth Rogoff of Harvard sketch out what would happen to the dollar if the current account deficit returned to balance, and the results are not pretty. The dollar could fall by as much as the Mexican peso did in 1995. And in our case, the downside could be even greater because there is no international monetary authority that is large enough to bail us out. Inflation would rise and output contract.
What could precipitate such an event? President-elect George W. Bush could try to unite the country after the divisive election by delivering a large tax cut and expensive prescription drug plan, shattering the budget discipline of the late 1990's.
Although a sudden withdrawal of foreign investment is unlikely, a lesson of the Long-Term Capital Management collapse in 1998 is that nine standard deviation events -- that is, statistical long shots -- do sometimes occur.
 
VIRGINIA POSTREL Editor at large of Reason magazine and author of "The Future and Its Enemies: The Growing Conflict Over Creativity, Enterprise and Progress."
The economy is slowing, with consumer spending, stock prices and new-economy hype all down from their recent highs. The question is whether this slowdown represents an inevitable correction -- a healthy pause before another upward trend -- or the beginning of a serious slump.
Both long-term productivity growth and short-term resilience depend on how creative and adaptable private enterprises are. This is partly an issue of management. Executives shaped by good times have different skills and instincts from those who developed during downturns, and it is often difficult to adapt to new circumstances.
The range of available options also matters, however, and here government policy makes a tremendous difference. Regulatory mandates, often passed in good times, bite more when economic growth slows. And they, in turn, reduce growth-enhancing investment, feeding a vicious cycle.
A $1 minimum wage hike passed when business is booming and labor is short throws few people out of work. But when the time comes for belt-tightening, the extra $40 a week, plus related payroll taxes, will lead to layoffs and aggravate the slowdown.
Similarly, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's controversial new ergonomics regulations will divert billions of dollars into redesigning work spaces and buying new equipment. The $20 billion that United Parcel Service estimates it will have to spend upfront to comply will not be available for new trucks, planes or tracking systems or for employee raises. If the law requires people to worry about ergonomics instead of sales or service, they will do so, but productivity will inevitably be hurt.
Year-end wrangling between Congress and the White House has blocked the latest minimum wage hike, although several states have passed their own. Opponents are challenging the OSHA standards in court. It's possible, though unlikely, that neither will survive. Economic downturns exercise a powerful check on regulatory overreach.
In a sunnier economic scenario, we will see conflicts between new business models -- representing growth rather than belt-tightening -- and existing or proposed regulations. Already, Internet businesses have collided with state restrictions on competition in businesses from optometry to auto sales. The Federal Trade Commission is under increasing pressure to impose a single regulatory standard on data gathered online. And we can expect continued culture wars over biotechnology.
Whether setting limits on growing new businesses or restricting struggling old ones, regulatory expansion poses the greatest long-term threat to economic prosperity.
 
JEFF MADRICK -- Editor of Challenge Magazine and adjunct professor of social sciences at Cooper Union.
Despite rapid growth over the past five years, we are often told these days that the American economy is remarkably well balanced. What this usually means is that, in contrast to the 1980's, federal and local government spending has been held well within the nation's means to pay. But such an analysis has an eye cast dangerously to the past.
Odds are still that America will survive 2001 without a recession. But make no mistake about it: there are economic imbalances that could turn a slowdown into a more painful downturn.
There are two related concerns. Because we save so little and borrow so much, America has become dependent on a high value for the dollar in order to attract needed capital. The high dollar also helped keep inflation down by keeping import prices low. A new study by the New York Federal Reserve Bank finds that the subdued level of inflation in the late 1990's, in fact, was largely due to low import prices.
But if the economy slows and stock prices continue to perform poorly, investors may withdraw their capital and sell the dollar. Under such circumstances, the Federal Reserve, fearing that a falling dollar will provoke higher inflation even as the economy is slowing, may keep interest rates higher than it otherwise would in order to attract dollar buyers. Just when we need lower interest rates to stimulate the economy, the Fed might well find its hands tied. The dollar fell by 40 percent in the 1980's.
The second problem is that while the federal government is generating budget surpluses, both individuals and corporations are borrowing in record amounts. This has provided the stimulus to consumer demand and capital investment that has allowed the economy to grow so rapidly. But if personal income and profits grow more slowly, and if interest rates rise, the proportion of funds that must be allocated to debt service will rise. This will leave less to spend and invest.
Given falling stock prices, higher oil prices and tightened credit, a significant slowdown in economic growth is a growing likelihood. At such a point, the economic imbalances, so easily dismissed in a time of prosperity, could take a serious toll. The last five years have provided one pleasant surprise after another, but the economy in 2001 is likely to be highly delicate. Managing it will be more difficult than in the recent past.

SECTION: Section C; Page 26; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1529 words

HEADLINE: REFLECTIONS;
From Well-Wired Offices, Musings on Tomorrow's Technologies

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
These people see the future every day.
For the most part, they are quite young. They are universally precocious. And their very livelihoods revolve around reading, thinking and talking about stuff most of us might consider fanciful, bordering on incomprehensible. 
 So when they were asked to finish the thought, "I can't wait for the day when . . .," some of the responses were far from prosaic. Others qualify as laments for remedies to life as we know it.
Here is a sample of what a group of America's best and brightest young business types are hoping for.
 
ERIC E. SCHMIDT -- Chief executive of Novell Inc.
At age 45, Eric E. Schmidt is hardly over the hill. But his body is talking to him.
"I can't wait until I can replace all these aging body parts," he said. "And if you look at organ cloning, it is reasonable to expect that in the next 20 to 30 years we will be able to do that."
Dr. Schmidt, who presides over the software company Novell from its headquarters in Provo, Utah, also talked about something he said would happen much faster.
"I can't wait for the day when there are 50,000 video channels on the Internet and I don't have to have a television and a personal computer on at the same time," he said. "That is a viable possibility next year."
 
LARRY PAGE -- Chief executive of Google.
As co-founder and head of Google, the soon-to-be public Internet portal company based in Mountain View, Calif., Larry Page, 27, said, "I spend a lot of time thinking about what should be, as an inventor."
In a sense, what Mr. Page can't wait to happen is already taking place.
"As computers get faster and faster, the effect that will have on the world will be pretty extreme," he said. "The complete readout of a person's DNA will fit on a CD-ROM."
At Google, "we already have 100 times the disk space to store what is on the World Wide Web," he said. "That is sort of mind-boggling to me. As computer capacity and speed increases, they will have the ability to do more and more things."
 
JIM BREYER -- Managing partner of Accel Partners.
Accel Partners, a venture capital firm based in Palo Alto, Calif., receives 25,000 business plans a year. But Jim Breyer, its 39-year-old managing partner, has a fairly straightforward vision.
"I can't wait for the distinction between the old economy and the new economy to disappear entirely," he said. "I live in a world that is ground zero of the Internet. And in the past three years we have lived in pretty frothy times. But the real power of the Internet is when it is married to the very best of the old economy."
Education and entertainment are two areas where the marriage between the old and the new is likely to be consummated quite soon, Mr. Breyer said.
"The music and entertainment businesses are being fundamentally transformed by the Net," he said. "Napster and RealNetworks are doing this."
"In the newspaper, publishing and magazine world, the marriage of the Net with the old economy provides fundamentally better and more interesting information to consumers than either can individually.
"I also look forward to the day when investors believe there are good businesses to be built to improve the education system. I am looking forward to a decade when people look at investing in education the way they invested in health care in the 1980's. Old economy and new economy ideas can fundamentally target the education system and improve the education experience in this country."
 
DONNA M. IUCOLANO -- Executive vice president of the Scholastic Internet Group.
In her capacity as an executive with the online division of the New York-based Scholastic Corporation, the world's largest publisher of children's books, Donna M. Iucolano has personal and professional hopes for the not-too-distant future.
"I can't wait for the day when you hit the submit button on an Internet order and the U.P.S. man is almost instantaneously on the porch," she said.
Ms. Iucolano, 37, has a more realistic professional aspiration.
"From a Scholastic point of view, I can't wait for the day when every child has a computer on their desk," she said.
"I would love to think that is going to happen in the next year or so, but three years out is a more realistic target."
Ms. Iucolano acknowledged that universal access to computers would not be a panacea for the educational system's shortcomings. But she said it would transform the educational experience in important ways.
"It will allow for a lot more collaboration in learning, through Intranet activities and through the Internet, not only locally but around the world," she said.
"Peer-to-peer activities can happen much more in real time or as a natural part of the day as opposed to now, when there is a designated time to use the computer."
 
GEOFFREY BAEHR -- Chief network officer for Sun Microsystems.
Geoffrey Baehr is suffering from data overload.
"I can't wait for the day when there are tools to sift, analyze and adapt the data to my job, my function, my life," said Mr. Baehr, 43, the chief network officer at Sun Microsystems of Palo Alto, Calif. Sun is a leading provider of hardware, software and services that power the Internet, and Mr. Baehr, as chief network officer, is in charge of the company's computer networks. At the moment, "the signal-to-noise ratio is going down precipitously," he said.
"I can't wait for the day when there is a relevancy test on the data that I get. I think 5 percent of the data floating around the world is valuable, and the rest is junk."
 
JUDY NEUMAN -- Operating partner of Maveron L.L.C.
Judy Neuman is a thoroughly modern executive who dearly wants to simplify her life as an operating partner at Maveron, a venture capital firm based in Seattle.
"I can't wait for the day when I have one device that is fully voice-enabled so I never have to look at a phone number to make a call, a machine that could provide real-time e-mail, wireless access to the Web, be a cell phone and come with all the accouterments of a Palm Pilot or Blackberry," she said.
"Clearly, people are trying to get there. But in the meantime my purse -- and my life -- is complicated because I have all these technological accouterments."
Ms. Neuman, 43, said she expected a device that could do all this to be available on a limited basis "within no more" than 18 months. "It is a race to see who comes up with this first," she said. "This device would transform a consumer's life."
 
JONATHAN M. ROTHBERG -- Chairman and chief executive of CuraGen.
The 37-year-old head of CuraGen, a genomics company based in New Haven, said he could not wait for the development of drugs that will wipe out a number of deadly diseases. That will start to happen in five to seven years, he said.
"We feel confident that over that time frame we will be marching through the genome and pulling out cures for unmet needs, developing protein drugs and antibody drugs that can knock out diseases like cancer and late-onset diabetes. The hint of that reality is on us right now."
"The first drugs will be proteins right from our bodies," he said. "And in the next five to seven years we will have them. It is different, and it will be a big deal."
 
CYRUS L. HARMON -- General manager of Affymetrix.
The first two items on Cyrus Harmon's wish list are a bit removed from his professional life at Affymetrix, a Santa Clara, Calif., genomics company where he is vice president for computation genomics as well as the general manager.
"I can't wait for the day when we have a cell phone that works everywhere in the world, one with one number that can be reached anywhere. That would be great."
Addressing a quality-of-life issue also ranks high. "I am waiting for the day when we recognize as a society what a destructive force traffic is and build a transportation system that deals with it," said Mr. Harmon, who just turned 30. "In the Bay Area, the problem has gotten worse and worse."
Like Dr. Rothberg, Mr. Harmon sees big things coming from the mapping of the human genome.
"We have been traveling down the curve in the progression of medicine from art to science since the time of the Greeks," he said. "The pace toward science has been accelerating rapidly over the last 25 years. Computing power, communications and information in the genome are seeing another re-acceleration along that curve.
"In the next three to five years, we will be able to measure every single cell in a human and understand what is going on in those cells. Once we have this, we will be able to utilize it to better stratify disease."
Mr. Harmon is also excited about nanotechnology, manufacturing things on a molecular basis. "People are now figuring out how to make gears, levers and motors and bearings on a scale that is infinitesimally small," he said. "Medical devices are straightforward applications, machines that target cardiac muscle cells. But even outside the medical realm, it will revolutionize a lot of products we manufacture. But that is too far out. Thirty years from now we will look back and see how nanotechnology has changed the world."

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2081 words

HEADLINE: REFLECTIONS;
Brooding Over Shifts On Main Street and Wall Street

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
THE world of business has changed remarkably in the past quarter century. AT&T is preparing its third split-up, while the government seeks to break up Microsoft, a company that did not even exist then. The Internet has opened vistas for business that no one saw even a decade ago, and the United States is in its longest period of economic expansion ever.
But amid the progress, what has been lost that was worthwhile? We asked several people who used to be at the heights of different aspects of business to assess what they regretted most about the changes that have occurred. They singled out situations ranging from the new "villainy" of globalization to the lack of real thoughtfulness now given to investments. 
 Following are their responses:
 
RICHARD J. MAHONEY -- Former chief executive of the Monsanto Company; now Distinguished Executive in Residence, the Weidenbaum Center, Washington University.
Americans doing business in developing countries in the 1970's, 1980's and even into the early 1990's were generally welcome partners. We brought the desired technology, market access, management skills and money for investment. I recall being the subject of local newspaper photo-ops to celebrate the opening of a new facility or the establishment of a technology collaboration with a local partner.
As the 1990's progressed, however, the headlines changed from collaboration to exploitation with the appearance of a villain called globalization. To be sure, the business parties and government officials still found the agreements attractive, but opposition emerged, particularly in the "have" countries among groups protesting the exploitation of the "have nots."
Facts were not necessarily important; appearance was -- the appearance of exploitation, whether in local wages paid, farm-cropping practices exported, Western culture "imposed" or a host of other issues that were embodied at the wild gathering of international trade protesters during the W.T.O. meeting in Seattle last year.
In the early 1990's, I received an award and an ovation following a speech I made describing the promise of agricultural biotechnology to feed the world. My successor as C.E.O. in the late 1990's received a pie in the face from a protester at a similar forum. What a difference those few years have made.
No doubt we paid too little attention to potential public reaction as we in the industry made our program more international, urged on by our trading partners in the developing world. Perhaps we should have seen that the same technology that brought instantaneous trading around the world would foster instantaneous "anti" communication and organizing.
Whatever the cause of the rise of opposition, it is here to stay, a cynic would say, as long as strong economies and rising living standards provide the luxury of protest. But I think it will be even longer than that.
Still, one yearns to return to a time when enlightened self-interest -- doing well by doing good in helping to raise living standards -- was considered progressive instead of profligate. A time when the results of world trade were considered glorious rather than globaloney. Alas.
 
ROBERT L. CRANDALL -- Retired chairman of American Airlines; now board member of American Express and Celestica.
The thing I miss most today is political civility. Twenty or 25 years ago, political conversation tended to be a good deal more issues-oriented and much less partisan and much less personally bitter.
The acrimony and the incivility and the outright dishonesty that is beginning to characterize political life is causing the American public to lose faith in its government. I think that's a great loss. We need to believe what our government officials say. They need to be both a good deal more forthright and more forthcoming.
I don't know when it really started. I certainly think Watergate was a seminal event. But the lack of civility is now affecting every aspect of American life. It affects the business climate and endangers important issues -- the status of Social Security, the status of Medicare, the real need for a certain level of taxation. These are things about which we have to make decisions that have very long-term implications for the economy and, thus, for the business community, and we are no longer capable of having the kind of public debate in the examination of these issues that we had in years past.
I'm not talking about moderating the level of competition. I think vigorous competition is a good thing. I don't think airline executives are any more uncivil; in fact, the business community as a whole, I think, continues to have a much greater ability for civilized dialogue than does the political community.
We've got to get back to circumstances where we can have an intelligent, civil dialogue about major public policy issues.
 
WALTER B. WRISTON -- Retired chairman of Citibank; now a private business consultant.
What one longs for is the return of trust, trust in our government, trust in the judicial system, trust in what we read in the paper, hear on the radio and see on television. Today the old newspaper mantra of who, what, when and where in many cases has been replaced by a little editorial built into each story reflecting the political or social bias of the reporter. While we are overwhelmed by information from the media, our trust in its accuracy is diminished.
A similar situation occurs when the spin doctors of all political stripes inform us of their version of events and the spins are picked up and magnified by the media until many Americans simply tune out. While political hyperbole is not new, its volume and quantity have eroded public trust.
Trust is the glue that holds society together, and when it is lost strange things happen, none of them good. True, politics has always engendered the spurious statement, but never on the scale of today's outpouring. Consider just one example: Social Security is going broke; Social Security is in great shape until 2030; Social Security will not be paid to our children; and so on. The elderly become frightened and the young believe they will never see a benefit. After a while, people cease to listen, which in a republic like ours is a dangerous thing.
Trust can be reclaimed, and I have no doubt that over time it will be. But in the meantime it is much missed.
 
PETER S. LYNCH -- Former manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund; now vice chairman, Fidelity Management and Research Company.
There was a time when people were more careful with their investments. Of course, there have always been some who gambled and speculated, maybe by buying options or trying to guess the market's direction.
But I miss the time when people really thought they bought Dow Chemical or Kodak or Johnson & Johnson. They planned to hold on, not pig-headedly but because they thought the company over time would be great. That method was a winning formula 50 and 20 years ago -- and I think it would still be 20 years from now.
Part of the reason this has changed is that people who choose to use a broker often do not take full advantage of the broker's knowledge. There was a time when people treated their stockbroker like they treated the doctor, the lawyer, the accountant. They would come in with a harebrained idea and he would tell them so.
But many people buying stocks now are not giving quality time to their portfolio. The fact that brokerage commissions have gotten so cheap may contribute to this. But it may also work the other way, providing less incentive for some brokers to develop sound relationships with customers.
Stocks are not lottery tickets. If companies do well, you'll do well. My best stocks have been ones that performed solidly in the third, fourth or fifth years I've owned them, not in the third or fourth days or weeks. People today are trying for too much; they're saying, my gosh, this is Wednesday and I haven't bought anything yet this week.
You ought to be able to explain to a third grader why you own a company. Do the same research as you would when you buy a house or car. And with all this technology, especially the Internet, it's never been easier to do the research. People ought to use the technology to enhance their knowledge of what they own and why they own it, whether they invest online or with a broker. But a lot of people use the Internet to buy 10 stocks a day and sell 10 stocks a day, becoming day traders. And you get the same results you would get at a casino -- with more paperwork.
 
JOAN GANZ COONEY -- Co-founder and former chief executive of the Children's Television Workshop; now chairman, executive committee, Sesame Workshop (formerly CTW).
There was a period in America not so long ago when American corporations were very much a part of our daily lives, not just their products but their names. It was during the 1950's and early 1960's, and the medium that made corporate names literally household words was television.
In those days, there were only two networks that really mattered, NBC and CBS, and there was no cable. A single sponsor brought into the home most of the quality drama as well as music shows and comedy hours. There was the U.S. Steel Hour, Kraft Theater, Westinghouse Presents Studio One, Philco Playhouse, Firestone Music Hour, Colgate Comedy Hour, Texaco Star Theater with Milton Berle and many more. The names of major corporations were on the lips of everyone who watched television -- as in, "Did you see Armstrong Circle Theater last night?"
In that time, corporate C.E.O.'s were also far more active in public policy than today. They felt they had a public duty to be involved in national or civic matters. John McCloy at Chase, for instance, had been High Commissioner of Germany. Charlie Wilson at General Motors told senators that "What was good for our country was good for General Motors, and vice versa." Ben Fairless at US Steel was an iconic figure.
Today, I don't think the average citizen knows very much about the corporations and their C.E.O.'s, except perhaps about Bill Gates of Microsoft. For one thing, so many C.E.O.'s are replaced quickly if they don't produce results. Corporations, meanwhile, lost the cachet that came from sponsoring a television show when multiple sponsors became the norm and such an endeavor became prohibitively expensive.
In the '50s, there was almost a small-town quality to the country in which individuals felt a connection to the nation's corporations, a sense of community with them. That has gone, and I miss it.
 
BOONE PICKENS -- Founder and former chairman of Mesa Petroleum; now chief executive, the Pickens Fuel Corporation and Mesa Water.
After 50 years in the oil and gas business, I'd like to reminisce about America's comprehensive energy policy. Sadly, I can't recall what's never been.
Although we've had a couple of attempts, specifically misguided programs during the Carter administration and global strategies that were good for the country but bad for the industry in the Reagan years, over all this nation has wallowed in energy policy rhetoric for decades.
Meanwhile, its dependence on foreign oil has skyrocketed. In 1973, the United States relied on foreign sources for 36 percent of its oil; today, that figure is 56 percent, the highest ever and climbing. We remain particularly vulnerable because our two primary suppliers of oil, the Middle East and Venezuela, are relatively unstable. The Saudis, in particular, do not have the production capacity to effectively serve as a swing producer to the extent they have in the past. That leaves Iraq with a trump card over world market stability.
Separately, our infrastructure needs are changing. This country continues its transition to a service- and technology-based economy. Electricity fuels the superhighways of this new economy. While base demands are shifting, the oil and gas industry remains as important as ever.
In short, America must shape a coherent national policy. Develop an accelerated program for pipelines to bring abundant natural gas supplies from the Arctic coastal plains through the Northwest Territories, allot significant government research funds for alternative fuel development and institute more aggressive conservation efforts.
Granted, this is prickly political ground. Democrats and Republicans alike have failed to address this issue, but neither party can afford to any longer.

SECTION: Section C; Page 14; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 787 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Few Banks or Insurers Capitalize on Their New Freedom to Merge

BYLINE: By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
It is hard to remember now, but one of the driving forces behind the financial services overhaul bill that Congress passed in November 1999 was the $70 billion merger between Citicorp and the insurer Travelers Group to form Citigroup. The deal, which closed in 1998, involved a successful bet that mergers between insurance companies and banks, prohibited under the Glass-Steagall Act, would soon be allowed.
A year later, however, no large United States banks or insurers have teamed up to create their own version of Citigroup. Most insurance companies are too small to try acquisitions themselves. More important, the overhaul of financial services came amid a slump in bank stocks, denying banks the currency to finance deals. 
 Bank stocks have been volatile this year and, even with some recent gains, are now down more than 10 percent from their highs in April 1999, according to a Keefe, Bruyette & Woods index.
Some analysts question just how attractive a business underwriting insurance is for banks. "Banks think of life insurance as a slow-growth, low-return-equity business, and the property-casualty underwriting business is too volatile," said Ronald Mandle, an banking analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein. "If banks were going to buy something, it would be in asset management and capital markets because those are closer fits with their existing businesses."
It is important to remember, Mr. Mandle added, that when Travelers merged with Citicorp, insurance was only part of its business mix; it also had a brokerage division in Salomon Smith Barney and an asset-management business. Today, insurance accounts for just 20 percent of Citigroup's profits over all.
Clearly, many banks have other priorities these days, as a downward shift in the credit cycle has hurt their core business. The Bank One Corporation, struggling to overhaul its banking and credit card franchises, acquired a small insurance company, Congress Life Insurance, in November. But near term, Bank One, which will underwrite just $300 million and sell $2.4 billion in insurance this year, will generally offer only a select number of insurance products to its correspondent banks or to small companies that do business with it.
To engage fully in the insurance business, Bank One would need to ask the Federal Reserve to regulate it as a financial holding company, as opposed to its current status as a bank holding company. Such a change is not a priority right now, said Thomas Kelly, a Bank One spokesman. "We've got bigger issues," he said.
Still, as their stocks recover, some of the larger banks are expected to take an interest in life insurance, which, through the sale of annuities, provides a backdoor way into money management.
Some might want to follow the lead of ING Group, the Dutch financial services company, which has been one of the few companies to undertake sizable insurance acquisitions this year. In May, ING bought the ReliaStar Financial Corporation, the eighth-largest publicly traded insurer, for $6.1 billion, and announced in July that it was buying Aetna's financial services and international units for $7.7 billion. The deals made ING the 11th-largest asset manager worldwide, according to company figures, up from 19th.
"Virtually all the deals we've seen so far have been by foreign acquirers," said H. Rodgin Cohen, chairman of the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell, which has been active in financial services deals.
Their stock prices have also held up better: ING is trading at 20 times this year's estimated earnings, compared with price-to-earnings multiples in the low teens for banks in the United States. There is also a scarcity value to the life insurance business. There are only six publicly traded life insurers with market capitalizations of $5 billion or greater that could be acquired, according to Ronald McIntosh, an analyst following the life insurance industry at Fox-Pitt Kelton, a brokerage firm specializing in financial services.
Insurance companies, meanwhile, have been making tiny inroads into the banking business, mostly by starting banks from scratch. Forty insurance companies have been granted savings and loan charters since 1997, according to the Office of Thrift Supervision, with five more applications pending.
But one insurance company is likely to be an active acquirer, said Mr. McIntosh. MetLife Inc., which went public in March and has a market capitalization of $26 billion, announced earlier this year that it planned to get into the banking business, either by acquisition or by building a new operation. "They are the only one big enough to survive" any takeover attempt, Mr. McIntosh said, "and they will undoubtedly get bigger."

SECTION: Section C; Page 23; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1253 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Weak Since Birth, the Euro Seems Poised for a Growth Phase

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
Finally, after two years of nearly nonstop decline, Europe's fledgling unified currency may now be coming into its own. But will the same be true for Europe itself? Forecasting a recovery for the euro has thus far been the monetary equivalent of waiting for Godot. Since it was adopted as a common currency by 11 nations on New Year's Day 1999, the euro has lost about one-quarter of its value against the dollar and even more against the Japanese yen.
Now the winds are shifting. Amid evidence that the United States faces what could be a sharp slowdown in economic growth, many economists said they believed that European and American growth rates would be more or less on par with one another for the first time in many years. If one believes the most recent economic forecasts, growth is likely to settle in around 3 percent on both sides of the Atlantic. That would be a big slowdown for the United States, but a solid year for Europe. 
 The euro is already showing signs of new life. It climbed nearly 5 percent in early December, after new data showed American growth might be slowing much more abruptly than previously expected. And while the euro may slip a few more times, most analysts are now convinced that it is poised for at least a partial rebound.
A big part of the euro's decline stemmed from the much faster growth rate in the United States, which made the nation a magnet for international investment. The huge net capital flows into the United States overwhelmed virtually all efforts by the European Central Bank to shore up its beleaguered currency.
Now, the United States growth suddenly looks more dubious and the euphoria about Internet and technology stocks has soured. Beyond simply worrying about an American slowdown, some analysts say that investors are backing away from riskier investments over all. And that means pulling back from a broad spectrum of dollar investments, from dot-com stocks to high-yield junk bonds.
"It's not so much that Europe is cheap," said Jesper Dannesboe, chief currency analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson in London. "It is that people are becoming more risk averse."
The challenge for European countries this year is to keep growing even if its rival on the other side of the Atlantic threatens to become seriously winded.
It will not be easy. European industrial confidence, an important leading indicator, has declined for the last several months. In Germany, Europe's biggest economy, industrial production appears to be slowing down. The stock markets, another important leading indicator, have fallen almost as sharply here as in the United States.
In another disconcerting echo of past patterns, European growth remains dependent on exports.
Thanks to high oil prices and high taxes, consumer spending continues to be lackluster in many countries. If foreign demand for heavy industrial equipment declines sharply, as it did during the Asian crisis, recent hard-won gains in job creation could easily disappear.
And there have been significant gains in jobs. Unemployment across Europe has dropped from about 12 percent in 1997 to 9 percent at the end of 2000. Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands and Ireland are acutely short of workers in many areas. French unemployment has dropped from more than 12 percent two years ago to less than 10 percent. Germany is now recruiting skilled workers from India, though unemployment is nearly 8 percent in western Germany and more than 15 percent in the east.
There are other reasons to be optimisticabout the longer term. Europe is undeniably changing in fundamental ways, and most of those changes are good for long-term economic growth -- and for the euro. European conglomerates are putting themselves through remarkable restructuring efforts -- buying and selling businesses to focus their strategies, setting more ambitious goals for profitability and making themselves much more responsive to outside shareholders.
Europe's labor markets, which have been criticized for years as overpriced and rigid, have changed as well. Even though demand for workers has increased sharply, real wages have remained flat or even declined in some areas. And though Europe still looks like a bastion of strong unions and tough job-protection rules, temporary and part-time workers now occupy about 30 percent of jobs in the private sector.
"The fact here is that, despite the reluctance of most governments to liberalize their domestic labor markets, economic forces have done the job on their behalf," Eric Chaney, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in London, wrote in a report in late October.
Political reform has been much slower than corporate reform, but here, too, there are changes. Germany, France and Italy have both pushed through significant tax cuts that will leave a little more money in people's pockets next year. Though tax rates in Europe will remain far higher than in the United States for a long time to come, the trend is toward relief.
Among corporations, the trend toward greater openness is unmistakable. Many of Europe's biggest companies -- from Deutsche Bank and DaimlerChrysler to BASF -- are now listed on the New York Stock Exchange and report their earnings in conformance with generally accepted accounting principles or international accounting standards.
European companies that once raised working capital by getting loans from their local banks are now selling bonds to international investors. That, in turn, means that companies are opening themselves up to the scrutiny of international rating agencies like Standard & Poor's and Moody's.
The number of European industrial corporations rated by Standard & Poor's has climbed 38 percent since the spring of 1999.The volume of European corporate bonds has more than doubled, from $96.6 billion for all of 1998 to $207.7 billion in the first nine months of 2000.
"We are seeing a standardization in the quality and quantity of information," said Agnes de Petigny, head of corporate ratings in Europe for Standard & Poor's. The move to bonds forces companies to be more transparent.
"It is one thing to talk to a few banks, and another to talk to several hundred investors you don't know at all," she added. "That really has forced European companies to talk to ratings agencies, to go out on road shows and to meet with investors."
In pursuit of greater focus and fresher strategies, companies have also been overhauling their corporate structures at a remarkable pace. Almost all the old chemical and pharmaceutical conglomerates have been selling off businesses that do not fit well while buying others that do. Thanks to deregulation, Europe's telecommunications companies and electric utilities are becoming steadily more competitive as they attack each other's territories and look for new areas of expansion.
European companies are also investing more heavily in technology. Jean-Francois Mercier, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney, estimates that European companies increased their spending on new equipment by as much as 8 percent last year and will increase it by as much as 5.5 percent next year.
None of that means that either Europe or the euro have been liberated from the past. But the combination of changes has made at least some analysts more confident.
"The U.S. is likely to be more volatile that Europe," said Holger Schmieding, Merrill Lynch's head of European economics in London. "Europe just isn't as vulnerable as it was in the past."

SECTION: Section C; Page 6; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1319 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
The Challenge for Utilities: Increase Capacity and Efficiency

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
The nation hit its biggest pothole yet on the long road to deregulation of the utility industry this past summer when electricity shortages in California sent wholesale power prices soaring.
Stunned consumers revolted as the local utility in San Diego passed the costs on to them, and other utilities in the state sought permission to do the same in their areas of service. Politicians blasted the industry, and regulators were plunged into what promises to be a lengthy battle over proposed price controls and other measures to ease the pain. 
 The controversy intensified in recent weeks when prices soared again and the state faced blackout threats, driven in part by reduced supplies when some power plants closed for seasonal maintenance and others were shut down to comply with air pollution regulations. The crisis threatened to spill into the Pacific Northwest when California, in a contrast to past years, was unable to send power north to help meet the demand for electric heat.
"California has slowed deregulation in all the states that haven't gone through it yet," said Andrew Levi, who follows the industry for Credit Suisse First Boston. "California is somewhat of a unique situation, but it doesn't bode well for the rest of the nation."
Such comments reflect Wall Street's view that any attempt to shield consumers from market forces sends the wrong signal to both consumers and investors and can only delay the investments needed to bolster supplies. But even backers of deregulation acknowledge that California's deregulation plans, like many others, had assumed that there would be enough electric power around for prices to fall. They admit that too little thought had been given to what would happen with shortages.
Thus, many analysts expect deregulation advocates to pay more attention to consumer protection measures for the next couple of years. Such measures could include offering homeowners and small businesses contracts similar to those in the home-heating market where fuel oil companies guarantee prices for the coming winter in return for prepayments. Others might tie pricing to varying levels of service, allowing consumers to pay lower bills in return for accepting the utility's right to cut off air-conditioning or other appliances when power supplies are tight.
The deregulation movement may also become bogged down next year in continued uncertainty about how to handle the transmission grid. The core of the grid is a huge network of high-voltage lines that was built to bolster local power reliability but is now the interstate highway for trading vast amounts of power.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has ordered all utilities that own transmission lines to come up with plans to put them under control of regional transmission authorities to ensure open access, but details of how the grid will be administered and improved are very much up in the air.
One reason for the uncertainty is that the commission itself may undergo big changes next year. The term of its chairman, James J. Hoecker, a Democrat, ends June 30. One commissioner's spot is vacant and one is already in Republican hands, so analysts are calculating that Republicans will have a majority on the five-member commission by next July and will possibly revise a number of the commission's current policies.
Whatever happens, analysts anticipate relatively high prices for consumers and, despite higher fuel costs, strong returns for most utilities for the next year or two. Thus, while 2000 was the first year since the early 1990's that the utilities as a group outperformed other stocks, analysts expect a repeat performance in 2001.
The hottest growth is coming outside of their traditional business. In addition to generating power that is wholesaled to other utilities, power companies are also investing in a wide range of unregulated activities from energy trading to telecommunications to energy management consulting.
Some, like Enron, have become big investors in overseas energy projects. Analysts project that the $218 billion industry's revenues from unregulated activities will exceed regulated revenues in 2001 for the first time.
Deregulation has also turned the once-staid sector into a playground for mergers and acquisitions specialists and the investors drawn to such transactions. Activity was down to about $90 billion this year from 1999, when a record $120 billion in utility assets changed hands, but investment bankers like Robert Hoglund, an energy industry expert at Salomon Smith Barney, expect it to bounce back to about $100 billion next year.
"There were about 150 public gas and electric companies in 1995," Mr. Hoglund said. "Consolidation has brought it down to about 100 now, and it's headed toward a couple of dozen by the end of the decade."
While such consolidation is intended to make the industry more efficient, it does not directly attack the most pressing challenge, namely bolstering the nation's capacity and its ability to efficiently move what energy it does produce from areas where there are extra supplies to those where there are shortages.
California currently has the most pressing problems, with demand next year expected to exceed capacity by 5,000 megawatts, the equivalent of five large power plants or enough to power five million homes. "Even normal weather will bring higher prices in California," said Richard Priory, chief executive of Duke Energy, one of several companies racing to expand generating capacity in the state. Expansion of its power plant at Moss Landing, Calif., will be one of the few projects to be completed next year.
But analysts say several other regions, especially the upper Midwest and the Northeast, are very likely to encounter price surges and possible blackouts if there are any severe heat waves next summer.
Thanks to deregulation, help is on the way, according to industry groups that track the state of the utility grid and investments in new generating capacity. The so-called merchant sector of the industry, in which Duke Energy and other companies generate power to sell to other utilities, is growing rapidly through both acquisition of existing power plants and construction of new ones.
About 20,000 megawatts of new capacity came on line this year and, according to the Electric Power Supply Association, more than 230,000 megawatts of new capacity has been announced for the next four years. No one expects all the announced plants to be built. Nevertheless, capacity additions are finally increasing faster than demand after years of decline, and industry officials expect the overall reserve margins to increase over the next few years.
The electricity wholesalers include the deregulated arms of well-known utilities like Duke Energy, based in Charlotte, N.C., and American Electric Power, based in Columbus, Ohio, plus new companies that are strictly merchant generators, like Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif., and AES in Arlington, Va. The Electric Power Supply Association estimates that merchant generators will control 25 percent of the nation's capacity by the end of next year, double the level of 1998.
The same forces encouraging the merchant generators are increasing interest in alternative energy-generation technologies, including solar, wind, fuel cells and small gas or diesel-fired turbines. Analysts like Hugh F. Holman, who follows such companies for CIBC World Markets, say that the new technology sector is prone to volatility and disappointments as individual companies miss development targets but that the overall outlook is strong for next year and 2002. And Masroor Siddiqui at Goldman, Sachs said up to 30 new power-related companies will go public or be spun off from companies like General Electric, Enron and the United Technologies Corporation in 2001.
"The universe of investment plays should expand," Mr. Siddiqui said.

SECTION: Section C; Page 14; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 929 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
The Year That European Corporate Acquirers Invaded America

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
The business-class cabin on British Airways' Flight 183 was packed to the last sleeper seat with investment bankers for much of this year. That is the airline's last flight out of Heathrow Airport in London bound for Kennedy International Airport in New York every night. It became so frequently packed with wheeling-and-dealing bankers -- negotiating $263.9 billion worth of trans-Atlantic mergers so far this year -- that it was dubbed the Deal Express by some of the flight's crew members.
By almost any measure, 2000 was the peak of Europe's corporate invasion of the United States. What began with the Daimler-Benz acquisition of Chrysler in 1998 got into full swing this year with a raft of deals in almost every sector. In the third quarter alone, European companies initiated North American acquisitions worth a total of $124 billion, easily topping the previous quarterly record of $98 billion set in the first quarter of 1998, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data. Since Jan. 1, European companies have bought almost 800 American concerns worth $263.9 billion -- about 10 percent above last year's pace. 
 The value of domestic mergers was effectively flat for the year with the exception of the $111 billion combination of America Online and Time Warner, which raised the total value by about 10 percent.
Globalization prompted the boom in trans-Atlantic transactions, said Steven Koch, chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston's mergers and acquisitions group. "Capturing market share in new geography is a prime motivator," he said.
Most of the action this year was east to west because Europeans realized that to be a serious player throughout the world they needed to be a serious player in the world's largest single market, the United States.
European companies were particularly eager to negotiate big trans-Atlantic deals using their highly valued stock because, in at least part of the year, their stocks were trading at significantly higher multiples than those of their counterparts in the United States.
Vivendi, the French water and utility company turned entertainment and telecommunications conglomerate, agreed to buy the Seagram Company and its Universal movie and Polygram music units for $34 billion in stock. (It was poised to sell Seagram's wine and spirits business to Diageo P.L.C. and Pernod-Ricard S.A.) And Terra Networks, the Spanish Internet company seeking to expand its virtual reach, swallowed up Lycos, of Cambridge, Mass., for $12.5 billion in stock.
Deutsche Telekom offered more than $50 billion in stock for VoiceStream, of Bellevue, Wash., to gain its first substantial foothold in the United States. Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer products group, acquired Bestfoods, of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., the maker of Knorr soups, Skippy peanut butter and Hellmann's mayonnaise, for about $20 billion in cash.
Even the banks arranging some of these takeovers were not immune from being taken over. UBS, the giant Swiss bank, bought PaineWebber, while Credit Suisse Group agreed to acquire Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette for cash and stock.
There are signs the trend may wane soon. Several bankers said that "deal flow" has slowed significantly since September because, with stock markets on both sides of the Atlantic gyrating, companies are less eager to buy or sell. European telecommunications companies have also been hurt by the extraordinary cost of mobile phone licenses in Britain, Germany and elsewhere. Britain alone received $35.5 billion for five licenses sold at its auction in April. That has crimped the financing of telecommunication companies, which just six months ago were expected to buy chunks of the American telecommunications market.
Europeans' ambitions in America have also been hampered by the market's reaction to earlier deals. Some analysts contend that the Daimler-Benz acquisition of Chrysler faltered simply because it was a trans-Atlantic deal.
Many American shareholders have been wary about owning foreign stock, in part because of currency risks and because some fund managers are forbidden to own foreign stocks. As a result, many shareholders sold their stock once the transaction was completed, driving down the share price and leaving German investors owning more than two-thirds of the combined DaimlerChrysler. The share price was also pounded because, being foreign, it was removed from the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, causing funds that track the index to sell the stock.
Bankers call this "flowback" -- because when American investors balk at owning foreign stock, most of the shares flow back to the country of the acquiring company. The phenomenon has affected most trans-Atlantic stock-for-stock deals this year.
"For a European company to buy in to the U.S., flowback is a huge issue," said Mr. Koch, the Credit Suisse First Boston banker. "Most of the deals will be done in cash."
Cash, though, presents its own problems for European acquirers, beyond its scarcity following the mobile phone license auctions earlier in the year. European currencies -- whether euro, pound or Swiss franc -- have weakened appreciably against the dollar this year, raising the relative cost of American companies by 10 percent or more.
That shift, however, may open up opportunities for new trans-Atlantic deals -- in the other direction. Depressed European currencies could let Americans buy European concerns on the cheap, analysts said.
That, in turn, could maintain the premium on business-class seats on British Airways Flight 183 well into the new year.
