SECTION: Section C; Page 19; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1797 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
In Japan, an Established Company Is Transformed

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: NAGOYA, Japan

 BODY:
Akio Toyoda is Japan's Willliam Clay Ford Jr. Widely regarded as the heir to the throne at the Toyota Motor Corporation by virtue of both his bloodlines and his experience, he seems well on his way to taking over one of Japan's most distinguished and financially sound companies.
But Mr. Toyoda has chosen a somewhat unorthodox means of proving himself: he has set out to demonstrate that even a bastion of the economic old guard known as Japan Inc. can make waves in the new economy. 
 His pet project, a Web site called Gazoo.com, is widely regarded as evidence that Japan's corporate monoliths will find it far easier to thrive and compete in an information-technology-enriched economy than many experts originally imagined.
Gazoo is helping Toyota speed up the disposal of used cars, cutting the time between orders placed and payment received and providing a treasure trove of customer data. It is also enabling the company to retain young, restless employees who might otherwise strike out for Bit Valley, Japan's version of Silicon Valley.
"The big companies were slow to move at first, but now everyone is incubating new businesses inside of them," said Joichi Ito, president and founder of Neoteny, an incubator backed by Whitney & Company. "Their delay has actually become an advantage because they have all of the cash and the markets are cheap right now."
Similarly, the corporations' reluctance to cut jobs, long criticized as a major drag on the Japanese economy, is also now working to their benefit, Mr. Ito said. "The brains are still at the big companies," he said. "They've never quit or been pushed out, so all the good new economy people are still sitting in the old economy companies."
Thus, Toyota's Web venture is thriving, and Fujitsu and the NEC Corporation are locked in a fierce battle to determine which of them will be the America Online of Japan. Even N.T.T., the former government telephone monopoly whose high prices make it the new economy's worst enemy, is embracing new technology that is likely to make it the leading provider of low-cost, high-speed Internet connections and sophisticated telecommunications services. That shift will be much to the chagrin of several small, new companies that have been counting on N.T.T. to be too big, too dumb and too slow to compete in new markets.
To the extent that Japan's economy is a reflection of the efforts of companies like these, their metamorphoses suggest there are reasons for optimism despite statistics indicating that growth over the short term may be stagnant at best, and despite fears that the financial sector is lurching toward another crisis -- still plagued by too much bad debt. Japan's big companies, only recently dismissed as the brontosauruses of the global economy, are reinventing themselves to stay competitive, and therein lies hope for the economy.
To be sure, not all Japanese companies understand the need to transform themselves, and even those that do are moving cautiously. Gazoo -- the name is derived from the two Japanese characters for "visual," celebrating the site's ability to bring the showroom to the customer -- was started as a venture business inside Toyota, largely to retain young employees chafing at the seniority system of advancement.
The company has been up and running for the last two years, but planning for it began about five years ago. "The directors thought Gazoo was just a hobby for young kids," said Mr. Toyoda, who is 44 and the only son of Shoichiro Toyoda, the company's honorary chairman. "So we didn't get any money to develop it."
When the Gazoo team wanted to buy a computer to test its online venture in a dealership in Shikoku, the smallest and least populated of Japan's four main islands, the board turned down the request for money. So Mr. Toyoda put up a little less than $2,000 of his own money to buy components, and the team assembled a computer. "We did it at less than one-third of what it would have cost to buy the same thing," Mr. Toyoda said proudly.
Maintaining the computer was a frustration. During a meeting in Hokkaido, Mr. Toyoda received an urgent call on his cell phone from the dealer in Shikoku, complaining that it had crashed and asking him to please send someone immediately to repair it. A Gazoo team member was hastily dispatched, only to discover that the plug had been pulled out of the socket. "That cost me 80,000 yen," Mr. Toyoda said. "Not cost-efficient."
One might even assume that Toyota had it out for Gazoo. The company housed its fledgling Web business in a brand new office building, but on the 42nd floor -- a floor that companies in this country traditionally shun because the number 42 is read "shi ni," which means "death" in Japanese.
A Toyota spokesman insisted, however, that the floor number said nothing about corporate sentiment toward Gazoo. "The rent was cheap because of the floor number," he said. "That's what we care about at Toyota."
However skeptical headquarters may have been, the company now appears fully committed to Gazoo. In June, Mr. Toyoda -- who studied business at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass., and has worked in various parts of the company since 1984 -- was named to Toyota's board, an unusual appointment for one so young. Also this year, Gazoo was officially placed into a separate division, along with some of Toyota's other businesses related to venture capital. The action was regarded as a sign of commitment to them. "Top executives have supported us," Mr. Toyoda said.
They had to. Autobytel and Carpoint, two purely online car-sales ventures, had aimed to put an end to Toyota's tight grip on its dealerships. Honda dealers and Nissan dealers leapt at the chance to participate in the independent online-sales ventures.
But Toyota's dealers were harder to convince because Gazoo provides them with all of the benefits of an Autobytel or Carpoint, but none of the costs. Gazoo, with 660,000 members and more than 60 million Web page views a month, gets more hits than either Autobytel or Carpoint and has proved so attractive to Toyota dealers that Carpoint's sales team has stopped trying to recruit them.
Gazoo was clearly a case of the empire striking back. By offering its dealers an attractive alternative to other online car sales services, Toyota, which controls about 30 percent of the total car market, expects effectively to shrink the potential market for Gazoo's competitors by one-third.
"It's part of the Toyota nature," Mr. Toyoda said. "Toyota is the kind of company that wants to do things by itself."
Indeed. While other Japanese companies are busy disengaging themselves from their keiretsu -- the clusters of suppliers and financial institutions linked by mutual shareholdings that have long stifled competitions and innovation -- Toyota has moved in the opposite direction, increasing its stakes in suppliers and building a financial services business.
Gazoo is playing a big role in that effort, serving as a sort of glue binding the dealerships and customers to Toyota. For instance, Toyota owners can receive online repair and service estimates, features likely to increase that more profitable business, and much of the cumbersome paperwork associated with buying a car here can be completed in advance over the Web.
Once Toyota puts its financing capabilities online next spring, analysts say it will be hard to beat. "The addition of automobile insurance and loans, as well as cash management account services and varied financial products provided by Toyota Financial Services, could turn Gazoo into a full-service Web site for the total range of Toyota products," two analysts, Christopher Redl and Keith Truelove, predicted in a recent report from UBS Warburg. For the moment, the two ascribe a value to Gazoo of about 2 percent of Toyota's stock price.
The data Gazoo generates may eventually lead to the development of a new car, Mr. Toyoda said. It has already taught Toyota invaluable lessons about the used-car business, which is picking up in Japan. For instance, customers online are telling Toyota that the used car they would most like to purchase is three years old. The automaker combs through its databases for customers with three-year-old Toyotas, and dealers dispatch salesmen to approach those people about trading in their cars.
"It's just a suggestion," Mr. Toyoda said. "They don't automatically agree, but it gets them thinking, hey, with 1.5 million yen, I could buy this or I could buy that. Eventually, some of them convince themselves that the salesman was right, it is time to trade in their old cars."
He acknowledges that not all those customers trade in their old Toyotas for new ones. But the Gazoo-inspired pitch may ensure that they sell their old cars to a Toyota dealer rather than trading them to a Honda dealer for a new car, and that helps keep more Toyota business within the family.
Mr. Toyoda also sees opportunities for Gazoo to link some of Toyota's more disparate businesses, like telecommunications and housing development, which have thus far been disappointing investments. "Young people are willing to pay 20,000 yen a month for a cellular phone, but they don't want to pay 5,000 yen a month in car payments," he said, his exasperation clear in his voice. "So, fine. We could sell them mobile phone services and add a Toyota car to the package as a sort of bonus on the side."
Gazoo's offerings also extend beyond the Toyota family. Gazoo sells 1,000 to 2,000 used books every day, according to Mr. Toyoda, through its association with the Bookoff Web Corporation, an online bookseller that is owned by a former Toyota employee. Gazoo employees spent three months establishing a distribution center for Bookoff based on Toyota's famous production methods.
By comparison, Kinokuniya, a bookstore that has an impressive online service, estimates that it sells about 3,500 new books a day.
"Customers don't shop every day for a car, so we had to find a way to increase traffic and give people a reason for revisiting the site," Mr. Toyoda explained.
Gazoo has also found a way to reach consumers who do not have Internet access over a computer, perhaps because Internet access charges in Japan are still relatively high by global standards. It is installing freestanding multimedia terminals that offer Gazoo's services in 13,000 convenience stores throughout the country, giving users the ability to download music onto minidiscs, make travel arrangements, process digital photos and, of course, buy cars.
"It always seems like Japanese are less connected to the Internet than Americans," Mr. Toyoda said. "But if you include access to the Net over cell phones and multimedia stations, I think the numbers are much more similar."

HEADLINE: TALKING BIOTECHNOLOGY WITH: George Rathmann;
An Industry Patriarch at the Forefront As Genomics Science Comes of Age

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
After years in the doldrums, biotechnology became a glamorous investment in 2000. Excited by the sequencing of the human genetic code, announced in June, investors poured far more money into biotechnology this year than in any other year in history. And dozens of companies took advantage of the open spigot to go public.
But the ride was not straight up. Biotechnology stocks plummeted in March and again toward the end of the year as investors got the jitters. Is genomics really the start of something new? Or will the biotechnology companies crash like the dot-coms did before them? 
 If anyone in the relatively young biotechnology industry has the long-term perspective to address such questions, it is George B. Rathmann, one of the industry's patriarchs.
Mr. Rathmann in 1980 became the first chief executive of Amgen Inc., which he turned into the nation's largest biotechnology company. In 1990, he was a co-founder of the Icos Corporation and served as chief executive through most of the 1990's. The company, based in Bothell, Wash., is now testing what could be a potent competitor to Pfizer's impotence treatment, Viagra.
Now, at age 72, Mr. Rathmann is still on the industry frontier. In February, he left Icos to become chairman, and subsequently chief executive, of Hyseq Inc., a Silicon Valley genomics company. This could be his greatest challenge yet. Hyseq's stock, which reached a high of $139.50 in February is now at $16.50 and Mr. Rathmann personally extended a $20 million line of credit to the company in November.
In a recent interview, he discussed where the biotechnology industry has been and where it's going in the year ahead.
Following are excerpts from that conversation:
 
Q. What would you say were the highlights for the biotechnology industry this year?
A. The highlights come very close to the lowlights. I think the accurate prediction that genomics is going to change the world was why stocks were driven up suddenly. And then, when people began to appreciate that it wasn't going to happen overnight, a lot of the stocks, including ours, plummeted.
Q. Over all, though, biotech stocks are up strongly this year. Are we still in for more of a dot-com-like crash?
A. I don't think so. I don't think it really was a dot-com situation anyway. I think it was a different set of parameters, but it certainly had a parallel. I don't think there's that much fluff left in anybody's stock that they are going to see a further crash. But it might be a long time before we hit the peaks we hit in March.
Q. What will be the key trends and developments in 2001?
A. I think it will be the arrival of the genomics age in reality rather than in theory. You're going to begin to identify real progress with discoveries that were made by simply sequencing genes.
But we won't be telling people that it's a shortcut through the F.D.A. I think some people had the feeling that because you're doing genomics, you're going to see products popping out in a year or two. It's still going to take the 10-year cycle to get a product out into treating patients.
Q. A lot of the companies that have gone public this year offer technology for use by drug companies in testing genes or discovering lead compounds. Is that enough to sustain a business, or does a company have to develop drugs?
A. A year ago, I would have said unquestionably you can't sustain this without developing drugs. The reason I modify it a little bit is there have been a few organizations that look like they're awfully sustainable today that haven't developed any drugs.
But I do think that most companies are saying, "Hey, to be sure I've got a future, I'm going to develop drugs, too." I can't see any of these companies saying we absolutely are not going to develop drugs.
Q. Do you think that applies to Celera Genomics the company founded by J. Craig Venter that sequenced the human genome and says its business will be selling genetic information ?
A. You bet I think it applies to Celera. It doesn't look like it right now, I have to admit. But I don't think there's any doubt. He is too smart to not take the next step.
Q. We've heard for years that the biotechnology industry is about to undergo a wave of mergers and consolidation. Do you see that happening?
A. The thing that makes you feel it's still true is that the gigantic companies have not slowed down in their efforts to get together with each other. So any one of us would be pretty smug to say, "Well, SmithKline Beecham wasn't big enough and Glaxo wasn't big enough, but we're big enough."
So I'd say the consolidations will continue, and I would imagine they'll accelerate. And yet I would imagine that five years from now there are going be more biotech companies than there are today because they are being spawned at a pretty good pace.
Q. What impact will genomics really have on drug development?
A. It opens up horizons. If you were to look at what happened when we first started in biotech, it seemed like you had infinite horizons. We could make any human protein in a reactor. In 1987, I listed 15 proteins that were likely to be useful, and they all got on the market eventually. If you knew 15 in '87 you would have figured that probably there would be a steady stream of these over the next 10 years. But, actually, even the largest companies didn't make a proportionate number of discoveries. In fact, if you calculate the money that was being spent from 1990 to 2000, you'd have to say, "Wow, diminishing returns." Amgen would end up with a billion-dollar budget, and we had a $20 million budget when I was there. And yet they weren't getting 50 times as much stuff out. What it meant was we had exhausted the supply of well-defined proteins.
And then all of a sudden we see these new horizons created by the fact that we're going to find genes randomly rather than finding the ones that people have already thought about. And so suddenly you have 10,000 genes. That's just got to look like a more fruitful field to play in than where you look and look and find one in a year. And so I think the payoff from genomics is going to be maybe lower-quality leads but so many of them that the overall opportunity is far in excess of what it was.
Q. Many experts say that by analyzing a patient's genes it will be possible to tailor medicines, increasing effectiveness and avoiding side effects. But others say that personalized medicine will not be attractive for drug companies because it will require more drugs with smaller sales for each. What's your view?
A. Those two positions are both correct. I think pharmacogenomics is here to stay and has got some enormous benefits. But I'm not sure that in the limit the industry's going to prosper by having an Andy Pollack version of this drug and a George Rathmann version. On the other hand, when we go into the clinic and we find out that 30 percent of the patients don't respond, if we can find out what the genetic link is, wow! You take a study of 10,000 patients that might be required when you've got a 30 percent noise level, and you can get it down to 500 patients, very likely. And that is going to happen.
Q. The big issue next year in Washington is expected to be high and rising drug prices. Is biotechnology contributing to high prices?
A. You bet it's going to be contributing to the cost of pharmaceuticals. But unfortunately the equation is never worked out as fully as it should be. If you find out that you've avoided hospitalizations, you can in many cases establish that there's been an economic gain, not an economic loss.
Q. Should there be some sort of pricing restraint by biotech companies?
A. We ran that experiment in 1994. We were talking to the Hillary task force, and some pretty smart guys said to us: "Look, we have to have price controls. Congress will not buy national health care on the risk that costs are going to go way out of sight."
And what did it do? We just about drove every biotech company out of business. Our stock dropped by 82 percent in a six-month period.
Companies are not going to be able to fund the research and development to make new drugs. It's not so clear for the pharmaceutical industry. You don't know, if they have a windfall from a big successful product, that they necessarily are going to put it back into R & D. In fact, the favorite criticism by congressmen is that they put it back into advertising. So you have all of this castigation of the industry. But I know where biotech puts it. We won't survive. You can't do R & D without investment that believes there's going to be a return.
Q. Do you see any resolution of the controversy about genetically modified foods?
A. I'm not very well informed there. The problem up until now has been that the benefits, which eventually accrue to the consumer, are still kind of trickle-down. I'm doing something that's going to be good for the farmer. But it's not something so tangible as saving your mother's life, which is what biopharmaceuticals have done. And as a result a certain amount of concerns were generated. Why should I be subjected to this for the benefit of the farmer or middleman?
Q. Do you see this controversy spilling over to the medical area?
A. Not at all. In fact, it will be snuffed out in those areas where you say, "Look, if I had this rice instead of the old rice, I could prevent thousands of cases of vitamin deficiency." Once you start having products like that, they'll be insulated from this kind of concern because the consumer is seeing a benefit.
Q. Most people at 72 would be retired, not running a start-up. Why are you doing it? Do you have any plans for retirement?
A. Well, I've had a lot of plans for retirement. But I don't take them very seriously. If you really think you're doing something useful, that's where you want to be.

SECTION: Section C; Page 8; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1347 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
H.M.O.'s Are Pressed on Many Fronts to Reinvent Themselves

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The managed care industry can hope to be reasonably prosperous next year, but many critics both in and outside the industry say H.M.O.'s will soon have to reinvent themselves, or perish.
Bigger premiums next year should provide bigger profits for many. But higher costs in a number of areas -- in installing high-technology equipment, paying for new drugs and modernizing facilities -- are taking their toll. Hospitals and physicians are also rebelling against what they consider inadequate payments, and employers are railing against rate increases. Add to this legislation in Congress that supports patients' rights, and it becomes clear that the industry is under great pressure to re-evaluate its operations on many fronts. 
 "The very model that the health plans function on is being called into question by the plans themselves," said Kenneth A. Tannenbaum, a health care consultant in Atlanta with Tillinghast-Towers Perrin, the benefits consulting firm.
Taking advantage of the still-vibrant economy and tight labor market that has stoked demand for employee health coverage, insurers raised premiums 8 and 9 percent for large companies for 2001 and as high as 20 and 30 percent for small concerns.
With profits improving at many for-profit health maintenance organizations, their stock prices have rebounded from the lows of the last few years. But smaller managed care plans are in danger as they scramble to merge and come up with financing for new information systems. More than half the health plans reported losses for 1999.
The industry's main concerns, said Leonard D. Schaeffer, chief executive of Wellpoint Health Networks, one of the strongest health insurers, include assessing the costs and efficacy of changing new technology, especially expensive new drugs. The industry must also meet the growing needs of aging baby boomers and keep on the right side of employers who may be reluctant to cover growing health costs if the economy falters.
Michael Barrett, a senior analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., said that "a real collision is brewing" for managed care companies. "Employers don't want to see a return to double-digit rate increases," he said. "Doctors and hospitals are getting higher reimbursements, and consumers are not inclined to play patsy for cost shifting."
He said many H.M.O.'s will need a significant amount of money for improvements in information systems to keep customers happy and try to keep costs in line. But with profit margins slim, "they do not have any ready means of raising it."
Managed care companies have also been fighting a raft of lawsuits from patients whose lawyers are seeking class-action status and charging that the system does not deliver the quality of care that it says it does. The companies have won several rounds in federal appeals courts. On another front, a bill that would make it easier to sue H.M.O.'s for medical malpractice is now moving through Congress. It was passed last year by the House and has been stuck in the Senate, but the new Congress may be more receptive to the legislation after the defeat of several senators who had opposed it.
Finding that their attempt to manage costs by delaying and denying payments for care has broken down in the face of consumer resistance, some health plans are planning to give consumers more choices of coverage and follow up with close attention to preventive measures, which they hope will safeguard the health of those at risk of contracting expensive illnesses.
Industry experts say the insurers must shift to policies that permit consumers to put together their own customized health plans and offer help to them in deciding what to do. Insurers are also beginning to provide consumers with personalized Web pages to see how their medical claims are being handled, said Jeff Goldsmith, a health care economist who is president of Health Futures, an independent consulting firm in Charlottesville, Va.
As they adopt sophisticated new strategies, the health plans must spend heavily to "Web-enable" their communications with providers and consumers of care and payers, said Mr. Tannenbaum of Tillinghast-Towers Perrin.
"Health plans are trying to control costs by delivering information online," said Jack Reichman, director for health insurance at Standard & Poor's, the credit rating agency. "The new systems cost $200 million to $300 million," he said.
But there is little choice. "Those that don't invest will ultimately have higher costs," Mr. Reichman said. And all health plans must comply with new federal regulations requiring standardized computer language and privacy and security measures to protect patients.
The federal requirements will cost 20 to 30 percent more than last year's multimillion-dollar outlays that prepared computer systems for Year 2000 problems that largely failed to materialize, Mr. Tannenbaum said.
If the economy sours, the pressures will only increase. "When corporate employers' cash flow begins to decline significantly, the plans will be in serious trouble," Mr. Goldsmith said. When consumer prices and wages are rising at low single-digit rates, employers will reject big increases for health care, he said.
Mr. Schaeffer of Wellpoint added: "If the economy slows even a little bit in 2002, the chief financial officers will come out of their offices. Right now, the sales guys are in charge."
Mr. Reichman said 10 to 15 percent of employers might turn to "something like defined contributions" next year, rather than swallow further rate increases. Under defined contributions, individual members of health plans have to make their own money stretch to cover costs, instead of having a commitment from their employer or an H.M.O. to cover their medical needs.
Many hospitals, meanwhile, have been aggressively demanding higher payments after years of being squeezed by the health plans. Some strong hospitals have refused to do business this year with insurers who squeezed too hard. Both hospitals and physician group practices are avoiding the risks of accepting capitation arrangements, in which they receive low monthly per capita payments for groups of health plan members, many of whom may need expensive care.
"Physician enterprises are in a serious mess," Mr. Goldsmith said at Health Futures. "In the West, a lot of health plans drove them into bankruptcy." More than 100 medical groups in California have filed for bankruptcy protection the last three years.
For-profit hospital chains were among the first to increase their revenues and earnings by making their operations more efficient. Share prices of HCA Healthcare, Tenet Healthcare and other big chains have soared this year. But the picture is still mixed as the industry lobbies vigorously for restoration of federal budget cuts.
"A third of the 4,800 hospitals are doing real well," said Rick Wade, a senior vice president of the American Hospital Association, a Washington trade group. "About a third have taken it on the chin from the balanced budget act cuts and state Medicaid cutbacks, and the rest are in the middle with profit margins of 1 to 5 percent, not enough to go to the bond markets with," he said.
Most hospitals need big amounts to modernize buildings that were put up with liberal federal help under the Hill-Burton act after World War II. Some are seeking financial help from local governments, businesses and philanthropies, to make up for cutbacks by managed care and Washington.
Nurses and other hospital workers are in short supply, and unions regard health care as "the last great frontier" for them to organize, Mr. Wade said. There have been strikes around the country but he said the hospitals "do not have a lot of options for coming up with the money."
"This industry has been in a recession for two years," Mr. Goldsmith said. Now hospitals are beginning to cut administrative costs, eliminate highly paid administrators and consolidate departments, he said.
"I'm cautiously optimistic for next year about both hospitals and health plans," he said.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Airlines Wait to Learn The Fate of the Big Deal

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The coming year will be a landmark for the domestic airline industry. Or it will not be.
That is the consensus of airline executives, analysts and consultants as they all await the outcome of the $4.3 billion bid by the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, to acquire US Airways. 
 The conventional wisdom is that if the deal is consummated as proposed, it will precipitate a consolidation frenzy within the industry that will quickly reduce the top six airlines to three giants that will control 85 percent of domestic air traffic.
But the belief is just as strong that the Justice Department's antitrust division, which has taken a hard line against the big airlines in recent years, will not allow the deal to be completed, or at the very least will demand radical changes that could divide US Airways' assets among several competitors.
The endgame may be near. United and US Airways have already presented the Justice Department with all the documents that have been requested. The two sides will probably engage in behind-the-scenes negotiations in an effort to reach some mutually agreeable settlement. The election of George W. Bush as presidentn could complicate matters, but United and US Airways still predict that the deal will be completed early next year.
There is little doubt that the size and scale of the merger and its long-term effect on the industry presents the Justice Department with its most important decision since the industry was deregulated in 1978.
After United, the world's largest airline, and US Airways, the country's sixth largest, announced their deal in May, talks sprouted among American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines, the three largest carriers behind United.
The most plausible combinations, given antitrust obstacles, have American buying Northwest and Delta buying Continental. But talks between American and Northwest stalled earlier this year after Northwest demanded a high price and showed little interest in selling. And Continental, which recently negotiated to buy back most of a controlling stake held by Northwest, wants to stay independent.
Indeed, none of the airlines, with the exception of United, seem to relish the idea of a merger. Combining airlines is a notoriously messy affair. Only a few deals in modern history have turned out to be profitable. American, for instance, became embroiled in a costly battle with its pilots last year after it agreed to buy tiny Reno Air. A merger with Northwest would be much more disruptive.
But airline executives say privately that they would have no choice if United succeeded in swallowing US Airways. The deal as proposed would give United by far the biggest domestic route network, filling the large gap it now has in the Eastern United States. American and Delta, which are now roughly the same size as United domestically, would find it hard to compete for contracts that make them the preferred airlines for large corporations, their bread-and-butter business.
That is one of the concerns that the Justice Department is likely to raise, antitrust experts say. United and US Airways counter that the two have few overlapping routes and that the merger would increase competition and lower air fares.
But United's credibility in Washington, which was already low when the deal was announced in May, has plunged. A summer slowdown by its pilots and machinists forced United to cancel more than 20,000 flights. Its on-time performance fell to 40 percent from about 70 percent.
Many senators and congressmen wondered aloud how much worse the situation would have been had United owned US Airways. James L. Oberstar, the ranking Democrat on the House Transportation Committee, has written to the Justice Department twice urging it to reject the merger.
United and US Airways recognize that their combined share of the market in Washington is a problem. They have proposed spinning off most US Airways assets at Reagan National Airport in Washington to a new airline called DC Air to be owned by Robert L. Johnson, the founder and chairman of Black Entertainment Television and a US Airways director.
That has opened the door to the possibility that the Justice Department will demand larger divestitures. One course short of full consolidation among the big six carriers would have United gaining some of US Airways East Coast routes with the remainder being divided among American, Continental and Northwest.
In that case, said James M. Higgins, an airline analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, American and Delta might try to buy smaller airlines, like Alaska Airlines and America West, to fill out their route networks and keep up with United.
Mr. Higgins also said that the election of George W. Bush as president might not bode well for United. While a Republican administration is normally seen as hands off when it comes to antitrust enforcement, Mr. Bush's home state of Texas is also the home of American and Continental, the two airlines most eager to see the deal fall apart.
Finally, if the stock market is any guide, the chances that the deal will go through are slim but improving. UAL offered $60 a share for US Airways. For most of the summer, US Airways stock traded at about $30 a share, an indication that few investors believed that the deal would be completed. But in recent weeks, US Airways shares have risen, closing on Friday at $43.75 a share.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A New Horizon for China in Trade

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
Liang Bingjun, chatting on his mobile telephone, is one reason the West ought to be excited about China joining the World Trade Organization next year.
A quarter of every dollar spent on the phone by Mr. Liang and other mobile phone owners in China could belong to a foreign company as soon as China joins the W.T.O. That's not small change. With more than 65 million cell phone users, China is already the world's second-largest wireless market and is expected to surpass even the United States by the end of next year. 
 Telecommunications is just one way in which China's trade organization membership will make an immediate splash. While reams of questions remain about what will happen after the world's most populous country joins the global trading club, there are some reasonable certainties about instant changes that will alter the global market forever. Others will happen gradually over five years.
China's W.T.O. membership will not change everything: the country will continue to protect many of its sectors from foreign competition. But joining the organization will force open the nation's economy more in the first five years than during the previous 20 years of reforms. Some of the biggest changes will come on the first day.
Tariffs are set to fall on a wide range of products. On the first day of China's W.T.O. membership, for example, the import duty on some automobiles will drop to 63.5 percent from 80 percent now, the first step in a five-year decline that will bring all car duties down to 25 percent.
Finance companies like GMAC, meanwhile, will be allowed to offer car loans, putting millions of Chinese consumers within sudden reach of buying an imported car.
And China has promised to scrap the murky, politicized process by which it decides what companies have access to its market.
Insurers, for example, will no longer wait years to hear if they are among the anointed ones. The day after China joins the W.T.O., the country's insurance regulator is supposed to have applications on hand for qualified companies that want to sell insurance in the country. And, under W.T.O. rules, the regulator will have to act on the applications within a set period of time, giving a written explanation to companies whose applications are turned down. That will be a relief to insurers that have spent millions of dollars waiting for word from the regulators with no information at all.
Insurers are eager to start: China's entire insurance market is still smaller than Taiwan's, but the government expects it to expand at a double-digit rate for at least the next decade.
"With incomes rising, there's little doubt the market will grow quickly," said Patrick Cranley, the Cigna Corporation's representative in Shanghai and the chairman of the American Chamber of Commerce here.
As a W.T.O. member, China won't be able to arbitrarily limit the number of foreign insurance companies operating here.
Other foreign services will become immediately legal. Foreign law firms, which have operated in a gray area for years, will at last be allowed to counsel clients on Chinese laws and rules related to commercial transactions, though they will not yet be allowed to argue cases before Chinese courts.
In some cases, China is already amending those laws and regulations to comply with W.T.O. standards. The country's legislature has drafted amendments that will lift burdens from foreign investors setting up factories in China. Those amendments will take effect when they are approved by the full legislature, a largely rubber stamp body, at its next session early next year.
Among other changes, foreign companies will no longer be required to use a certain amount of local materials or components in the products they make in China. And factories that are 100 percent foreign-owned will no longer be required to export at least half their China-made goods. Nor will licenses for wholly foreign-owned manufacturers be granted based on the level of technology they bring to China.
"That should make it easier for foreign companies to invest," said Patrick Norton, a Shanghai-based lawyer with the American law firm O'Melveny & Myers.
Few of the immediate changes will be as momentous as the opening of China's telecommunications industry, though, which itself is on the verge of explosive growth. Upon China's joining the W.T.O., foreign companies will be allowed to buy up to 25 percent of Chinese mobile telephone networks, and up to 49 percent within three years.
Foreign telecommunication giants are already jostling for position: Britain's Vodafone Group paid $2.5 billion for a 2 percent stake in China's biggest mobile telephone company, China Mobile Communications, earlier this year and has said it is ready to buy more. Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa holds a 2 percent stake in China Unicom, China's second mobile telephone operator, which is shopping for a still larger strategic investor. And there may also be more mobile telephone licenses issued in China after the country joins the W.T.O.
Mr. Liang, 25, who keeps his cell phone glued to his ear at a coffee shop on Shanghai's bustling Nanjing Road, said he was happy about the changes W.T.O. entry will bring. "If there are foreign companies in the market, there will be more competition and prices will come down," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Southeast Asia Braces For More Economic Pain

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
For the last two years, international lenders and economists have been warning Southeast Asia to learn the lessons of its financial crisis, use its rebound as an opportunity to sweep out old-economy cobwebs and reduce the region's reliance on exporting to the United States.
Time's up. 
 With oil prices still high and evidence mounting that demand from United States consumers and companies is slackening, especially in the once-feverish electronics sector, economists now predict that Southeast Asia's economic growth rates will cool significantly in 2001.
"Asia is going to feel a bit more pain," said William C. Belchere, head of fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch.
Vexing to investors, slowing growth in Southeast Asia presents a potentially more serious challenge to political leaders expected to produce livelihoods for a population whose average annual income is just a little more than $1,000 and one-third of whom are under the age of 14.
But many of those same political leaders have become distracted with problems of their own. Corruption scandals, impeachment bids and campaign challenges in Southeast Asia's three functioning democracies have left two-thirds of the region's citizens without the kind of leadership needed to push through the difficult reforms that economists say might have better prepared them for a slowing economy in the United States.
For the most vivid illustration, look no further than the Philippines, where the impeached president, Joseph Estrada, is defending himself in the country's Senate against charges of taking kickbacks from illegal gambling operations.
Mr. Estrada's trial is expected to drag on until February, but economists and analysts say that no matter what the outcome, there is little sign that the country's political establishment has the kind of financial discipline needed to rein in a ballooning government deficit.
"The budget deficit remains a key constraint to growth and stability in the economy," said Desmond Supple, a director at Barclays Capital in Singapore. "Estrada or his successor won't be able to escape that."
The trouble, economists say, is that Estrada is just one man in a corrupt and inequitable system. Removing Mr. Estrada will do little, for instance, to end widespread tax evasion by the country's business elite, the same class now leading calls for his ouster. Nor will it address the fact that, while poverty levels are declining, the gap between the rich and poor is widening and much of the country still belongs to the very rich.
"A few families have a huge portion of the national land -- peasants are controlled by landlords," said Takahira Ogawa, director of sovereign ratings at Standard & Poor's in Singapore. "They need agricultural land reform."
Mr. Estrada's impeachment trial, meanwhile, has diverted the Senate from passing legislation that would privatize the deeply indebted national utility, a step deemed imperative by both the Asian Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
The result: a loss of investor confidence that has sapped the currency, the peso, battered the stock market and sent interest rates soaring.
A similar scenario is being played out in Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia, confounding predictions a year ago that foreign investors would plow money back into Southeast Asia to capitalize on the region's recovery. On the contrary: concerns about corruption and poor corporate governance have prompted a stampede by foreign investors, helping to send the region's leading stock indexes down 30 percent and more.
Hastening the exodus are foreign fund managers, who often calibrate their investments to match the relative size of the world's markets. The smaller Southeast Asia's markets become, the more these fund managers sell to adjust their exposure.
Slumping stock markets have also closed an important avenue for the region's corporations and new-economy entrepreneurs to tap Southeast Asia's prodigious savers, something economists have advocated as a way of reducing the region's reliance on borrowing from banks.
But the region's banks are still preoccupied with digging their way out from under the loans that went sour during the financial crisis of 1997 and 1998. In Thailand, for example, banks have managed to reduce the level of nonperforming loans to 25 percent of all loans from 45 percent, but this hasn't been compensated by new loans to Thailand's hungry economy.
Some Thai companies have been able to sell bonds to the public to raise operating cash, but for the most part, economists say companies are relying on their own sales revenues, especially their exports.
America's high-tech slump is likely to have the biggest impact not in Thailand, however, but in the region's electronics powerhouses, Malaysia and Singapore. Electronics exports account for about two-fifths of Malaysia's economy and roughly three-quarters of Singapore's. J.P. Morgan predicts that Singapore's economic growth will taper to 4 percent in 2001 from roughly 10 percent this year and Malaysia's to 3 percent from 9 percent.
Some economists warn that Southeast Asian nations need to do more than put each of their own houses in order. To increase the region's allure as a market and export base, tangible progress needs to be made, they say, toward pledges of greater economic integration and free trade. China's eventual membership in the World Trade Organization, they warn, will make it a tougher competitor.
The urge to protect domestic industries has held up such efforts so far, but China represents a greater potential threat, warns Mr. Ogawa at Standard & Poor's. "They have to unite and come up with some kind of countermeasures," he said.

HEADLINE: 2000 HIGHLIGHTS;
A New Era for U.S. and Vietnam

 BODY:
President Clinton opened a new chapter in relations with Vietnam in November by spending three days in the country. It was the first visit by an American president since the end of the war 25 years ago. Mr. Clinton gently but insistently urged Vietnam to set aside its fears and join the global marketplace of trade and ideas, though some Vietnamese leaders did not seem at all sure that they wanted to. Ordinary people were an easier sell: Mr. Clinton was thronged and cheered wherever he went. The president's visit came shortly after the two former adversaries signed a trade agreement that, if carried out, may tear down many of the walls Vietnam has erected around its economy and society. The accord, Mr. Clinton said, will promote "a more open, sophisticated free market, based on international rules of law."

HEADLINE: Despite Turkish-Greek Thaw, Cyprus Quarrel Is Not Melting

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Accelerated by "seismic diplomacy" as they helped each other through devastating earthquakes, and soothed by Greece's agreement to Turkey's desire to join the European Union, the traditionally thorny relations between Turkey and Greece have improved rapidly in the last 18 months.
A dispute during NATO exercises in October that could have turned nasty was swiftly defused without lasting damage to the reconciliation; tourism will double this year and two-way trade will vault to $1 billion from $630 million. Educators, judges and business groups have all held rare and productive exchanges. 
 But that, it turns out, was the easy part. Progress made by the two countries' foreign ministers, and brought to the popular level when first Turkey, then Athens, suffered bad earthquakes in 1999, was maintained by concentrating on incremental matters and shelving the tough questions.
In the end, the historic enmity between Greece and Turkey -- awkwardly locked into the same defense alliance, NATO -- can be turned into durable peace only if the two countries can agree on the fate of Cyprus and settle territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea.
Interviews with both foreign ministers, Ismail Cem of Turkey and George Papandreou of Greece, and with other diplomats and officials in the two countries revealed that despite unanimous optimism about short-term prospects, the new relationship remains fragile. Substantive differences still separate two of the most important countries in a region of strategic significance to the United States and Europe.
Sitting in his ornate office in Athens earlier this month, Mr. Papandreou sounded convincing when he said that the countries were closer than at any time in 40 years and that he expected more progress. But at some point, Mr. Papandreou made clear, there must be a solution on the divided island of Cyprus.
"There are big issues that have not been solved and it's going to be painful," he said. "Issues like Cyprus will either unite us or divide us."
A few days later, overlooking the Bosporus at the Ciragan Palace Hotel in Istanbul, the Turkish foreign minister, Ismail Cem, was equally upbeat in his prognosis. But he rejected his Greek counterpart's stance on Cyprus, saying the island's ultimate fate should be determined by the Greeks and Turks who live there in an uneasy peace.
"Cyprus is an issue that has to be dealt with primarily by the two parties on the island," Mr. Cem said. "I told the Greeks at the start that Cyprus was not an issue that I would address with them."
The ministers were similarly divided on resolving the quarrel in the Aegean, where the ownership of hundreds of islands is in dispute and Greece says its continental shelf extends 12 miles. Greece insists that the matter be handled by mediation and the International Court of Justice at The Hague, while Turkey maintains that there are other international and Greek-Turkish mechanisms.
The fact that Mr. Papandreou and Mr. Cem differ on these important issues is significant, for these two men almost single-handedly provided the spark and momentum to bring their countries closer together.
Mr. Cem began the process with a letter to Mr. Papandreou in June 1999. Since then, they have negotiated a pragmatic course forward, navigating past obstacles like the botched NATO exercise in October and the flare-up last month over Greek insistence that Turkey resolve the Cyprus and Aegean issues before joining the European Union.
"They have made a strategic decision for rapprochement and I think that decision holds today, despite the problems of the last two months," R. Nicholas Burns, the American ambassador in Athens, said in an interview. "What we've seen now is what you often see in diplomacy -- it takes more than a year and a half to bridge profound historical divisions."
The question is, how much time do Mr. Papandreou and Mr. Cem have? The history of conflict between Greece and Turkey dates back centuries and includes 400 years of Ottoman occupation of Greece. But for Turks and Greeks alike, history is not only what is read in books. It is present, it is personal and it is recent.
In 1974, Turkish soldiers invaded Cyprus after a coup by military officers favoring union with Greece. The Turkish prime minister who ordered the intervention, Bulent Ecevit, is the country's current leader.
Just four years ago, Greece and Turkey narrowly averted going to war over two rocky Aegean outcroppings. Despite the recent progress, diplomats and businessmen in both countries worry that a single incident could resurrect old hatreds.
The question of time is more crucial for Mr. Papandreou, who must guard against appearing to give up too much without substantive returns and is constrained by lingering domestic suspicions that Turkey remains a potential neighborhood thug.
Mr. Papandreou is a member of the socialist party Pasok, which won re-election last April by a single percent. While Prime Minister Costas Simitis has been credited with improving the economy, Greece remains the poorest country in the European Union and the government has been criticized for corruption and the slow pace of privatization.
The main opposition party, the center-right New Democracy, also has hammered away at Mr. Papandreou over what it sees as his dovish attitude toward Turkey. They say he has received nothing of substance despite allowing Turkey to become a candidate for the European Union.
"It is a unilateral concession policy," Costas Karamanlis, the opposition leader, contended earlier this month.
The government clearly expected progress by now toward its goal of a unified Cyprus, but Mr. Papandreou accurately said reconciliation remains popular among the Greek people. He also said bringing Turkey into the European club will be as beneficial for Greece as for Turkey.
But he acknowledged that his advocacy carries political risks, particularly for someone often mentioned as a future prime minister.
"As foreign minister, I am identified with this policy," he said. "I am judged. I hope to see results in the next four years."
Thanos Dokos, an official with a foreign policy foundation in Athens, was more blunt. "If things go wrong, his political career is going to be wrecked," he said.
The stakes are not as high for Mr. Cem, though he is also regarded as a potential prime minister. Turkey is much larger, with a population of 65 million compared with 10 million in Greece, and its foreign policy interests stretch from the Middle East and Russia to Central Asia and the Caucasus.
Indeed, Mr. Cem sees Turkey's regional role as the chief reason his country will ultimately join the European Union and he said the candidacy approved at the Helsinki summit meeting a year ago reflected Turkey's progress, not Greece's acquiescence.
"The timing was right for many reasons," he said. "Greek relations had improved. Terrorism within Turkey was under control. The government was stable. The economy was growing smooth. Democratic improvements were taking place. It became in the interest of Europe as a whole to bring Turkey into the club."
When it comes to Greek relations, Mr. Cem seemed content with the pace of progress. "If we allow what is taking place to go smoothly, it will be a major accomplishment," he said.
Mr. Cem's contention that Cypriots must determine whether the island becomes a confederation of equals or a unified state avoids the reality that Turkish Cyprus is a client-state of Turkey. The government in Ankara is the only one that recognizes the Turkish Cypriot government, 30,000 Turkish troops are garrisoned there, and Turkey provides $100 million a year in aid.
Still, Mr. Cem must also contend with sometimes-tumultuous domestic politics and a virulent Turkish aversion to any policy that appears to give up sovereignty. Neither man could probably withstand a headline in his country's lively national newspapers saying that he had given away Cyprus, which embodies too much of the past for both peoples.
"History is not over and the reference point with Cyprus goes back through the whole gamut of the Turkish-Greek relationship," said Ahmet Evin, a dean at Istanbul's Sabanci University who is working on a conflict resolution project with Greek and American academics. "Memory is opened every time there is friction between the two countries and it will take time and work to heal."

HEADLINE: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: THE VICE PRESIDENT-ELECT;
Cheney Says Bush Administration Will Move Rapidly on Issues Central to Campaign

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The incoming Bush administration signaled today that it would make education its first legislative priority after taking office next month, and pledged to move rapidly on the other main pieces of its campaign platform, including a big tax cut and overhauls of Social Security and Medicare.
In appearances on Sunday television news programs, Vice President-elect Dick Cheney and Andrew H. Card Jr., who has been designated as the new White House chief of staff, said they had no plans to scale back the conservative agenda on which President-elect George W. Bush ran. 
 In Austin, Tex., today, Mr. Bush reiterated his support for a $1.3 trillion tax cut over 10 years despite Democratic opposition.
"I campaigned on a tax relief package that I firmly believe -- believed then and believe even more now -- is important as an insurance policy against any economic downturn," Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Cheney said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation": "As President-elect Bush has made very clear, he ran on a particular platform that was very carefully developed; it's his program and it's his agenda and we have no intention at all of backing off of it. The suggestion that somehow, because this was a close election, we should fundamentally change our beliefs I just think is silly."
Democrats warned that Mr. Bush risked spoiling whatever chance he had of cultivating bipartisanship should he fail to reach out to them from the start.
"You can't start with the hard-core right-wing base," Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader in the Senate, said on the ABC News program "This Week." "You can't start with the hard-core left-wing base. We've got to find common ground in all of these proposals."
Mr. Cheney said Mr. Bush intended to talk with Congressional leaders this week about how best to win approval of his entire $1.3 trillion package. Neither Mr. Cheney nor Mr. Card ruled out trying to pass the tax bill in pieces, as many Republicans in Congress would prefer. But they said that with the economy slowing they would like to see quick action on the biggest component of the tax plan, an across-the-board reduction in income tax rates.
Mr. Cheney said Mr. Bush would have breakfast in Washington on Monday with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to talk about the economy and the proposed tax cuts.
Mr. Daschle said he could not "think of anything that would divide this nation more quickly, right off the bat" than for Mr. Bush to press immediately for his full tax package. He said Democrats were willing to consider a tax cut in the range of $500 billion over 10 years.
Mr. Cheney suggested that Mr. Bush would do what he could to attract Democratic support for his proposals on a case-by-case basis, but indicated that he was not going to start off by giving ground.
"I think what you'll find in the way President-elect Bush likes to operate is that he is prepared to work on putting together coalitions to pass legislation," Mr. Cheney said. "What he's not willing to do is compromise on principle."
Education is shaping up as an early test of how both sides will handle the close division of power in Congress and the lingering ill will from the presidential election.
Although efforts to write legislation updating federal education programs bogged down in Congress this year, there is considerable common ground between the parties.
But there is also a deep rift between them over whether the federal government should provide vouchers to parents of children in school districts that are judged to be substandard, to subsidize private school tuition. Voucher programs were rejected this year by voters in Michigan and California, and a program in Cleveland was struck down last week by a federal appeals court. Most Democrats oppose vouchers.
But Mr. Card said Mr. Bush would stick with the voucher plan in his package of education measures.
"We will be talking about some kind of vouchers or opportunities for public schools that are not living up to their expectations to be challenged by the private sector, if you will, to make sure no child is left behind," Mr. Card said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
In interviews last week, Democrats in Congress said there was plenty of opportunity for Mr. Bush to get much of what he wants in education, particularly in granting states more flexibility in how they use federal money in return for greater accountability. But they said that if Mr. Bush insisted on vouchers there would be little hope of a deal.
"If he goes a bridge too far and puts vouchers in the equation, he risks having the whole enterprise collapse," said Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana, a centrist Democrat.
Democrats said they would also be watching carefully to see how Mr. Bush approaches the two most popular provisions in his tax-cut proposal, the repeal of the federal estate tax and a reduction in taxes for many married couples.
Democrats moved significantly toward the Republican position in Congress this year. If Republicans are serious about bipartisanship, Democrats said, the legislation addressing the estate tax and the so-called marriage penalty will provide plenty of opportunity to compromise.
"They can probably be bipartisan in symbolic ways and marginally successful in the beginning," said Representative Tim Roemer, a Democrat from Indiana. "Or they can be genuinely bipartisan and lay the groundwork for success beyond some individual tax measures."
Beyond education, Mr. Bush is likely to push fairly quickly for at least one component of his Medicare plan. It would provide $48 billion over four years to help states pay the costs of prescription drugs for low-income retirees.
The proposal is intended to ensure that people being hit hardest by the rising cost of prescription drugs get some immediate help while Congress and the new administration work out a more comprehensive approach to overhauling Medicare and adding drug coverage.
The Bush camp has not yet decided how to advance Mr. Bush's proposal to add individual investment accounts to Social Security. Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said today that he was considering calling in coming weeks for the creation of a bipartisan commission on Social Security, a step Mr. Bush is also contemplating.
But Mr. Bush could face legislative fights from the beginning that upset his efforts to approach his agenda in an orderly way.
Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, has pledged to bring up his proposed overhaul of campaign finance law as quickly as possible after the new Congress convenes early next month. Mr. Bush opposes the bill that Mr. McCain has co-sponsored with Senator Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin, a Democrat.
There is also a possibility that social conservatives in Congress will move quickly to pass a bill banning a type of late-term abortion that its opponents call partial-birth abortion. "If it passes, it will be signed," Mr. Cheney said.

HEADLINE: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: THE SECRETARY OF STATE;
A Higher Threshold for U.S. Intervention Means Adjustments Abroad

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Dec. 17

 BODY:
In his first remarks as the designated secretary of state, retired Gen. Colin L. Powell spoke on Saturday with force and eloquence. But General Powell made few binding commitments, discussing the future foreign policy of a Bush administration with broad strokes, promising study and consultation.
The world's reaction to his appointment shares the same slightly hopeful fuzziness, with relief that President-elect George W. Bush has chosen a secretary of state with experience, standing, caution and knowledge of alliance politics. 
 Mr. Bush's commitment to a missile-defense system for the United States is going to be among the most controversial goals of his presidency, presaging fierce disputes with Russia, China and Europe, and probably involving the abrogation of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.
But even on this issue General Powell was careful, promising a hard look at the state of the technology to accomplish an effective missile defense. Similarly, while General Powell did not dissent from a Bush campaign promise to try to extract American troops from peacekeeping duties in the Balkans, he vowed study, assessment and consultation, the emollient words that NATO allies are happy to hear.
General Powell was most specific about his intention to "re-energize those sanctions" against President Saddam Hussein in Iraq, the country against which he commanded the successful Persian Gulf war in 1991. The sanctions have been collapsing, with at least eight European countries authorizing flights and humanitarian aid to Baghdad. Iraq's reaction today to General Powell's threat was dismissive.
In general, the world seems not unhappy with the idea of a less interventionist United States -- or, perhaps more accurately, a United States with clearer thresholds for the use of military force that have more to do with national and security interests than with ill-defined "humanitarian intervention," as in Somalia and Kosovo.
And a President Bush with a divided Congress and a wafer-thin electoral triumph is understood to be less likely to make big ideological shifts or to ignore the views of moderate Democrats on any issue, from trade policy to NATO.
For China, which Mr. Bush and the Republican Party have identified as Washington's main security challenge in the future, there is concern over a missile-defense system and Taiwan. But General Powell is seen as less interested than Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in issues of human rights and democratization.
"This team seems more military oriented, and I predict that political disputes, such as human rights and democracy issues, will be moderated while military disagreements, on issues like Taiwan and missile defense and arms control, will become more intense," said Yan Xuetong, executive director of the Institute of International Studies at Qinghua University in Beijing.
China, with only 18 long-range nuclear missiles, considers itself the main target of an American missile-defense program, and would like to avoid the expense of building more weapons to be able to overwhelm any new defensive system.
But with Mr. Bush's commitment to press ahead with a missile-defense program, Mr. Yan said, "it appears that the only thing that could prevent" eventual deployment was "a technology obstacle," which would strain relations.
The problem would be worse, Mr. Yan said, if a Bush administration offered nuclear defenses to other areas of the world, and included Taiwan under that protective umbrella. That, he said, would only intensify the move toward independence on Taiwan. Mr. Bush's intentions to increase the sale of sophisticated arms to Taiwan already promised new problems with Beijing and would, Mr. Yan said, "seriously affect U.S.-China relations."
There is also concern in the region that like Dr. Albright, neither General Powell nor Condoleezza Rice, a Russian scholar picked today for the job of national security adviser, knows much about Asia or economics.
Ms. Rice describes herself as a "Europeanist," but in Europe, too, there is unease about the potential for a further rift between the European Union and Washington over issues like missile defense and the relationship between NATO and a nascent European rapid-reaction force.
Foreign Office Minister Peter Hain of Britain said today that his government recognized American concerns over nuclear threats by so-called rogue states, but hoped the new administration would heed allied angst and go slow on missile defense.
"What we don't want to see is any unilateral steps by Washington which could breach the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, especially in terms of Russian interests," Mr. Hain said.
That is a view shared by Germany, said Karl Kaiser, a government adviser and an analyst of American-German relations. But there are more pressing issues. Noting that Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen spoke recently about the danger of NATO becoming "a relic" if the new European force was planned independently of NATO, Mr. Kaiser urged talks with General Powell.
"It is very urgent that we have a real dialogue on how the U.S. and European roles are redefined," Mr. Kaiser said. "The beginnings of an estrangement have been visible lately, and Powell must engage quickly to head this off."
Berlin, far more than Paris, wants to keep NATO healthy and the Americans deeply engaged in Europe, but the Germans are as committed as the French and the British to a more effective European defense identity lending plausibility to a European Union foreign policy.
There is also some concern about Ms. Rice's suggestion that the Europeans can do peacekeeping in the Balkans while the Americans reserve their military for fighting wars. NATO is all about collective sharing of risk, and to undermine that could also start a crisis.
While Bosnia is essentially stable, Kosovo is more explosive with the fall of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and pressure for independence from the majority ethnic Albanians, who trust Washington more than they trust Europe.
The man who succeeded Mr. Milosevic, Vojislav Kostunica, said he welcomed a less interventionist Washington and thought that a Republican administration would not have gone to war over Kosovo.
The Republicans "always had an isolationist wing," Mr. Kostunica said, "which is strictly against American interference in disputes in certain parts of the world, and which is against the thinking that protection of American interests demands a presence in the Balkans or bombing like the one last year against Yugoslavia."
Given General Powell's doctrine of using force only when there is a clear goal, popular support, an exit strategy and overwhelming numbers, many wonder whether he would have supported a Kosovo war.
As Mr. Kaiser put it: "Powell still has to demonstrate that he is able to integrate a military and foreign-policy approach. The world does not consist of situations where you can apply the Powell doctrine, where you gather the force, know what to do, apply that force and get out. In politics, you need allies, institutions and multilateral approaches, not merely American power."
On the Middle East, little substantial change is expected under Mr. Bush, who was said by a Jordanian official to have spoken by telephone on Saturday to King Abdullah of Jordan. The official said his country, which refused to join the American-led coalition against Iraq in the gulf war, respected General Powell.
In Israel, Prime Minister Ehud Barak, who has known General Powell for more than a decade since visiting Washington as an Israeli military strategist, spoke with him today, Mr. Barak's office said. There was no indication as to whether General Powell endorsed the latest, last-ditch effort for a Middle East peace deal under President Clinton.
Italy, one of NATO's most reluctant participants in the war in Yugoslavia, greeted the Powell appointment with some satisfaction. The headline in the Italian daily Corriere della Sera on an article about General Powell's foreign policy read: "His doctrine: more diplomacy, less intervention."
There was a similar sentiment in the Chilean paper El Mercurio: "There is the hope that Washington will initiate an era of moderate diplomacy on the world scene."
Lucio Caracciolo, editor of Limes, an Italian foreign-policy journal, said Europeans trusted General Powell as a reluctant warrior. "He would prefer to only fight wars that are already won," Mr. Caracciolo said dryly.
Unlike many German analysts, Mr. Caracciolo does not view the withdrawal of American troops from the Balkans with alarm. "The only way Europe will ever develop its own security policy is if it weans itself from Mother America," he said. "This could help Europe face its own responsibilities."
Predrag Simic, a Serbian analyst with the Institute of Foreign Policy in Belgrade, said he regarded the American presence in Kosovo as crucial, at least for now. "American troops should leave," Mr. Simic said, "but only when new institutions are built in the Balkans, and that won't be for some years. Security depends on a U.S. military presence in the region."
To fight over Kosovo and then abandon it too soon, Mr. Simic said, would be irresponsible. Still, given the anger of the Serbs over the bombing, "with a new administration we're allowed to start from zero, so we're now at a new beginning in both countries," with a chance to re-establish good relations of the kind that dominated the last century, before Mr. Milosevic.
