SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1747 words

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: A Cell Phone Surge Among World's Poor;
In Haiti, Entrepreneurs as Suppliers

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
Cellular telephones may be an increasingly popular convenience in the United States and other prosperous countries. But demand is growing even faster in the world's poor nations, including in Haiti, where wireless phones are considered a necessity for those who can afford them.
With financially distressed governments often unable to provide adequate public services, including telephones, people are turning to privately built wireless networks as a way to communicate over extended distances. 
 "My cell phone allows me to dream of romance," said Remarais Brunel, a 24-year-old assistant director of a computer school here. He has learned Spanish to be able to speak with his girlfriend, who lives in the Dominican Republic, which shares the island of Hispaniola with French- and Creole-speaking Haiti. "My only problem is that I must budget my calls to just a few minutes each month."
Amid new political and economic tension in Haiti, where presidential elections recently returned Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power, one of the few systems that works reliably is the privately run cellular telephone network built by the local unit of an American company.
Less than 1 percent of the country's nearly eight million people have conventional, fixed-line phone service, compared with more than 95 percent in the United States. And while regular telephone service is less expensive than wireless service, there are 400,000 Haitians on the waiting list for a conventional phone line. The wait can last as long as five years, local people say, and the bureaucracy is such that the social and political standing of the person seeking service outweighs other considerations.
The delays, and the scarcity of phone lines, help explain why the number of mobile subscribers in Haiti climbed 150 percent last year compared with 1998, to about 25,000, enabling cellular phone users to account for more than a third of the nation's telephone customers.
Haiti is not alone among poor countries in witnessing the growth of wireless communications services, according to figures from the International Telecommunication Union in Geneva.
In some Latin American countries, wireless subscribers now outnumber customers of traditional fixed-line telephone companies. Wireless customers, for instance, account for almost 60 percent of phone subscribers in Paraguay, where the number of mobile phone users increased 88 percent last year, to 436,000. In Venezuela, some 57 percent of telephone subscribers use mobile phones.
And while the number of wireless users was growing by 24 percent in the United States last year and 70 percent in Europe, the growth rate in Africa was 116 percent. To be sure, the number of cell phone users in rich industrial nations is still higher.
Still, Zimbabwe had the fastest-growing wireless industry in the world in 1999, with wireless subscribers increasing by more than 800 percent, to 174,000. In Botswana, Rwanda and the Ivory Coast, wireless phone subscribers already outnumber users of the traditional telecommunications network.
"The advantage is that the existing infrastructure in these countries is often terrible," said Kent Lupberger, manager of communications investments at the International Finance Corporation, the investment banking arm of the World Bank. "And even in the worst places, there are people with money that are desperate for a viable communications network."
There are other reasons behind the growth of mobile communications systems in poor lands. The cost of adding a wireless line has declined to less than $600 from as much as $1,500 five years ago, said Mr. Lupberger, whose group has invested in more than 20 communications projects.
But perhaps the most important factor has been the eagerness of public officials to allow private companies to build and operate wireless networks, even as some governments try to maintain control over dilapidated fixed-line networks.
"Wireless is much less of a politically charged issue than wire-line in most countries," said Marc Beuls, president and chief executive of Millicom International Cellular, a company based in Luxembourg that operates wireless systems in Vietnam, Pakistan, Paraguay and even in war-devastated Sierra Leone.
"There's also the fascination with wireless technology that eases entry into new markets," Mr. Beuls said.
If there is any country that embodies the opportunities and challenges of adding mobile phone users, it may be Haiti.
In the last few years, government officials -- like those in some other poor countries -- have studied the possibility of privatizing the state-controlled phone company, Telecommunications d'Haiti. But the effort has been shelved because of the political uncertainties associated with Mr. Aristide's imminent return to office.
"It's run like the fiefdom of a select number of bureaucrats with no interest in improving service," said Francois Benoit, a former Haitian ambassador to the United States, who now manages the nation's main Internet service provider. In addition to cellular phones, Mr. Benoit relies on an elaborate walkie-talkie system to communicate with his staff.
The cellular network was built and is operated by a unit of Western Wireless of Bellevue, Wash., whose executives were early to recognize the commercial potential of bypassing a precarious state-controlled communications network that showed few signs of modernization.
After three years of negotiations that began in 1995, Western Wireless was finally granted a license, and the unit, ComCel, which was formed with Haitian investors, completed the construction of a network here in the capital, Port-au-Prince, late last year. Since then, it has been competing with a locally owned company, Haitel, and has succeeded in signing up more than 18,000 subscribers.
"This was a rare chance to build a viable private enterprise in Haiti," Bernard Fils-Aime, general manager of the Western Wireless operations in this country, said in an interview here. The building is guarded by half a dozen men with assault rifles who search all visitors for firearms. "The country doesn't have a long history of putting something like this together," Mr. Fils-Aime noted.
Despite impressive growth in the first year of operations, Mr. Fils-Aime said there were substantial challenges to operating a wireless carrier in Haiti. For instance, some subscribers have complained that they do not have enough electricity in their homes to recharge the batteries for their cell phones. So Mr. Fils-Aime allowes them to plug in free of charge at company headquarters.
Such quick fixes aside, Haiti's fragile economy remains an impediment in various ways. The Haitian currency, the gourde, has declined in value this year by nearly 40 percent, to a rate in New York just over 23 to the dollar -- squeezing ComCel's profit margins as most of the company's equipment costs are in dollars.
And metered service -- the standard, pay-for-what-you-use billing method in the United States -- is not practical here. Bill collection is simply too iffy in a nation where few people have bank accounts and the postal system is unreliable. The payment system involves prepaid service cards that are sold by a network of more than 80 local dealers.
With the average annual income, according to some United States data, only about $350, and with 70 percent unemployed, the cards are still out of reach for most people. The least expensive provides 200 minutes of time for the equivalent of $24. A 600-minute card, with a 5 percent discount, runs about $68.
Still, Western Wireless is pressing forward with its business in Haiti and several other countries. In fact, the company, which also focuses on under-served rural areas in the United States, has one of the most adventurous business models in the wireless industry.
So far, in addition to Haiti, Western Wireless operates networks in Bolivia, the Ivory Coast, Ghana and the former Soviet republic of Georgia. The company complements these operations with systems in higher-income nations like Ireland, Iceland and Croatia. "We go where the big guys fear to tread," said Brad Horvitz, its president of international operations.
The experience of companies like Western Wireless shows how third world areas are adopting some technologies faster than others.
Poor countries, where perhaps four-fifths of the world's people live, had about 40 percent of mobile phone lines in 1999, up from 20 percent in 1995. But those same countries had only about 5 percent of the hub computers of the Internet, according to Emmanuel Forestier, an economist at the World Bank.
"It's undisputed that wireless technology has had a far greater impact on people's lives in developing countries than the Internet," Mr. Forestier said.
Of course, income levels and other economic and political uncertainties are limiting the expansion of wireless systems in some places. In Pakistan, for instance, the government shut down a European company's wireless system for 18 months in 1995 and 1996 out of concern that separatists were using the network.
"You need to know how to operate a business in places without the basic structures of commerce," said Joseph Gatt, president of InterCel of Reston, Va., a company that operates wireless networks in Congo, Madagascar and Guinea.
Still, the startling growth in some markets has created unforeseen opportunities. Brazil, for instance, has more than 15 million wireless subscribers, outnumbering the number of users in Finland, Sweden, Denmark and Iceland combined.
"The publicly traded cellular companies in Brazil are the most attractive stocks in Latin America," said Peter Gruber, president of a hedge fund in the Virgin Islands that invests in Latin America. "Who would have predicted it a few years ago?"
In Port-au-Prince, the cell phone can be necessary baggage for other sorts of entrepreneurial aspiration.
Consider Francois Emmanuel Carlyle-Courtois, who dreams of fame as a rap star. Mr. Carlyle-Courtois, a 32-year-old graphic designer who works at a cultural center in a crumbling gingerbread house, has a wireless phone he shares with his brother to cut costs.
He raps in a rapid-fire mixture of Creole, French and English. "With a cell phone, I can talk to my producer in New York," said Mr. Carlyle-Courtois, or Elylrac by his stage name. "I can even rap on demand into the cell if he wants something fresh. The Americans love it when I do that."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Aetna to Raise Premiums And Eliminate 5,000 Jobs
Aetna, the nation's largest health insurance company, said that it would shed 2 million of its 19 million members over the next year as it raises premiums and tries to make its troubled managed-care business more profitable.
The company also announced plans to eliminate 5,000 jobs, about 13 percent of its work force. The cuts, more than half from attrition, will include some in New Jersey. Page A1. 

Business Tax Shelters Flourish
As companies have discovered how much money they can save using deals designed to help them avoid taxes, Wall Street bankers, lawyers and accountants have rushed in to serve them, charging a fee based on the savings from shelters they design and sell. A1.
 
Budget Bill Curtails Radio Plan
Budget legislation that President Clinton will soon sign contains a provision sought by the nation's largest broadcasters that sharply curtails the plans of the Federal Communications Commission to issue licenses for low-power FM radio stations to 1,000 or more schools, churches and other community groups. A1.
 
Gillette to Cut 8% of Work Force
Gillette said that it would shut down eight factories and 13 distribution centers and lay off 2,700 employees, about 8 percent of its work force. Edward F. DeGraan, the company's acting chief executive, said the layoffs were a result of new technology that allows the company to increase its productivity and efficiency. Shares of Gillette rose $1, to $34.81. C2.
 
Chrysler Loss to Hit $1.4 Billion
DaimlerChrysler indicated that losses at Chrysler would balloon to $1.4 billion in the fourth quarter. And next year may be worse. The disclosure confirmed widespread suspicions that Chrysler's slide had accelerated sharply. World Business, Section W.
 
'Survivor II' to Challenge 'Friends'
CBS said that the second season of its hit show "Survivor" would be broadcast at 8 p.m. on Thursdays, up against "Friends," which leads off NBC's dominant lineup. C7.
 
Fed to Consider Rates Today
More than a decade after the start of the last recession, the Federal Reserve will meet today to debate how to keep the current slowdown from becoming a downturn. C2.
 
Blue Chips Rise as Nasdaq Falls
Optimism that interest rates might soon be cut lifted blue-chip stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 210.46 points, or 2 percent, to 10,645.42. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 10.59 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,322.74. The Nasdaq composite index fell 28.75 points, or 1.1 percent, to 2,624.52. C10.
 
Shell Plans to Increase Savings
Royal Dutch/Shell said at an annual meeting of shareholders that it planned to increase cost savings and maintain production in the face of expectations for declining oil prices. It also said that Phil Watts, group managing director, left, would succeed the company's chairman, Sir Mark Moody-Stuart, when he retires in July. World Business, Section W.
 
Verizon Pulls Long-Distance Petition
Verizon withdrew its application to offer long-distance communications services in Massachusetts, fearful that the petition would be rejected by federal regulators. C4.
 
Prudential Lays Off 160 Bankers
Prudential Securities dismissed 160 investment bankers and will now almost exclusively provide financial advice and sell insurance and securities through brokers. C8.

Israeli Parliament Votes Not to Disband for Election
The Israeli Parliament voted against dissolving for new elections, meaning that Israel will go to the polls in February to elect only a prime minister. Benjamin Netanyahu, a former prime minister who had considered running again, reportedly pulled out of the contest. A1 

U.N. Says No to Mideast Troops
The Palestinians failed to muster enough votes in the United Nations Security Council to send an international protection force to the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel and the United States have strenuously opposed the proposal. A14
 
Yugoslavia Appeals to NATO
The Yugoslav government is urging NATO to let the country's military and police forces move more freely in a security zone that borders Kosovo, to beat back ethnic Albanian militants. Currently, only Serbian police officers, with light weapons, may enter the zone, where they have been attacked repeatedly by Albanian militia. A13
 
Russian Leader in Canada
President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia visited Canada and lined up support for "strengthening" a cold-war treaty that the Russians see as blocking American deployment of a national missile defense system. A7
 
I.M.F. to Aid Argentina
The International Monetary Fund and private banks promised as much as $39.7 billion to help Argentina reduce its mounting debt burden, spark its economy and stem a crisis of confidence that some economists worried could spread through Latin America. A16
 
Pentagon Criticized for Imports
A Pentagon agency that runs stores on American military bases imported $138,290 in clothing made in Myanmar at a time when the Clinton administration had banned new investments in that country, documents show. While such purchases are not illegal, critics in Congress and human rights groups say they violate the spirit of the administration's economic sanctions. A11

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
United Rentals, which rents construction and industrial equipment in the United States, Canada and Mexico, said bad weather, project delays and the slowing economy were eating into its revenue, and it warned that fourth-quarter earnings would be about 40 cents a share, less than two-thirds of the 62 cents analysts had forecast. HEADLINE: THE 43RD PRESIDENT: THE PRESIDENT-ELECT;
PRESIDENT-ELECT COURTS CONGRESS AND URGES TAX CUT

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
President-elect George W. Bush courted Republican and Democratic leaders in the Capitol today and promised to salve "whatever wounds may exist" from the election.
Yet Mr. Bush also emphasized that he planned to push for his full campaign agenda, including a broad tax cut, and would use "head-knocking" and "gentle arm-twisting" to prevail. 
 Mr. Bush's triumphant sweep through the capital took place as the Electoral College met in states across the nation and cast the votes that sealed his presidency. In a whirlwind day, he had breakfast with the Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, met lawmakers, paid a visit to President Jacques Chirac of France and interviewed candidates for his cabinet.
Republicans said that former Senator Daniel R. Coats, Republican of Indiana, was all but certain to be named defense secretary; that Paul H. O'Neill, chairman of the aluminum maker Alcoa, was a strong contender for treasury secretary; and that Ann Veneman, former California agriculture director, was a prospect for secretary of agriculture.
On Capitol Hill, Mr. Bush stood side by side with all four Congressional leaders of both parties. Glancing often at the two Democrats, he vowed that "this isn't a single photo opportunity" but the first step in building a working relationship.
While the president-elect's victory tour of Washington is a ceremonial tradition, this one was marked by strange political and historical cross-currents. Mr. Bush's father, President George Bush, put some of the blame for his defeat on Mr. Greenspan, believing the Fed had not acted aggressively enough to end the recession that helped Bill Clinton defeat him. Page A30.
And when Laura Bush and Hillary Rodham Clinton shared tea this morning, Mrs. Clinton was not just a first lady but also a senator-elect whose name is already bandied about as a possible presidential candidate for 2004.
While Mr. Greenspan prefers tax cuts to increases in government spending, he has long argued that the best choice is to use federal surpluses to reduce the national debt. But until a few months ago, the Fed's main concern about the economy was that it was too strong.
Now the situation is very different. And there were no signs of strain today between the incoming president and the Fed chairman who has become a revered Washington institution. The Fed is expected to signal on Tuesday that it is ready to cut interest rates next year to ward off a recession.
"I talked with a good man here," Mr. Bush said, placing his hand on Mr. Greenspan's shoulder as he escorted him out of his hotel this morning. "We had a very strong discussion about my confidence in his abilities."
Perhaps the day's most significant tableau came on Capitol Hill in the Rayburn Room, named after another powerful Texan, the legendary former speaker Sam Rayburn. Before a battery of television cameras, Mr. Bush appeared with the Congressional leaders who would go a long way toward determining his success in these divided political times.
To Mr. Bush's right stood the Republicans, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader. To his left stood the Democrats, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader. Mr. Bush made a point today of spending time one-on-one with each of the two Democrats.
All five men took pains to sound conciliatory and Mr. Bush said jokingly, "I told all four that there are going to be some times where we don't agree with each other, but that's O.K. If this were a dictatorship, this would be a heck of a lot easier."
Chuckling, he added, "Just so long as I'm dictator."
More seriously, Mr. Bush said, "I've got opinions and they've got opinions." He added, "It's amazing what happens when you listen to the other person's opinion and we began the process of doing that today."
But for all the good will, the difficulties facing Mr. Bush and the divided Congress were also apparent.
The two Democrats stood stone-faced as Mr. Bush insisted he would move forward with his plan for $1.3 trillion in tax cuts across 10 years and said the slowing economy made it essential. He said he would make the case that "marginal rate reductions will help spur economic activity and economic growth."
"I think the case is even more solid today than it was a year ago when I started campaigning on the issue," the president-elect added.
Mr. Bush's tax-cut plan calls for an across-the-board reduction in all income tax rates, dropping the bottom rate to 10 percent from 15 percent, for example, and reducing the top rate of 39.6 percent to 33 percent. The proposal would also repeal the estate tax, reduce the taxes of some married couples, and double the child credit to $1,000 per child from $500.
The plan was one of the starkest dividing lines of the campaign, with Vice President Al Gore proposing less than $500 billion in tax cuts across a decade, mostly for certain specific social needs like a college education.
"There's going to be a lot of discussions, a lot of head-knocking, kind of gentle arm-twisting," Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Gephardt, perhaps sending Mr. Bush a message about how far the Democrats are willing to bend, said, "We will be there coming 50 percent of the way, sometimes even further, to the middle to get things done for the people that sent us here and hired us."
But unlike his remarks on the Sunday talk programs, when Mr. Gephardt danced around the question of whether he recognized Mr. Bush as the legitimate president, today he showed no hesitation. Noting that the Electoral College was meeting this very day to elect Mr. Bush, he said, "I don't know how you can get more legitimate than that."
Mr. Daschle said, "Absolutely, President-elect Bush is a legitimate president of the United States."
Republicans said that when Mr. Bush met with a larger group of the House Republican leadership earlier in the morning, there was discussion of how to sell the tax plan, including whether to pass it piece by piece. Several Republicans counseled that the president should not focus on the broad numbers of the plan but should make the policy case for it.
"We learned from the first session and second session of the 106th Congress that simply talking about numbers is a mistake," said Representative David Dreier, a California Republican.
Mr. Bush, a former oilman, also talked extensively with lawmakers about his desire for an aggressive energy policy to increase national production and make the nation less dependent on foreign oil.
"I'm not going to allow the working people of this country to suffer," Mr. Bush told Congressional leaders, his spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said. During the campaign, Mr. Bush proposed, among other steps, opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to more exploration.
Mr. Gephardt said later in an interview, "I think it's possible to get to some compromise on this, but you can't forget the environmental side of it."
Mr. Bush also spent much of the day interviewing candidates for his cabinet. Vice President-elect Dick Cheney disputed a report in The New York Times that he and retired Gen. Colin L. Powell, tapped to be secretary of state, were backing different candidates for defense secretary.
Mr. Cheney said in an interview on CNN's "Wolf Blitzer Reports" that Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, who was said to be Mr. Powell's candidate, had withdrawn his name weeks ago. Republicans close to the Bush campaign said that Mr. Coats was the leading contender for the post.
Mr. Bush and his aides tried to keep his cabinet deliberations private. But other officials said Mr. Bush had a lunch meeting with Mr. O'Neill, the treasury candidate. Mr. O'Neill served in the White House budget office in the Nixon and Ford years and is friendly with Mr. Greenspan, said one Republican who knows both men.
And Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey was seen at midday entering the Washington hotel that is Mr. Bush's Washington headquarters. Republicans said she could be a candidate for administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Mr. Bush's trip to Washington is just one of the many steps he is taking this week to prepare for governing. On Wednesday, aides said, he will meet in Austin, Tex., with an array of religious leaders, many of them from prominent black churches, to explore the "compassionate conservative" themes with which he began his campaign. Plans for the meeting were first reported by The Washington Post.
On Thursday, he is to meet with many Hispanic leaders to discuss issues of education.
One of Mr. Bush's cabinet nominees was already on the job today. General Powell arrived for his first day of work on the transition at the State Department this morning.
Early this evening, Mr. Bush paid a courtesy call on President Chirac, in town for a European Union meeting with Mr. Clinton.
"Mr. President, I am so honored," Bush said to Mr. Chirac as the two posed for a picture at the French ambassador's residence.
Before returning to Texas on Tuesday, Mr. Bush will visit President Clinton and Mr. Gore. The last time Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore encountered each other in person was in their testy third debate in October.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Intelligex, a new Web site, moves into the new world of online market-research exchanges.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE fledgling field of online custom market-research exchanges is getting another entry as two entrepreneurs put up a Web site intended to bring together buyers and sellers.
Matthew J. Storm and Eric B. Fishman have opened Intelligex Inc. in New York to operate the site (www.intelligex.com), which has signed 90 research suppliers and 60 research buyers as initial partners. The research companies working with Intelligex include Maritz Marketing Research, the Opinion Research Corporation and Yankelovich Partners. 
 The formation of Intelligex, which comes soon after the introduction of Marketinginfo.com in New York, is indicative of a growing belief in the importance of proprietary market research as advertisers and agencies seek more penetrating insights into how and why consumers buy -- or don't buy. Just yesterday, VNU N.V., the Dutch publishing giant that owns the Nielsen Media Research television ratings company, agreed to spend $2.3 billion to acquire the A. C. Nielsen Corporation, which measures and analyzes sales and behavioral data.
"The value of quick and convenient information is extremely high," said Mr. Fishman, 28, the chief operating officer at Intelligex. "Whoever has the information first, wins."
Yet as the research industry keeps expanding, said Mr. Storm, also 28, who is the chief executive of Intelligex, many advertisers and agencies "don't have the time or expertise to find the optimal supplier of custom research."
Needless to say, Mr. Storm and Mr. Fishman are not eager for Intelligex to be characterized as a business-to-business dot-com, a label now derided as much as it was prized mere months ago. Rather, as they seek venture capital in addition to the $1 million raised in a first round of financing, they describe the company as an intermediary, intended to lower costs to buyers while generating additional revenue for sellers.
"It helps to level the playing field between a larger research company and a smaller research company like us, which can't spend the money to market itself the way the larger ones can," said Nicholas Tortorello, president at Guideline Research and Consulting in New York, one of the suppliers working with Intelligex.
"We also see Internet research as a quickly growing part of our business that will be a great leg up on doing work globally," said Mr. Tortorello, the incoming chairman of an industry association, the Council of American Survey Research Organizations. "Everything is moving online, including advertising and marketing services."
To be sure, there are risks involved in trying to alter longtime habits.
Custom market research "can be very specialized," said Gregory Ellis, vice president and general manager for the research division at DoubleClick in New York, and "seemingly subtle differences in specifications can result in significantly different costs."
"This complexity poses unique challenges to a successful buyer-seller exchange," said Mr. Ellis, a member of the Intelligex advisory board. "Resistance to change poses additional challenge."
Still, he described himself as convinced that a custom market-research exchange "will ultimately be successful."
One Intelligex customer, Kelly Eng, senior analyst at Creative Good, an Internet consulting company in San Francisco, said she "would definitely use Intelligex again," adding that next time she would focus on the quality of the research as well as the cost.
"The quality ended up not so great, but a lot of it was our fault," Ms. Eng said. "I'd be willing to pay a little more to get the quality up."
"Matthew and I have talked about how to improve the service," she added. "We've learned a lot."
That's a thought also expressed by the head of Marketinginfo.com, which began operating in September with research suppliers like Greenfield Online; the NFO Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies; A. C. Nielsen; and Taylor Nelson Sofres.
"Every day for us as a company is a learning process," said Bruce Weinstein, 26, chief executive at Marketinginfo.com, which has a partnership agreement with the Advertising Research Foundation in New York.
Still, "our experience has been overwhelmingly positive," he added.
Whether, to paraphrase a line uttered by gunfighters in old Western films, there is room in this business for both companies remains to be seen. In the meantime, both are working to, as Mr. Storm put it, "make the process of purchasing research less painful and less costly." 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: December 21, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising column in Business Day on Tuesday, about online custom market-research exchanges, misstated the given name of the chief executive at Marketinginfo.com in New York. He is Brian Weinstein, not Bruce.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: TAX MAGICIANS/A special report.;
Sham Shelters for Business Flourish as Scrutiny Fades

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch saved AlliedSignal $180 million. A division in Merrill's army of bankers, lawyers and accountants -- known as the financial engineers -- had invented a way for AlliedSignal to escape taxes it owed the federal government on the sale of an oil business.
The scheme worked this way: the company transferred the taxable profit on the sale to a newly created partnership with a foreign company, which turned around and returned the same amount to AlliedSignal in a way that made it no longer count as taxable profits. 
 For their efforts, Merrill and its associates got a cut of the savings -- $25 million, or more than 13 cents on every dollar rescued from the government.
For decades, accountants and lawyers charged by the hour for advising corporations on how to arrange deals to legally avoid as much tax as possible. But the business has changed in two significant ways. First, Merrill and others decided they could create business deals that existed only on paper and could wipe out enormous tax bills. Second, they could demand a cut of the savings for devising the techniques that make the deal look real. The bigger the savings, the higher the fee.
As companies have discovered how much money these deals can save them, Wall Street bankers, lawyers and accountants have rushed in to serve them. All of the Big Five accounting firms -- PricewaterhouseCoopers, Ernst & Young, Deloitte & Touche, KPMG and Arthur Andersen -- now charge corporations a fee based on the savings from tax shelters they design and sell. So do big investment houses, notably Merrill Lynch, Goldman, Sachs and Bear, Stearns.
Some of their colleagues in these fields are appalled. They say that many of these tax shelters are illegal because they have no business purpose; they exist only to avoid taxes. They say that such shelters would be much less likely to be approved by advisers who are not compromised by the possibility of profiting handsomely from work that requires strikingly little time.
Indeed, the United States Tax Court ruled the AlliedSignal deal, struck in 1990, was a sham, and an appeals court upheld that decision earlier this year. AlliedSignal, now called Honeywell and planning to merge with General Electric, is appealing. Merrill Lynch sold a similar shelter to 10 other companies.
But few tax shelters are uncovered by an Internal Revenue Service whose resources have been significantly reduced in recent years. And even if one is discovered, penalties are rare. Criminal prosecution is almost unheard of. And, as in the AlliedSignal case, the Treasury is still without the money while appeals drag on for years.
In short, the money to be made can seem well worth the very small risk of being caught. That is why the tax shelter business is thriving to an extent that worries even some people in the field.
Paul J. Sax, former chairman of the American Bar Association's tax section and a partner at the law firm of Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe in San Francisco, used simple math to explain why tax shelters are so attractive -- "if you are willing to turn a blind eye to whether a deal really works or is a sham."
He cited a case he knows about on the condition that he not identify the participants. It involved a $7 million fee for a tax shelter that will save a company $100 million.
"I have a chance of being hit by the I.R.S. with a 20 percent penalty" for false reporting -- $20 million on top of the $100 million owed, Mr. Sax said. "Based on my experience I calculate that chance to be one in 50 because the likelihood of the I.R.S. detecting this transaction in my very large tax return is small, the chance of them pursuing it correctly is small, the chance of them pursuing through to litigation is small, the chance a judge will uphold a penalty is small."
What that means, he said, is that "once I get past 'I know I am doing something wrong here,' the arithmetic settles it for me."
"What is $7 million for at least an 80 percent chance at $100 million?"
He noted that the recent weakness of the I.R.S. because of budget cuts and new restraints imposed by Congress has only emboldened corporations. They "could not pick a better time to exploit the inability of the I.R.S. to deal with this under present law, under present funding and under the present demoralized state of the auditors."
Promoters of tax shelters are eager to play because of the dazzling payoff. "To think up a shelter, work out the details and then put it down on paper so you can sell it to others takes, maybe, 100 hours," said Peter L. Faber, a tax partner at McDermott, Will & Emery in New York who wants a crackdown on abusive tax shelters. "Then you take that idea to the biggest companies and tell them your fee is $10 million. Where else can you earn that kind of money?"
Lawyers asked to render opinions on whether a shelter was legal can also be intoxicated by the chance to profit handsomely. Buck Chapoton, a tax lawyer at Vinson & Elkins in Washington and a former tax policy chief for President Ronald Reagan, said he had been offered hundreds of thousands of dollars to write a letter characterizing as legitimate a tax-avoidance plan he considered a sham. Mr. Chapoton said another top tax lawyer told him that he had turned down more than $1 million to write such a letter.
"For those kinds of fees, the purveyors are not buying your professional advice," Mr. Chapoton said. "They are buying your good name and, sadly, at those prices there are lawyers and law firms that will sell."
Some corporations, including Ford Motor, say they refuse to participate in questionable tax shelters. But others have participated. Colgate-Palmolive, United Parcel Service, Winn-Dixie Stores and the advertising agency Foote, Cone & Belding, now part of True North Communications, have all engaged in tax shelters that the courts held were shams. Each of these rulings is now being appealed.
But the great majority of shams go undetected, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers says. His aides have said that audits uncover perhaps one of every 10 illegitimate shelters.
Indeed, the Treasury Department has identified corporate tax evasion as the nation's biggest tax enforcement problem, and such shelters are at the core of it. Over the next decade, illegitimate tax shelters will short the government tens of billions of dollars, Mr. Summers said, adding that this official estimate is conservative because audits uncover "just the tip of the iceberg."
The Treasury Department has learned of some tax shelters through anonymous mailings of tax shelter documents, presumably sent by participants who found them improper but could not stop them. In recent weeks the department has proposed regulations intended to shut down tax shelters with names like Captain Sandy's, the Guam Residence Trust and, earlier this year, BOSS and Baby BOSS.
The Guam Residence Trust, first disclosed in the journal Tax Notes, relied on an opinion by Daniel M. Berman of the Washington office of the law firm of Sutherland Asbill & Brennan. Mr. Berman has been a tax official both with the Treasury Department and the Joint Committee on Taxation.
Mr. Chapoton and Mr. Sax said they were angry and saddened that Mr. Berman wrote an opinion letter for a trust that Mr. Chapoton said "doesn't even pass the smell test."
Mr. Berman denied there was anything improper and said, "I am not in the tax shelter business."
 
The Fees
The More You Save, The More You Pay
Charging a fee based on a percentage of the taxes avoided is prohibited by ethics rules of the accounting industry and is widely frowned upon by other tax professionals. The more subtle, and widely accepted, variation is called value pricing, in which the sellers of tax shelters set their price based not on hourly fees but on how much a client would be willing to pay to save a lot more on taxes. In some cases that amount is half the savings. The sellers assert that this more fairly compensates them for the value of the techniques that they invented.
In some cases, the tax shelter adviser is paid even if the tax savings are disallowed; in others the fee is contingent on surviving any challenge.
There are basically two kinds of tax shelters. In both cases, they become illegitimate when they serve little or no purpose other than avoiding taxes.
One kind lets companies take a deduction today and pay taxes later, in effect borrowing from the government the taxes owed and paying no interest.
Others, like the Merrill Lynch shelter that AlliedSignal bought, create an artificial deduction so that taxes are never paid. The deal allowed AlliedSignal to shift profits to a partnership created with a Dutch bank and two newly created entities in countries with no income taxes. Later Allied took back its money, but it appeared on its books as an untaxable return of capital. The Tax Court and an appeals court said it was all a sham.
Merrill Lynch sold the same shelter to companies including American Home Products, Borden, Brunswick, Colgate-Palmolive, Dun & Bradstreet and Schering-Plough. Some of these companies helped finance Colgate-Palmolive's so far unsuccessful fight to win approval for the shelter in court.
Merrill Lynch said both its tax experts and its clients' advisers thought the tax and economic aspects of the deals were proper, but "it would be fair to say that in the wake of the court's ruling our business places far greater reliance on the economic component" in deals it now markets.
Merrill Lynch relied on an opinion by Mark A. Kuller, then a tax lawyer with the Washington office of the law firm of King & Spalding. The appeals court sharply criticized Mr. Kuller for merely assuming a legitimate business purpose existed.
"I was asked to write an informal memo based on the assumption that there was a business purpose," said Mr. Kuller, who is now with McKee Nelson Ernst & Young in Washington.
 
The Pioneers
Early Plan Blocked Because of Pricing
The business of selling tax shelters began to grow quickly after bold moves by accountants like Robert M. Dolgin of St. Louis. Sixteen years ago he proposed to his partners at what is now Ernst & Young an arrangement that was a precursor of the ones today.
What troubled Mr. Dolgin's partners was not the tax shelter itself so much as the way he wanted to charge corporations for it.
"Instead of an hourly rate, Bob wanted his fee to be a percentage of the tax savings," recalled John O. Niemann, who was Mr. Dolgin's mentor. "We said no to that."
Sharing in the tax savings was unacceptable, Mr. Niemann said, because it raised questions about how the accounting firm could give detached professional advice when it had a stake in the outcome of that advice.
Mr. Dolgin formed Dolgin & Associates in Houston and soon boasted to his former mentor that he was making $1.5 million annually.
He declined to discuss his clients or his tax shelters. But documents filed in a Tax Court case involving General Signal, now part of the SPX Corporation, show that Mr. Dolgin charged a percentage of the taxes clients saved for using his tax shelter, which manipulated the rules on financing employee benefit plans to accelerate deductions.
The shelter was ruled a sham by the Tax Court, and General Signal later paid the taxes.
The I.R.S. has investigated Mr. Dolgin's shelters, but has taken no action against him.
 
Another Shelter
Creating Losses Where None Existed
Another big player in tax shelters is Robert N. Gordon, founder of the Twenty-First Securities Corporation in New York.
Both Compaq Computer and Alliant Energy, which operates a large electric utility in Iowa, bought tax shelters from Mr. Gordon that the Tax Court found were shams. The shelters involved arranging trading losses that offset profits from investments in other companies.
A trading partner was needed, and so was a tax-exempt pension fund. And an enormous number of shares had to be borrowed from unwitting pension funds, change hands briefly overnight through a Bear, Stearns office in Amsterdam, and then be bought back and returned to the pension fund.
In most of these transactions the trading partner was Foote, Cone & Belding, which was paid $1,000 a day for its role in the trades. Foote, Cone was a "passive investor" in these deals and was not aware of the plan, said Kathryn Woods, a spokeswoman for Ture North Communications.
Mr. Gordon said he disagreed with the Tax Court finding and said he was not selling tax shelters but, rather, products that take advantage of "the stupid ways" the tax laws are written.
His firm charges what he said were modest fees, often less than 5 cents for each share traded. But the volume of trades that Alliant Energy needed to wipe out $12 million in taxes was huge. Indeed, Alliant Energy paid Mr. Gordon's firm $5.5 million.
Mr. Summers said that the Treasury Department and the I.R.S. would propose this month a tightening of the rules under which accountants and lawyers who practice before the I.R.S. conduct themselves. Whether the Bush administration will follow through on those changes or seek to undo them is not known.
The changes could not come too soon, said Mr. Chapoton, the former Reagan tax policy official, because prominent tax lawyers are now writing opinions that endorse shams "and, unfortunately, my profession does not look down on them for doing it."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 25, 2000, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Tuesday about abusive corporate tax shelters misstated the source and target of a sharp criticism involving a shelter sold to investors by Merrill Lynch. The criticism was made by the Internal Revenue Service in a filing with the the United States Tax Court, not by the appellate court, and was directed at the shelter, on which Mark A. Kuller, a Washington tax lawyer, gave advice, not at Mr. Kuller himself.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Making Taxes Go Away"
Wall Street bankers, accountants and lawyers have invented a variety of techniques to help corporations avoid many millions in taxes. Such techniques are illegal if they have no business purpose and exist only to avoid taxes. But many such techniques, which involve a flurry of deals that send money back and forth, are never uncovered. Here is one that was ruled a sham by the tax court. It cut the taxes of the utility Alliant Energy by $12 million. The company paid the creators of the strategy $5.5 million. Twenty-First Securities arranged 332 transactions like the one below, which each took only a few hours, with stock worth $9.2 billion.
 
The Technique: Using a Lost Tax Credit
 
FOREIGN STOCK
Owned by many pension plans, which are tax-exempt.
 
THE TAXES
When dividends are paid by foreign companies, foreign governments tax those dividends at a 15 percent rate.
 
THE LOST CREDIT
Most United States taxpayers who lose part of their foreign dividend to foreign taxes can claim a tax credit in the U.S. equal to the taxes. That credit is useless for the pension plans because they are already tax-exempt.
 
Recycling The Credit
How Alliant Energy acquired the use of the lost tax credit.
 
STOCK BORROWED
A company called Foote, Cone & Belding, acting as a middleman in most of the trades, borrowed the stock from the pension plans, putting up cash equal to 102 percent of the value of the borrowed stock.
 
STOCK SOLD
Through Twenty-First Securities, Foote, Cone immediately sold the stock to Alliant Energy for an amount equal to the value of the stock plus 85 percent of the dividend that was due.
 
DIVIDEND COLLECTED
Alliant Energy held on to the stock for only minutes to qualify to collect the 85 percent of the dividend in cash and the other 15 percent as a foreign tax credit it would use to reduce its U.S. income taxes.
 
STOCK SOLD BACK
Alliant Energy, through Twenty-First Securities, sold the stock back to Foote, Cone moments later at a loss equal to 85 percent of the dividend. This loss offset the 85 percent of the dividend Alliant would collect in cash, and Alliant now owned the right to the foreign tax credit.
 
STOCK AND DIVIDEND RETURNED
Foote, Cone returned the stock to the pension plans with the 85 percent of the dividend, which offset its profits from the trades with Alliant so its tax situation was unaffected.
 
COLLATERAL RETURNED
In turn, the pension plans refunded the collateral that was equal to 102 percent of the stock's value.
 
The Result
 
PENSION PLANS
Was able to invest cash equal to 102 percent of the value of the borrowed stock for the duration of the loan.
 
ALLIANT ENERGY
Claimed the credit for foreign taxes paid on dividends and used it to reduce its United States income taxes by nearly $12 million.
 
FOOTE, CONE & BELDING
Was paid $1,000 for its role in each of the transactions.
 
TWENTY-FIRST SECURITIES
Collected $5.5 million in fees.
 
U.S. GOVERNMENT
Lost $12 million in taxes.
 
(Dylan Loeb McClain/The New York Times)(pg. C8)

HEADLINE: Keeping Workers Safe, but at What Cost?

BYLINE: By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
In November, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration issued a far-reaching, controversial rule intended to protect employees from repetitive stress injuries -- the disabled arms, aching backs and other maladies that each year fell an estimated 600,000 Americans who type, bend, reach and lift objects repeatedly at work.
Businesses have until October to comply. In the meantime, though, a range of businesses, trade groups, insurance companies and unions are filing legal challenges. Congressional opponents are expected to try to repeal the rule in the coming session, and President-elect George W. Bush's administration is likely to propose revisions. 
 Much of the business community's unhappiness with the ergonomics rule centers on its anticipated cost. Many managers contend that repetitive stress injuries are poorly understood, and that government is forcing companies to pay huge sums to reduce hazards that may not really exist.
How huge? The projections are all over the map. OSHA estimates that businesses will spend $4.5 billion on compliance in the rule's first year. The National Association of Manufacturers puts the cost at $6.7 billion for just its core constituency of 10,000 small and medium-size manufacturers. The Employment Policy Foundation, a business-oriented research group, predicts a toll on the economy of $125.8 billion in the first year of compliance, and a budget-busting $886.6 billion over the coming decade.
What is a nonspecialist to make of these wildly conflicting numbers? History may hold insights.
In 1992, members of the House Committee on Education and Labor were also troubled by the dueling cost projections each major new OSHA rule seemed to generate. Vinyl chloride, cotton dust, lead, formaldehyde -- each new standard elicited cries from business that the rule would bankrupt them, and countercharges from labor that OSHA was making the standards too lax. Committee members, concerned that something was seriously out of whack, asked the Office of Technology Assessment, a Congressional research agency, to take a careful look at OSHA's cost projection methods.
The research agency put together a panel of economists and occupational health specialists from academia, industry and organized labor. The group looked at more than a dozen major OSHA safety rules that had been on the books for at least five years, and in one case for more than two decades. Because so much time had passed, the panelists were able to determine, for eight of the rules, how much the affected industries had actually spent on compliance.
The findings, published in 1995 -- the same year the research agency was closed by a budget-minded Congress -- make interesting reading today, given the uproar about OSHA's newest rule. Not only did the panelists learn that the affected industries' fears of crushing costs were usually way off target; they found that even OSHA tended to overestimate the cost of its rules.
In the case of vinyl chloride, for instance, the plastics industry railed that OSHA's rule, promulgated in 1974, would cost $65 billion to $90 billion to comply with and wipe American plastics off the map. OSHA projected that industry would have to spend $1 billion to reduce worker exposures to vinyl chloride, a gas that may cause cancer. In fact, users were able to eliminate the substance for no more than $278 million.
When OSHA proposed limiting worker exposure to cotton dust, the industry warned that compliance would cost $2.3 billion. OSHA revised the rule and issued a projection of $280.3 million, which industry said was still too low. In the end, however, textile mills were able to reduce the risk to workers' lungs for $82.8 million.
OSHA's 1987 rule on formaldehyde elicited cries that it would cost users $251.2 million. The O.T.A. panel looked only at one large group of users -- metal foundries -- and found again that while OSHA had projected costs of $11.4 million, the affected companies eventually cleaned up their workplaces for $6 million.
Only in one out of the six mandatory rules studied did OSHA underestimate the cost to business, that of ethylene oxide, a toxic sterilizing agent used in hospitals. And in that case, the panelists discovered that OSHA had failed to anticipate the scrupulousness with which hospitals moved to reduce exposures. They reduced ethylene oxide leaks to levels lower than OSHA had required, and thus spent more money than OSHA had projected they would.
For a fifth rule, covering workplace lead exposures, the panel was unable to draw clear lessons because the affected industries requested extensions and were not yet in compliance.
Why did OSHA overshoot so often? The panelists concluded that the agency's main problem was a tendency to assume that business would reduce workplace hazards by stepping up existing technologies. If, for instance, the problem was an airborne poison, then companies would reduce worker exposures by installing new ventilators or putting lids on vats.
In practice, though, businesses were in many cases able to devise radical new manufacturing processes to reduce the hazards. Instead of installing ventilators, for example, they might substitute different raw materials, eliminating the offending toxin from the stream of production. These innovations pared hundreds of millions of dollars off the estimated compliance costs.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: From grain dust, left, to cotton particles, top, to lead, above, OSHA has issued rules requiring businesses to protect employees from harm at work. (Bettmann/Corbis, left; David Smart, top)
 
Chart: "Overshooting the Mark"
When OSHA creates a new workplace regulation, it estimates the cost to private industry. Private industry also tries to estimate the cost, usually coming up with higher figures. Often, however, all estimates end up being too high.
 
RULE CONCERNING: Vinyl chloride
WHEN PASSED: Oct. 4, 1974
 
OSHA estimate: $1 bil.
Range of industry estimates: $65 bil.
If top estimate were to scale, it would be about 5 feet 9 inches tall: $94 bil.
Actual cost: $278 mil.
 
Figures are total cost in 1974 dollars
 
RULE CONCERNING: Cotton dust
WHEN PASSED: June 23, 1978
 
OSHA estimate (Includes equipment costs amortized ): $280 mil.
Range of industry estimates: $273 mil.
Does not include initial outlays of $865 million to $1.57 billion: $444 mil.
 
Actual cost: $83 mil.
 
Figures are annual cost in 1982 dollars
(Source: Occupational Safety and Health Administration; Office of Technology Assessment)

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT;
For Armstrong, Bankruptcy Is Lesser of Two Evils

BYLINE: By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

DATELINE: LANCASTER, Pa.

 BODY:
It was a wrenching choice, and last August, Armstrong Holdings, hired Michael D. Lockhart as chief executive to make it: either accept the risk of a slow death by litigation or suffer the stigma of seeking relief in bankruptcy court.
Four months later, after an exhaustive study of claims against Armstrong for decades-old asbestos injuries, Mr. Lockhart took the only course that he thought would ensure the company's long-term survival. He directed its Armstrong World Industries unit to file for Chapter 11 protection from creditors. 
 "Almost no one associated with this company was interested in Chapter 11," Mr. Lockhart said in a recent interview at Armstrong headquarters in Lancaster. "The stigma is, you go into Chapter 11 because your business is no good."
That was not the case with Armstrong, a manufacturer of floor and ceiling materials that employs 18,000 people worldwide. In the three months ended Sept. 30, it earned $74.3 million on sales of $835.6 million, up from $71.7 million on sales of $844.3 million in the period a year earlier.
Indeed, Mr. Lockhart said, the company could have obtained additional credit, albeit on increasingly unfavorable terms. But that would have only prolonged the uncertainty, he said. And so Armstrong joined a roster of other Fortune 500 companies with otherwise solid balance sheets, including Texaco and Owens Corning, that have turned to the bankruptcy courts as part of a broad strategy to resolve potentially ruinous legal woes.
"This is a business problem, not an emotional problem," he said. "A problem like any other."
But it was too difficult a problem for an Armstrong insider to solve, analysts said. Mr. Lockhart, 51, filled the bill as an objective outsider, they said. He had been chairman and chief executive of General Signal, a Stamford, Conn., manufacturing company, for three years until it was sold in 1998 to SPX, and had spent the time since then mostly sailing the Caribbean. Previously, he had been an executive at General Electric for 13 years and before that, a consultant at the Boston Consulting Group for six years.
"He was likely less emotionally attached to this decision," said Budd Bugatch, senior vice president at Raymond James & Associates, an investment firm in St. Petersburg, Fla.
When Mr. Lockhart arrived at Armstrong last summer, he ordered a thorough review of all asbestos claims filed against it over the years, mostly by people who were not Armstrong employees but who in the 1950's worked at a construction site or shipyard where insulation was installed. The company has tried to prepare for future claims by taking charges against profits totaling $765 million, but its estimate of future liability ranges from $700 million to $1.4 billion, over the next six years. There is no way of precisely calculating how many other potential victims might sue and win huge verdicts from juries in the future, Mr. Lockhart said.
"That's an unknown -- disputed liability that threatens the viability of the company," he said.
Over the years, Armstrong had contested some claims, tried to settle others and even reached a substantial settlement with a group of claimants in the mid-1990's, a settlement that was later overturned by the Supreme Court.
"The genius -- and by that I mean clairvoyant -- would've filed for Chapter 11 on that day," Mr. Lockhart said.
The review he ordered showed that the number of claims was rising, rather than falling as it previously appeared. "We were seeing costs above what we hoped to see," Mr. Lockhart said.
The risk of skyrocketing jury awards, combined with the unlikelihood of legislation resolving nationwide asbestos-related claims in the fall of an election year, started to make Chapter 11 the most attractive option, he added, and the company hired Weil, Gotshal & Manges, a New York law firm known for its bankruptcy practice, for advice.
"They've done a great job of trying to break down our biases about some things," Mr. Lockhart said. "You have a debt, you think you should pay it," but the lawyers explained that is not the way to think in the context of Chapter 11, he said.
Once a company files a petition for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11, litigation against it and its obligation to pay creditors are both automatically frozen, said Christian C. Onsager, general counsel of the Broe Companies in Denver and co-chairman of the American Bankruptcy Institute's committee on business reorganization.
Then, a "bar date" is set, before which all claims must be filed with the court, Mr. Onsager said. That is beneficial to Armstrong because it means that all current asbestos claimants will have to file claims in the bankruptcy court in Delaware, where Armstrong filed, rather than in separate state court proceedings around the country.
Payment of claims must then be negotiated and described in a plan for reorganization of the bankrupt company, and ideally a trust is established to pay future claimants, he said. The court must approve the plan.
And at the end of bankruptcy, there is a discharge of liabilities, so that claimants cannot seek more than they are allotted under the reorganization plan, Mr. Onsager said. "You are enjoined from trying to collect your debt forever," he said.
There is a cost to the company: significant expenses must be approved by the court, which means they are a matter of public record and subject to review by competitors, for example. "That's frankly one reason companies don't want to operate all the time in Chapter 11," he said.
Nervousness over mounting asbestos claims drove Armstrong's share price down to a low of 75 cents on Dec. 6, the day the company filed for bankruptcy protection, from a high of $36.81 in January, but the stock has since rebounded somewhat, closing at $2.19 yesterday. Both employees and customers have been reassured by the prospect of a final conclusion to the years of potential liability hanging over the company, Mr. Lockhart said, as well as by statements that there will be no bankruptcy-related work force reductions -- although some employees worry that the slowing economy may lead to layoffs anyway.
Because bankruptcy can be long and slow, years may pass before it becomes clear whether Mr. Lockhart's decision was correct. After all, a plan for payment of present and potential claims will have to be hammered out and agreed to by claimants, creditors and the company.
But at least there will be a resolution, Mr. Lockhart said. "We were going to have to find a consensual solution," he said. "In Chapter 11, there will be a consensual solution. The question is when."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
In a Nod to Slower Economy, SBC Cuts Earnings Forecast

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
SBC Communications, the nation's second-largest provider of local telephone service, lowered its forecasts yesterday for sales and earnings next year in a sign of how the slowing economy is beginning to affect large telecommunications companies.
SBC said its problems were caused in part by regulatory hurdles it faces in introducing long-distance service in states like California and also by high-speed digital subscriber line problems at Ameritech, the company with operations in Illinois, Michigan, Ohio, Indiana and Wisconsin that SBC bought in 1999. 
 But gloomier prospects for the American economy also contributed to SBC's decision to lower forecasts. This is a contrast to previous years, when large telecommunications providers were generally thought to be shielded from an economic downturn because demand for their basic products like local and long-distance service remained strong.
"The telecom industry of today is dramatically different from that of 10 years ago," said Simon Flannery, a telecommunications analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "There's an Achilles' heel to introducing so many new products if sales of these services are shown to decline when demand slumps."
Instead of percentage growth in earnings per share in the midteens, SBC now expects per-share earnings to increase 11 percent to 14 percent next year. And sales, instead of climbing 10 percent, are expected to rise 8 percent to 9 percent, said Edward E. Whitacre, SBC's chairman and chief executive.
Analysts were quick to react after SBC's announcement. Adam Quinton of Merrill Lynch downgraded the stock to accumulate from buy, and lowered his firm's target price to $60 from $65. And Dan Reingold of Credit Suisse First Boston also lowered the target price to $64 from $66 but refrained from recommending to investors that they trim their SBC holdings.
Shares in SBC, which until yesterday had mostly been spared the recent turmoil at other large telecommunications companies like AT&T and WorldCom, fell $6.75, to $46.56. Until yesterday SBC stock had climbed 9.4 percent in 2000. Now the stock is down 4.5 percent for the year.
While analysts, for the most part, remained cautiously optimistic, investors showed concern that difficulties at SBC could signal similar problems at other large providers of local telephone service. Shares in BellSouth declined $2.63, to $41.25, and shares in Verizon Communications fell $3.94, to $51.88.
"Everyone is wondering whether this will have a contagious effect on the industry," said Tim Ghriskey, a senior portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation. "Could it be that demand for high-capacity data services are slowing at a time when competitive pressure in areas like D.S.L. is growing? Questions like these are all of a sudden on everyone's mind."
Verizon sought to play down these concerns by reaffirming its financial projections for 2001 and 2002. And the company added that it was adding 3,500 D.S.L. lines a day, having already exceeded its year-end target of 500,000 D.S.L subscribers.
"Our problem is that we're trying to keep up with the orders in areas like D.S.L. that are hard to fill quickly," said Eric Rabe, a spokesman for Verizon, which was formed by Bell Atlantic's acquisition of the GTE Corporation. "It's certainly not affecting our bottom line."
To be sure, SBC's problems are largely of a similar nature. But in the states where its Ameritech unit operates, SBC acknowledged that "recent service issues" have prevented the rollout of D.S.L. service as smoothly as the company had hoped. To deal with the problems, SBC has dispatched technicians from other areas to the Ameritech region.
The growing popularity of D.S.L. service, which allows users to gain access to the Internet over regular telephone lines at speeds far faster than a regular dial-up connection, has emerged as a flashpoint for much of the turmoil in the telecommunications industry.
The technical complexity of adapting copper telephone lines for high-speed data delivery have made the business complicated when it comes to installations and repairs. Those problems are compounded by the confusion generated by the large number of relatively small service providers and wholesalers that need access to local phone networks to get D.S.L. to the consumer.
Companies like SBC are continuing to expand into sophisticated services like D.S.L. and add-ons like call-waiting and caller I.D. as they seek to use a large customer base to cross-sell products. But judging from SBC's warning yesterday, these new services also appear to make local telephone companies vulnerable when the economy slows.
"The old predictability of the local phone company is out the window," said Jeffrey Kagan, an independent telecommunications analyst. "It looks like the rewards of riding an unprecedented wave of demand during the last few years for new telecommunications products also presents its fair share of risks."

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Is Down, but Only a Bit

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit declined slightly in October but was still the second highest on record, the Commerce Department said today. Imbalances with China and Japan both hit records, reflecting imports of cars and toys, and the bill for foreign oil also rose to the highest level ever.
The trade deficit fell to $33.2 billion in October, down 1.6 percent from the record of $33.7 billion in September. 
 Through the first 10 months of the year, the trade deficit is running at an annual rate of $363 billion, almost $100 billion higher than last year's $265 billion deficit.
But the departing Clinton administration and some private economists saw glimmers of hope that the soaring imbalances may begin to turn around in the new year as the United States economy slows and foreign economies rebound.
"With the U.S. slowdown looking more real every day, the trade deficit may have passed its peak," said Bill Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston.
The administration insisted that the trade deficit represented the effect of larger economic forces -- fast growth in the United States and sluggish growth overseas -- rather than a failure of open-trade policies.
For October, exports of goods and services slipped 1.5 percent, to $91.2 billion, the second consecutive monthly decline, reflecting small decreases in a wide variety of products from computer chips and commercial airliners to farm goods.
Imports, which had set a record the previous month, fell a slight 1.6 percent in October, to $124.4 billion, the second-highest level on record. This decline primarily reflected a return to more normal levels of service trade after a big one-time payment in September made by NBC to cover the Olympics.
October imports continued to show a high level of oil shipments. Imports of crude petroleum hit a record high of $8.5 billion in October as the volume rose even as the price dipped slightly to $28.62 a barrel from a 10-year high of $28.98 in September.
The deficit with China rose 4 percent in October, to a record $9.1 billion, the biggest deficit ever set with a single country. China is on track to pass Japan this year, the perennial leader as the country that has the biggest trade surplus with the United States.
The deficit with Japan also hit a record in October at $8.4 billion, a sharp 38 percent increase over the September level as shipments of Japanese autos soared.
The small drop in exports in October still left total export sales up 13.4 percent in the first 10 months of this year at $789 billion. Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, predicted exports would top $1 trillion this year for the first time. Imports so far this year are up an even larger 19.9 percent, at $1.19 trillion through October.
The United States deficit with Canada, its largest trading partner, set a record at $4.7 billion, while imports from Mexico set a record even as the deficit with that country narrowed slightly, to $2.4 billion.

HEADLINE: Text of Statement by Fed

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, said that it had left interest rates unchanged but that it now had a stance to reduce borrowing costs in the future:
The Federal Open Market Committee at its meeting today decided to maintain the existing stance of monetary policy, keeping its target for the federal funds rate at 6.5 percent. 
 The drag on demand and profits from rising energy costs, as well as eroding consumer confidence, reports of substantial shortfalls in sales and earnings and stress in some segments of the financial markets suggest that economic growth may be slowing further. While some inflation risks persist, they are diminished by the more moderate pace of economic activity and by the absence of any indication that longer-term inflation expectations have increased. The committee will continue to monitor closely the evolving economic situation.
Against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the committee consequently believes that the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Investors Show Displeasure As the Fed Lets Rates Alone

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Apparently disappointed that the Federal Reserve did not cut short-term interest rates immediately, investors drove down stock prices yesterday even though the Fed clearly signaled that it was likely to reduce rates soon.
Before the Fed's announcement at around 2:15 p.m., major market averages were trending higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average up nearly 140 points shortly before the decision of the Fed's Open Market Committee was released. 
 But prices began to slide nearly immediately after the Fed said that it had shifted its concerns to a slowing economy and was no longer particularly worried about the threat of higher inflation. While that was a more drastic change in emphasis than many analysts had expected as recently as last Friday, it left lots of investors wishing for more.
"As an equity investor, seeing the Fed say they are worried about a slowdown but not do anything sort of makes you rethink things," said Jim Paulson, chief investment officer for Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. "I am not saying what they did is the wrong move," he added. "But I think it would have been bullish if they had cut rates."
The afternoon selling pushed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index down to their lowest closing levels of the year.
Led by declines in Verizon Communications, the American International Group and Microsoft, the S.& P. index fell 17.14 points, or 1.3 percent, and closed at 1,305.60.
Companies like Ciena, Siebel Systems and JDS Uniphase -- all major suppliers to communications companies -- were the big losers on the Nasdaq. The composite index fell 112.81 points, or 4.3 percent, to 2,511.71. As evidence mounts that the economy is hitting the brakes, stocks that depend on rapid growth appear to be the most vulnerable.
"The Nasdaq more than any other index needed some really positive news that could jump-start the economy and earnings and lower future financing costs," said Kenneth M. Sheinberg, head of listed trading at SG Cowen. "It's nice the Fed went to an easing bias, and it looks like they will do something in January. But that is still a month away."
At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 61.05 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,584.37. Declines in stocks like SBC Communications and Boeing more than offset gains in drug and oil stocks.
Some traders and stock market analysts expressed concern that the economy might already have stopped growing. But many economists said that had almost certainly not happened yet.
"I think we are a ways from a recession," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Fleming Asset Management.
Phil Orlando, chief investment strategist at Value Line Asset Management, said he was "astounded" by the market's reaction, given that the Fed was moving to an easier stance. "The market is a screaming buy," he said. "The Fed has to be considering interest rate cuts of between half a percentage point and a full percentage point over the next six months. If you are a contrarian looking at fundamental valuations, you have to be licking your lips."
It has been more than two years since concerns about a slowing economy spurred the Fed to ease monetary policy and lower short-term interest rates.
In a speech earlier this month, the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, outlined his worries about the economy but said current economic conditions were much better than the climate in the second half of 1998, when the Russian default and the collapse of the hedge fund Long Term Capital Management caused many analysts to worry that the world financial system was at the brink of disaster. But for a day at least, many stock investors seemed worried that the Fed was moving too slowly to stave off a downturn.
Ciena and Siebel Systems were two of the biggest losers on the Nasdaq. Ciena slumped $23.19, or 24 percent, to $73.19, after it announced that it had agreed to buy the closely held Cyras Systems for about $2 billion in stock. Cyras is a developer of optical switching systems.
And Siebel fell $15, to $63.38, after a Credit Suisse First Boston analyst said growth in its customer-relations software was growing more slowly than investors expected.

Treasury Prices Fall
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates steady but said it now saw economic risks tilted toward an economic downturn rather than inflation.
 The 10-year Treasury note fell 3/32, to a price of 104 8/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.18 percent from 5.17 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32, to 111 11/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.47 percent from 5.44 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: On Sales Tour in Canada, Putin Assures Investors of Better Times

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 19

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia brought his capitalist road show to Canada's business capital today, promising investor security, low tax rates and renewed economic growth.
"Attracting foreign investment is seen by us as a major factor for integrating Russia in the world economy," Mr. Putin told a luncheon audience of nearly 2,000 people. "We have expanded the legal framework to improve protection of investors' rights." 
 In what may be a dress rehearsal for a visit to the United States next year, Mr. Putin stressed that Russia is getting its macroeconomic house in order. He said the economy is expanding by 7 percent this year, personal income is up by 9.4 percent, a budget surplus has cut inflation and industrial production is up by "15 to 20 percent."
Despite the politeness of his Canadian hosts, Mr. Putin knew he was playing to a wary audience.
Welcoming him to Canada's largest city today, The National Post, a conservative newspaper, published a cartoon showing the president protected by two looming thugs, while an interpreter asks a bespectacled Canadian businessman: "President Putin is asking why you Canadians are so wary of investing in Russia?"
"A lot of people had bad experiences in Russia," said David Mosher, president of High River Gold, a mining company based here that produces gold in Eastern Siberia. "Once people feel there is transparency, that your investment can be protected, that international accounting rules are accepted, the sky is the limit."
Trade between the world's two northern giants has dropped by half since the ruble collapsed in 1998. Last year, Canada's trade with Russia was only $520 million, slightly more than with Rhode Island.
Although Canada has barely one-fifth of Russia's 145 million people, Canada's gross national product of $591 billion is almost double that of Russia's. Russia accounts for two-tenths of 1 percent of Canada's foreign trade and Canada accounts for one-half of 1 percent of foreign investment in Russia.
Good intentions expressed in Canada need follow-through, said Lloyd Axworthy, who worked on promoting trade with Russia until he stepped down as Canada's foreign minister this fall.
"It was a classic problem of pulling a lever, hearing a lot of noise and not having anything come out the other end," Mr. Axworthy said of efforts to cut through bureaucracy and corruption to promote trade.
"It should be a real priority for Canadians and Americans to do as much as they can, but it is going to be very difficult to do until you clear up the various barriers that are there."
Despite the general wariness, Canadian companies are cautiously expanding investments in Russia.
On Monday SNC-Lavalin, a Montreal-based conglomerate, signed a $143 million contract to aid the construction of a rapid-transit system linking Sheremetyevo airport with downtown Moscow. A second contract, worth $1.1 million, was signed by Nascor Inc. and Rostnefteresurs Ltd. of Russia for the Canadian company to provide technology and equipment for prefabricated houses in the Rostov region.
"Things are starting from scratch again," Mr. Mosher said of the gradual return of investment since the collapse of the ruble. "The Russians are building a base for sustainable development. This time it will work."
