HEADLINE: Nuclear Power's Second Act;
Rising Demand for Electricity Revives Aging Reactors

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: VERNON, Vt.

 BODY:
Nobody has ordered a new nuclear plant in this country in more than 20 years, but rising demand for electricity and prices for natural gas are forestalling extinction and giving aging reactors a new lease on life. Consider Vermont Yankee, on the banks of the Connecticut River here.
For years many people thought that the plant was at death's door. It is one of the oldest nuclear reactors that is still operating in the United States. The core shroud, a crucial internal part that holds the fuel in place and channels cooling water, is showing damage from age. The owners are short of money. 
 But now a bidding war is brewing among three eager buyers, and financial analysts say the winner is likely to invest even more to seek to extend its operating license for decades and possibly to raise its power output.
Similar decisions have quietly transformed dozens of plants around the country. While no one expects any American utility to order a new nuclear plant in the foreseeable future, the overall effect is a much-improved prospect for the long-battered industry.
Several factors are helping to turn nuclear white elephants into valuable heirlooms. The price of natural gas, the main source for new generation, has quadrupled in the last year. The market price of electricity has soared under deregulation, and the growing economy has led to shortages of generating capacity.
"Suddenly people realize that you can actually make money with these plants," said Ted Marston, the chief nuclear officer at the Electric Power Research Institute, a nonprofit research consortium in Palo Alto, Calif., that has helped utilities obtain license renewals beyond the initial 40 years for which they were approved.
In March, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved a 20-year extension on a twin-reactor plant in Maryland, Calvert Cliffs, which is now owned by the Constellation Energy Group. Two months later, it did the same for the three-reactor Oconee plant, owned by Duke Energy, in South Carolina.
Since then, Mr. Marston said, the market value of nuclear reactors has increased tenfold.
The effect is visible here. In October 1999, the AmerGen Energy Company, a partnership between the PECO Energy Company, the parent of Philadelphia Electric and itself a unit of the Exelon Corporation, and British Energy, made a $23.5 million bid in a battle for Vermont Yankee.
But the state Department of Public Service, which represents the interests of energy consumers, said the price was too low, helping kill the deal. AmerGen is now offering more than $93 million, but a second company, the Entergy Corporation, based in New Orleans, has indicated it will offer more. Entergy recently announced a merger with the FPL Group, parent company of Florida Power and Light, which would create the nation's largest electric utility.
The Vermont Public Service board has told Entergy to file a bid by Jan. 12, and told the plant to cooperate with the company in due diligence. The board also told two other companies, Dominion, based in Virginia, which has expressed interest, and Constellation Nuclear, a subsidiary of Constellation Energy, that it would offer them similar accommodations.
The companies say they want to buy up reactors around the country, and through economies of scale and their extensive nuclear experience, run them better and make more money from their operations. AmerGen has already bought Three Mile Island 1, the undamaged twin of the reactor near Harrisburg, Pa., that experienced the nation's worst nuclear accident. It has also acquired Clinton, in southern Illinois, and Oyster Creek, in Toms River, N.J. Entergy has a deal to buy Nine Mile Point 2 and James A. FitzPatrick, near Scriba, N.Y., and Indian Point 3, in Buchanan, N.Y.
While Vermont Yankee has not yet applied for a license extension -- its license is good until 2012, and the sellers are leaving that to a new owner -- applications have been approved or submitted for about a third of the nation's 103 surviving reactors. In addition, in the last decade, 57 reactors have quietly received the commission's permission to increase heat output and thus electric production, according to the Nuclear Energy Institute, a trade association in Washington. Some did it more than once. The capacity increase totals 2,200 megawatts, which is the equivalent of adding two huge reactors.
The independent company that owns Vermont Yankee says output could probably be raised by 15 percent at a cost of about $200 for every kilowatt of additional capacity, which is far cheaper than a kilowatt of capacity at a new natural gas plant. Making the investment only makes sense, though, if the owner believes that the plant will run for more than a few years.
The higher prices for reactors have pushed them roughly into the range of prices for fossil fuel plants, and do not approach a level that would lead to new nuclear construction. Still, it is a sharp turnaround from the idea that nuclear power would be phased out almost entirely over the next 10 or 15 years.
The recovery is visible not only on the balance sheet but in improved operations. Vermont Yankee, for example, now shuts for refueling once every 18 months, and finished the job in 1999 in 34 days. In the 1970's and 1980's, it would shut down every year, for 60 or 70 days.
"We did it under budget, under dose and under days," said Joseph P. Cox, who schedules engineering work at the plant, meaning that money, radiation exposure and time are all carefully watched.
And 28 years into its lifetime, "we're hitting the top of our game," said Michael Balduzzi, vice president for operations.
In the early days, emergency shut-downs came every couple of months or so; now they are so infrequent plant managers remember each one, and every manual shutdown. The last shutdown was in August. Before that, Vermont Yankee ran 285 days uninterrupted. The run before that was 372 days, a plant record.
The result of more powerful plants running more days of the year is that a reduced number of reactors is producing more and more power; in 1999, the 103 reactors produced more power than the whole industry did in the early 1990's, when the number of plants peaked at 110.
The turnaround has stunned opponents, like Debbie Katz, who lives in Rowe, Mass., near the now closed Yankee Rowe plant. Yankee Rowe was one of the four Yankee reactors built by New England utilities, with overlapping ownership and some shared engineering services; she expected them all to close. The other three did. And she pointed out that in 1992, Shearson Lehman Brothers predicted that within 10 years, 25 reactors could face closing because they were not economically viable.
Ms. Katz now tours Vermont with a camper emblazoned with the words, "No Nukes," and painted with the propeller-shaped logo that is the international symbol of radiation. In a reference to AmerGen's British partner, the sign also has a silhouette of Paul Revere on his midnight ride of warning.
Like many nuclear opponents, she was counting on nuclear power to fail the economic test. But deregulation, combined with the recent electricity shortage, has given the industry new life instead. "These reactors they are selling would have closed," she said. Speaking of the wild price swings, she said, "This is such a destabilized situation, it's like being in the Wild West all over again."
Ms. Katz and others say the sales of old plants are putting the job of decommissioning -- for which money has already been set aside -- into the hands of companies focused on profit, not safety; she likened it to an unscrupulous fortune-hunter marrying a rich widow and soon burying her cheaply.
Critics say the idea of a 60-year-old reactor makes them nervous. Vermont Yankee's shroud, a barrel-shaped structure around the fuel that directs the flow of water being boiled into steam, shows damage in places that were heated during welding. Metallurgists have diagnosed something called intergranular stress corrosion cracking, a process not understood when the part was made in the 1960's. They have added reinforcing rods around it.
But engineers, managers and operators insist that simple age is no barrier to performance.
"They have B-52's flying around that were flown by the pilots' grandfathers," said Michael G. Laporte, a work management supervisor here. A 20-year extension might make the same true for Yankee Rowe.
The owners have spent tens of millions of dollars modernizing and re-analyzing in order to address safety concerns. The control room is now full of digital readouts and a monitoring system that runs on Gateway personal computers, undreamed of in 1966, when work here began.
But Vermont Yankee and other plants still face problems, such as how to store the spent fuel, which is kept in a pool that will be full in 2008.
Immediate neighbors like the plant. "We've always been careful to watch it, but it is very, very well run, and a safe plant," said Patricia O'Donnell, who represents Vernon in the state House of Representatives and is also one of the five members of the Board of Selectmen, the town's executive body. Mrs. O'Donnell expressed her confidence from behind the counter at the clerk's office in town hall, a solid brick building that also houses a spacious library, less than a mile from the reactor that paid for it. The plant is 73 percent of the local property tax base. It is comforting to many here that the goose that lays the golden eggs may not, in fact, be getting too old yet.
In Brattleboro, William L. Morse saw it a little differently. His brother-in-law has worked at Vermont Yankee, Mr. Morse said, and in general, nuclear power "doesn't bother me any." Mr. Morse is the proprietor of Earth's Treasures, which sells Native American arts and crafts to tourists, and the shop is adjacent to one gasoline station and across the street from another, probably more of a hazard than the reactor down the road, he said.
But pondering the idea of running it for 20 years beyond its 40-year license, he said that they "better have a big shutdown and go through it really carefully."
"You hear people say, 'They closed those other plants down,' " he said. "Why run this one?"

CORRECTION-DATE: December 21, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about renewed interest in old nuclear plants misstated the name of the company that is buying the Nine Mile Point plants. It is Constellation Nuclear, not Entergy. The article also misstated the name of the plant that could be run by the original workers' grandchildren. It is Vermont Yankee, not Yankee Rowe.

HEADLINE: Revolutions Come and Go, but a Porcelain Factory Endures

BYLINE: By JOHN VAROLI 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

 BODY:
IMAGINE a tea party with the following guests: the New York designer Eva Zeisel, 94; the New York financier Henry R. Kravis, 56; the St. Petersburg designer Mikhail Sorokin, 52; and Douglas Boyce, 34, an American business consultant who is Mr. Sorokin's new boss.
It is not hard to imagine what they would be discussing over their smoky caravan tea, since only one thing binds this unlikely fraternity: the strange plight and uncertain future of the Lomonosov Porcelain Factory. This is not just any porcelain factory. 
 Some 300 years ago, the Russians, in a Sputnik-style campaign, strove to replicate the magically translucent milky white porcelain being imported from China by the richest families in Europe. Peter the Great tried, and failed. It wasn't until 1744, 14 years after German alchemists cracked the formula for making porcelain, that Peter's daughter, Empress Elizabeth, opened the Imperial Porcelain Factory and began cranking out porcelain pieces painted gold, red and blue -- colors designed to mask the early flaws.
The factory continued to ply the czars with gilded figurines, place settings and centerpieces, until the Bolsheviks took over in 1917. Eventually, in 1936, they renamed it the Leningrad Porcelain Factory.
Skip ahead through the Soviet era and glasnost to 1997 and the Park Avenue triplex of Mr. Kravis. A onetime purveyor of the leveraged corporate buyout, a 1980's financial tool that helped make him a billionaire, Mr. Kravis, sponsor of the Kravis wing of European decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, declined to be interviewed for this article, but two years ago he became interested in an unusual proposition. He was offered an opportunity to help bail out the porcelain factory. It had been privatized in 1993, when it was again renamed, this time after the Russian scientist Mikhail Lomonosov. Which brings us to the new director, the devoted Mr. Boyce.
As he walks the corridors of the sprawling factory, in a clump of buildings overlooking the Neva River, Mr. Boyce is greeted as "Dooglas Giorgivich," sort of a Russian version of his name. But while Mr. Boyce speaks fluent Russian and knows Russian culture, in fact he hails from Chicago.
He arrived in St. Petersburg seven years ago as a consultant at PricewaterhouseCoopers but ended up at the U.S.-Russia Investment Fund, an economic development fund. With $440 million and a mandate to prod the Russian economy, the fund had purchased a 30 percent stake in the Lomonosov plant. Mr. Boyce agreed to oversee it.
In six months, he has raised the salaries of the 1,800 employees (80 percent of them women); introduced new accounting, sales and marketing procedures; tightened workplace rules; and looked into charges that previous managers had sold porcelain at cut rates in return for kickbacks.
"I want to bring back the glory of this factory's great past," he said. "It sometimes seems that I am more a Russian nationalist than most Russians."
If he seems like a man in a hurry, consider his task. Along with the rest of the work force, Mr. Boyce reports to outside investors eager to see the factory on its feet and back to its original business: designing, making and selling some of the world's most expensive porcelain.
Which brings us back to Mr. Kravis. A principal in the New York investment firm of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, Mr. Kravis was drawn to the factory around the time that Russia's financial crisis became so bad that Lomonosov employees, despairing of being paid, started selling off shares they owned in the plant. In the end, Mr. Kravis and some colleagues formed the International Porcelain Company, which also purchased 30 percent of the factory.
The Lomonosov factory, still carrying out most work by hand, needed infusions of cash and savvy. But when the old guard saw the Americans coming, they feared they would sell off the factory's 25,000-piece museum, which contains a tea set made for Empress Elizabeth and drawings by Kandinsky, who designed motifs for the factory in the 1920's, and Kasimir Malevich. The managers persuaded the government to sue for an annulment of the factory's privatization. Ultimately, the Russian courts ruled in favor of the outside investors, while the government stepped in to claim the museum.
Why all the fuss over an aging porcelain factory? "The decision to invest in Lomonosov was made because it was viewed as an attractive investment," said Ruth Pachman, a spokeswoman for Mr. Kravis. It "possesses rich historic traditions," she added, "and in the past it has produced world-class porcelain masterpieces, which are sought by collectors of Russian imperial art. It's a unique company with a special legacy that deserves to be preserved."
Though the last few decades were hard on the factory, it held on to its reputation as an artistic and cultural treasure chest. When President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, visited Moscow in 1988, they went home with a Lomonosov vase and a coffee service for six, a gift from the Gorbachevs. In 1999, a vase was a gift for the King and Queen of Norway.
"During its long history, the factory has nurtured some of Russia's and St. Petersburg's most important artistic, architectural and literary talents," said Karen Kettering, the associate curator at the Hillwood Museum in Washington, which has the largest collection of Russian decorative art objects outside Russia, including many Imperial Porcelain pieces. "No other European or American factory had such a unique or productive collaborative relationship with contemporary artists."
Even under the Bolsheviks, who viewed it as a propaganda tool, the factory attracted skilled designers and craftsmen. In the 1920's, they recycled a stockpile of white porcelain by decking it with Communist slogans. Many pieces were hung in public places like state-owned banks; others were snapped up by members of the surviving bourgeoisie, who recognized the porcelain's value. The collectibles have gained cachet recently in other circles: about six years ago, Jane Fonda placed an order for a reproduction of a plate embossed with the words "Land to the Workers."
Current patterns, most notably the glossy blue and white Cobalt Net, remain popular in Russia, and though Lomonosov porcelain is not readily available in the United States, vintage imperial ware and Lomonosov collectibles are sold in specialty stores and on the Internet. A recent Web search for "Russian Imperial Porcelain" turned up a dozen items, including a circa-1830 gold-rimmed teapot advertised at $1,350. (The Metropolitan Museum of Art has a nice sampling of the factory's 18th-century works and sells a reproduction of one of the plates.)
Items from the 20's and 30's are harder to find -- which brings us to Eva Zeisel, considered one of the 20th century's leading industrial designers.
Hungarian-born, Ms. Zeisel worked at three ceramics factories in the Soviet Union during the 1930's, including the one in Leningrad, and within five years she was named art director for the state's china and glass industry. But during one of Stalin's cleansing campaigns, she was jailed. In 1937, she was deported and landed in New York.
Last year, eager to re-establish a link, Mr. Boyce tracked down Ms. Zeisel at a studio she keeps north of New York City, inviting her to make her first visit to Russia in more than six decades. Last July, she spent two weeks in St. Petersburg, visiting her old haunts and working with a Lomonosov designer on a tea service expected to go into production soon.
Ms. Zeisel, interviewed in New York last summer, called the current generation of designers "sensitive and high-quality artists who are perfectionists." But she said the factory had fallen behind in failing to mechanize, adding that it faces competition from the Germans and the Japanese.
"Of course it's worth saving, because of its great tradition and history," she said, "and because of the beautiful pieces it has produced for centuries. Lovely things. Some of the things they make now, such as the Cobalt Net tea set, are also exquisite, and their hand-painted decorations are unique."
She continued: "We must save these great old factories, because porcelain, unlike shoes, for instance, documents a culture, just as the written and printed word do."
In St. Petersburg, Mikhail Sorokin, the new chief designer, seemed optimistic. He looked around his cramped studio at the factory, its surfaces littered with molds.
Lomonosov is "not just a factory, but rather it is an experimental art studio," he said, adding, "We emphasize art, and especially creating new art forms through porcelain."

HEADLINE: Group of Metal Traders Sues Russian Aluminum Producer

BYLINE: By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 20

 BODY:
A Russian corporate battle reached United States courts today when a group of metals trading companies sued Russia's biggest aluminum producer, Russian Aluminum.
Base Metal Trading Ltd., a company registered in the Channel Islands, filed suit under federal racketeering laws against Russian Aluminum, which produces more than 70 percent of Russia's aluminum. 
 The company, together with two other foreign-registered metals trading companies, Base Metal Trading S.A. and Alucoal, accused the Russian metals giant of extortion and murder to gain control of an aluminum plant in Siberia.
The trading companies assert that some of the crimes took place using United States institutions, and have hired Robert Abrams, a former New York state attorney general, to represent them.
Russian Aluminum says the suit is an extension of a battle for control of the Siberian-based factory being waged by Mikhail Zhivilo, the former manager and owner of the factory. Russian Aluminum said the trading firms are front companies for Mr. Zhivilo, who it says is behind the suit. Mr. Zhivilo and his brother, Yuri, dominated the Siberian region's aluminum industry in the 1990's.
They have been accused by government officials in Siberia of organized-crime ties and questionable business practices, including involvement in the bankruptcy of a leading Russian bank that caused foreign shareholders, including the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to write off millions of dollars in investments.
Base Metal Trading shares an address in south central Moscow with Mr. Zhivilo's company, which is called Mikom, and has figured prominently in previous court cases in Russia brought by Mr. Zhivilo aimed at stopping the bankruptcy of the Siberian metals factory.
The factory, called the Novokuznetsk Aluminum Plant, is at the center of the conflict. It was forced into bankruptcy early this year with the help of the region's governor, shifting its main production and cash flows into the hands of companies linked to Russian Aluminum.
Both sides have accused the other of numerous criminal acts. Mr. Zhivilo has been charged with trying to assassinate the Siberian region's governor, Aman Tuleev, and is currently in hiding. Base Metal says the charges have no merit.
The battle has been raging for months in courts in Russia and other countries. The trading companies filed suit in the United States for $900 million, which could be tripled to $2.7 billion under racketeering provisions, which also allow for such a suit even if only a portion of the suspected crimes occurred in the United States.
Though Mr. Zhivilo no longer owns any stake in the aluminum factory, companies affiliated with him are creditors of the factory and say that the company is still obliged to honor contracts concluded during his tenure. Under Russian rules, control over a company that is declared bankrupt passes from shareholders to creditors.

HEADLINE: Charter School Costs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Suburbs Face Tests as Charter Schools Continue to Spread" (front page, Dec. 18): 
 The premise of New Jersey's charter school law is that students leaving regular public schools for charter schools take only their "per capita share" of tax dollars with them. But this premise confuses per capita share (the budget divided by number of students) with the actual cost of educating students in existing schools, which is far less than the per capita share. Thus, deducting per capita shares from district budgets makes no economic sense and unfairly penalizes the district schools.
The charter school law also ignores a fundamental law of economics: competition may improve an industry only where there is a liquid market. Under home rule, districts can't simply get new "customers" to replace those who choose charter schools.
 
LISA KENT
Highland Park, N.J., Dec. 18, 2000
 
The writer, a lawyer, represents public school districts on charter school issues.

HEADLINE: Gains Reported In Construction Of New Homes

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Construction of new homes rose in November, led by a surge in apartments, condominiums and townhouses, government figures showed today. The November performance keeps housing construction on track for its third best year of the current economic expansion.
New-home starts rose 2.2 percent last month, to an annual rate of 1.562 million after a 0.6 percent decrease in October, the Commerce Department said. All the increase was in the West. 
 A drop of a full percentage point in fixed-term mortgage rates since May has underpinned demand for new homes, and with Federal Reserve policy makers poised to cut rates to keep the record expansion from coming to an end, mortgages are likely to become cheaper.
Builders are on pace to start 1.603 million single-family homes, apartments, condominiums and townhouses this year. Home builders began work last year on 1.667 million homes, the most since the expansion began in 1991, after 1.617 million in 1998.
Still, a 0.4 percent decline in starts of single-family homes in November, the third straight monthly decrease, suggests builders are becoming "very cautious in starting new homes," said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. in New York.
The expectations of the nation's home builders fell in December to the lowest level in six months, a survey showed on Tuesday. The National Association of Home Builders housing market index fell to 57 this month from 65 in November. This month's reading is the lowest since 57 in June.
New construction of multifamily homes, which includes apartment buildings, condominiums and townhouses, rose 12.9 percent, to 342,000 at an annual rate from 303,000 in October.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
America, don't smirk. The European Union is no joke in any language.

BYLINE: By Jeff Madrick; This column appears here every Thursday. Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a new collection of essays, "Unconventional Wisdom: Alternative Perspectives on the New Economy." Mr. Madrick, Virginia Postrel, Alan B. Krueger and Hal R. Varian rotate as contributors.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
THE relentless fall of the euro in 2000 at least until recently -- has lulled Americans into thinking the European Union has lost some credibility as an economic power. Add to this the failure of the recent summit meeting of European leaders in Nice to reach agreement on sharing power, and it is easy to cast aside the ambitions of Europe to form a less fractious and much bigger union. Even the news media in France, which played host to the meeting, were critical of the event.
But European finance ministers like Karl-Heinz Grasser of Austria; Vincenzo Visco, head of Italy's Treasury; and Laurent Fabius, the French finance minister, exhibit little loss of confidence. To the contrary, they point out, Europe is growing at an annual rate of 4 percent and unemployment is at last falling. Not bad for a set of countries roundly criticized for so-called inflexible labor policies and squashing their entrepreneurial instincts. "Remember that 10 years ago no one believed we could form a single market, either," Mr. Grasser said. 
 Because of the euro, Europe has also entered a period of financial tranquillity compared with the recent past, when nation after nation kept interest rates damagingly high to maintain currency parity with the German mark. Now rates are low throughout Europe as policies have been harmonized. "All this would not have happened without the euro," Mr. Visco said. "We even absorbed the financial crises of the 1990's in a stable way."
Still, the easy part, including establishing a single market by eliminating most trade barriers and adopting a single currency, may be over. Now the European Union has smaller, less mature economies, from Poland to Turkey, knocking at its door. The member nations increasingly have to begin sacrificing their special interests if Europe is to unite further to make decisions on such matters. Attracting most concern, traditionally proud France may have to yield power to Germany, whose population is half again as large. Some say the friction will keep the euro too weak ever to pose any serious threat to the dollar as a reserve currency.
But we should be wary of too much cynicism about the European Union. History may well be on its side -- and not merely Europe's history, but America's own. To Mr. Fabius, who runs the largest ministry in France, the benefits of a large market like America's are apparent. The fragmented markets of a single nation would sustain companies that served only niches. With some 300 million consumers, Europe can now produce both vital small companies as well as what he calls "champions."
"As I understand the economy, the decisive factors will be innovation, creativity, knowledge research," he said. "You need a 300- million-person market for this. I don't know if big is beautiful, but strong is beautiful. At the least, it is very useful."
American historians have long said the same thing about the United States. Alfred D. Chandler Jr., the esteemed business historian, has persuasively argued that America's true exceptionality was its ability to manage enormous operations, from U.S. Steel and Standard Oil to I.B.M. and Microsoft.
To the economic historians Gavin Wright and Richard Nelson, the size of America's market might have been its single greatest advantage. It enabled business to raise mass production and distribution to a level of efficiency Europe could not come close to achieving until well after World War II. America's continentwide domestic market has no tariff barriers, only one language and has mostly been served by one currency since the 19th century. To be competitive, Mr. Fabius said, all economies must now be continentwide.
But still, how does one overcome differences that domestic citizens take very much to heart? The European Union's best bet is that further economic advantages of union will pull it together. In fact, political integration always worked this way. What became the Common Market in the 1950's actually started out as a political dream to unite Europe to prevent war. But it was easier to find agreement on economic issues like reducing tariffs on key products. Economic growth and rising standards of living opened Europeans to political integration.
Mr. Fabius said a major unifying event might come early in 2002, when the euro itself becomes the daily working currency. Europeans will have euro bills and coins in their pockets, and resistance to change may diminish further. He also said the monthly meetings of the finance ministers from the 12 euro nations, called the Eurogroup, are providing practical grounds for overcoming obstacles. "In the beginning the meetings were rather abstract and superficial," he said. "But no longer. Step by step we build a common culture. First it was only economic, now it is also social." Mr. Fabius said the 12 nations that had adopted the euro would find common ground more readily than those that had not.
If the Europeans succeed, and the euro strengthens, there are consequences for America. In recent years, the high value of the dollar kept import prices down, and attracted direly needed capital, even as the trade deficit soared and Americans saved less and less. In coming years, it will not be as easy to import capital and keep interest rates low if the euro provides serious competition for the dollar.
But, on balance, a strong European Union, even if it means a higher value for the euro, will be a benefit. It will provide vibrant markets for American companies and may help keep the domestic economy growing. Moreover, little is as important to the nation's security as Western democracies that are economically strong.
The Europeans profess to have few illusions. They will not abandon their social programs, which are more costly than America's, but they say they will have to become more competitive to compensate, including further liberalization of their markets and coming to terms with future pension obligations.
The danger is that the European Union might take its current economic success too seriously. Restrictions on fiscal spending are still fairly tight, and the management of the European Central Bank has been heavy-handed. These policies may well slow progress.
Europeans have a longer time frame than Americans. "The history of Europe is one of slow and steady improvements even if I would like to see us move faster," Mr. Visco said. The members of the European Union are embarked on one of the great political experiments of our time. America's own success suggests, against the odds, that over time they may just pull it off.

HEADLINE: In Final Fight, Weary Envoy Counts Ticks On U.N. Clock

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 20

 BODY:
After more than 16 months in the thankless job of refereeing between a hostile Congress and a lot of angry countries, Richard C. Holbrooke, American ambassador to the United Nations, is out of diplomatic patience and into outburst territory.
Today, as another deadline passed for deciding whether the United States will get a reduction in the dues it pays to both the regular and peacekeeping budgets, representatives of the 189-member General Assembly were staring at two sleepless nights ahead. The gavel comes down on the Assembly session on Friday. At moments like this, unity is always the last thing to be found. 
 "There is no way this is going to be finished by midnight Friday," Mr. Holbrooke said today, slumping on his office couch as one aide after another brought a phone or an urgent message on a 3-by-5 card. "A tremendous fight has broken out. It's not everyone against the U.S. It's everyone against everyone. Each country is protecting its own turf, sometimes for tiny amounts of money."
Mr. Holbrooke, who will leave the United Nations and government service for the quieter environment of the Council on Foreign Relations next year, is keeping an eye out for countries that may now accept the inevitability of reductions in American dues, looking for anyone else to pick up the slack: about $34 million a year worldwide. He has seen a nation as rich as Singapore balk at a $3 million annual increase in peacekeeping payments, and the Sultan of Brunei refuse to part with an extra $150,000. And then there was the hurricane thing.
"In one of the most dramatic moments," he said, "a country that shall be unnamed in print suddenly erupted and started to lecture me about their economy and that they get hurricanes all the time and how they therefore had to reduce their peacekeeping bill. So I said, O.K., Mr. Ambassador, let's check the record. Last year you paid to the U.N. annual dues of $11,000 in the regular budget, and your peacekeeping budget was $4,000 -- and you want a dramatic reduction because of hurricanes."
"That's an extreme example of self-indulgence," Mr. Holbrooke said, adding that colleagues had chided him for humiliating an envoy in front of his peers.
"There is also a bizarre situation where some of the oil-producing countries do not wish to give up their discounts on peacekeeping because, they say, they have single-commodity economies and they are vulnerable if oil goes to $8 a barrel," he said. "Of course it's at $28 now and going up."
Argentina, Korea, Brazil, China and scores of others all have their own rationales for being excused.
"The Congress, in turn, says, 'We've got troops in Korea, we're protecting you in the gulf, we just participated in a $15 billion bailout of Argentina through the I.M.F.,' " Mr. Holbrooke said. " 'What are you talking about?' "
He has spent more than a year traveling between here and Washington trying to get more flexibility from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, whose chairman is Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. He and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the committee's ranking Democrat, wrote an agreement that tied payments of American dues and peacekeeping assessments -- governed by separate budgets -- to a reduction in American payments. Hundreds of millions of dollars already appropriated hang on this week's decision.
The agreement seeks a cut to 22 percent of the United Nations regular budget, from 25 percent -- and, on the peacekeeping budget, a cut to 25 percent from 30 percent. "The only reason I think we have a chance of success is that the cost of failure is so immense," Mr. Holbrooke said.
A failure to reach consensus would mean that assessments would be frozen for another three years until the next review. If a deal is struck, Mr. Helms and his committee will decide whether it suits them. Mr. Helms told Mr. Holbrooke this week that he would wait and see. "We're a lame-duck administration carrying out a mandate from Jesse Helms," Mr. Holbrooke said.
As for the European Union's refusal to pay more, it widens a rich-poor, North-South gap, he said. "Their core argument is indisputable. They pay more than their share of world G.D.P. and we pay less. But this is not a debating society. We have two days left to save the U.N. system. We are in overtime now, and there are no timeouts."
Even with a deal, there could be last-minute hurdles, based on past performances.
"Finally, and very importantly," Mr. Holbrooke said, "after all the other countries are finished working out their deals -- if they work them out -- the Cubans and the Libyans are going to come in and try to blow it up."

HEADLINE: Levitt to Leave S.E.C. Early; Bush to Pick 4

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Arthur Levitt, the longest-serving chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced yesterday that he would resign from the commission by mid-February, clearing the way for President-elect George W. Bush to make four appointments to the five-member commission early next year.
Mr. Levitt, 69, who became chairman in July 1993, declined to say what he would do after he left the commission, but he said he had no plans to retire. 
 In an interview, Mr. Levitt was harshly critical of Wall Street analysts who opposed a new S.E.C. regulation aimed at blocking companies from selectively disclosing information to analysts, and of accounting leaders who bitterly fought S.E.C. efforts to place restrictions on the amount of consulting work they do for audit clients.
And he said he regretted his actions in 1994, when he persuaded the Financial Accounting Standards Board to back down on a proposed rule that would have required companies to deduct the value of stock options given to executives and employees from their profits.
There was fierce opposition to that proposal from many corporations, which argued that reporting options as an expense would damage their stock prices, and the Senate adopted a resolution opposing the rule sponsored by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut.
In retrospect, he said, he should have stepped aside and let the accounting board act. "They would have come up with a rule, an interpretation, and that would have been it," he said. "I doubt that Congress would have come up with the votes to roll it back."
Mr. Levitt's term on the S.E.C. expires in 2003, and although he could have stayed on as a commissioner, the new president would have the right to replace him as chairman. There is currently one vacancy on the commission, and another Democratic appointee, Isaac C. Hunt Jr., is serving after his term has expired, pending the nomination of a replacement.
Mr. Levitt's departure will give the new president three appointments, and the expiration of Commissioner Laura S. Unger's term in June will give him a fourth.
Mr. Levitt said he had generally good relations on Capitol Hill despite conservative Republicans' having run the committees with oversight responsibility for the S.E.C. during most of his tenure. "We did these things," he said, "and we were not rolled back once."
Nonetheless, the possibility that some of his actions would be rolled back during the next administration was clearly on his mind. He expressed concern that a new S.E.C. might not be as vigilant about pushing accountants to resist the temptation to fudge numbers to make companies look better. "If you don't have an activist chief accountant," he said, "the competitive juices of corporate America are such that they will stay close to the line, and some of them will go over the line. It requires continual attention."
He also said he thought efforts might be made to repeal Regulation FD, for fair disclosure, the rule that bars selective disclosure of material information. "We have heard from corporate executives who lament being unable to do certain things because of fair disclosure," he said, adding that "they never should have been doing those things" anyway.
Mr. Levitt, a former president of the American Stock Exchange and a top executive of a brokerage firm -- known in Wall Street jargon as the sell side as opposed to the buy side represented by institutional investors -- showed little patience for complaints from brokerage firm analysts who say that the rule has made it harder to do their jobs.
If some companies are cautious about giving information to analysts, he said, "I think after some of the excesses of the recent past that caution is warranted," and adding "Sell-side analysis has lost all its credibility anyway."
Asked what he was most proud of, he cited changes in the Nasdaq stock market, which stemmed from the discovery that market makers had violated antitrust laws by conspiring to keep customers' trading costs high, as well as his initiatives to force the issuers of prospectuses to use plain English and to promote investor education.
Perhaps the most bruising fight of Mr. Levitt's tenure came over his attempts to reduce the amount of consulting that auditing firms can do for their clients. He argued that such work compromised a firm's independence, and two of the Big Five firms, PricewaterhouseCoopers and Ernst & Young, said they were willing to work with the S.E.C. But the three others -- KPMG, Arthur Andersen and Deloitte & Touche, along with the leadership of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants -- sought Congressional legislation to block the move and for months refused S.E.C. entreaties to negotiate. In the end, they did, and a new rule was recently passed.
"They had a fortress mentality," Mr. Levitt said of the top executives who battled the S.E.C. "They chose to make war rather than try to work with the commission. They lacked any ability to arrive at consensus between themselves. They spent a fortune of money to fight us legally and legislatively. The kind of settlement we reached could have been reached a year ago. The public attention garnered by this battle is something that will remain a lasting legacy for the profession to overcome."
He praised the Clinton White House for never intervening in an S.E.C. policy matter. "And when I needed help on the accounting issue," he said, "they were there."
As for a successor, Mr. Levitt noted that business executives who come to Washington often have trouble learning to deal with Congress, and err in one of two directions. "A typical businessman," he said, "comes in, either so terrified of the Congress that he stays away from them -- and Congress will take advantage of any weakness they see -- or he becomes so belligerent that he becomes involved in constant public battles with them."
He said that he thought it took years to learn to do the job well, adding that "I think my second three years were much more productive than the first."
And Mr. Levitt said a new chairman would have to deal with one matter where he failed in his dealings with Congress -- getting pay raises for the S.E.C. staff, a group he praised effusively, to bring their compensation into line with that of other financial regulatory agencies. Legislation to do that came close to passage this year, but died in a dispute over whether to tie it to a reduction in fees the S.E.C. charges to businesses that issue securities.
"Maybe that was a personal failure," he said. "I did not focus on it with the same ferocity that I did other issues. It was not until late in the game that I really began to work on pay parity."

HEADLINE: More Experienced Applicants at Business Schools

BYLINE: By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
When Kirsten Muetzel was laid off earlier this month by @TheMoment Inc., an Internet company in California, she was thrilled. Now, she thought, she could focus on getting into business school.
"This has worked out perfectly," Ms. Muetzel said. "Up until last week, I had no time to study." 
 The number of people who, like Ms. Muetzel, are interested in business school is up this year, according to business schools and both Kaplan Inc. and Princeton Review, which offer preparatory courses for the Graduate Management Admissions Test, or G.M.A.T. Some applicants, like her, are refugees from troubled or failed dot-coms, and others are looking to dodge a slowing economy.
This wave of applicants has more work experience behind it than previous classes, according to Kaplan and Princeton Review. For example, Ms. Muetzel, who is 26, had already worked at the accounting firm Arthur Andersen for nearly three years before she left in May to join @TheMoment, which makes products that include software that allows companies to sell goods through Web sites that operate like stock exchanges.
At Kaplan, revenue from G.M.A.T. course offerings jumped 24 percent from September through November, compared with figures in the period a year earlier. Princeton Review, which would not disclose revenue growth, also had gains, said Chris M. Volpe, the company's assistant vice president for marketing.
Of course, it is early in the course of the business school admissions cycle to predict with certainty how many people will begin studying for M.B.A.'s next fall. But the numbers at G.M.A.T. preparatory programs offer a sneak preview of how popular business schools will be.
"We are a leading indicator of demand for business schools," said Trent Anderson, vice president and publisher at Kaplan. "We tend to get people earlier in the cycle," he said, because people must take the G.M.A.T. to apply to schools.
While it is too early for business schools to have received, let alone have counted, all applications for next year, preliminary indications show interest in the form of surging attendance at recruiting events, said Randee Sacks, a spokeswoman for the Columbia Business School.
"On campus, we have seen a 45 percent increase in attendance at events," compared with last year, and attendance at off-campus events has risen about 75 percent, she said.
Last year, business schools reported a sharp decline in applications. At the time, the drop was attributed to the overwhelming temptation of a hot job market, which drew people to practice business rather than study it. Now, it seems, the reverse is true: more people want to study business, whether it is because they are fleeing a failed start-up or because they simply want career advancement.
On average, the age of would-be test-takers is rising, as is the level of experience of most applicants, Mr. Volpe said. This may be because people who experimented with the technology economy now want to return to school.
"We have had a trend toward students with more experience over the past 10 years," said Jay S. Stowsky, associate dean for school affairs and initiatives at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. In particular, he said, the number of applicants with engineering backgrounds has risen, to 27 percent last year from 18 percent the year before.
"That's probably because of all these people who decided to try their luck in the dot-com world," he said. Still, over time, he said that he expected to see a trend toward younger students as older people switch to programs focused on working professionals.
Applicants and admissions officers say that part of the reason for the increase in demand for the M.B.A. is the result of the perception that a graduate degree is necessary.
"What we're seeing now is that it's just become a presumption that in certain industries you have a graduate degree in order to advance," said Mr. Anderson of Kaplan.
"It's necessary to make the next step," said Ms. Muetzel, who hopes to work overseas for a strategic consulting firm. Most young people who rise in big organizations like the consulting firms that interest her have graduate degrees, she said.
Unfortunately for applicants, the quality of applications has increased sharply, making this a highly competitive year for a spot in next fall's class, said Alex L. Brown, associate director of admissions at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.
Students have more varied and stronger backgrounds, he said. "There are some really cool people applying to business school right now," he said. "That's a good thing."
Joshua Gold, a victim of recent layoffs at the e-business consultant MarchFirst, has one of those interesting backgrounds. Mr. Gold, 27, graduated in 1999 from Georgetown University with a degree in finance; he grew up in Puerto Rico, moved to Israel when he was 14 and served in the Israeli army for three years. At MarchFirst, he helped manage a team responsible for designing a Web site for a financial company.
The different experiences are useful fodder for his application essays, Mr. Gold said. "It's so hard to differentiate yourself nowadays," he said. "They have a lot of bankers and consultants."
His plan is to apply to several top-ranked schools in the United States as well as at least one in Europe. Afterward, he said, the entrepreneurial life still appeals to him -- but not at a dot-com.

HEADLINE: Oil and Mining Leaders Agree to Protect Rights in Remote Areas

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Several big oil and mining companies have agreed to principles meant to safeguard human rights while protecting employees and property in remote parts of the world, the State Department said today.
The department announced that the companies, human rights organizations and the governments of the United States and Britain have agreed to a set of voluntary guidelines after months of negotiations. 
 Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said she was pleased with the accord, which she said embodied precepts "that we hope and expect will become the global standard in the oil and mining industries."
Human rights organizations said that the rules of conduct were an encouraging step, but that their voluntary nature meant there was still no formal regulation for the conduct of the companies abroad nor a system for monitoring possible abuses.
The guidelines address situations that were once little noticed but that, with the global economy and instant communications, have become more common and more publicized. Diplomats and others who have studied the problems said today that they arose when residents near mines, drilling fields or pipelines resented their government leaders and law enforcement officials and saw the companies as being in league with them. In such cases, explosive ingredients are present, they said.
The countries of greatest concern include Angola, Cameroon, Chad, Colombia, Ecuador, Equatorial Guinea, Indonesia and Nigeria. Oil exploration in Nigeria, for instance, has seen deadly pipeline explosions that have killed hundreds of people. Oil companies and the government have faulted vandals for pipeline breaks. But some people fault the government for not enforcing safety codes.
Under the guidelines, companies agree not to hire security forces implicated in human rights abuses, and they have to ensure that police equipment provided by the companies is not used to violate citizens' rights.
The accord states that companies should pressure governments to make security arrangements "transparent and accessible to the public." When there are reports of human rights abuses, "companies should actively monitor the status of investigations and press for their proper resolution," one guideline states.
An assistant secretary of state who heads the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, Harold Koh, said, "The global marketplace is a tremendously powerful tool for promoting freedom."
"No government, even the most committed, can promote human rights alone," Mr. Koh said.
Those agreeing to the guidelines include BP Amoco, Chevron, Freeport McMoRan Copper & Gold, Conoco, Shell and Texaco, along with Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch and other rights groups.
Mr. Koh's deputy, Bennett Freeman, called the accord "the start of a process, not an end." Department officials acknowledged that some of the biggest multinational names in business were not listed.
Aron Cramer, vice president of Business for Social Responsibility, whose 1,400 member companies pledge to improve business practices, acknowledged in an interview from San Francisco that the accord was but a beginning, and a nonbinding one at that. Still, Mr. Cramer said, what was announced is significant. Not so long ago, he said, such an accord would have been "unlikely, bordering on unthinkable."

HEADLINE: Kentucky Insurance Chief Leaves for New York Life and Big Raise

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
The New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had hired one of the country's most highly regarded and influential regulators. The move raised concern among some consumer advocates who have long criticized what they call an overly close relationship between the insurance industry and the state officials who oversee it.
George Nichols III, 40, who resigned as Kentucky's insurance commissioner two weeks ago after finishing a year as president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, will become a senior vice president at New York Life, working on marketing and international business. He will report to Sy Sternberg, the company's chief executive.
J. Robert Hunter, the director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America, said the shift might be legal, but "it sure looks bad." 
 "It undermines consumer confidence in regulation," he said. "You say you're protecting me, and the next day you're with the very guy you say you're protecting me from."
Both Mr. Sternberg and Mr. Nichols said they saw nothing improper about the new job. Mr. Nichols, who has been widely praised for his effectiveness as the head of the national association, which creates guidelines for insurance regulation in all the states, said Mr. Hunter raised "a legitimate issue." But he said he was proud of his "long record of achievement on behalf of consumers" and said he thought he was known and respected for his integrity.
New York Life would not disclose Mr. Nichols's salary, but it said that most senior vice presidents there earned $350,000 to $700,000 last year. Both Mr. Sternberg and Mr. Nichols said Mr. Nichols's pay would fall near the middle of that range. Mr. Nichols's salary in Kentucky was $92,000 a year.
Mr. Sternberg said Mr. Nichols would do no lobbying or be involved in regulatory affairs.
But Mr. Sternberg said that New York Life expected to receive a license to sell insurance in China early next year and that Mr. Nichols, who has advised the China Insurance Regulatory Commission, "could be very helpful in some sort of ambassadorial role."
"With respect to communicating with the regulatory commission," Mr. Sternberg said, "having George on our staff will certainly be a plus."
Mr. Hunter said Mr. Nichols did "quite a good job" as president of the regulatory group. "He's a good man who I think truly cares about consumers," Mr. Hunter said.
He added that protections for insurance consumers had been eroded over the last year but that Mr. Nichols was not largely responsible for that. In Kentucky, Mr. Nichols began a program that provides more affordable coverage for people with serious health conditions. He also created an omsbudsman program, to explain insurance to consumers, and an antifraud bureau.
In general, senior federal and state officials are allowed to take jobs in industries in which they have been involved on behalf of government, but they usually cannot deal directly with their former agencies for a year or two. Even so, Charles Elson, the director of the Center for Corporate Governance at the University of Delaware, said, "The conflict issue always comes up."
But, he said, there are good reasons for permitting people to move between government and private industry. "If people leaving government could not serve in areas with which they are familiar, you would discourage good people from going into regulatory work," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Tumbles 7.1% as Fed Bias Shift Fails to Halt Skid

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
The slide in stocks picked up speed yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index suffered the biggest of seven consecutive declines and its biggest percentage loss since April. The technology-dominated index has now crumbled 53.8 percent from its peak in March.
The other main gauges skidded by lesser, though still sizable, amounts as investors bailed out of a wide range of companies. Utility and drug stocks, along with the bond market, were among the few places to provide refuge in a market poised to turn in its worst annual performance in a quarter century. 
 The Nasdaq tumbled 178.93 points, or 7.1 percent, to 2,332.78, the seventh worst day since the index was started in 1971. The index is down 42.7 percent this year. Yesterday's close was the lowest since March 1999.
Nasdaq volume was 2.85 billion shares, the second-heaviest trading on record, surpassing last Friday's 2.77 billion shares and just behind the 2.88 billion on April 4. Declines led advances about four to one.
Three main forces were weighing on the market: fears that the economy may be downshifting so abruptly as to risk a profit-eroding stall; forced sales by those who had bought shares with borrowed money; and end-of-the-year selling to establish tax deductions. Cisco Systems, down $5.25, to $36.50, was a prominent casualty after it was downgraded by a Merrill Lynch analyst, who said lower corporate spending could be a drag on revenue. Shares of Cisco sold at $82 in March.
"The feeling is the economy's falling off a cliff," said Frank Cappiello, president of McCullough, Andrews & Cappiello in Baltimore.
"This is about the severest market I've seen," added Mr. Cappiello, who has been in the market for 30 years. "We're facing terror, fear."
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 40.86 points, or 3.1 percent, to 1,264.74, 13.9 percent lower than at the end of 1999 and heading for the worst annual showing since 1974, when it fell nearly 30 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 265.44 points, or 2.5 percent, to 10,318.93, down 10.3 percent so far this year.
Although Wall Street got what most analysts expected in the Federal Reserve's decision on Tuesday to switch its stance toward cutting interest rates from raising them, analysts said the market appeared to reflect hopes that it would actually make a cut and not wait for perhaps another month.
"I couldn't believe the market was discounting an easing, but it obviously was," said R. Crit Thomas, a portfolio manager at National City Bank in Cleveland.
The fear that the Fed, whose latest increases last spring are thought to be taking effect only now, may be waiting too long to cut rates when faced with declines in retail sales and other sobering economic data contributed to Tuesday's post-meeting skid and yesterday's sharp, largely unrelieved, drop.
Taking a somewhat longer view, Charles J. Pradilla, chief investment strategist at SG Cowen, pointed to what he called the "full-fledged mania" that elevated the prices of technology companies, those with sound as well as shaky business models, to extremely high levels that he said could never be sustained.
EMC, downgraded by A. G. Edwards to "accumulate," slumped $7.38, to $55.63, after trading at $91.25 last week.
Cisco, with a rarely surpassed 169.75 million shares changing hands, was by far the most actively traded issue. Sun Microsystems, in second place, was the only one of the 28 most active issues to manage a price gain, up 50 cents, to $27.44.
J. P. Morgan took the biggest hit among blue-chip stocks. It fell $5.06, to $159.13, followed by I.B.M., American Express and Microsoft, all down more than $3. Only five of the 30 Dow stocks rose, the biggest winners being Merck, up $1.88, to $93.38, and Johnson & Johnson, up $1.44 to $100.63.

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Bond prices staged their biggest rally in two weeks yesterday as forecasts of lower corporate earnings suggested the economy was slowing and inflation would not accelerate.
"The feeling is growing by the minute that we are moving toward a recession, which is forcing people into the bond market," said Alan Koepplin, who has about 40 percent of the $500 million he manages for institutional clients at SG Cowen Asset Management in bonds.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note rose 16/32, to 105 14/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.03 percent from 5.18 percent on Tuesday.
The 30-year Treasury bond rose 13/32, to 112 14/32. Its yield fell to 5.40 percent from 5.47 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: An Aluminum Man for Treasury

 BODY:
As the president's point man on tax policy and international economic affairs, the secretary of the Treasury is one of Washington's most powerful officials. President-elect George W. Bush acted wisely yesterday in naming Paul O'Neill, the pragmatic chairman of Alcoa, for the job, despite the grumbling of some conservative ideologues.
Conservatives are particularly alarmed by Mr. O'Neill's past views on the paramount importance of cutting the national debt and his support in the early 1990's for energy taxes on fiscal and environmental grounds. Though he said yesterday that he believed Mr. Bush "has the right ideas about where our economy should go," we are hopeful that in time Mr. O'Neill will exercise his sound judgment by counseling Mr. Bush to scale back his proposed tax cuts. 
 During his 12-year tenure as chief executive officer of Alcoa, the aluminum giant based in Pittsburgh, the understated Mr. O'Neill was a highly regarded executive. It would be wrong to suggest that because he ran an industrial conglomerate he is ill suited to guide the economy in the information age. Mr. O'Neill turned the stodgy company into a highly profitable one by embracing new technologies. Under his leadership, Alcoa became a case study at business schools for the proposition that a company's investments in technology can reap large productivity dividends and enhance workplace safety.
As the chief executive of a multinational corporation with operations in three dozen countries, Mr. O'Neill brings to the Treasury Department a firsthand understanding of how currency fluctuations affect the economy. He is also familiar with the ways of Washington, having worked at the Office of Management and Budget from 1967 to 1977. He was its deputy director during the Ford administration. Mr. O'Neill has been close to Alan Greenspan since his Washington days. He is also a good friend of Dick Cheney, the vice president-elect.
Mr. Bush's three other designations yesterday further deepened his cabinet's diversity. He named Ann Veneman, the deputy secretary of agriculture in his father's presidency, to run the Agriculture Department. She has impressive credentials for the position, but she must reassure Americans that she will not seek to overturn decisions protecting designated national forest lands from development.
Mel Martinez, a Cuban-born immigrant and Republican leader in Florida, was selected to take over the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. Bush owes his election in part to the support of the Cuban-American community in Florida. Mr. Bush named Don Evans, his old friend and campaign chairman, as commerce secretary.
In introducing his Treasury secretary-designate, Mr. Bush alluded to the economy's slowdown. Indeed, another selloff on Wall Street amid concerns about declining corporate earnings provided an ominous backdrop to Mr. O'Neill's appointment. The rapidly changing economic climate will challenge Mr. Bush's economic team from the start. Mr. O'Neill will have to prevail upon Mr. Bush to act prudently on the tax front and work closely with his old friend at the Fed to stave off a recession.

HEADLINE: The Lindsay Legacy

 BODY:
John V. Lindsay presided with passion, idealism and courage over New York City during one of the most beleaguered periods of its history. In his eight turbulent years as mayor, from 1966 through 1973, New Yorkers endured racial unrest, strikes, economic decline, rising crime rates, antiwar protests, fiscal crises, police scandals and finally a revolt of the white middle class that discouraged him from seeking re-election to a third term. He was a glamorous but divisive figure who battled labor leaders, rival politicians and countless others. Yet his biggest fights were waged against racial hatred and poverty, and he helped awaken all Americans to the cause of the cities.
Mr. Lindsay's death yesterday, at age 79, brings back many indelible images of that time, including garbage piled high on the streets, angry picket lines at the city's schools and a transit strike that began the second he took office on New Year's Day of 1966. There was the way he led cyclists and pedestrians back into the city's crime-ridden parks for concerts, festivals and "happenings," offset by the 1969 debacle of snow clogging the streets of Queens long after a blizzard, a frozen symbol of a city government in collapse. But surely the most memorable image is of a mayor in a trench coat, heading bravely into the city's tormented black communities to assure them that someone did care after the murder of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968. That singular gesture helped keep the city together in an era when other cities across the country had gone up in flames. 
 Mr. Lindsay's 1965 mayoral campaign slogan had been: "He is fresh, and all the others are tired." Eight years later, he was as tired of the city as it was tired of him. It is easy in hindsight to see the mistakes that Mr. Lindsay made. They include failed liberal experiments like school decentralization, "maximum feasible participation" of the poor in anti-poverty programs, and giant housing projects for minorities in middle-class neighborhoods, as well as unwieldy government superagencies and a mistaken belief that the city could tax itself out of financial troubles.
No doubt there was arrogance and a condescension toward the middle class running through some of those ideas. But in today's affluent times, it is worth recalling that his programs reflected an urgency to address the grievances of those left out, and a willingness to challenge the status quo.
Mr. Lindsay was an alluring figure in many ways. Handsome, tall and self-assured, he seemed to glide through the messiness of the city with patrician ease. In truth, he lived modestly after leaving Gracie Mansion. He began his career as a liberal pro-civil-rights Republican in the House of Representatives, and ended it by switching to the Democratic Party and making an embarrassingly unsuccessful run for president in 1972.
But his legacy is enormous. He inspired a whole generation of idealistic young people, many of them minority members and women, to join the cause of public service. Look around the city, and you can also see a separate legacy, brought by a new generation of gifted architects and planners from his day who created vest-pocket parks, Model Cities programs and innovative building projects. But the greatest legacy of all is the memory of a time when the city was sorely tested and even experts wondered whether it would ever see great days again. John Lindsay may have overreached, but he embodied the city's combative spirit, the honor of public service and ultimately the city's ability to renew itself.

HEADLINE: Stock Exchange Signs Deal for New Site in Financial District

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Two years after the New York Stock Exchange threatened to move to New Jersey, exchange officials signed a formal agreement with the city and the state yesterday for a new, modern trading complex on Wall Street that would receive more than $600 million in subsidies.
Under the terms of the agreement, the largest deal of its kind, the city would acquire the block bound by Wall, Broad and William Streets and Exchange Place to build the 10-story trading complex, which the stock exchange would occupy, and a 1.3-million-square-foot office tower on top, which would be rented out. The city and the state have agreed to provide up to $480 million in cash for the trading complex and an estimated $160 million in tax breaks. 
 "It's a very significant milestone in the course of the project," said Michael Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "It means everybody's committed to going forward."
But first, the city must buy the land, which is expected to cost taxpayers up to $450 million. The agreement, known as a letter of intent, states that the city must acquire the site for the project by June 30 and complete the complex by 2005. Mr. Carey said he already had an agreement with Rockrose Development Corporation to buy the apartment house at 45 Wall Street. He expects to resume negotiations with J. P. Morgan & Company, which controls the other buildings within the block.
The stock exchange has agreed to invest about $400 million in new equipment and technology and pay an annual rent starting at $10 million. The city hopes that rent from the office tower will offset the land costs, although it has had no success so far in attracting a tenant.
The deal has come under increasing criticism over the last two years, as costs have soared and some analysts questioned the need for an expanded trading floor when electronic networks were growing increasingly popular. In addition, some urban planners and public officials are questioning why the Giuliani administration would get involved in building an office tower even as it has urged the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to sell the World Trade Center and get out of the real estate business.
"The stock exchange is like a baseball stadium in that it may be somewhat good for civic pride and the economy, but it's not worth paying an exorbitant price," said Charles Brecher, director of research at the Citizens Budget Commission. "We may have provided a deeper subsidy than the underlying economic judgment could justify."
The stock exchange would replace a series of trading floors totaling 45,000 square feet with one new 50,000-square-foot trading complex. Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the stock exchange, has said that the exchange has to consolidate its trading operations into a single modern complex to compete globally.
City officials are hoping that the agreement and the purchase of the land will give the project some much needed credibility and help attract a major tenant for the tower. But some real estate executives say that the city is undertaking enormous financial risks by agreeing to start building the project by 2004 with or without a developer and a major tenant.
"It is our expectation that we will have a developer and a tenant for the tower," Mr. Carey said.

HEADLINE: Residents of New London Go to Court, Saying Project Puts Profit Before Homes

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 20

 BODY:
Efforts to revive the economy of this impoverished old port city are focused on the redevelopment of Fort Trumbull, a ramshackle waterfront neighborhood where Pfizer Inc., the global pharmaceutical giant, is building a new $270 million headquarters for its research and development operations.
But the city's plans for $200 million in additional development in the neighborhood, including new offices and housing, have set off a court battle by some local residents and business owners who say their property is being seized through the city's power of eminent domain, not for a greater public good but to enrich commercial interests. 
 "We do not want to sell," said Michael Cristofaro, 38, a computer technician, whose parents own a home at 53 Goshen Street that the family says is worth about $200,000. "The property has been in our family for the last 36 years. They could come in here and offer us $500,000 for it and we wouldn't take it. It's really not the money issue. It's the principle of it."
Seven property owners in the Fort Trumbull neighborhood, including the Cristofaros, filed a lawsuit today in State Superior Court here seeking to prevent the condemnation of their homes and businesses. Their efforts are being backed by the Institute for Justice, a nonprofit public interest law firm in Washington that specializes in helping property owners fight confiscation under eminent domain.
The institute has won some well-publicized cases, including that of Vera Coking, a widow whose home in Atlantic City was going to be seized for the expansion of the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino. That case, decided by a state court in 1998, focused on whether the state could condemn land on behalf of someone else.
The New London case will raise similar issues. But unlike the New Jersey case, which pitted the interests of one large casino against a homeowner, the Fort Trumbull case involves what many city leaders argue is a comprehensive effort to revitalize a sorely depressed local economy, to attract commercial investment and new jobs and to increase the tax base.
"Going back to John Locke, the concept of private property, after due remuneration, being transferred to public benefit is a longstanding tradition in the United States," said Claire Gaudiani, the president of the New London Development Corporation, a private nonprofit group authorized by the city to direct the redevelopment plan.
Ms. Gaudiani, who will step down in June after 13 years as president of Connecticut College here, has led the economic redevelopment effort and is largely credited with persuading Pfizer to put its new research headquarters on a formerly polluted site. Her husband, David G. Burnett, is a Pfizer executive, the director of Pfizer Research University.
"We all need to sacrifice," Ms. Gaudiani said, adding, "If this city can become a lively, diverse hub of activity that improves life for people of color, for poor people, from middle income, for working poor and for upper-income people, then it is going to be a great American city."
Some residents have blamed Pfizer, saying the city is trying to please the company by moving working-class people out of the Fort Trumbull neighborhood. A spokeswoman for the company, Kate Robins, said that Pfizer's new headquarters was not contingent on any other part of the development plan. "We're moving in in June," she said. "Our project is almost finished."
Ms. Robins said that the company had outgrown its research center across the Thames River in Groton and that the new headquarters would have up to 2,000 workers.
Among the residents refusing to give up their homes is Susette Kelo, whose pink Victorian cottage on East Street was the site of a news conference this morning to announce the lawsuit. "It's not for sale," Ms. Kelo, a nurse, said of her house, which has a front porch overlooking Long Island Sound. "I told them that from the beginning, and I told them if they kept messing with me they're going to be sorry."
Already, the development corporation has bought 65 properties in the 90-acre neighborhood and is in the process of seizing 21 more from owners who have refused to sell, said Chris Riley, a spokesman. Some of those owners, like Ms. Kelo, have already received orders to move out.
And on East Street, things are starting to get lonely. The owners of the two identical cottages next door to Ms. Kelo have both sold, and the homes have been reduced to mounds of rubble. Four other homes in the near vicinity have also been sold and demolished. Ms. Kelo herself is under orders to be out of her house by March 9, a deadline that her lawyers say will most likely be postponed by a judge.
Some officials have proposed that the project include a Coast Guard museum, but the Coast Guard has not made a commitment to the plan.
Scott G. Bullock, a lawyer with the Institute for Justice, said the lawsuit argued that the use of eminent domain in Fort Trumbull violated the rights of property owners under the federal Constitution, the state Constitution and the city charter.
Mr. Riley said that the development corporation lawyers were reviewing the lawsuit but that they were confident they had followed all state and local statutes.
