HEADLINE: The Little Guy Is on His Mind;
An Author Savagely Indicts Notions of a New Economy

BYLINE: By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
The telephone rings. It does not chirp or beep, it rings an actual clapper strikes brass bells and the 1940's Bakelite body shudders -- like a voice from another time, like a wake-up call.
Thomas Frank answers. He has been waiting, here in his home office in the Hyde Park neighborhood. On the other end of the line is an interviewer from a National Public Radio station at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, ready to fill an hour with a phone-in discussion of Mr. Frank's new book, "One Market, Under God: Extreme Capitalism, Market Populism and the End of Economic Democracy" (Doubleday). 
 In a sweeping, savage and witty indictment of American business, Mr. Frank, 35, slams the notion that the 1990's lived up to the promise of the new economy -- a sensibility summed up by commercials for WorldCom that ask, "Is this a great time, or what?"
Mr. Frank argues that the answer is "or what." Behind the go-go stock market and the feel-good atmosphere, he says, the American economy that bloomed in the 1990's is sick: the divide between rich and poor has widened, he insists, and mechanisms like government regulation and unions that traditionally protected underdogs have been hobbled.
Mergers and globalization, meanwhile, are homogenizing the world into one big Wal-Mart. Yet, he says, Americans have been sold the notion that the pixie-dust prosperity has touched almost everyone.
His timing could not be better: Mr. Frank is riding a nascent wave of antibusiness resentment that shows itself in everything from consumer complaints about health maintenance organizations to trashed Starbucks stores during last year's World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle. Vice President Al Gore knew the sentiment was there when he attacked "big tobacco, big oil, the big polluters, the pharmaceutical companies, the H.M.O.'s." And even Business Week asked on its Sept. 11 cover: "Too Much Corporate Power?"
"One Market, Under God" vivisects the libertarian manifestoes, management how-to books, academic gobbledygook, advertisements and finance-oriented cable networks to describe Mr. Frank's key bete noire: market populism.
This phrase, Mr. Frank argues, captures a new genre of spin that turns traditional populism on its head. Instead of the classic populist stance on behalf of the little guy, market populism hijacks the power-to-the-people language to glorify capitalism and its biggest winners. Yeoman farmer, make way for the Foosball-playing high-technology chief executive, courtesy of evangelists like George Gilder, the former Reagan administration icon turned tech cheerleader; Tom Peters, the management guru; Walter Wriston, once the chief executive of Citicorp; and the creators of the Motley Fool stock-pickers Web site.
Mr. Frank has been laying out elements of this argument for some time in his obscure magazine, The Baffler, and in earlier books, including "Commodify Your Dissent (W. W. Norton, 1997). But "One Market, Under God," published in November, is his manifesto. He attacks business pretensions, not with the cruel streak of Michael Moore in his films or the studied folksiness of Jim Hightower on radio, but with a cool, ironic wit that evokes the line of Elvis Costello, the rock star, who sang, "Oh, I used to be disgusted/
And now I try to be amused."
 Admire machines -- worship their inventors
-- newspaper advertisement for Merrill Lynch, pinned to Tom Frank's corkboard
 
 As he sits through the radio interview, elbows propped on his aged oak desk and head resting on his hands, Mr. Frank gives his spiel, its freshness faded by repetition over the course of a grueling book tour. He has returned just the night before from a California swing. But he limbers mentally as he speaks, his voice almost preppy and slightly nasal, holding up his part of the disembodied conversation, the anger rising. The sentences build and flow with the fluidity of hot jazz and the urgency of hard rock, one thought after another tumbling out.
With the business boom on the Internet, he says:
"A lot of business thinkers thought they had happened onto a kind of Golden Age, onto a new world. There's a business magazine out there calling itself Business 2.0, as if all of, all of history was, like, version 1.3, 1.4, that sort of thing -- and then now we've turned this Grand Corner, and market populism is kind of the expression of that feeling, of business at its most righteous, and at its most self-confident, and most willing to take on its enemies and, and shout them down if you will.
"Basically, market populism understands corporations and the workings of the market as more LEGITIMATE than government, as closer to the people, as something the people understand -- and that's why they, according to market populism, even C.E.O.'s as wealthy as Bill Gates are men of the people in a way that someone like Al Gore, because he spent his life in government, can never be."
Thanks to the attention his attack has drawn, the peripatetic Mr. Frank is showing up virtually everywhere, and virtually as well. In the online magazine Slate, he recently fought it out in the Breakfast Table, a daily debate feature, with David Brooks, an editor of the conservative Weekly Standard. Mr. Brooks also examined 90's-era prosperity in a book about what he calls "Bobos," or bourgeois bohemians: "Bobos in Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There" (Simon & Schuster, 2000).
"We both think and write about consumption a lot," Mr. Brooks wrote to Mr. Frank in their discussion. "But whereas you have emerged as a left-wing critic of capitalism and consumption, I'm a right-winger who celebrates capitalism and consumption while finding them insufficient."
Mr. Brooks accused Mr. Frank, in so many words, of being a faux populist. In an acidic exchange, he chided Mr. Frank for saying that he would rather talk with "300 wage employees randomly chosen from Chi-Chi's, Cheddars, Chili's, Shoney's and Kenny Rogers of Rockford, Ill., over the entire punditocracy." Mr. Brooks retorted, "Why are you hanging around the University of Chicago editing a highbrow magazine and writing books if all the insightful people are over at Shoney's?"
Mr. Frank responded: "You have touched on an issue that comes up a lot at The Baffler. Where do such highbrows as us get off taking the side of the working class? Who do we think reads us, anyway?
"My colleague David Mulcahey, who is sipping a 40-ouncer at the next desk as I write this, suggests that our audience is largely made up of people who like good writing but feel like they're getting a raw deal at work. Think Microsoft temps or academic adjuncts. They are, in short, proletarian bohemians, or probos."
There seem to be a lot of probos out there -- a population of Americans who did not buy Microsoft stock in the early 1990's; who didn't reinvent their careers on the Internet; who feel that something is just wrong. He speaks for them, said Thomas Geoghegan, a lawyer and chronicler of the decline of the labor movement. "If enough people say it and do it, you know people are afraid to speak up and say, 'You know, this is nonsense.' "
In doing so, Mr. Frank has commodified his own dissent, "branded" himself and his critique of market populism. And it sells.
No one seems more surprised at this than Mr. Frank. As the radio interview progresses, his eyes grow wide in apparent disbelief. The callers are not going to argue with his premise, as some have, insisting that the Internet will make everything better. These are not even timid liberals, or disaffected Naderites. They are full-blown lefties. Asking questions about Karl Marx and quoting the turn-of-the century revolutionary Rosa Luxemburg.
In Urbana.
Who knew?
They may be lonely, but they are not alone.

 "Frank's 'One Market, Under God' is but another in a series of superficial, ill-informed, poorly thought-out screeds on the shortcomings of modern capitalism. . . we get a long and self-indulgent sneer from a writer who seems more intent on rallying his band of true believers than on marshaling facts and analysis that might enlighten a wider audience."
 -- Steven Pearlstein
 The Washington Post
 
 Many people, of course, hear no music in Mr. Frank's message. Mr. Pearlstein lampooned his notion that people like George Gilder and Walter Wriston actually have an effect on the mind of middle America. Jacob Heilbrunn, writing for National Review, lauds Mr. Frank as "hip and cool and authentic," but adds, "He ignores fundamental truths about today's economy, like, umm, the fact that it's been good for just about everybody."
Indeed, while the gap between rich and poor remains stubbornly wide, the wages of low and middle-income workers have risen faster than inflation since 1996 for the first time in years.
David Eggers, author of "A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius," said in an e-mail interview that he was a fan of Mr. Frank, but his book "isn't always fair, and it's often overstated." Still, he adds: "We need Tom Frank to take his stance, to be unwavering in his rage. If he didn't exist, we would have to invent him."
Mr. Frank claims not to have read the critiques. "Reviews can say whatever they want. I go after plenty of people in my book," he says. "I didn't invite Tom Peters to write a rebuttal."
After the radio interview, Mr. Frank drives to The Baffler offices, across the Midway Plaisance from the University of Chicago campus. It is the kind of run-down neighborhood where a shoestring budget can go a long way. "The secret to happiness is low overhead," Mr. Frank jokes.
The weathered brick building, a former parking garage, is not square nor rectangular, but a crazy rhombus, its shape defined by the crowding-in of other structures that were long ago torn down. Inside, the building contains the studio of an artist who often works from recycled materials, along with the workshops of a cabinet maker and a mechanic who restores abandoned bikes.
In such a place, The Baffler seems perfectly at home. Mr. Frank and the rest of the staff -- all of whom have other jobs to actually pay the bills -- applied the coats of peach-colored paint that cover the walls and weirdly curving ceiling. Two sets of heavy wooden shelves divide the room, with the University of Chicago law professor Cass Sunstein's name still taped below one cubbyhole. Other cabinets, hand built in the wood shop downstairs, separate Mr. Frank's desk from Greg Lane's, a fellow editor, and sport a sliding wooden window and screen retrieved from a junked confessional.
The Baffler, too, crafts its wares from found objects, from the commercials on the air to the sprawl of the suburbs and the blandification of the cities. The magazine's commentators take these things, clean them off and put them in a new context, a different light.
Mr. Frank is, in his way, trying to restore a languishing tradition -- social criticism -- and bring it to a popular audience, reaching back to the time of Edmund Wilson and the preternaturally cranky H. L. Mencken. One of the things Mr. Frank takes pains to show off in his offices is a shelf of Mencken's acerbic brainchild, The American Mercury magazine, whose format and design The Baffler freely imitates.
Mr. Frank does not, however, live entirely in the past. Yes, the telephone is older than he is, but he bought it on eBay. It sits next to a Bondi blue iMac. The Baffler has a Web site, thebaffler.com. "This isn't just Mencken redux," Mr. Geoghegan says. "This is somebody who's read everything since Mencken and gone back to him -- a more sophisticated and nuanced view."

 "Who Can Carry the Baton in the Race Toward 6,000?"
-- Headline trumpeting the surge of the Nasdaq index past 5,000, pinned to Mr. Frank's corkboard

 Seeing the recent precipitous decline to under 2,500 of the Nasdaq, the tech-rich market that was supposed to share the wealth with the little guy, Mr. Frank says he feels recession on the way, and no "soft landing," either. "It's going to be awful, awful." he said. "There's going to be a lot of efforts to put the blame at somebody's doorstep."
The blame game has already begun, he says, with fingers pointed from the editorial pages of The Wall Street Journal and elsewhere. The targets? Liberals and social critics.
"Not the investment bankers and the brokers, mind you," Mr. Frank says. "It's people like me. I'm really looking forward to that."

HEADLINE: Tea And Transition

BYLINE: By Douglas Brinkley; Douglas Brinkley, director of the Eisenhower Center at the University of New Orleans, is author of "The Unfinished Presidency: Jimmy Carter's Journey Beyond the White House."

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
Given the surreal closeness of Election 2000, and the impeachment of the sitting president less than two years ago, the White House transition from Bill Clinton to George W. Bush has so far been a stroll. In the past few days we've seen Hillary Rodham Clinton having tea with Laura Bush, a jovial Vice President Al Gore swapping niceties with Mr. Bush, and President Clinton behaving like a helpful holiday host to Mr. Bush at a nearly two-hour-long Oval Office meeting. Far from enduring the post-election acrimony most pundits predicted, we appear to be in the midst of one of the smoothest presidential transitions in recent memory. If this seems like an exaggeration, consider some far less cordial transfers of power in the past.
One came in 1953, when Dwight Eisenhower took over from Harry Truman after defeating Adlai Stevenson with 442 electoral votes. Stevenson took his loss with gentlemanly equanimity, but Truman disdained Eisenhower. "The general doesn't know any more about politics than a pig knows about Sunday," was one of his kinder remarks before Election Day. 
 Earlier, Truman had appointed Eisenhower to high military posts and had even flirted with the idea of working to nominate him as a Democratic candidate for president in 1948. But the two had never personally liked each other, and the 1952 campaign extinguished whatever good will there had been. Truman was enraged by Ike's pledge that if elected he would personally go to Korea, a promise Truman considered a shameful use of the bitter war there as a vehicle for self-promotion. And he disliked Eisenhower's acquiescence in the Republican witch hunts aimed at supposed Communist subversives.
Eisenhower, for his part, was incensed by Truman's belligerent attitude toward him. His strategy for dealing with people he detested was to write their names on index cards and file them away under "To Be Ignored." During the transition, he ignored Truman to the point of refusing Truman's invitation for a pre-Christmas White House lunch. On Inauguration Day, when it is customary for the president-elect to greet the outgoing president before the two depart together for the ceremony, Eisenhower refused not only to enter the White House but even to leave his car to greet Truman before they drove off together. "The hatred between the two men that day was like a monsoon," Clark Clifford said.
 The transition in 1981, from Jimmy Carter to Ronald Reagan, was scarcely better. In their race against each other the previous fall, Mr. Reagan had successfully painted President Carter as a spendthrift liberal responsible for sending America into a "depression." When economists criticized Reagan's rhetorical upgrading of what actually was a recession, he began telling audiences: "I'm told I can't use the word depression. Well, I'll tell you a definition. A recession is when your neighbor loses his job; depression is when you lose your job. Recovery is when Jimmy Carter loses his."
Meanwhile, Mr. Carter's advertisements suggested that Mr. Reagan was not to be trusted with access to the nuclear button.
Given the vigorous policy disagreements between the two, there was great apprehension before they met in the Oval Office soon after the election to discuss national security and nuclear policy issues. At the meeting, Mr. Carter grew dismayed that Mr. Reagan listened without comment and did not take notes. The Republican adviser Richard Darman now laughs at the awkwardness of that meeting. "We've both been governors," Mr. Darman remembered Mr. Carter telling Mr. Reagan, sounding like a concerned Sunday School teacher. "But let me tell you, it's different in the White House. The day begins early. A C.I.A. officer briefs you at 7 a.m." At that moment Mr. Reagan smiled and interrupted, "Well, he's sure going to have to wait a long while for me." Mr. Carter just stared, unamused.
Soon after this meeting, there was a stir over Nancy Reagan's "gentle hint," reported to Rosalynn Carter by the United Press International correspondent Helen Thomas, that the Carters move into Blair House a few weeks before Inauguration Day so Mrs. Reagan could redecorate the White House. And the president-elect's son Ronald told reporters he would refuse to shake President Carter's hand because Mr. Carter had "the morals of a snake."
Arthur Schlesinger Jr. once noted that the point of history is to remind us that our own times are not uniquely oppressive. We should be thankful that civility seems to have taken root in Washington now, however temporary it may prove to be. Vice President Gore deserves credit for his good-hearted concession speech on Dec. 12. President-elect Bush picked up the cue and has been behaving graciously, with no gloating. But it's President Clinton who has truly set the proper tone.
Since Election Day, Mr. Clinton has reassured foreign countries about the inherent stability of our government, assiduously stayed out of the partisan fray, and brought appropriate touches of light humor to the Florida recount charade. He has behaved, well, downright presidentially. Critics may mock him for always feeling our pain and feigning atonement, but for the past six weeks he has been a steadying force. As the transition proceeds, we can be grateful that Mr. Clinton, unlike some of his predecessors, seems to be keeping both national unity and good manners in mind.

HEADLINE: Group of Countries Protests U.S. Change in Dumping Law

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 21

 BODY:
A group of countries led by Japan and the European Union filed a joint complaint with the World Trade Organization today against a new American law that would award the proceeds of anti-dumping sanctions to the affected industry.
The countries challenged an amendment passed by Congress last month that changes the anti-dumping law barring the sale on American markets of foreign goods at prices below their cost of production. 
 The current law, which has been invoked by the embattled American steel industry against foreign imports, allows the United States government to impose tariffs against such below-the-market products.
The amendment, sponsored by Senator Robert Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, would divert the tariff revenues from the Treasury and award them to the complaining industry. The amount involved could range from $40 million to $200 million a year, but it is uncertain because heavily taxed imports are less likely to be sold on the American markets, which would drive down any tariff income from them.
However, Japan, which has tangled with the United States over steel imports, and the European Union maintain that the tariff awards amount to giving complaining American industry a subsidy, which is barred by global free trade rules.
The Byrd amendment, championed by the lawmaker to protect his state's steel manufacturers, was attached to a farm spending bill that passed Congress just before the election. President Clinton signed it into law, but urged lawmakers to repeal it.
United States trading partners have complained that the law encourages American companies to make claims of dumping because they would receive a double reward -- less competition from imports and income from increased tariffs.
American trade officials had no immediate comment on the complaint, which will lead to a review by a W.T.O. dispute-resolution panel if agreement is not reached in 60 days.
Of the nine countries signing the complaint, most have been subject to duties on steel. In addition to Japan and the European Union, which have been fined by American trade officials for selling steel at prices lower than production costs, they are Australia, Brazil, Chile, India, Indonesia, Thailand and South Korea.
A few weeks ago, the European Union said it wanted W.T.O. consultations with the United States to negotiate import restrictions on steel wire rod and welded line pipe that the Clinton administration had imposed earlier this year. South Korea had already brought a complaint against the same measure.
Last month, the European Union began the dispute-resolution process over Washington's refusal to lift countervailing duties on European steel makers. Also in November, the W.T.O. panel issued a preliminary ruling against American anti-dumping duties on Korean stainless steel imports. It will issue a decision early next year on American anti-dumping duties imposed on Japanese hot-rolled steel.

HEADLINE: New Chief for Canada's Central Bank

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY PRITCHARD 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 21

 BODY:
David A. Dodge, the newly appointed governor of Canada's central bank, says his mandate "is to keep inflation low and stable," the legacy of his predecessor, Gordon A. Thiessen.
Other priorities may arise, however, because Mr. Dodge faces the uncertainties of slower economic growth after a decade of strong gains. 
 In these circumstances, it may prove advantageous that Mr. Dodge, 57, is moving from a senior job in the federal civil service, where he has been an adviser on fiscal policy, to become governor of the Bank of Canada, which sets monetary policy.
A surprise selection over the senior deputy governor, Malcolm Knight, Mr. Dodge is the first person outside the bank's hierarchy to get the top job in its 66-year history.
In Canada, as in the United States, it is accepted that the central bank should set monetary policy without political interference. Mr. Dodge is known to be independent minded, and most economists say they think he will remain so as governor. But they also say he may have more influence on broader economic policy than his predecessors.
"I am joining a body that has a reputation for independence," Mr. Dodge said at the news conference announcing his appointment on Wednesday. "I think as governor I can continue that." He said he favored the bank's current policy of keeping inflation within a 1 to 3 percent range. He also said that he would continue Mr. Thiessen's efforts to explain the bank's actions to the public -- a significant departure from the style of previous governors, who have ruled in silence.
Mr. Dodge has been a career civil servant and occasional academic for 28 years. As deputy minister of finance from 1992 to 1997, he worked with Finance Minister Paul Martin on the plan to eliminate Canada's budget deficits. That accomplished, he took a sabbatical, teaching at the University of British Columbia, before returning to Ottawa as deputy minister of health in 1998.
Having been inside government, Mr. Dodge is well acquainted with the Liberal government's plans to cut taxes sharply while increasing spending on social programs. That may be possible if the economy continues to expand, even at a more moderate pace. It will not be possible if Canada experiences a slowdown similar to what the United States is experiencing, unless the government goes back into deficit.
At present, Canada's economy is healthy. It grew at a 4.8 percent annual pace in the third quarter, more robust than the 2.2 percent annual rate of growth in the United States that quarter. Canadian inflation is running at only 2.8 percent -- 1.5 percent if energy prices are excluded. The unemployment rate of 6.9 percent is near a 25-year low.
But the economies of Canada and the United States are closely tied. Economic growth and interest rates south of the border are important indicators for Canadian policy makers, and the slowdown in the United States, which accounts for more than 80 percent of Canada's merchandise trade, is a cause for concern.
For the last decade, the Bank of Canada has followed most of the interest rate moves taken by the United States Federal Reserve, although Canadian rates are currently lower. The Bank of Canada rate, which is comparable to the federal funds rate, is currently a half-point lower at 6 percent. The prime lending rate in Canada is two points lower, at 7.5 percent.
Comparatively lower interest rates have weakened the value of the Canadian dollar, which was worth 82 United States cents when Mr. Thiessen began his seven-year term as governor. It has been as low as 63 cents in recent years and is currently trading at 65.67 cents. The low dollar has not seemed to concern the Bank of Canada, or the government, because it has bolstered Canadian exports. But that could change if high-cost imports begin to have more of an impact on inflation.

HEADLINE: Paid Maternity Leave: The Other Gold Standard

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "In a First for Swiss, Women in Geneva Gain Maternity Benefits" (news article, Dec. 17): 
 Paid and job-protected maternity leaves are standard not only for Western Europe but also for much of the world.
These leaves exist in 129 countries, including almost all the countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (excluding the United States and Australia) and all the countries in the European Union. The typical paid maternity leave in these countries lasts 16 weeks, and the cash benefits provided during the leave replace 70 to 100 percent of wages.
These leaves are important for the physical health of mothers and babies, the emotional well-being of babies and their parents, and the economic situation of families dependent on parents' earnings.
They are an essential component of any country's child and family policy.
 
SHEILA B. KAMERMAN
New York, Dec. 17, 2000
 
The writer is director of the Institute for Child and Family Policy, Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Growth Slows To 2.2% Pace, A 4-Year Low

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The United States economy slowed sharply during the summer, to an annual growth rate of 2.2 percent, the weakest performance in four years, the Commerce Department reported today.
The report provided further evidence that boom times are over, and it sent economists scurrying to lower their economic forecasts for the coming months. 
 The department said the third-quarter increase in the gross domestic product -- the total output of goods and services -- was even weaker than previously thought, as the trade deficit deteriorated further. A month ago, third-quarter output was estimated to have risen 2.4 percent.
The performance in the July-September period represented a striking slowdown from a growth rate of 5.6 percent the previous quarter, April through June, and the weakest showing since a 2 percent increase in the third quarter of 1996.
The falloff in economic growth during the summer and mounting evidence of more recent weakness, including disappointing Christmas sales, have increased worries that a slowing economy might be in danger of toppling into recession.
In another report indicating weakness, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose by a sharp 34,000 last week, to 354,000. That pushed the four-week moving average for claims to the highest level since July 1998.
The Commerce Department's report suggested that the slowdown was having the Federal Reserve's desired effect on inflationary pressures. An index tied to the G.D.P. rose at a rate of 1.6 percent in the third quarter, down from an estimate a month ago of 1.9 percent. That G.D.P. price gauge had risen at rates of 2.4 percent in the spring and 3.3 percent in the first quarter.
From June 1999 to May of this year, the Fed increased interest rates six times, seeking to pre-empt inflation. But recent economic statistics indicate that the central bank may have overdone its credit-tightening.
Those concerns prompted the Fed to switch its policy directive this week away from inflation worries to a concern about economic weakness -- a turnabout that signaled to economists that the Fed might begin cutting interest rates at its next meeting on Jan. 30-31.
Revised figures for the third quarter showed a larger trade deficit than previously estimated, reflecting weaker export sales.
The government also said that consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of total economic activity, rose at an annual rate of 4.5 percent in the third quarter.

HEADLINE: Fed Rejected a Shift in Stance Last Month

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers debated in November whether the economy had slowed so much that they should announce that the risk of accelerating inflation no longer was greater than the risk of weaker growth, minutes of their meeting showed.
In the end, they decided price pressures were still evident and unanimously retained their statement from previous meetings that inflation was the bigger threat. They also unanimously approved leaving the overnight bank lending rate unchanged at 6.5 percent, minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Nov. 15 showed. 
 "The members agreed that a stronger case could be made for a shift to a balanced risk statement than at the previous meeting," the minutes said. "Even so, they were unanimous in concluding that such a change would be premature at this time." Some members said measures of inflation excluding energy and food costs were still rising, and others said the economy "had slowed more quickly" than they expected.
"While the members could see an increased risk of a marked slowing of growth relative to the rapid rate of expansion of the economy's potential, the degree to which growth in demand might remain sufficiently damped to contain and offset those inflation pressures was quite uncertain," the minutes said.
Panel members also were concerned that an unexpected shift in their public statement of risks "might induce an undesirable softening in overall financial market conditions."
By their latest meeting on Tuesday, the economy had cooled enough that policy makers warned the slowdown posed a risk of further "economic weakness" that was greater than the inflation threat.

HEADLINE: Stocks Drop Sharply in Japan

BYLINE: By MIKI TANIKAWA 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Japan's stock market fell sharply today as the benchmark Nikkei index dropped to its lowest level in nearly two years, deepening fears that Japan's feeble economic recovery might be losing ground.
Analysts said weakness in the United States market, particularly the Nasdaq index, contributed to the fall, but underlying the downturn were broader concerns about local economic conditions like weak consumption and the fear that resurgent corporate earnings may lose steam. 
 Particularly hard hit were leading technology companies like Softbank, down 7.8 percent; NTT DoCoMo, down 6.7 percent; and Sony, which lost 4 percent. The Nikkei fell 491 points to close at 13,423.
"To put it in a word, the market has awakened from an illusion," said Ryoji Musha, strategist at Deutsche Securities in Tokyo.
"People had thought the information technology revolution will save the economy," he said. Demand for personal computers, cellular phones and home electronics products expanded rapidly, he noted, pushing up technology stocks and fueling corporate investment in information equipment.
Japanese banks altogether hold 150 trillion yen of stocks and bonds, five times the value of their shareholder capital. A number of other factors also are making investors cautious.
They include the possibility of a global economic slowdown, particularly in the United States; a survey by the Bank of Japan released last week that showed a decline in business confidence among manufacturers of electronic goods; and the persistent deflation that is driving down prices in Japan.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Will Stop Importing Burmese Clothes for 1,400 PX's

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The Pentagon announced yesterday that a Defense Department agency that runs 1,400 stores at military installations will stop importing clothing from Myanmar.
Pentagon officials announced this policy change after it was reported that the agency, the Army and Air Force Exchange Service, had imported $138,290 in clothing from Myanmar despite a ban by the Clinton administration on investing in that country. 
 "They have ceased to do business with Burma," a spokesman for the Pentagon, Maj. Tim Blair, said, using Myanmar's former name.
In 1997, President Clinton barred all new investment in Myanmar in the hope that such economic sanctions would weaken the junta in Yangon and help bring democracy. United States law does not prohibit imports from Myanmar, although Washington has frequently urged companies not to do business with the country.
Human rights groups, labor rights organizations and several members of Congress praised the Pentagon decision to halt the imports, saying it is important that the Defense Department procurement policies not be seen as helping prop up the Myanmar dictatorship.
"This is a clear victory for democracy," said Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Committee, a group in New York that seeks to pressure overseas factories to upgrade working conditions. "We're all very pleased that the U.S. military did not delay in in doing the right thing, in dropping its purchases from Burma."
In 1988, Myanmar's military refused to recognize the election victory by the opposition party and its leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, a Nobel Prize winner who has been under house arrest for six of the last 11 years. Two weeks ago, Mr. Clinton awarded her the highest civilian honor of the United States, the Medal of Freedom.
The information about the clothing, first reported in The New York Times, caught the administration off guard, causing one foreign policy official to say, "One hand of the administration did not know what the other hand was doing." That official said the purchases violated the spirit of the sanctions.
This week, 14 members of Congress sent a letter to the General Accounting Office, urging it to investigate the purchasing practices of the Army and Air Force Exchange Service and the conditions in the overseas factories it uses. With $7.3 billion in revenues last year, the exchange service, a nonprofit arm of the Pentagon, is one of the nation's largest retailers.
A spokesman for the service, Fred Bluhm, did not return calls yesterday. On Monday, he defended the purchases from Myanmar, saying new investments there are banned, but not imports from the country.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Double Duty

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
There was a letter to the editor the other day about a column I wrote on Colin Powell, scolding me for suggesting that Mr. Powell needs to have a concept for how he will approach things like the Clinton team's 1995 bailout of Mexico. The letter writer argued that economics will be the Treasury secretary's responsibility, not the secretary of state's.
I beg to differ. In fact, I predict it won't be long before Mr. Powell hangs a sign above his office door that reads: "It's the economy, stupid." 
 The key Clinton economic players understood, correctly, that America's national interest had been redefined in the past decade. It is now what I would call "sustainable globalization." After all, it is America's political ideals (the primacy of democracy) and economic ideals (the primacy of free markets), as well as America's technologies, styles, products, values, cultural norms, fast foods (good and bad) and Hollywood movies (good and bad) that are most being globalized today. Moreover, globalization has contributed to world economic growth and stability. Millions of Chinese, Brazilians, Mexicans and Indians, to name but a few, have been able to grow out of poverty by adopting market-oriented systems.
That's why our overriding national interest today is "sustainable globalization" -- sustaining this system from which America has benefited enormously and which has undergirded our political and economic interests around the world. How do we sustain it? One way is by providing the security for all this global integration to continue -- beating back the bad guys in Serbia, Iraq and North Korea. Another way is with generous economic assistance programs, and support for the global development banks, to help others build the institutions they need to be successful at globalization and to cushion its negative social and ecological side effects. Still another way you sustain it is by supporting reasonable bailouts of key countries if they collapse in crisis, such as Mexico, Korea, Thailand and Argentina.
But the most important way to sustain this system is to keep the American economy healthy. With Japan faltering and with Europe growing slowly, America has been the buyer of last resort for much of the world. It is America's appetite for imports that has enabled countries like Brazil, Mexico, Thailand, South Korea and China to export their way into the globalization system, and to recover quickly from economic crises.
But today's American-led globalization system has never been stress-tested. The real stress test comes when, and if, America goes into recession. If that happens, America will be telling people to get with the program and downsize, streamline, marketize and democratize -- but we can't buy your stuff anymore. That would be Colin Powell's nightmare. Not only will the global trend toward democratization and regional integration be stalled if the U.S. engine of global growth stalls, but you could see some serious, serious instability, both within and between countries, from Latin America to Asia to the Middle East.
So U.S. economic health is integral to U.S. foreign policy. What Bush team players say now is that when it comes to helping a country like Turkey, whose economy is teetering, they would be sympathetic -- because Turkey is a member of NATO. But when it comes to bailouts in general, key Bushies opposed Mexico and would be inclined to oppose others.
So what you have in the Bush team, notes the global analyst Richard Medley, are players who support aiding a country like Turkey for classic cold-war, geopolitical reasons, and players who oppose any economic bailouts of any countries for classic ideological reasons.
"But a lot of countries fall in between those two," notes Mr. Medley. "And what you don't see in the Bush team, as it's now shaping up, is anyone who argues that sustaining the system of globalization as a whole is now our overriding national interest. And to sustain the system, you can't just help NATO members or leave the market alone to sort it all out."
If President-elect Bush feels that our national interest is something other than sustainable globalization, it is important he articulate it. If he agrees that it is our overriding interest today, he needs a team that is willing to act accordingly. But whatever he decides will have a huge impact on Colin Powell's day job. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 581 words

HEADLINE: The Fed's Challenge: How to Cope With a Burst Bubble

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
ALAN GREENSPAN thought it might be a new era.
History, the Federal Reserve chairman said in January, may conclude that "at the turn of the millennium, the American economy was experiencing a once-in-a-century acceleration of innovation, which propelled forward productivity, output, corporate profits and stock prices at a pace not seen in generations, if ever." 
 Or, Mr. Greenspan said, history may conclude "that a good deal of what we are currently experiencing was just one of the many euphoric speculative bubbles that have dotted human history."
The stock market's verdict is in. It was a bubble.
Given the wild volatility of the stock market, one can hope that verdict will change. But if it does not, the Federal Reserve and corporate America will have to cope with a radically different world than the one visible a year ago -- and one whose changes they have not yet fully grasped.
A sign of those difficulties came this week from Microsoft. It plans to cut costs and raise salaries.
Raises are needed because real pay is down a lot at Microsoft and a host of other technology companies. The money used to be in stock options, but now more than half the outstanding options at Microsoft are underwater. "Reality has set in, here and industrywide," wrote Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft's president, as he announced the changes. "The world is not full of get-rich-quick opportunities."
Unfortunately, the fictional accounting permitted by generally accepted accounting principles did not treat all those options as compensation. So investors will see Microsoft's labor costs going up while workers know their income has fallen sharply.
Microsoft can afford to pay more cash. Many companies cannot, and the need to do so will squeeze already tight budgets. "Investment spending will shrink significantly next year," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company. The biggest victim will be the biggest beneficiary on the upside -- the high-technology sector. The productivity figures that seemed so impressive will decline along with that sector's fortunes.
Consumer spending, already weakening, will fall as the wealth effect shifts into reverse. "Big cycles are self-reinforcing on both the upside and the downside," said Ray Dalio of Bridgewater Associates, a money management firm. "We expect falling stock prices to cause weaker economic and profit growth, which will weaken stock prices as earnings chronically disappoint, causing credit spreads to widen, which will constrict lending activity, which will hurt spending and lower investment rates."
That scary sequence is not widely accepted now, in part because it appeals most to those -- like Mr. Barbera and Mr. Dalio -- who thought there was a bubble before it burst. The Fed's statement this week, in which it noted signs of a sharp slowing in economic activity, "is an intelligent list of the symptoms the U.S. is suffering," Mr. Barbera said. But to treat it, "they need to make a diagnosis."
To deal with it, the Fed needs to cut interest rates substantially -- starting before the economic statistics confirm the weakness that is being telegraphed by the stock market. Tax cuts can also help, but it should be understood that the projections of huge budget surpluses were based in part on government revenues inflated by taxes on bubble-related income, particularly from stock options.
Post-bubble eras are not fun. But this one will be less painful if the Fed acts quickly.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: One More Time for Cendant;
Despite Sagging Shares, an Executive Plans to Rebuild

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Can Henry R. Silverman do it all over again?
At a meeting last month with analysts and investors, Mr. Silverman, chairman and chief executive of the Cendant Corporation, talked about the "new" Cendant. The company, he told the assembled crowd, was actively going to pursue acquisitions to fuel growth. Its primary focus would be on building its travel and real estate businesses in brands like Ramada, Days Inn, Century 21 and Avis. 
 Basically, Mr. Silverman was talking about using the same strategy that had been such a success at the old HFS Inc., the company he built into a franchising powerhouse in the 1990's. A skilled deal maker, he had used HFS's rising stock price to make a dazzling array of acquisitions and amass some $13 billion in market value.
But HFS's disastrous merger with CUC International, a direct marketing company, to form Cendant in late 1997 erased much of that success. Just a few months after the deal closed, the discovery of what proved to be a huge earnings fraud at CUC sent the company into a tailspin. It has yet to recover.
Mr. Silverman may find the climb more difficult this time. At HFS, he benefited from a robust economy and a strong stock price. He now faces a slowing economy and a stock market that seems immune to his charms.
Although Cendant's stock rallied a bit in 1999, it has dropped about two-thirds so far this year and is now mired not too far off its 1998 lows, closing yesterday at $8.94.
To revive Cendant, Mr. Silverman said he planned once again to buy businesses where he can cut costs and increase revenues to generate the kind of earnings growth that investors reward with high stock prices.
"The good news is that the management who did that is still here," Mr. Silverman said in a recent interview at the company's headquarters in Midtown Manhattan. "I don't think we all grew stupid overnight."
Over the last few months, Mr. Silverman, 60, has started trying to prove that he has not lost the golden touch. Cendant announced several acquisitions, most of which are relatively small businesses that fit neatly into the company's existing portfolio. It added the AmeriHost brands to its hotel franchise operations, for example, and will buy Fairfield Communities, a time-share business.
In its largest acquisition, the company agreed to pay $935 million in equity for Avis Group Holdings, the rental-car business HFS spun off in 1997, keeping an ownership stake. Earlier this week, it said it would pick up virtually all of Merrill Lynch's mortgage business in a deal in which it will provide mortgages to Merrill customers as it does to customers of other financial services companies, like U.S. Bancorp.
"Henry Silverman is back," said Henry D. Cavanna, a portfolio manager with J. P. Morgan, which owns a fair number of Cendant shares. "While it may not be the same Henry Silverman with the same bravado as before, he seems to be good at making acquisitions."
Cendant is "very much in a show-me situation," he added, and needs to deliver several quarters of improved performance before investors are convinced.
Using a combination of smart acquisitions and the profits generated by the businesses Cendant already owns, Mr. Silverman predicted that he could deliver double-digit earnings growth beginning in 2002 that should eventually lift the stock. Cendant's shares trade at less than a quarter of the multiple investors award General Electric, although the companies expect to increase profits at about the same rate.
"We have one last shot at credibility," Mr. Silverman said. "If we don't execute this time, they will say, 'They really are bozos.' And they will have good reason."
The last three years have proved to be an extraordinarily ugly distraction. The combination with CUC to use its direct-marketing prowess to sell all of HFS's various services was supposed to be Mr. Silverman's crowning achievement, the deal that would eventually enable him to step down as chief executive on top of the world. He has instead spent much of his time trying to contain the damage done by the fraud.
After discovering "accounting irregularities" at CUC in April 1998, Cendant cooperated extensively with regulators to uncover the extent of the fraud -- some $500 million of false profits over three years -- in a scheme that took place for more than a decade. Three former CUC executives pleaded guilty in June to inflating CUC's earnings, and investigations by federal regulators continue. The company negotiated a $2.8 billion settlement with shareholders about a year ago.
Unable to do much while shareholder lawsuits were pending, Mr. Silverman retrenched. The company shed about $4.5 billion in assets, including the bulk of the businesses inherited from CUC. In an attempt to shore up its balance sheet and lift its stock, Cendant also bought back more than $3 billion worth of its shares.
While Cendant must still use money it would otherwise use to make acquisitions or invest in its own businesses to pay shareholders, it is now in a position to move forward, Mr. Silverman said. The impact on earnings should ease significantly in 2002. "The real cost is the opportunity cost," he said.
But despite Mr. Silverman's pointed belief that he was as much a victim as any of Cendant's shareholders, many investors blame Mr. Silverman for what happened. The company's decision to reprice Cendant options as a way of retaining people during the crisis has also been sharply criticized.
"The reality is that this is a company a lot of people -- unjustly in our opinion -- don't trust," said Henry A. Diamond, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston. Like most of his Wall Street colleagues, he has been recommending the purchase of Cendant. "It's like a wound that hasn't healed."
Mr. Silverman now acknowledges that the repricing of his own options was a mistake. But he is clearly impatient that some investors continue to shun his stock. "You can come up with a dozen excuses to own a stock or not own a stock," he noted.
Making acquisitions now represents a chance at a turnaround and is critical for morale. While Cendant has been able to retain nearly all the senior managers from HFS, their frustration about the events of the last few years is palpable. Making acquisitions, even small ones, is a relief.
"Within the travel division, there's a sense of renewal and energy because we're on the acquisition trail," said Stephen P. Holmes, a Cendant vice chairman who oversees the travel division. "Growing is exciting; shrinking is not."
Even Mr. Silverman, on whom all this has clearly also taken a toll, is most engaged when discussing the possible return to the days of doing deals and then using a rising stock price to do even more. He wants to return to "that virtuous circle," he said.
What stands in his way, now that the threat of litigation is largely over, is a changed environment. Some investors are wary of investing in a service company that could be hurt in an economic downturn. Mr. Silverman insisted that Cendant is "recession resistant," largely because its franchise business is immune to such cycles and because of the variety of businesses Cendant operates in. He also said Cendant would be able to increase its share of its markets even if the economy shrinks. "We will be O.K. in a recession," he said. "We will not grow as quickly, but we will still grow."
Still, Cendant's lackluster stock presents something of a Catch-22: without a strong currency in the first place, it is difficult to do very many deals, said Thomas Graves, an equity analyst at Standard & Poor's. Even November's meeting with investors, at which Mr. Silverman outlined his plans, has had little impact, with the shares still drifting downward.
Mr. Silverman acknowledged the quandary Cendant faces. "Unless we get the stock up," he said, "we will not be able to do a lot more than what we have identified unless we sell." If the stock does not recover, he explained, he will do just that: sell off some Cendant businesses that are not as closely related to its main operations to generate cash for acquisitions. The company would continue to make transactions, he said, shuffling its portfolio.
At least one major investor is willing to give Mr. Silverman a second chance. After making a $400 million investment in Cendant last December, Liberty Media increased its holdings to about 6 percent of Cendant's common stock last month, even after the stock price had fallen.
Mr. Silverman "had been terribly punished by the equity markets for CUC," said John C. Malone, chairman of Liberty Media, who also sits on Cendant's board. 
"It was a huge setback," he said. "I don't think it should be allowed to stop what was a masterly demonstration of skill."
Mr. Malone, for one, said Mr. Silverman may benefit from not being able to return to the glory days of HFS. "The best companies are built by their bootstraps, with limited resources, a limited ability to buy anything they want," he said. "You need to build it a brick at a time."
Mr. Silverman may have to do just that.

HEADLINE: Sharp Production Cutbacks Are Announced by Ford

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Joining its crosstown rivals in responding to a rapid deterioration in the auto market, the Ford Motor Company announced sharp production cutbacks today -- including the closing of 13 of its 18 North American factories during the third week of January -- and lowered its forecast of fourth-quarter earnings for the second time in three weeks.
The General Motors Corporation said separately today that 6 of its 25 North American assembly plants would be closed in the first week of January. Together with recent cutbacks in output at DaimlerChrysler, the moves by Ford and G.M. were the clearest signs yet that the auto industry, still the mainstay of the economy in the Great Lakes states, has slowed precipitously after nearly seven years of very strong sales. 
 Ford said its earnings would probably come in 10 cents short of analysts' expectations of 74 cents a share in the fourth quarter. On Dec. 1, Ford had also encouraged analysts to cut their forecasts by 10 cents. Today's additional warning was necessary, the company said, because production has been hurt this month by bad weather in North America and parts shortages overseas.
George Pipas, a Ford market analyst, said that the production cutbacks in the first quarter reflected a response to a drop in consumer demand, combined with a corporate decision not to keep sales high by offering ever larger rebates and other discounts. "This is a bold move," he said, "because our assessment of consumer demand in the next few months -- and it's harder to see farther than that -- is lower than what we previously thought."
Earlier this month, Ford had predicted that it would build 1,157,000 cars and light trucks in the first quarter, already a slower pace than in the first quarter of this year, when it made 1,270,000. But today, the company reduced its forecast to 1,050,000, down 17 percent from the total in the first quarter of this year.
Although automakers release monthly figures for sales by their dealerships, the automakers book sales for quarterly earnings purposes when they ship vehicles to dealerships. So their earnings are sometimes susceptible to weather-related production reductions of the sort that Ford blamed today in posting a second warning about earnings.
Ford announced today that the same factory, which builds Ford Expeditions and Lincoln Navigators, would be closed in the second week of January, a sign that even big sport utilities, one of the auto market's strongest segments since the early 1990's, is slowing. Ford will close one factory the first week of January and three in the second and fourth weeks, in addition to closing the 13 factories in the third week. The factory closings will furlough 2,200 workers in the first week, 5,000 in the second week, 33,600 in the third week and 4,600 in the fourth week, Mr. Pipas said. Under the Big Three's contracts with the United Automobile Workers union, workers continue to receive 95 percent of their pay excluding overtime when a factory is closed, with Ford topping up payments that the workers receive from state unemployment programs.
Lower profits for automakers will also translate into much smaller profit-sharing for workers, which could hurt sales of houses and even new cars. G.M. said last week that it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $1.5 billion to $2.5 billion for various projects, including shuttering its ailing Oldsmobile division and reducing its white collar work force by 10 percent. DaimlerChrysler warned on Monday that its once highflying Chrysler unit was expected to post a $1.2 billion loss in the fourth quarter.
Chrysler workers received $8,000 profit-sharing checks a year ago.

HEADLINE: Global Money Launderers

 BODY:
America's security is threatened by the spread of international crime cartels -- a dark side of globalization. A valuable new White House report documents how the collapse of the Soviet Union, the lowering of trade barriers and advances in telecommunications have increased the reach of crime syndicates, from Russia and Eastern Europe to Asia, Latin America and the diamond-rich war zones of Africa. The Clinton administration has led an international campaign to crack down on an essential component of the problem, money laundering. But American banks are themselves among the world's leading conduits for laundered funds. Unless America's own laundering laws are strengthened, international efforts to curtail the flow of dirty cash will have limited impact.
In the wake of the Asian and Russian financial crises and last year's Bank of New York scandal, in which Russian oligarchs moved billions through accounts at the bank, the Group of 8 industrialized countries started a campaign to "name and shame" countries that were lax about laundering. The list included familiar targets like Panama and offshore havens in the Caribbean and the Pacific. It also included Israel, where banks have been suspected of laundering huge sums looted from Russia by Russian mobsters. The effort has had results. Seven of the listed countries, including Israel, have enacted laws to criminalize money laundering and allow closer scrutiny of suspect bank accounts. 
 But America's own house is hardly in order. A recent General Accounting Office report found it "relatively easy" for foreigners to launder money through American banks. Such laundering is defined as a crime if the money comes from drug trafficking, terrorism or bank fraud. But profits from prostitution, extortion, smuggled immigrants and arms trafficking can still be laundered through an American bank with no consequence to either the bank or the depositor. Corrupt dictators and their business partners can still legally deposit their loot in American financial institutions.
Efforts by the Clinton administration to toughen money-laundering legislation died in Congress earlier this year. The Bush administration and Congress will need to plug the loopholes in America's own money-laundering statutes if there is to be real progress in combating global crime.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Great Plains Software Purchased by Microsoft

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., Dec. 21

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation agreed today to buy Great Plains Software Inc. for $1.1 billion in stock in a deal that seeks to improve Microsoft's line of products for small and medium-size companies.
Microsoft said it would swap 1.1 of its shares for each share of Great Plains, a pioneer in computer-based accounting that is based in Fargo, N.D. That values Great Plains at $45.65 a share, or 29 percent more than Tuesday's close. Great Plains shares jumped to $48 at midafternoon today, but closed at $46.56. Microsoft rose $1.94, to $44.88. 
 Microsoft is pushing to sell more software and Web services to the 25 million small businesses that account for about half of the gross domestic product. It also is seeking new products and services to offer on its forthcoming .Net platform, which is akin to a new computer operating system based on the Internet.
"Great Plains has a depth of expertise in business-process applications and services which Microsoft doesn't have," said Jeff Raikes, who leads Microsoft's Productivity and Business Services Group.
The acquisition is expected to close in the first half of 2001.
Great Plains, with about 2,000 employees, will become the Great Plains division of Microsoft. It will continue to develop, market and support business-management software. Later, it will provide new products to complement Microsoft's Web service for small companies.
Great Plains aims it products at about 2 million businesses with $1 million to $500 million in annual revenue, said the company's chief financial officer, Tami Reller.
It was founded in 1981 and first sold shares to the public in 1997. It had fiscal second-quarter revenue of $75.5 million, up 59 percent from $47.4 million a year earlier. Sales for the fiscal year ended May 31 were $194.9 million.
The company's products are focused on accounting, record-keeping and similar business software.
The Great Plains chairman, Doug Burgum, and two relatives together own about 23 percent of the company.

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
New Arena Plan Shifts Risk, But Still Doesn't Eliminate It

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The YankeeNets are seeking to advance stalled negotiations aimed at financing a $325 million arena in downtown Newark by offering a revamped plan that they hope will be palatable to government officials and taxpayers.
The YankeeNets have been trying to persuade Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey to increase a $75 million commitment for infrastructure needs for the arena, which would house the Nets and Devils. 
 The state recently proposed adding $25 million more from the Department of Transportation, and the two sides have also discussed using local taxes that could pay off $100 million more in state-backed bonds.
Now, the YankeeNets are seeking an alternative: first, take the $100 million in hard money from the state off the table.
Second, use 80 percent of the state and local taxes generated by arena activity to pay off bonds that would be issued by the state and Essex County, but would be guaranteed by the arena and the teams.
"The newest thing is taking away the hard money and the risk," said Marc Ganis, a consultant to Newark Sports and Entertainment, which is developing the arena. "We think that this is politically acceptable."
Ganis said the YankeeNets are willing to assume the risk of estimating the amount of taxes generated by arena activity and reach into their pockets to pay off the bonds if revenues fall short. One form of revenues that can be estimated and used for bond repayment is the $4.5 million a year in what are called payments in lieu of taxes, which are to be paid by the arena's developer.
"The big risk for us is being able to issue the bonds without a governmental guarantee and having people buy them," Ganis said. "We'd have to persuade the investment community that the collateral is good."
The plan described by Ganis is called "tax increment financing," or T.I.F., and would have to be approved by the state legislature.
This form of financing rankles officials at the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority because it would mean that financing for the Newark building would be based in part on tax revenues paid at Nets and Devils games. The sports authority runs the Meadowlands Sports Complex, which includes Continental Arena.
Essentially, a T.I.F. isn't new revenue, but money shifted from one area to another. "Speaking as a former state treasurer," said James DiEleuterio, the president of the sports authority, "the concept of a T.I.F. has always been resisted in New Jersey by treasury folks," in part because actual tax revenues don't always meet the bond payments.
He declined to comment on his position if the state were relieved of guaranteeing payment of the bonds.
Ganis said the authority's concerns that the economic activity created by the Nets (whose lease expires in 2008 but contains escape clauses) and the Devils (whose lease expires in 2007) would go to Newark is based on their staying beyond their current leases. "They've said they won't play at the Meadowlands forever -- or for a few more years," Ganis said.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Gabby Drivers Have Nothing On Regulators

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
JUST in time for holiday travel, the city's leaders have contemplated a question for drivers with cell phones: When you reach out and touch someone, is your car going to reach out and smash someone else?
The answer is too often yes, say the politicians competing to restrict the use of hand-held phones. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone this week demonstrated the earpieces and headsets required by the bill they are supporting. Another bill before the Council would restrict calls even from those hands-free phones. 
 When a New York politician announces a plan to protect citizens from themselves, you can usually assume that most citizens will be the worse for it. In this instance, though, there might be a case to be made for regulation. But it's probably not the one that politicians are making.
The city's politicians, like the cell-phone prohibitionists in Suffolk and Rockland Counties who have already voted for restrictions, point to statistics showing that drivers who talk on cell phones are more likely to be in accidents. One much-quoted study in Canada found that talking and driving quadrupled your risk of being in a minor accident (one without injuries). The risk of serious accidents may not be so high, but researchers don't doubt there is some risk.
Whatever the toll may be, politicians operate on the principle that one death is one too many if they can get on the evening newscasts by promising to prevent it. The remedy becomes irresistible if it costs them nothing (no money out of their budgets, no interference with their phone calls from the back seats of chauffeured cars) and might even yield financial benefits (like campaign contributions from headset manufacturers).
But the cost-benefit analysis looks quite different to Robert W. Hahn, the director of the American Enterprise Institute-Brookings Joint Center for Regulatory Studies. He and two other economists at the center have published a paper in the journal Regulation examining proposals like the ones before the City Council.
By looking at spending on cell phones, and at research showing that 60 percent of all cell phone calls are made while driving, the economists calculate that American drivers put a value of $25 billion annually on the calls from their cars. That's about five times the social costs of the accidents involving cell phones, according to the economists' calculations.
Putting a dollar value on injuries and deaths appalls many people, but the figure is based on what Americans say they are willing to spend for extra safety measures. And the figure reflects the economists' calculations that a total ban on cell phones would reduce the number of accidents by less than 1 percent.
Even the more modest ban on just hand-held phones flunks the economists' test. They estimate that the costs of the headsets and other hands-free equipment would still slightly exceed the value of the extra safety. And it's still an open question, they say, whether these devices actually do as much good as their promoters say.
 WE simply don't know very much about the effectiveness of hands-free devices in preventing traffic accidents," Dr. Hahn said. "They show some promise, but we don't yet know enough to mandate them." By rushing to regulate, Dr. Hahn said, politicians could end up increasing other risks on the road.
Fewer cell phones in cars, for instance, could mean longer delays in summoning lifesaving equipment to accident scenes. If drivers are unable to use cell phones to call for directions, they might resort to reading maps and sending e-mail while driving 60 miles per hour. Or, if many drivers buy headsets and find them easy to use, they might spend much more time on the phone than they do now, perhaps becoming even more accident-prone.
"It's premature to regulate drivers' cell phones," Dr. Hahn said. "If there really is a serious problem, drivers and phone manufacturers and insurance companies will be looking for solutions. Mandating a solution now may forestall a better one in the future. The best course for the government now is to monitor the problem until we understand this technology better."
That may be the best advice for promoting the common good, but there's a selfish counter-argument that can be made for regulations in just New York City. Since many of us city residents don't drive cars, the costs of the ban wouldn't be borne directly by us. We nondrivers would instead reap the benefits: a slightly lower chance of being run over by a sports utility vehicle driven by a yapping suburbanite.

HEADLINE: Ontario Journal;
At California 'Swap Meet,' $1 Goes a Long Way

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: ONTARIO, Calif., Dec. 17

 BODY:
Latrice Rocha's eyes seemed to grow as big as grapefruits.
"Look," she said, turning to her sister, Angelina, and holding up a six-pack of athletic socks for $4. "In the mall, these would cost at least $10.99, plus tax. That's a huge difference. And here maybe they don't charge me the tax." 
 With such bargains, a way of life plays out every Saturday, Sunday and Tuesday here at the Ontario Swap Meet, a giant open-air flea market where a few bucks can fill a lot of bags. Around the country, flea markets, many of them decades old, are a booming industry, generating $7.5 billion a year in sales, said experts who monitor such things, and more than 100 new such markets open each year.
Particularly here among new immigrants in Southern California, the swap meets serve as a convenient alternative to malls. In towns like Ontario, a city of 145,000 people in San Bernardino County, east of Los Angeles, the large populations of working-class families that include many Hispanic and Asian immigrants find that even a modest savings can help stretch the budget considerably. Here at the Ontario market, which opened in 1936, a salesman will reduce the price of almost anything, even a $1 pair of shoes.
In California and other Sun Belt states, the cheap prices are available year-round, even if it is wise to remember you generally get what you pay for. Here, shoppers like Ms. Rocha, 18, spend hours strolling past booths that sell every imaginable product, even livestock and pets -- from roosters, ducks, hens and quail to rabbits, geckos, scorpions and snakes (plus the mice to feed them, at $1 each).
And such deals! At one booth, every item -- shoes, handbags and stuffed toys -- is $1. At a vegetable stall, $1 buys four softball-size avocados that would cost $2.50 each in Los Angeles. For $2, a shopper can take home a meaty chicken (live) or buy refurbished headlights for the car. Even expensive items can be a bargain. R. Eduardo Rodriguez, a vendor of sleek Italian-style leather jackets made in China bearing the "Tuskany" label, said he would lower the price of a $100 jacket to $70 or $80, if that was all a buyer could afford.
The number of markets, vendors and visitors is reaching record levels, according to the National Flea Market Association, a trade group based in Dallas that formed three years ago to organize vendors and track economic trends. But along with them come signs that flea markets may be growing too successful for their own good.
In the last Congress, bipartisan bills emerged in the Senate and House aimed at tightening restrictions on flea market vendors. Among other things, the measures would prohibit tampering with bar codes or expiration dates as a safeguard against selling products that have passed their prescribed period of effectiveness or that have been stolen.
No action was taken before Congress adjourned last week. But trade association officials, who fear that the bills will be introduced next year, saw them as reflecting concerns not so much about public well-being or stolen goods, as about protecting major retail and grocery trade groups. Flea markets, after all, are cutting into their sales.
Jerry A. Stokes, the executive director of the National Flea Market Association, said the legislation would unfairly burden flea market vendors by requiring them to keep more detailed records of their transactions.
"We would support a bill, if it's fair to everybody, but this is discrimination," Mr. Stokes said. "If flea market vendors have to do something, why shouldn't all other retailers have to?"
It is hard to gauge just how much of an impact flea markets are having on more traditional retailers. Phil Paleg, manager of the Kmart about a mile from the Ontario swap meet, said the year-round warm weather in Southern California and other Sun Belt states took away "dollars that have the potential to come into your store."
"If they go bye-bye," Mr. Paleg added, "obviously that would help our numbers as well as other retailers."
But he said that "dollar shops," which sell every item for $1 or less, presented more competition to stores like his, mainly because swap meets operated only a few days a week.
There is also the increasingly chaotic competition from within. As the number of flea market shoppers has shot up, so has the number of vendors, trying to undercut one another on prices.
Angela Alarcin's stall resembles a small department store, with all the "little junk I like to buy," she said. But many of Ms. Alarcin's items, like hair products and soccer balls, are available at other booths for less or at the adjoining area reserved for people selling used products.
"To me this is all junk," said Gracie Hurd, who was wandering through Ms. Alarcin's booth with her husband, Charles. "But I found a pair of gloves for $3. At Kmart, they would have been $5.99."
Mr. Rodriguez, the leather jacket salesman, said he rented a booth here in Ontario, rather than at a swap meet in a neighboring city, because no one else here was selling the same kind of outerwear.
"But you still have to keep the prices low to do business," he said.
While many shoppers said they were searching out deals because they wanted to, not because they had to, some found the swap meet more of a necessity. Alfredo Rosales, a gardener, was shopping for Christmas gifts for seven nieces. He bought each of them a doll, for a total of $21. The same ones in a store, Mr. Rosales said, might have cost him $80 or more.
"I come here every two weeks," he said. "For food. For everything."

More than a 100 such markets open each year. (Photographs by Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Partners Hope to Expand Harry Winston

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Peter Lamm, the chairman and chief executive of Fenway Partners, a private equity company in New York, said he once invested in a family-owned Mexican frozen food business where "everyone was clawing each other's eyes out." That, it seems, is just the way he likes it.
"We love complicated, messy dysfunctional-family stories," he said yesterday while sitting in the elegant office of Ronald Winston, the jewelry magnate. 
 By that standard, Mr. Lamm seemed to have come to the right place. Fenway has just acquired a $50 million stake in Harry Winston Group, the jewelry business known for adorning celebrities with million-dollar baubles. The investment marks the final chapter of a nasty 12-year legal battle between Ronald and Bruce Winston over the future of the business founded by their father. In July, Ronald Winston and Fenway settled the case by agreeing to buy out Mr. Winston's younger brother for $54.1 million.
The newly minted partners make an odd couple, with Mr. Winston in suit and Gucci loafers and Mr. Lamm in jeans, a sweater and cowboy boots.
But they said they shared common goals for expanding the company without diluting its reputation. That means expanding its presence overseas, particularly in Asia, offering jewelry priced as low as $4,000 (the current "entry point" is $6,000) and making the vault-like flagship store on Fifth Avenue and 56th Street seem less forbidding to first-time "clients," as Winston's customers are known.
"We want people who can shop here to feel comfortable," said Mr. Winston, who will remain chairman of the company.
But don't expect to see a Winston in every mall. "People in America tend to want to come to the mother store, to see the full range of everything we have," said Mr. Winston, who also has a shop in Beverly Hills.
At a time when more Americans than ever are able to indulge themselves in jewelry costing $10,000 or more, limiting access this way is a flawed strategy, said Russell Shor, a jewelry industry consultant. "People are time-pressed," he said, "They want convenience, they want service."
Describing Winston as "an opportunity that's been in limbo for so long," Mr. Lamm predicted that the partners could increase the size of the $100 million business as much as fivefold over the next few years -- although a soft economy could delay that progress. The company employs about 210 people, Mr. Winston said.
But Mr. Shor said that Winston was facing an uphill battle, because most of the luxury business is consolidating, with the development of huge conglomerates like LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, which offered this week to acquire Donna Karan International for $195 million.
"To keep up with companies that have revenues in the multiple billions, with resources around the world, is going to be very difficult," he said.
To most people, the name Harry Winston is associated with the one-of-a-kind necklaces that are made in a workshop above the Fifth Avenue store, in a corner building that the company has owned for 40 years. Mr. Winston, who inspects the diamonds and approves all the designs, said it took about a thousand hours to produce the most elaborate necklaces, which sell for upwards of $3 million each. A quarter of a million designs going back to the company's founding in 1932 are neatly stored in binders.
But there is more to the company than multimillion-dollar jewels. For the last 12 years, Harry Winston has also made watches, which are sold in jewelry stores around the world. The watches range in price from $10,000 to $100,000 and represent the fastest-growing part of the business, Mr. Winston said.
Winston also makes inexpensive jewelry in factories in Hong Kong and Rhode Island for mass-market retailers like J. C. Penney Company, which are not allowed to disclose the origin of the items. Mr. Winston said the unbranded jewelry represents about 20 percent of the company's business.
For Fenway Partners, Harry Winston represents its first foray into luxury retailing, Mr. Lamm said. The company has also invested in companies like Quality Farm and Country, an agricultural specialty retailer; Aurora Foods, which makes Aunt Jemima pancakes; and Simmons, the mattress manufacturer.
With his legal problems behind him, Mr. Winston said he should be able to attract the kind of first-rate executives who shied away when the company's future was uncertain. "As long as we've been in court, we couldn't always attract the best talent," he said. "I'm thin on top-level managers."
