HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Northrop Grumman to Buy Litton in $3.8 Billion Deal
Northrop Grumman, the military contractor, agreed to buy Litton Industries, a supplier of military electronics and information systems and the nation's largest maker of surface combat ships, for $3.8 billion in cash.
 Under the terms of the deal, Northrop will pay $80 for each common share of Litton, a premium of 28 percent over the company's closing price of $62.63. It will also pay $35 for each Series B preferred share of Litton and assume $1.3 billion in debt. Page C2. 

Job Worries Curb Manufacturing
As the economy has slowed sharply, the manufacturing sector has been hit hardest because consumers have grown far more hesitant about making large purchases like appliances and cars. Many of the primary culprits -- tighter credit, higher energy costs and a falling stock market -- have been hampering the economy for the last year. What has changed in recent weeks, economists say, is that Americans have suddenly become more pessimistic about their job prospects in 2001. A1.
 
Xerox Issues Weak Profit Estimate
Xerox said that it had a solid stash of cash on hand but that its fourth-quarter earnings were likely to be dismal. Investors quickly registered their disappointment. Shares of Xerox, which had regained some ground last week when the company announced the sale of its China operations to the joint venture Fuji Xerox, dropped $1.19, to $4.81. C2.
 
Ford to Cut Back on Production
Ford announced sharp production cutbacks and lowered its forecast of fourth-quarter earnings for the second time. C2.
 
255 New Radio Licenses Granted
The Federal Communications Commission said that 255 churches, schools and other local organizations had qualified for licenses to operate low-power FM radio stations. C5.
 
Stocks Finish Slightly Higher
Stocks edged up after giving up most of their hefty early gains. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 168.36 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,487.29. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 10.12 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,274.86. The Nasdaq composite index ended up 7.34 points, or 0.3 percent, to 2,340.12. C7.
 
New Challenges for Central Banker
David A. Dodge, left, the newly appointed governor of Canada's central bank, says his mandate "is to keep inflation low and stable," the legacy of his predecessor, Gordon A. Thiessen. Other priorities may arise, however, because Mr. Dodge faces the uncertainties of slower economic growth after a decade of strong gains. World Business, Section W.
 
Rate Increase Seen in California
In a move to show Wall Street that California is committed to ensuring the health of its utilities, the California Public Utilities Commission said a rate increase was likely. A16.
 
KFC and Philips to Switch Agencies
Two big advertisers, KFC and Royal Philips Electronics, unexpectedly dismissed their longtime agencies in a sign of continuing tumult in competitive consumer product categories. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C5.
 
U.S. Bond Market Will Close Early
The United States bond market will close at 2 p.m. today in advance of the Christmas holiday on Monday. The stock markets will have regular trading hours today.

HEADLINE: THE 43RD PRESIDENT: THE VICE PRESIDENT-ELECT;
Cheney and Lieberman Agree to Agree on Some Issues

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Vice President-elect Dick Cheney and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, rivals in the bitterly contested election until just a week ago, met today and pronounced afterward that they would work together to improve the country's education system, national security and anything else where common ground could be found between Republicans and Democrats.
Unlike the tense, 15-minute meeting earlier this week between President-elect George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore, today's meeting in Mr. Lieberman's Senate office had the air of nothing more serious than two old friends who ended up on opposite sides of a spirited touch-football game. 
 When asked by reporters after the 25-minute meeting, convened at Mr. Cheney's request, whether the two men disagreed on any matter, the vice president-elect glanced at Mr. Lieberman and said: "I can't think of a single area. Can you, Joe?"
Mr. Lieberman, without missing a beat, replied, "Only on the outcome of the election in Florida." (Amid laughter, Mr. Lieberman quickly added that he was only joking, and that the subject had never actually come up.)
If there are two players whose statures were enhanced during the bruising campaign, they may have been Mr. Cheney and Mr. Lieberman. Beginning with the studied civility in their debate on Oct. 6, the two understudies have avoided political warfare with each other.
Because of his government experience and authoritative demeanor, Mr. Cheney is in a position to be a major power broker on Capitol Hill, both as the tie-breaker in the 50-50 Senate and as a bridge to conservative House Republicans who might bridle at compromises Mr. Bush may want to make with Democrats.
For his part, Mr. Lieberman, a centrist known for working with Republicans, before Mr. Gore tapped him to be his running mate, the campaign gave him national stature that he can now wield on the issues he focuses on.
"We stressed the positive," Mr. Lieberman said.
Of course, there are limitations to cooperation, both men acknowledged.
Mr. Lieberman, for example, mentioned that he still supports demonstration programs for school vouchers -- a concept that is an anathema to most Democrats but supported by Mr. Bush and many Republicans -- but that such a plan would likely die in the Senate.
Mr. Lieberman said a bill to provide federal aid to schools in poor areas, which he and other moderate Democrats introduced earlier this year, contained similarities to the Bush plan on education, excepting vouchers "because we felt it would make the overall proposal a nonstarter. It's such a controversial idea."
"I haven't counted heads or anything," Mr. Lieberman added, "but my guess is that's still true, and that's something we'll have to work out."
Not that Mr. Cheney, who will be looking to shepherd some quick legislative accomplishments through the Congress to give the administration positive momentum, was pushing anything contentious.
"It was not a session to persuade each other about what ought to be in a bill," Mr. Cheney said. "We were simply comparing notes that there are major areas of agreement, and that we both thought this is an area where a new administration could work with the Congress and make some progress."
The two men, who first met during the Persian Gulf crisis when Mr. Cheney was secretary of defense and Mr. Lieberman was on the Armed Services Committee, also said that they agreed to work together to help modernize America's military arsenal and defend the country against a range of new threats, from terrorism to chemical weapons.
But Mr. Cheney did not remain completely above the partisan fray. The vice president-elect, who earlier this month came under fire from the White House for warning that the United States might be on the "front edge of a recession" today softened his rhetoric.
"We don't want to talk down the economy, clearly, and I think both President Bush and I have tried to be cautious in that regard," Mr. Cheney told reporters.
"There does seem to be a lot of evidence out there that in fact the economy has slowed down some," he said. "Whether or not this ultimately results in a recession, that is negative real growth, nobody knows at this time."
In a conference call with Connecticut reporters later in the morning, Mr. Lieberman said "we really didn't talk about the economy."
But the national economic adviser, Gene Sperling, criticized Mr. Cheney and others in the Bush camp for fueling fears of a steep economic downturn.
"By continually speculating on a worst-case scenario, they run the risk of hurting confidence and creating a self-fulfilling prophecy," Mr. Sperling said. "A president should not seek to paint the economy as significantly more rosy or significantly more pessimistic than the consensus forecasts for political purposes. Doing the latter can create unnecessary anxiety and have an adverse impact on the economy."
After meeting with Mr. Lieberman, Mr. Cheney paid a 30-minute courtesy call on former Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, who ran unsuccessfully against President Clinton in 1996. "They talked about transition business and legislation," said Juleanna Glover Weiss, Mr. Cheney's spokeswoman.
On Friday, Mr. Cheney will continue to work on transition matters from his office in McLean, Va., before leaving town on Saturday to spend the holidays at his home in Jackson, Wyo., Ms. Glover Weiss said.

HEADLINE: Fund Adviser Accused of Fraud

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
A New Jersey hedge fund adviser was accused by federal regulators today of inflating portfolio holdings and hiding $71 million in losses from investors.
Michael L. Smirlock, a former partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, was indicted in federal court in Manhattan on criminal charges and was sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission on civil charges, regulators said. 
 The commission also filed fraud charges against Mr. Smirlock's firm, Laser Advisers, of Short Hills, N.J. Mr. Smirlock resigned as president and chief executive of Laser Advisers, but he is still the chairman and majority shareholder, the commission said.
Mr. Smirlock, 44, of Loveladies, N.J., and his lawyer were unavailable for comment.
According to the commission, Mr. Smirlock handled the investment strategy of Steed Finance, a "hub" fund for three hedge fund clients: Shetland Fund, Mustang Investment, and Trakeher Fund. Mr. Smirlock was said to have bought for the funds options on interest rate swaps, known as swaptions, which are thinly traded and difficult to value. Once a month, Mr. Smirlock was required to get independent prices from broker-dealers for the swaptions, which were used to prepare periodic reports to investors. As interest rates fell from late 1997 through mid-1998, the hedge fund portfolios incurred losses, which the commission said Mr. Smirlock concealed by reporting inflated values for certain swaptions.
"By the time the fraud was discovered, the value of the investment fund portfolio was overstated by $71 million," the S.E.C. said.

HEADLINE: As Consumers Turn Pessimistic, Factory Workers Feel the Chill

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
For much of the last two years, the Frigidaire washer-and-dryer factory in Webster City, Iowa, could barely keep up with demand. The work force in the squat building -- just off the Boone River, close to Iowa's geographical center -- had increased since 1998 by about 700 people, or nearly 50 percent, and the company continued hiring new employees as recently as early in November.
Then everything seemed to come to a halt. Consumer purchases of large appliances, which had leveled off during the summer, started dropping. In Webster City, overtime hours disappeared, employees say. Soon after Thanksgiving, Frigidaire announced that it would lay off 130 workers almost immediately. Last week, plant managers told workers that 28 more people would lose their jobs before the end of the year. 
 "When you're pushing all year long, and you've got foremen riding you all year long to push things out the door, it comes as a shock," said Kim Willson, a 15-year employee who has kept her job but now works fewer hours.
Over the last month, similar kinds of shocks have reverberated from factory floors to executive suites to the office of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. The economy has slowed sharply, with growth in the third quarter at 2.2 percent annually, the weakest in four years. Page C2.
The manufacturers have been hit hardest, partly because consumers have grown far more hesitant about making big purchases like appliances, cars and personal computers.
Many of the main culprits -- tighter credit, higher energy costs and falling stocks -- have been hampering the economy for much of the last year. What has changed in recent weeks, economists say, is that Americans have suddenly become more pessimistic about their job prospects in 2001, despite an unemployment rate that, at 4 percent, remains near a 30-year low.
With this pessimism comes the risk that spending will fall further, requiring companies to reduce excess inventories and cut their payrolls -- a situation that could potentially snowball into something much worse.
Whirlpool, General Motors and Gillette all announced large job cuts this month.
Yesterday, Lucent Technologies and the Ford Motor Company disclosed layoffs, as well.
The number of people who are not working as many hours as they would like -- either because their overtime has been cut back, as Ms. Willson's was, or because they are now working only part time -- has risen sharply. Almost half of Americans, nearly double the level in November, expect the jobless rate to rise next year, according to a recent consumer survey at the University of Michigan.
"For the first time in a long time, consumers have begun to believe a recession is possible," said Richard T. Curtin, the director of Michigan's surveys. Early this month, consumer sentiment dropped by the sharpest rate since August 1990, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Retail sales fell last month, and many merchants say the holiday shopping season has so far been disappointing.
While service industries continue to expand at a healthy clip and most economists still think that a recession is unlikely next year, the roughly one-fifth of the American economy that manufactures goods is starting to move in reverse.
"I get reports every day of people seeing their orders drop sharply from the third quarter," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers in Washington.
The $37 billion appliance industry, with its reliance on consumers who are willing to spend hundreds of dollars at a time, provides a particularly telling example of how the economy has decelerated so quickly. As recently as September, shipments of major appliances, compared with a year earlier, were rising at a double-digit clip, as factories like the one in Webster City continued to stamp out thousands of machines a day. In the last two months, however, shipments have fallen more than 8 percent, according to the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers.
With companies already facing depressed earnings because of the strong dollar and higher costs, the sales fall-off forced the industry into painful actions. Whirlpool, the largest manufacturer, said on Dec. 13 that it planned to eliminate as many as 6,300 jobs, or one-tenth of its work force. The company also lowered its profit forecast for the second time in three months, saying it would earn about 25 percent less a share in the fourth quarter than it thought last summer.
The next day, Maytag, which had already lost its chief executive in November after a disappointing 15-month tenure, said it was lowering its fourth-quarter forecast for the second time.
Such about-faces have come with stunning speed. Between the start of 1998 and this summer, Americans increased their spending on appliances by 18 percent, according to the Department of Commerce, despite the fact few people own more than one of each appliance. A little earlier, in prosperous times, companies persuaded people to replace their existing machines with more expensive models -- ones that cooked more quickly or washed with less water, for example -- while a surge in new-home sales provided another lift.
"We've had three years of very, very robust sales," said Tina Settecase, vice president for home appliances at Sears, which sells more appliances than any other retailer. Sears sales remained strong through November, even as the industry turned down, Ms. Settecase said. But the first two weeks of December were weak.
Partly as a result of the appliance boom, household spending on durable goods rose to its highest share in at least 50 years. Appliances, cars, houses and other long-lasting items accounted for 19 percent of spending earlier this year, up from about 15 percent in 1990, according to James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management.
The spending fattened the manufacturers' bottom lines, but it also meant that many homeowners owned new machines in their kitchens and basements -- machines that were unlikely to need replacing any time soon. With the future looking less certain, consumers as a whole have pulled back.
"There has been a more precipitous drop than we historically see," said David R. Whitwam, Whirlpool's chief executive. "This is a pretty predictable industry normally."
The industry downturn has left many workers worried about the coming months. "I don't think people are opening their eyes and seeing what's going on," said Laura Nichols, who has worked for seven years on the assembly line at Whirlpool's plant in Clyde, Ohio, the town that was the basis for Sherwood Anderson's novel, "Winesburg, Ohio."
"People don't want to accept the fact that things are getting worse," Ms. Nichols said.
The newfound reluctance of consumers is rippling beyond Whirlpool, General Electric, Maytag and Frigidaire. Across the country, manufacturers that sell parts, raw material and machines to the appliance companies -- as well as to automakers and computer manufacturers -- are starting to suffer, too.
About 40 percent of the December orders for metal-stamping machines at Murata Wiedemann in Charlotte, N.C., have been pushed back until at least January, said Larry Hanzo, the company's director of corporate accounts. "It came rather suddenly," Mr. Hanzo said, although no order has yet been canceled. The company employs 110 people, down from 120 to 125 earlier this year.
The situation is more severe at Coe Press Equipment, a maker of steel-unwinding machines in Sterling Heights, Mich., that sells to G.E. and Whirlpool. In the second half of 2000, sales will be about 50 percent lower than in the first half. In response, the company's president, John C. Coe, said he had called off plans for a $650,000 plant expansion and put all the manufacturing employees -- about 50 people and almost half the company's payroll -- on leave for the next two weeks.
Kirt T. Howard is one of the workers who will begin collecting unemployment insurance on Monday. Six months ago, Mr. Howard, 28, was making almost $1,100 a week, thanks to 20 hours of overtime. Recently, his weekly salary had dropped to $620.
Mr. Howard said he had been able to make only the minimum payments on his three credit card bills lately. Now, he and his girlfriend will skip buying Christmas presents for their parents and instead get gifts only for the two family members whose names they have drawn as part of an annual tradition.
"Right now, it looks kind of rocky," Mr. Howard said.
Analysts have recently been saying similar things about the American economy, although most continue to predict growth of 2 to 3 percent next year. Yesterday, the government revised its measure of third-quarter growth to 2.2 percent, below the 2.5 percent annual growth rate that President Clinton on Tuesday said that many forecasters expected.
On Tuesday, as well, the Federal Reserve, while keeping interest rates unchanged, announced a reversal in its emphasis, saying that it now considered a recession to be a greater risk than inflation. Many economists predict that the Fed will cut rates early next year after six increases since mid-1999.
Mr. Whitman, Whirlpool's chief executive, said he expected the appliance industry's sales to decline in the first half of 2001 but to recover thereafter. "It's not a robust picture we see for our economy next year," he said, "nor is it a terrible one."

HEADLINE: Era Closes at Rockefeller Center With $1.85 Billion Deal on Sale

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A billionaire Chicago family has teamed up with Jerry I. Speyer, the New York developer, in a $1.85 billion deal to purchase Rockefeller Center, the 22-acre complex that stands as an international symbol of commerce and capitalism.
The deal severs the Rockefellers' remaining links to the historic complex that bears the family's name. For the first time since the family built the center 70 years ago, in the midst of the Depression, the Rockefellers will have no involvement with the 10 landmarked office buildings, Radio City Music Hall or the Rainbow Room. 
 Under the terms of the pending deal, Mr. Speyer and Lester Crown's family from Chicago, who together owned 5 percent of the complex, will be acquiring the interests of their partners: David Rockefeller, the former chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank; the Goldman Sachs Group; the Agnelli family of Italy; and the estate of the Greek shipping magnate Stavros Niarchos.
"We are thrilled to continue as stewards of a world-class landmark," said Mr. Speyer, who ran Rockefeller Center for the last four years as president of Tishman Speyer, a real estate company. "It has endured over the years because of its central location, its beauty and its functionality."
It is unlikely that there will be any major changes at Rockefeller Center when the deal is completed next spring. But the sale is another indication of a booming real estate market in New York, where over the last four years the giant financial services and media companies have expanded and tourists have flocked to the city. Rockefeller Center itself has doubled in value since the Goldman Sachs Group bought it in 1996 for the equivalent of $900 million. At that point, Rockefeller Center had slipped into bankruptcy and the Japanese company that owned the complex had walked away from what it thought was a losing investment.
Ten major buildings totaling about eight million square feet of space make up Rockefeller Center, which sits between 48th and 51st Streets, from Fifth Avenue to the Avenue of the Americas.
Mr. Speyer and the Crowns, who own a major share of the General Dynamics Corporation, the giant defense contractor, and the Chicago Bulls basketball team, also have stakes in another New York institution, the Yankees.
Mr. Speyer's sudden announcement last night came as a surprise to many people in the New York real estate industry and especially to the bidders competing for Rockefeller Center, which had been put on the auction block earlier this year. The value of the deal, however, fell short of the $2.2 billion or $2.5 billion many real estate executives said Goldman Sachs had been seeking. The investment bank's real estate fund owns half the complex and had set off the sale process earlier this year.
The deal did not come without some intrigue.
"I wish them well," said Mortimer B. Zuckerman, chairman of Boston Properties and a bidder for the complex. "It's a full price, but it's also a wonderful asset."
Mr. Zuckerman was one of the four finalists who submitted bids in September, along with the Fisher real estate family; Sam Zell, chairman of Equity Office Properties; and Steven Roth, chairman of Vornado Realty Trust. While all the tycoons wanted to own the property, the highest bids began moving downward to about $1.8 billion, according to two of the bidders.
In recent weeks, the Fishers, Mr. Zell and Mr. Zuckerman, who said he would not go as high as $1.8 billion, dropped out of the bidding. "We felt we could invest our money elsewhere at better returns," Mr. Zuckerman said.
At the same time, Mr. Roth of Vornado sought to forge a joint venture with Mr. Zell and the Fishers, believing that Rockefeller Center was too big for any one company to own. But no firm offer emerged.
Some of the bidders said they were upset that Mr. Speyer, an insider, ended up as the winning bidder.
In any event, the partners were considering refinancing the property when Mr. Speyer joined with the Crown family to offer $1.85 billion for the property, $50 million more than the tentative bid from Mr. Roth.
Daniel Neidich, chairman of Goldman's real estate fund, did not return calls requesting comment.
"We had had no intention of having anything to do with this purchase," Mr. Speyer said. "It was only in the last couple of days that we thought that the price was so compelling. On Wednesday morning, we talked to our partners, saying we were prepared to pay more."
David Rockefeller, 85, said that the pending change of ownership made him nostalgic. "In one sense, it seems sad," Mr. Rockefeller said last night. "But the fact that the new owners are good friends makes a big difference. I'm comfortable that Jerry Speyer will maintain the same quality and sense of public obligations that we tried to."
Mr. Rockefeller said his first memory of Rockefeller Center dated to 1929, when he poked his head through a peephole in a plywood fence to watch the excavation for the complex. He said so many people were interested in the construction project that his father, John D. Rockefeller Jr., had workers cut the holes in the fence.
The complex opened in 1933 and became both a sought-after corporate address and a tourist attraction, for visitors who wanted to skate on ice or admire the bronze Prometheus gliding above a fountain and the towering limestone buildings.
In 1985, the Rockefeller family began divesting some of its stake in the complex. The family borrowed $1.3 billion from a real estate investment trust and eventually sold 80 percent of Rockefeller Center and the Rockefeller Group to Mitsubishi Estate, which provoked an outcry over what was described as the sale of American patrimony to the Japanese.
But Mitsubishi's ownership proved short-lived. A recession cut deeply into profits, prompting the Japanese company to walk away from its investment rather than continuing to make payments on the mortgage. Rockefeller Center tumbled into bankruptcy.
The group led by Goldman Sachs and Mr. Speyer bought the property in 1996, paying $306 million for the mortgage and assuming $845 million in debt and other obligations. Simultaneously, the group sold a condominium interest in 30 Rockefeller Center to NBC for $440 million.
Mr. Speyer moved quickly to improve management of the complex and raise profits. He signed lucrative leases with the Cipriani family for the Rainbow Room and with Cablevision Systems to lease Radio City Music Hall for about $13 million a year. Mr. Speyer also renovated the retail space, signing leases with more upscale tenants, like Christie's auction house.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Europe Trade Proposals to End U.N. Dues Deadlock

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 21

 BODY:
New proposals from the United States and the European Union failed today to end a deadlock over how to revise the dues for member nations in order to give Washington reductions it is demanding. As midnight approached, diplomats said they expected to be in session until dawn, with no promise of an agreement.
In a last-ditch effort to break the deadlock over American payments, Ambassador Richard C. Holbrooke offered for the United States to pay the $34 million that other nations would be charged collectively over the next year to make up the shortfall if the United States' demand for a reduction was met. 
 Mr. Holbrooke had told diplomats -- informally over the last week and formally early this morning -- that the money would come from discretionary State Department funds. But tonight in an interview, he said that Ted Turner had offered the money to the government through his United Nations Foundation, which has supported a number of programs at the organization.
Mr. Holbrooke said that Timothy E. Wirth, the former senator from Colorado who is president of the foundation, had asked him not to disclose the source of the money. The Washington Post first reported that it was Mr. Turner. Mr. Holbrooke described it as a "visionary gesture" and added that Mr. Turner had first suggested the grant about six weeks ago as a way to avoid having to confront Congress for more money.
Other diplomats described the offer as a sweetener that does not deal with the longer-term problem of other nations' having to compensate for a reduction in American dues after the first year. Moreover, the $34 million would cover a gap only in the regular operating budget of the organization, not the peacekeeping fund. Other nations have said they wanted to solve the problems of the two budgets at the same time.
Diplomats said tonight that many other problems remained as nations bickered over their assessments. Mr. Holbrooke said just before midnight that a division had widened between the Europeans, who have said that they will not pay more, and developing countries who say they cannot afford to accept increases. The Russians, however, agreed to double their contributions, but their dues are only a very small fraction of the American assessment.
Earlier today, with the General Assembly bargaining strenuously over how to revise dues, the Europeans introduced an idea that could complicate negotiations further for the United States. Ambassador Jean-David Levitte of France said the Europeans were proposing that if Washington wins the cut in dues that it is seeking, Congress would have to release the money to pay all American debts by 2003. If that deadline is not met, he said, "then we will have to see whether we will have to push up the United States again."
Congress did not imagine such a condition when it demanded a cut in payments before releasing $800 million in already appropriated funds -- not to mention $700 million that the United Nations calculates it is owed but that Congress disputes.
Mr. Holbrooke, who has worked to push through a resolution to the issue for more than a year, would have to sell an agreement in the waning days of the Clinton administration. He has had the help of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who is the ranking minority member on the Senate foreign relations committee. Mr. Biden said here last week that there was not much flexibility on the committee, whose chairman is Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. Now some of the senators could see the conditional proposal as a threat.
Within the United Nations, the idea of giving the United States a reduction conditioned on paying arrears in full could satisfy some nations that do not believe Washington can be trusted to pay once it has won a reduction, or fear that the Americans will come back asking for more cuts in three years, when budget assessments are reviewed again.
Mr. Levitte did not disguise his distaste for the American position today. He called the Congressional ultimatum "an absolutely unjustifiable demand" and repeated the position that European nations collectively pay far more than the United States and are not asking for cuts.
The General Assembly is planning to adjourn on Friday. By then, its finance committee should complete work on the two budget systems, one of about $1 billion for regular operations and the other of $3 billion for peacekeeping.
But the hard bargaining does not come until the 11th hour. "That's what we're doing -- in pain, recrimination, screaming," Mr. Levitte said today. "But we are moving ahead."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing;
JOB GROWTH CONTINUES

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
Despite the slowing national economy and the turmoil on Wall Street, New York City employers continued to hire workers at a blistering pace in November, according to data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. Between October and November, the number of new jobs in the city rose by 33,100, or 0.9 percent, far faster than the statewide average increase of 0.4 percent. While some of the job growth came from stores hiring clerks for the holiday shopping season, big gains were also reported in business services, motion pictures and education. The financial sector also showed an increase, despite declining employment at banks as Chase Manhattan began its takeover of J. P. Morgan. The unemployment rate in the city was unchanged, but when adjusted for seasonal factors it edged up to 5.6 percent from 5.4 percent. The unemployment rate in the state also rose slightly, to 4.6 percent from 4.4 percent, as did the national average, to 4 percent from 3.9 percent. Leslie Eaton

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing;
RECORD LOW JOBLESS RATE

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Connecticut's unemployment rate decreased by 0.3 percentage points to an all-time low of 1.7 percent in November, the United States Labor Department said yesterday. Officials cautioned that they needed to see more data to determine whether the record was an anomaly. The rate was 1.2 percentage points below that of November 1999 and 2.3 percentage points below the national rate. Nonfarm jobs totaled 1,698,500 last month, up 20,300 from one year ago, the Labor Department said. The largest gain, 1,100 jobs, was in government, including American Indian tribal government.

PUB-DATE: December 22, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 45; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4691 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary, especially during the holiday season, and should be checked by telephone. Museum hours through New Year's Day may also vary and should be checked before visiting. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"GIORGIO ARMANI," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 17). The Guggenheim has served up another plateau of urban history: a retrospective of the Milanese fashion designer Giorgio Armani. What it lacks in depth it makes up for with sparkle, and Robert Wilson's architectural transformation of the museum's rotunda may be the best yet. In an inverted version of a life class, instead of the undraped body, the show offers just the drapes. The mannequins have been pared down to the edges of the costumes, and they cluster in groups in the building's structural bays, spatial modules with the proportions of shop windows. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 students and the elderly (Herbert Muschamp). 

* "ART AND THE EMPIRE CITY: NEW YORK, 1825-1861," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). The point is that during the antebellum years New York began to become, well, New York, America's megalopolis and an international crossroads. The great metaphor was the plan to grid Manhattan: unsentimental, open-ended, utilitarian and democratic, it created the blank sheet on which the city could draw its future. Amusing, gigantic, only marginally an art exhibition, the show is really an ostentatious illustrated history lesson via hundreds of pieces of old crockery, etchings, paintings, rosewood firescreens, daguerreotypes and mother-of-pearl folding fans. Custom-made for today's acquisitive age, the exhibition is probably the only occasion on which a 19th-century brown ceramic water cooler and a six-sided pitcher with pictures of the presidential candidate William Henry Harrison have been presented in the style of the treasures of the pharaoh's palace in "The Ten Commandments." Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
 * "THE DRAFTSMAN'S ART: MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE NATIONAL GALLERY OF SCOTLAND," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Feb. 25). This beautiful exhibition of 70 master drawings from the 16th to 19th century, many of them recently acquired, has been organized with an eye to achieving a harmonic convergence of diversity, continuity, quality, fame and obscurity. Leonardo, Raphael, Boucher and Seurat are here, in outstanding form, but so is an exquisitely detailed rendering of two Restoration gentlemen by David Paton, a Scottish miniaturist, and an almost cinematic genre scene that is considered the masterpiece of Etienne Jeaurat, a contemporary of Chardin. In between are works by Zuccaro, Pietro Testa, Pietro da Cortona, Hans Baldung Grien, Hendrick Goltzius and much more. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 "HIP-HOP NATION: ROOTS, RHYMES AND RAGE," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Dec. 31). The complex cultural amalgam of music, poetry, break dancing, art and fashion that is hip-hop poses a serious challenge to any art museum, but with the proper resources and curatorial expertise, it could have been met. Instead this show offers a partial outline of hip-hop history, conveyed by photographs, posters, magazine and album covers, memorabilia and monotonous expanses of clothes that make the show nearly indistinguishable from the gift shop. Garnished with graffiti art, it bypasses many other equally interesting connections to contemporary art. Because the show omits music videos, it manages to be virtually devoid of the sounds, words and moving bodies that are the essence of hip-hop. The results are a cross between a mall and a mausoleum. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 * "SOL LEWITT: A RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 25). Unexpectedly, the most beautiful exhibition by a living artist in a New York museum in a long time and an antidote to the nonsense in several other museums around town. Just about every other wall is covered with wall drawings, alternately eye-popping and gossamer. Those out there (you know who you are) who run from any artist linked to Conceptualism may want to stop and re-evaluate your views after seeing what's here. The master of chaste white cubes has undergone a transformation since his last retrospective in the late 70's. Now opulence emerges from the same seemingly prosaic instructions he came up with years ago. The appeal is still to patient observation, a lesson for everyone, delivered elegantly. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * HENRY LUCE III CENTER FOR THE STUDY OF AMERICAN CULTURE, New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (permanent). Nearly two-thirds of the museum's holdings of fine art and decorative objects is now on full public view. The fourth floor has been remade to house a brilliant display of nearly 40,000 objects, from paintings and furniture to Tiffany lamps, porcelain, pottery, silverware and women's fans. Among the nearly 500 American paintings on display are works by Albert Bierstadt, Frederic E. Church, Thomas Cole, Asher Brown Durand, Childe Hassam, Eastman Johnson and John James Audubon, neatly deployed in glass-fronted cases. With audio tours and other devices, the material is as accessible to the public as it is to scholars. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students over 12 and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
 *"MOROCCO: JEWS AND ART IN A MUSLIM LAND," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Feb. 11). When Arab Muslims arrived in Morocco, Jews had already been living there for centuries, and the two cultures formed a cooperative and uneasy bond. Their relationship is explored in this show, which offers a little bit of many things, mostly dating from the 19th and 20th centuries. In elaborate jewelry, shimmering textiles, liturgical objects and folk amulets, Jewish and Islamic ingredients often form a distinctive hybrid blend. A selection of European Orientalist paintings provides a firsthand outsider view of a once-vibrant interaction. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students over 11 and the elderly (Holland Cotter)
 
 * "OPEN ENDS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Jan. 2). The third and final cycle of "MOMA 2000" covers 1960 to the present and fills nearly the entire museum with almost a dozen different theme shows. "White" is one theme. Memorial art is another. Childhood and lost innocence is yet another. Like previous installments in this year-and-a-half-long navel-gazing reconsideration by the museum of how to present its permanent collection in anticipation of its future home, the show has the effect of being clever and a little too solipsistic: it's about smart curators' making occasionally vivid and previously unseen connections among disparate works without making particularly fresh sense of the period as a whole. It's artistic game playing, highly pleasurable up to a point. The themes are always arguable, which is part of the game. This also becomes an occasion for the museum to parade acquisitions of the last decade, which include Gerhard Richter's series of paintings based on the Baader-Meinhof gang, occupying an entire room and probably the exhibition's high point. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * "RAIN OF THE MOON: SILVER IN ANCIENT PERU," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through April 22). Symbols of power and prestige in ancient Peru, gold and silver were equally revered, and Peruvian metalsmiths acquired great skill in the techniques of working them. This show deals with silver, harder to capture and preserve than gold, dating from the late first millennium B.C. to the Spanish conquest in the 16th century. The objects range from nose ornaments and ear pieces, some of them amazingly large, to human and animal figures, like a famous Inka llama whose hanging fleece is evoked by the rippled, crumpled sheet of silver that covers its body. As most gold and silver objects in Peru were melted down by the Spanish conquistadors, this show -- half from the Met's collection and half from loans -- amounts to a bonanza. It is the first devoted to the subject of pre-Columbian Peruvian silver. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).
 
 * SCYTHIAN GOLD. "The Golden Deer of Eurasia: Scythian and Sarmatian Treasures From the Russian Steppes," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 4). "Gold of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures From Ancient Ukraine," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 21). Certain kinds of art are box-office gold. Art made of gold is one of them, and there's a Fort Knox-size supply of the precious stuff in these two opulent exhibitions. The Brooklyn show is a survey-style glimpse at some exquisitely wrought 14-carat objects drawn from museums in Ukraine, where the Scythians put down roots in the first millennium B.C. The Met has drop-dead museological rarities from the State Hermitage Museum, but the focus here, which gives the proceedings a kind of treasure-hunt thrill, is on a cache of objects excavated fairly recently from tombs belonging to non-Scythian people whose identity is something of a mystery. Ideally, the two shows should be seen together: they offer a really substantial archaeological update on the last big Scythian showcase in these parts, the Met's smash-hot "In the Land of the Scythians" of 25 years ago. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
* JAMES CASTLE, "The Common Place," Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through Jan. 13). Though deaf, speechless and illiterate, Castle (1900-77) drew with miraculous originality and steadfastness of purpose for most of his life. This exhibition presents more than 100 drawings, assemblages and small books, all created using homemade and found materials. The artist's strangely somber views of the ordinary rooms and grounds of the Idaho farm where he grew up have a haunting, deeply moving presence (Johnson).
 
 JOAN MIRO, "16 Late Masterworks," Salander-O'Reilly, 20 East 79th Street, (212) 879-6606 (through Jan. 6). Claims may be made for the Zen-like freedom of the paintings dating from 1966 to 1978 here, but in truth they look mostly unfinished. Miro's vocabulary of calligraphic signs, funny creatures, erotic symbols and radically simplified landscapes is familiar, but with the exception of a large, physically substantial collage on yellow sandpaper, most of the canvases look hastily and negligently made -- albeit with splattery energy -- and have none of the sensuous grace of Miro at his best (Johnson).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
"TIBOR DE NAGY GALLERY: THE FIRST 50 YEARS," Tibor de Nagy, 724 Fifth Avenue, (212) 262-5050 (through Jan. 20). This substantial exhibition of paintings celebrates the 50th anniversary of a gallery that started out as one of the most adventurous of its time. Selections from exhibitions of the past include Larry Rivers's famous life-size portrait of the poet Frank O'Hara wearing nothing but boots; a large, boldly calligraphic abstraction by Helen Frankenthaler in 1951; a wallpaper-like field of flowers by Joe Brainard; and a muted picture of buildings in the snow by Jane Wilson (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
* "THE IMPERIAL GAZE," Sepia International, 148 West 24th Street, (212) 645-9444 (through Dec. 30). The British photographer Samuel Bourne was in India for only seven years (1863-70), but he took thousands of pictures, established a lucrative business and became well known for his cityscapes and pictures of architectural monuments. Like many quest-driven travelers, though, he wanted, even needed, something from India: in his case, an experience of the Sublime in nature. In Kashmir, he encountered an earthly Eden, and on arduous treks to the Himalayas he discovered the meaning of hugeness. The pictures that resulted are part of one of the richest bodies of photographic work to emerge from British India (Cotter).
 
 "MODERNISM DEFINED: JULIUS SHULMAN AND RICHARD NEUTRA," Yancey Richardson, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 343-1255 (through Jan. 6). Now 90, Mr. Shulman began photographing the buildings of the modernist architect Richard Neutra in 1936. His black-and-white images of clean, airy, minimally furnished houses from the 1940's and 50's are more than just lucid documents; each glowing miniature conveys a heavenly vision of modern serenity (Johnson).
 
 "RECONFIGURING THE NEW YORK SCHOOL," Center for Figurative Painting, 115 West 30th Street, (212) 868-3452 (through Jan. 27). This show brings together 17 artists who continued to paint representationally over the last half-century despite the triumph of Abstract Expressionism. Ranging from Fairfield Porter's vividly painterly "View Through the Laundry Room Window" to a hyper-realist nude by Philip Pearlstein to Lennart Anderson's goofy neo-classical "Idyll," the show is incoherent and uneven but not uninteresting. Other works worth seeing are by Larry Rivers, Albert York and Louisa Matthiasdottir (Johnson).
 
 * CINDY SHERMAN, Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, (212) 206-7100, (through Jan. 6). With her latest untitled series Ms. Sherman is back in front of the camera lens again, disguised as women who, you might say, used to be somebody, maybe. They grin at the camera in clownish make-up, wobbly wigs and discount blouses, proud, valiantly oblivious to, or simply defiant of, our condescension, like the beauty pageant queen who drops her baton in the talent contest but keeps beaming. Formal devices by Ms. Sherman get overlooked because of the human element: the pattern of pigtails against plaid shirt; the purplish freckled face of a woman with purple shirt and purple cap. This formal order becomes a rational structure that gives to the work its mix of frigidity and heat, a perfectly ambiguous cocktail for an ambiguous moment and an antidote to the weary sophistication of which there is too much in art now (Kimmelman).
 
 "THRIFTING," Lombard Freid, 531 West 26th Street, (212) 967-8040 (through Jan. 6). Seven emerging Texas artists who cleverly recycle found materials. Bill Davenport makes eccentrically poetic works, like a group of blue cans bearing mounds of fake snow; Katrina Moorhead transforms a piece of Styrofoam packing material into a wonderful little swimming pool using miniature tiles and real grout; Brad Tucker produces funky conjunctions of words, materials and objects; and Francesca Fuchs merges consumer products and abstract wall painting (Johnson).
 
 FATIMAH TUGGAR, Greene Naftali, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 463-7770, (through Jan. 6). Born in Nigeria, educated at Yale, Ms. Tuggar works in a variety of media to sensitize viewers to the gulf between African and Western experience. In large computer-processed photomontages, she mixes and layers disconnected images -- placing Western fashion models in an open-air African meat market, for example -- to surrealistic and politically provocative effect (Johnson).
 
 MARY WEATHERFORD, Debs & Co., 525 West 26th Street, (212) 643-2070 (through Jan. 6). Since bursting on the scene at the end of the 80's with her feminist revisions of Noland, Johns and Warhol, Ms. Weatherford has followed an unpredictable path. Her new canvases, punctuated by starfish, seashells and sponges, hover uneasily between faux-naif landscape and sophisticated Color Field painting (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
"COLLECTOR'S CHOICE," Exit Art, 548 Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 966-7745 (through Dec. 30). Exit Art asked eight New York art collectors, "If you had $50,000 to spend on art, what would you buy?" The resulting sprawl of more than 100 works reflects the general complexion of the semi-hip marketplace more than any distinctively selective vision. Highlights include little colored balls in a corner by Tom Friedman, romantic paintings of toylike plants by Sally Ross and a mesmerizing video installation by Leo Villareal (Johnson).
 
 "FIGURE IN THE LANDSCAPE," Lehmann Maupin, 39 Greene Street, (212) 965-0753 (through Jan. 13). Organized by the conceptual artist Ronald Jones, this suggestive meditation on the influence of Philip Guston's viscerally cartoonish late work includes Matthew Ritchie's delirious, quasi-scientific mindscapes; Carroll Dunham's hilariously hostile macho-men; Monique Prieto's jaunty updates of Color Field painting; Anna Gaskell's mysterious photographic narrative about nurses; and an inert essay in art historical appropriation by David Salle. All revolve around a 1979 Guston work said to be a portrait of the artist's wife (Johnson).
 
 "FROM INSIDE THE BODY: CHINESE NEW PHOTOGRAPHY AND VIDEO," Ise Cultural Foundation, 555 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 925-1649 (through Jan. 6). Most of the 11 participants in this show are appearing for the first time in the United States, and together they give some idea of ways in which many young Chinese artists, with access to international art magazines, museum catalogs and the Internet, are tailoring global styles to culturally specific ends. Some cook up contemporary riffs on traditional genres; others dive straight into a hallucinatory present, with themes that sometimes dovetail with those in recent work by artists in New York (Cotter).
 
 KEVIN LARMON, Curt Marcus, 578 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 226-3200 (through Jan. 6). Mr. Larmon, who has been exhibiting regularly in New York since 1984, updates the old Surrealist-Abstract Expressionist connection. Working toward the centers of raw plywood panels, he layers grisaille glazes over loose, swirling pencil lines, creating murky depths, serpentine biomorphic forms and tension between illusory dream space and the raw immediacy of paint and wood (Johnson).
 
 ARNOLD MESCHES, "Echoes, a Century Survey," Donahue/Sosinski Art, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 226-1111 (through Dec. 30). An impassioned Expressionist painter, Mr. Mesches, now 77, has stayed with figuration through all the art world "isms" of his time. His work combines his interest in 20th-century history -- wars, strikes, the Holocaust, class and economic struggles -- with his own immigrant family saga. He gets it down with the energy, bold colors and lively humor (if not great painting) that keep you looking. An old-fashioned show about feelings in an era of art world ironies, it nevertheless works. The painting helps: its rough, guileless, straight-from-the-tube abruptness strikes just the right note (Glueck).
 
 "A NEW YORK CIRCLE," Susan Teller, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-7335 (through Dec. 30). Selected by a veteran New York modernist painter, Fannie Hillsmith, this exhibition of works by friends and acquaintances evokes a midcentury period when the progressive art world was far smaller and more intimate than today and the common language was Cubism. Besides Ms. Hillsmith's own robust Cubist still lifes, the show includes fine small works by such luminaries of American art as Louise Nevelson, Suzy Frelinghuysen, A. E. Gallatin, Alice Trumbull Mason and Charles Shaw (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
* SIAH ARMAJANI, "Glass Room," Senior & Shopmaker Gallery, 21 East 26th Street, (212) 213-6767 (through Jan. 6). You couldn't live in this endearingly homespun "glass room," but then, it's not meant for that. Made of glass and plexiglass bricks and set on wagon wheels like a prairie schooner, it is packed with fanciful allusions and tributes: to country carpentry, old-style American farm life, vernacular rural architecture and, at the same time, the futuristic visions that glass seems to offer. Despite its transparency, it has a more private aspect than the long roster of bridges, houses, reading rooms, gardens and other structures -- some functional, some purely aesthetic -- with which Mr. Armajani has adorned the built world. Enigmatic yet accessible, sturdily constructed but for contemplation only, "Glass Room" is a sparkling addition (Glueck).
 
 ELIZABETH CAMPBELL AND GUY RICHARDS SMIT, Roebling Hall, 390 Wythe Avenue, at South Fiurth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-5352 (through Jan. 15; closed tomorrow through Jan. 9). In a more-than-promising local solo debut, Ms. Campbell has created a kind of stage set of a lived-in bedroom, then replicated it, connecting the two versions by a short hallway. The tossed-back bed sheets in one room are identical in every crease and fold to those in the other; the contents of the wastebaskets are piled up in precisely the same way. The results feel both wryly businesslike and basket-case-obsessive. Also on view is a wacky film by Mr. Smit titled "The Ballad of Bad Orpheus," a rock-opera retelling of the Greek myth filtered through Genet, Fassbinder and "On the Town" (Cotter)
 
 * "HARD PRESSED: 600 YEARS OF PRINTS AND PROCESS," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through Jan. 13). A thumbnail history of exploration in the field of fine art prints, from earliest woodcuts to digital technology, running from Durer to Kiki Smith, from Rembrandt to Robert Rauschenberg and beyond. Woodcuts, intaglio prints, drypoint etchings, lithography and newer techniques are carefully explained and illustrated, with notable early examples like Rembrandt's drypoint "Three Crosses" and more current events like Peter Halley's unlimited edition "Superdream Mutation" (1993), which existed only on a computer screen (Glueck).
 
 * RICHARD NONAS, "A Ghost in Every Kayak," Five Myles, 558 St. Johns Place, Crown Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 783-4438 (through Dec. 30). Established by the theater director and performer Hanne Tierney in memory of her son Myles, a news photographer killed in Sierra Leone in 1998, this maverick gallery has an entrancing show put together by Mr. Nonas. Examples of his floor-hugging post-minimalist work run down the center of the gray-painted space. Walls are hung with an extraordinary collection of boats, full-scale replicas and near-abstract models fashioned by the artist (Cotter).
 
 PAUL PFEIFFER, the Project, 427 West 126th Street, Harlem (212) 662-8610 (through Jan. 7). The emotional, almost religious intensity that infuses Mr. Pfeiffer's tiny wall-mounted video tapes, and created such a buzz around the artist last spring, is all but absent in this show. The power of his work stems from intimate encounters with small, moving images lifted from pre-existing footage and ingeniously Pfeifferized. Thus a large installation and some manipulated photographs founder on the seas of one-liner cerebralness. Only "The Long Count (I Shook Up the World)," based on the 1964 Clay-Liston fight, reflects Mr. Pfeiffer's poetic understanding of the meanings to be found at the nexus of the body, the camera and American life (Smith).
 
 "TO BE CONTINUED," Art in General, 79 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-0473 (through Jan. 8); Parlour Projects, 214 Devoe Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (917) 723-8626 (Sundays, noon to 4 p.m., through Jan. 7); Bellwether,150 Franklin Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 389-3213 (Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m., through Jan. 7.) This collaborative show of Brooklyn artists is spread over the three galleries: all 13 artists appear at Art in General, and selectively at the smaller Brooklyn spaces. Anissa Mack's video "First Person/Third Party" starts everything off on just the right upbeat, networking note in Manhattan. At Parlour Projects, pieces by Anoka Faruqee and Douglas Ross look good, as do the works by Danica Phelps, Perry Meigs, Michelle Hines and Eli Sudbrack at Bellwether, which also has flatfiles to delve into (Cotter).
 
Last Chance
 
KIM DINGLE, "Never in School," Sperone Westwater, 121 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 431-3685 (through today). In dainty dresses and Mary Jane shoes, two small troublemakers, Fatty and Fudge, use classroom and playground for their subversive antics: fighting, taking off their clothes, writing dirty words on a blackboard and generally mess-making. What brings it all off is Ms. Dingle's chronicling of their cartoony doings in a satirical painting mode usually reserved for high-art subjects. Velazquez, meet Fatty and Fudge (Glueck).
 
 * "FROM THE ARTIST'S STUDIO: UNKNOWN PRINTS AND DRAWINGS BY MARY CASSATT," Adelson Galleries, 25 East 77th Street, (212) 439-6800 (through today). This extraordinary exhibition presents 120 prints and drawings from a heretofore privately held collection. Covering the entire course of Cassatt's printmaking career, it features multiple states of many of the great color etchings that she produced after seeing a show of Japanese woodcuts in Paris in 1890. These intimate images of women in private domestic moments or tending children are as striking for their abstract structure as for their incipiently erotic sensuality (Johnson).
 
 LASZLO MOHOLY-NAGY, Ubu, 16 East 78th Street, (212) 794-4444 (through today). Moholy-Nagy (1895-1946), the once hugely influential Modernist and Bauhaus educator, is today only hazily remembered. The show is like a hall of mirrors that palely reflect many more interesting artists: Rodchenko, Mondrian, Man Ray and others. Moholy-Nagy's dream of fusion among art, science and industry shows in a Constructivist formalism that, while not unplayful, has a bland, corporate impersonality (Johnson).
 
 LORDY RODRIGUEZ, "States," Clementine, 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 243-5937 (through tomorrow). Mr. Rodriguez's extraordinarily detailed, beautifully handmade ink-on-paper maps look normal from a distance, but up close you discover they are totally zany. Following a systematically re-imagined United States geography, New York has been moved to Michigan; Connecticut occupies a western coast and is engulfed by Montana; the capital of Kansas is Miami. These plausibly rendered yet fantastic revisions of reality are oddly exhilarating (Johnson).
 
 LAURIE SIMMONS, "Tourism, 1984," Skarstedt Fine Art, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 737-2060 (through tomorrow). Known for her photography of constructed miniscale scenes, Ms. Simmons concocted "Tourism, 1984" after a harried visit to the Acropolis that year. She decided that such glamour destinations might be better experienced in reproduction, the way most of us know and remember them anyway. So she photographed her doll-size "Teenettes" against sites blown up from bad slides: Las Vegas, the Great Wall of China, the Taj Mahal and other cliche attractions. To make it more fantastical, the stiff little mannequins that stand agape at the backdrops take on the coloration of the slides (Glueck).
